Praefatio.	Prologue.
Postquam compleui uobis o Filii, librum hunc, qui est postremus scientiae in medicina cum complemento ipsius, et consecutus sum finem in eo, ex expositionibus eius, et ipsius declarationibus, uisum est mihi, ut compleam ipsum uobis cum hoc Tractatu qui est pars operationis, id est, chirurgiae cum manu.	After I have completed for you, O sons, this book which is the last of medical knowledge with its complement and reached the end of it through its explanations and declarations, it seemed good to me to complete it for you with this Treatise which is part of operations, that is surgery by hand.
Quoniam operatio cum manu prostrata est in regione nostra, et tempore nostro priuata omnino: donec fortasse periit scientia eius, et abscissum est uestigium eius: et non remanserunt ex ea, nisi descriptiones paruae in libris antiquorum, quas mutauerunt manus: et accidit eis error et haesitatio, donec clausae sunt intentiones eius, et elongata est uis ipsius: Visum est mihi, ut uiuificem eam cum ordinatione huius Tractatus in ea secundum uiam ex positionis, et declarationis, et abbreuiationis: et ut ueniam cum formis ferramentorum Cauterii, et reliquorum instrumentorum operis: cum fit ex declarationis additione, et ex properatione eius quod est necesse.	Because surgery by hand is prostrated in our region and time, entirely lacking until perhaps its knowledge has perished and its trace has been cut off, and there remain from it only brief descriptions in ancient books which have been altered by hands: and error and hesitation have befallen them, until their intentions were closed and its sight was prolonged. It seemed good to me to revive it with the ordering of this Treatise according to the way of position and declaration and abbreviation, and that I may come with the forms of instruments of cautery, and others, making clear through addition declarations, and hastening what is necessary.
Caussa autem propter quam non inuenitur bonus artifex eius cum manu sua in hoc nostro tempore, est: quia ars medicinae est longa, et oportet auctorem eius exercitari ante illud in scientia anatomiae, quam narrauit Galenus, donec sciat iuuamenta membrorum, et ipsorum formas, et eorum coniunctionem, et separationem, et habeat cognitionem ossium, et neruorum, et lacertorum, et numerum ipsorum, et eorum egressionem, et uenarum pulsatilium, et quietarum, et locorum exitus earum.	The reason why there is not found a good craftsman of it with his hand in this our time is because the art of medicine is long and its author must exercise himself before that in the science of anatomy which Galen narrated until he knows the joints of members and their forms and their conjunction and separation, and has knowledge of bones and nerves and muscles and their number and their exit and pulsating veins and quiet ones and the places of their exit.
Et propter illud dixit Hippocrates, quod nomen cum nomine est multum, et cum opere est paucum, et praecipue in arte manus.	And on account of this Hippocrates said that "a name with a name is much, but with work it is little," especially in the art of hand.
Nos uero iam diximus de illo in introitu huius libri.	But we have already spoken about him at the beginning of this book.
Quoniam qui non est sciens, quod diximus de anatomia, non euacuatur, quin iam cadat in errorem, quo interficiuntur homines: sicut ego uidi multos ex illis, qui formantur de hac scientia, et iactant se de ea absque scientia, et sine experimento.	For he who is not knowing what we have said about anatomy will not be able to avoid falling into error which kills men, as I have seen many of those who are formed in this science and boast about it without knowledge and without experience.
Quod est, quia uidi medicum stolidum secuisse apostema scrophulosum in collo mulieris, et incidit quasdam arterias in collo: quare fluxit sanguis mulieris, donec cecidit mortua inter manus eius.	Which means that I saw a foolish physician incise an ulcerous boil on a woman's neck and he cut some arteries there so that blood flowed from the woman until she fell dead in his hands.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui praesumpsit ut extraheret lapidem uiro, qui processerat in aetate, et lapis erat magnus.	And I saw another physician who undertook to remove a stone from a man who had had it for many years, and the stone was large.
Peruenit ergo ad eum, et extraxit ipsum cum frusto uesicae.	So he approached him and removed it along with a piece of bladder.
Quare mortuus est uir in tertio die.	Whereupon the man died on the third day.
Et ego quidem iam uocatus fueram ad extrahendum ipsum: et uidi ex magnitudine lapidis, et dispositione infirmi, quod moriretur.	And indeed I had been summoned to remove it; and upon seeing the size of the stone and the condition of the patient, I deemed that he would die.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui accipiebat stipem apud quendam Ducum terrae nostrae propter medicinam: et accidit eunucho nigro, qui erat apud ipsum, fractura in crure eius prope calcaneum: et properauit medicus cum ignorantia sua, et strinxit fracturam super uulnus cum puluinaribus, et astellis strictura forti, et non dimisit uulneri expirationem.	And I saw another physician who was receiving payment from a certain Duke of our land on account of his medical skill; and there happened to be an accident involving a black eunuch who was with him, namely a fracture in his leg near the heel: and the physician, in his ignorance, hurriedly set the fracture upon the wound with bandages and splints tied tightly together, not allowing the wound to breathe.
Deinde absoluit eum secundum desyderia sua.	Then he dismissed him according to his wishes.
Postea dimisit eum diebus aliquot, et praecepit ei, ne solueret ligamentum: et stetit sic donec apostematum est crus eius, et ipsius pes, et peruenit ad perditionem.	Afterwards he let him go for a few days and commanded him not to untie the bandage; and thus it remained until gangrene set in on his leg and foot, and he met his ruin.
Vocatus sum ergo ad eum: et properaui ad soluendum ligamentum: et consecuta est tranquillitas, et euasit a doloribus suis.	Therefore I was summoned to him, and I hurriedly untied the bandage; and tranquility followed, and he was delivered from his pains.
Verumtamen corruptio iam confirmata erat in membro: et non potui refraenare ipsam.	However, the corruption had already become established in the limb, and I could not prevent it.
Pon ergo cessauit corruptio perambulare in membro, donec periit.	Therefore the corruption spread throughout the limb until he died.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui perforauit apostema cancerosum: et ulceratum est post dies, donec magnificata est malicia eius cum domino ipsius.	And I saw another physician who pierced an ulcerous cancer, and after a few days it became worse until its wickedness was increased with the death of his master.
Quod est, quia quando est cancer purus ex humore melancholico, tunc non oportet ut perueniatur ad eum cum ferro omnino, nisi sit in membro quod toleret, ut abscindatur totum eius.	Which means that when a cancer is pure and from melancholic humor, then it is not permissible to touch it with iron at all unless it is on a member which can bear amputation so that the whole of it may be removed.
Et propter illud o Filii, necesse est uobis, ut sciatis, quod operatio cum manu diuiditur in duas diuisiones: scilicet, operationem cui associatur salus: et operationem, cum qua est periculum in pluribus dispositionibus.	And therefore, O Son [of man], it is necessary for you to know that surgery is divided into two parts: namely, the operation with which recovery is associated; and the operation with which there is danger in many dispositions.
Et ego iam excitaui in omni loco huius libri, in quo uenit operatio, in qua est terror et timor.	And I have already pointed out in every place of this book where an operation comes about that has fear and trembling.
Quare necesse est uobis, ut caueatis illud, et dimitatis ipsum: ut non inueniant stolidi uiam ad loquendum, et dehonestandum.	Therefore it is necessary for you to be cautious about this [operation] and to conceal it: so that fools may not find a way to speak and dishonor it.
Accipite ergo mensuram cum sollicitudine et protectione, et infirmos uestros cum facilitate et firmitudine, et utimini uia meliore perducente gratia Dei ad salutem et successionem laudabilem: et dimittite aegritudines terribiles difficilis sanationis: et tollite animas uestras ab eo quod facit uos timere, ut ingrediatur super uos haesitatio in fide uestra et commodo uestro.	Therefore, take measurement with care and protection, and your patients with ease and firmness, and use the better path leading to health and commendable success by the grace of God: and leave behind terrifying illnesses difficult to heal, and remove from yourselves that which causes you fear, so that hesitation may not enter into your faith and benefit.
Est enim magis remanens ad gloriam uestram, et sublimius in mundo isto, et postremo ad quantitates uestras.	For it is more remaining to your glory, and higher in this world, and ultimately for your reward.
Galenus enim iam dixit in quibusdam suis admonitionibus.	Galen already said in certain of his admonitions.
Non medicetis aegritudinem malam: ne nominemini medici mali.	Do not treat bad illnesses lest you be called evil physicians.
Iam autem diuisi hunc Tractatum secundum tria Capitula. ¶	And now I have divided this Treatise into three Chapters.
Capitulum primum.	Chapter One.
De Cauterio cum igne, et Cauterio cum medicina acuta, capitulatum, et ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum, et ferramentis Cauterii: et omni quod necessarium est in operatione. ¶	Chapter One contains the cautery with fire and the cautery with sharp medicine, arranged from head to foot, including forms of instruments and tools for the cautery, and everything necessary for the operation.
Capitulum secundum.	Chapter Two.
De sectione et perforatione, phlebotomia et uentosis, et uulneribus: et extractione sagittarum, et similibus illius: et totum capitulatum, ordinatum formis instrumentorum. ¶	Chapter Two contains incision and puncture, bloodletting and bandaging, wounds, the removal of arrows and similar objects, all arranged with forms of instruments.
Capitulum tertium.	Chapter Three.
De restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus illius: capitulatum, ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum.	Chapter Three contains restoration and reduction, treatment of dislocations and similar conditions, arranged from head to foot with forms of instruments.
Soli Deo Gloria.	To God alone the glory.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis.	The Surgery Book of Albucasis.
Pars I.	Book One
¶ De Iuuamento, et Nocumento Cauterii: et quibus complexionibus conueniat, et quo tempore: et si cum ferro, uel auro.	Chapter One: On the benefit and harm of cautery; and with which complexions it agrees, and at what time: and if with iron or gold.
Caput I.	Chapter One.
Sed Ante Quidem Quam rememorer operationis cum eo, oportet ut dicam qualitatem Iuuamentorum eius, et Nocumentorum ipsius: et in qua complexione exhibeatur.	But before I recall the operations with it, it is necessary that I mention the qualities of its benefits and harms, and in which complexion it should be exhibited.
Dico ergo, quod sermo de qualitate iuuamenti Cauterii, et nocumenti eius, est sermo prolixus, et subtilis, scientia, et secretum occultum.	I say therefore that the discourse on the quality of cautery's benefit and harm is a lengthy and subtle science, hidden and secret.
Etiam locuta fuit in eo multitudo sapientum, et dissenserunt in eo: et mihi quidem sufficit parum ex sermonibus eorum, timens prolongationem.	Also many wise men have spoken about it and disagreed about it. But for me, a little of their words is sufficient, fearing prolivality.
Dico ergo, quod Cauterium confert uniuersaliter omni complexioni, quae est cum materia, et absque materia: excaeptis duabus complexionibus, quae sunt complexio calida absque materia, et complexio sicca absque materia.	I say therefore that cautery is beneficial universally to every complexion that has matter and lacks matter, except for two complexions which are the hot complexion without matter and the dry complexion without matter.
In complexione autem calida et sicca cum materia dissenserunt.	But concerning the hot and dry complexion with matter, they disagreed.
Quidam enim dixerunt, quod Cauterium iuuatiuum est in ea.	Some said that cautery is beneficial in it.
Et dixerunt alii contrarium illius, scilicet quod Cauterium non est conueniens in aegritudine, quae est ex caliditate et siccitate: quoniam natura ignis est caliditas: et inconueniens est, ut sanetur ex agritudine calida et sicca, cum calido et sicco.	And others said the opposite, namely that cautery is not suitable for the ailment which arises from heat and dryness, because the nature of fire is heat and it is unsuitable to heal with heat and dryness.
Et dixit ille qui dicit contrarium illius: quod per Cauterium fit iuuamentum in omni aegritudine calida et sicca, quae accidit in corporibus hominum: quoniam quando tu comparas corpus hominis, et humiditates eius, ad complexionem ignis, inuenis corpus hominis frigidum.	And the one who said the opposite said: that through cautery there is benefit for every hot and dry ailment which happens in human bodies, because when you compare the body of man and its moistures to the complexion of fire, you find the body of man cold.
Et ego quidem dico per sermonem eius: quia ex perimentum iam detexit mihi illud aliquotiens.	And I say through his speech that from experience it has often been revealed to me thus.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut ueniat super illud, nisi qui iam probatus est, et exercitatus in capitulo Cauterii exercitio ultimo, et cognouit diuersitatem complexionum hominum, et dispositionem aegritudinum in se ipsis, et caussas earum, et accidentia ipsarum, et spacium temporis earum.	But nevertheless it is not necessary for anyone to come upon it unless he is already proven and trained in the final chapter on cautery practice, and has known the diversity of human complexions and the disposition of ailments within themselves, their causes, accidents, and time duration.
Ex reliquis autem complexionibus non est super uos timor: et praecipue in aegritudinibus frigidis et humidis.	But with regard to other complexions there is no fear for you: especially in cold and moist ailments.
Iam enim conuenerunt omnes medici super eas: et non dissenserunt in iuuamento cum Cauterio in eis.	For all physicians have agreed upon these [ailments], and they do not disagree about applying cautery to them.
Et scitote filii, quod ex secreto curationis per Cauterium cum igne, et bonitate eius super Cauterium cum medicina comburente est: quoniam ignis est simplex, cuius actio non peruenit, nisi ad membrum quod cauterisatur: et non nocet membro alio coniuncto cum eo, nisi nocumento paruo.	And know, my sons, that the cure by cautery with fire is secret, and its goodness is combined with medicine burning on it. For fire is simple; its action does not extend except to the member being cauterized, nor does it harm another connected member, unless slightly.
Medicinae uero comburentis actio peruenit ad illud quod elongatur ex membris: et fortasse facit accidere in membro aegritudinem difficilis sanationis, et fortasse interficit.	But the action of burning medicine extends to that which is remote from the members and perhaps causes difficult-to-heal ailments to occur in another member, and perhaps kills.
Ignis autem propter subtilitatem suam et bonitatem substantiae suae, non facit illud, nisi superfluat.	Fire, however, because of its subtlety and the goodness of its substance, does not do this unless it is excessive.
Iam uero innotuit nobis illud per experimentum, propter longitudinem seruitutis et studii cum arte, et stationem super ueritatem rerum: et propter illud excusor a longitudine sermonis.	Now we have learned this through experience because of the length of our service and study with this art, and our standing on the truth of things; and for that reason I excuse myself from the length of my discourse.
Et si non esset, quia non licet huic libro meo, afferrem uobis secretum occultum in igne, et qualitatem operationis eius in corporibus expulsionis suae, qua expellit aegritudines sermone philosophico demonstratiuo, qui acueretur a mentibus uestris.	And if it were not so, because this book of mine does not permit it, I would bring you the secret hidden in fire and the quality of its operation on bodies from which it expels ailments in a philosophical demonstration that would penetrate your minds.
Et scitote filii, quod ipsi dissentiunt in tempore, in quo conuenit fieri cauterium, et ponunt melius tempus ueris.	And know, my sons, that they [physicians] disagree about the time when cautery should be performed, and they place the best time in spring.
Et ego dico, quod cauterium conuenit in omni tempore: propterea, quod nocumentum accidens propter tempus submergitur in iuuamento, quod attrahitur cum cauterio.	But I say that cautery is appropriate at any time, for the harm occurring because of the time is submerged in the cure that is drawn with the cautery.
Et praecipue si cauterium est propter dolores ex doloribus necessariis, fortibus, festinis, qui non tolerant tarditatem: propterea quod timetur ex eis, quod accidat malicia quae est maior, quam paruum nocumentum intrans propter tempus.	And especially if cautery is performed because of pains from necessary, strong, urgent pains that do not tolerate delay; for there is feared from them a greater evil than the slight harm that does not occur because of time.
Et non cadat in mentibus uestris o filii illud, quod non extimant, nisi uulgus et stolidi medici, scilicet quod illi aegritudini quae sanatur per cauterium, non est reditio semper: et ponunt illud consequens, et res non est sicut putant: propterea quod cauterium non est, nisi loco medicinae, quae alterat complexionem, et exiccat humiditates quae sunt caussae, quare accidunt dolores.	And do not fall into the belief, O sons, which only the common people and foolish physicians estimate, namely that there is always a recurrence of that illness which is cured by cautery; and they put forth this consequence, but the matter is not as they think: for cautery is nothing but a kind of medicine which alters the temperament and drives out the moistures which are the cause of pains.
Verumtamen cauterium superfluit super medicinam per uelocitatem ualetudinis suae, et uirtutem suae operationis, et uehementiam dominii sui: et possibile est, ut redeat aegritudo hora aliqua temporis secundum complexionem infirmi, et locationem aegritudinis suae, et uirtutem eius: et quod praeparatur in corpore eius ex aggregatione superfluitatum in eo: et quod peruenit ad ipsum in acquisitione sua ex cibis, et similibus illis ex caussis, nisi fit aegritudo, in qua administratur cauterium.	Nevertheless, cautery surpasses medicine by the speed of its action and the power of its operation, and the vehemence of its dominion; and it is possible for illness to recur at some time according to the temperament of the sick person, and the location of his illness, and the strength of it: and what accumulates in his body from an excess of superfluities therein: and what reaches him through foods, and like causes, unless there arises an illness in which cautery is administered.
Aegritudo subtilis in membro paucarum superfluitatum, et humiditatum, sicut cauterium dentis, propter dolorem, et similia illi, possibile est enim, ut non redeat in eo ille dolor.	It is possible for a subtle illness in a member of few superfluities and moistures, such as cautery of the tooth because of pain, etc., not to recur in it.
Sed illud fit in paucis.	But this occurs rarely.
At uero sermo uulgi iterum, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, est sermo rectus: non ad illud quod ipsi intendunt in illo: quoniam ipsi credunt, quod non est curatio quae conferat cum medicina, neque cum alio post occasum cauterii.	But the common saying that cautery is the last resort of medicine is true, not however as they mean it; for they believe that there is no cure that can compare with medicine or anything else after cautery has been performed.
Res autem est econtrario illius, et intentio, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, non est, nisi quod quando nos administramus modos curationis in aliqua aegritudinum, et non conferunt illae medicinae: deinde administramus in fine rei cauterium, et confert: tunc inde cadit, quod cauterium est postremum mediciuae, non secundum intentionem quam intelligunt uulgus et multistolidorum medicorum.	But the fact is quite otherwise than their meaning. Cautery is the last resort of medicine only in this sense, that when we apply methods of cure to certain illnesses and they do not succeed, then we apply cautery at last and it succeeds.
Antiqui autem dixerunt, quod cauterium cum auro est melius, quam cauterium cum ferro: et non dixerunt illud, nisi propter aequalitatem auri, et sublimitatem substantiae suae: et dixerunt, quod non facit pus locus cauterii.	Ancients said that cautery with gold is better than cautery with iron. They said this not because of the equality of gold's weight or its noble substance, but because it does not cause pus at the site of cautery.
Verum non est illud absolute: quoniam ego iam probaui illud, et inueni, quod ipsum non facit illud in quibusdam corporibus absque aliis.	But this is not absolutely true. For I have already proved and found that it does not happen so in certain bodies without others.
Et cauterium cum ipso est bonum, et melius quam cum ferro, sicut dixerunt.	And cautery with gold itself is good and better than with iron, as they said.
Verumtamen quando tu ignis cauterium in igne ex auro, non declaratur tibi, quando ignitur secundum quantitatem quam uis, propter rubedinem auri: et quando properat ad ipsum frigus, et si addis super ipsum ignitionem, liquescit in igne, et uertitur in laminas.	However, when you heat the cautery of gold in fire, it is not apparent to you how much heat you want because of the redness of gold. And when it starts cooling down, if you add more heat on top, it melts in the fire and turns into sheets.
Quare cadit artifex ex illo in occupationem: et propter illud fit Cauterium cum ferro apud nos uelocius et propinquius, ex rectitudine ad operationem.	Therefore, an artisan falls into trouble with it. And for that reason we use cautery with iron more quickly and appropriately for the operation.
Et ego quidem iam ordinaui hoc Capitulum in Cauterio, secundum capitula: et ordinaui ea a capite usque ad pedes: ut alleuient quaerenti illud quod uult ex eo.	And indeed I have already arranged this chapter on cautery according to sections and ordered them from head to foot so that one may easily find what he wants from it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Caput in commissura coronali.	Chapter: On the method of cauterizing in the coronal suture.
Caput II.	Chapter 2.
Confert hic cauterizatio ad dominium humiditatis et frigiditatis super cerebrum: quae duae sunt caussae sodae, et multitudinis fluxus humorum ex capite ad partes oculorum et aurium, et multitudinis somni, et doloris dentium, et doloris gutturis: et uniuersaliter omnis aegritudinis, quae accidit ex frigiditate, sicut paralisis, et sodae, epilepsiae, et apoplexiae, et similia illis ex aegritudinibus.	Cautery here is beneficial for the dominance of moisture and coldness over the brain, which are two causes of madness and abundance of flow of humors from the head to parts of eyes and ears, and abundance of sleep, and toothache, and sore throat, and generally all diseases that happen because of coldness, such as paralysis, epilepsy, apoplexy, and similar diseases.
Modus cauterizationis est, ut praecipias infirmo: ut euacuetur in primis cum medicina solutiua mundificante caput tribus noctibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod exigit uirtus infirmi, et eius aetas, et consuetudo eius.	The manner of cauterization is that you should order the patient to first evacuate with a purgative medicine cleansing the head for three nights or four, according to what the strength of the patient requires, and his age, and his habit.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radi faciat caput suum cum nouacula.	Next, command him to shave his head with razors.
Deinde fac eum sedere inter manus tuas quadratum, ita quod iam posuit manus suas super pectus suum.	Then make him sit between your hands on a square [pillow], so that he has placed his hands upon his chest.
Deinde pone radicem palmae tuae super radicem nasi sui inter oculos suos.	Then place the root of your little finger over the root of his nose, between his eyes.
Vbicumque ergo peruenerit digitus tuus medius, signa locum illum cum incausto.	Therefore wherever your middle finger reaches, mark that spot with a cauterizing iron.
Deinde igni Cauterium Oliuare: cuius haec est forma.	Then kindle the cautery of olive oil, which has this shape:
Deinde pone ipsum super locum signatum cum incausto, descensione, qua constringatur manus tua paulatim, et tu reuolues ipsum.	Then place it upon the marked spot with a descending motion, while your hand gradually tightens, and you roll it.
Deinde leua manum tuam uelociter, et aspicias locum.	Then quickly lift your hand, and examine the spot.
Quod si uides iam detegi ex osse quantitatem capitis alkiel, aut quantitatem zeuherbi, tunc eleua manum tuam.	But if you see that it has already melted away from the bone like wax or the amount of zeuherb, then lift your hand.
Et si non, itera manum tuam ferro ipso, aut cum alio ab ipso si infrigidatur: donec uideantur ossa, quae dixi tibi.	And if not, repeat the cautery with the same iron or another one if it cools down until you see the bones that I told you about.
Deinde sume aliquid ex sale, et solue illud in aqua, et imbibe in ipso cotum, et pone super locum: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then take some salt and dissolve it in water, and moisten the cotton with it, and place it upon the spot, and leave him for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, et dimitte illum super locum, donec destruatur eschara ignis.	Then place upon it cotton moistened in butter, and leave it there until the scab of the fire is destroyed.
Deinde cura illud cum unguento tetrapharmacon, usquequo sanetur.	Then dress it with tetrapharmacon ointment until it heals.
Iam dixerunt, quod quanto uulnus plus remanet apertum, emittit pus: quare est melius et magis iuuatiuum.	It has been said that the more an wound remains open, the more pus it emits. Therefore, it is better and more beneficial to keep it open.
Et dixerunt quidam eorum, ut cauterizetur cutis usque ad os: et teneatur Cauterium, donec aduratur quiddam spissitudinis ossis.	And some of them said that the skin should be cauterized up to the bone and the cautery held until a portion of the bone's thickness is burned.
Deinde radatur post illud quod adustum est ex osse, deinde curetur.	Then the burnt part of the bone is scraped away, then it is dressed.
Et dicunt alii, quod oportet ut cum cauterio perueniatur ad ultimum, donec imprimat in os impressionem for tem, ita quod cadat os, quod fit sicut forma kirate: aut instrumentum quod mulieres ponunt infuso alphabeti parui: et extimant, quod exspirantur ex hoc loco uapores capitis, et dimittatur uulnus apertum tempore longo.	And others say that the cautery should be applied to the very end until it leaves an impression on the bone like a seal ring or the tool used by women for impressing letters in dough. They believe that vapors from the head are exhaled through this location, and that the wound should remain open for a long time.
Deinde curetur, donec consolidetur.	Then it is dressed until it solidifies.
Mihi autem non uidentur hae duae species Cauterii omnino nisi in quibusdam hominibus secundum uiam timoris.	But these two methods of cautery seem to me not at all necessary except in certain cases where fear is involved.
Et dimittere ipsum, apud me est melius cum salute ipsius.	And it seems better to me to leave him as he is with his own safety.
Debilitatur enim caput ex solutione continuitatis ipsius naturalis: sicut testificati sumus in reliquis membris: et praecipue quando caput infirmi debile est natura: et species quidem Cauterii prima est magis salua et melior apud me, et ea utor: operare ergo cum ea in salute.	For the head is weakened by the dissolution of its natural continuity, as we have testified regarding other members, especially when the head is naturally weak. Indeed, the first method of cautery seems to me safer and better, and that is what I use; therefore act accordingly for the sake of health.
¶ De modo cauterizandi capitis in dolore totius capitis.	Regarding the manner of cauterizing the head in case of headache.
Caput III.	Chapter 3.
Quando in toto Capite accidit dolor chronicus: et prolongatur illud in infirmo, et utitur hyeris, et cochiis, et caputpurgiis, et oleis, et empleumatis.	When a chronic pain occurs in the whole head and persists in an invalid despite use of diaphoretics, cataplasms, purgatives for the head, oils, and plasters.
Et praecipue si iam cauterizatum est cauterio uno, quod narrauimus, et non confert ei aliquid ex illis: tunc considera.	And especially if it has already been cauterized once with the cautery we mentioned earlier, but there is no improvement from any of those remedies: then consider.
Nam si caput infirmi est fortis creationis natura, et non est debile, et inuenit frigus uehemens: tunc cauteriza cum cauterio alio sub illo parum.	For if the head of an invalid is strongly constituted and not weak, but intense cold is present, then cauterize it with another cautery underneath that one a little.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio, do nec pertranseat cutis, et discooperiatur ex osse quantitas, quam narrauimus.	Next, cauterize the top of the head itself with a cautery over all its horns, but do not let it penetrate the skin, and uncover as much bone as we have mentioned.
Et cauteriza ipsum cauterio uno in occipitio capitis sui, in loco qui nominatur uas: et est locus in quo ponitur uentosa: et eleua matum tuam in hoc, et non discooperias os.	And cauterize it with one cautery at the back of the head itself, in the place called 'the vessel': and this is the place where the windpipe is located. And raise your hand in this, but do not uncover the bone.
Infirmus enim inuenit propter illud dolorem uehementem, et diuersum a dolore reliquorum cauteriorum capitis omnium.	For the invalid finds intense pain because of it, and differing from the pain caused by other head cauteries altogether.
Et ego dicam hoc Cauterium in loco suo: et oportet quod sit cauterium, quo cauterizantur cornua capitis, et occiput eius subtilius cauterio, quo cauterizatur medium capitis.	And I shall say that this cautery is to be used in its proper place, and it should be a cautery with which the horns of the head are cauterized, and the back of the head more finely, with which the middle of the head is cauterized.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its shape.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in hemicrania, tam cum medicina adustiua, quam cum ferro.	On the method of cauterizing in hemicrania, both with burning medicine and with iron.
Caput IIII.	Chapter IV.
Quando accidit in parte capitis dolor et soda, aut extenditur dolor usque ad oculum, et euacuatur cum medicinis mundificantibus caput, et administratur reliqua curatio, quam dixi in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert illud totum: tunc cauterizatio in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterizatio cum medicina acuta comburente: aut cum ferro.	When pain and stiffness occur in part of the head, or the pain extends to the eye, and even after purification with medicines for cleaning the head and applying other treatments as mentioned in the divisions of illnesses, no improvement occurs, then cautery should be performed on it in two ways: either cautery with a sharp burning medicine, or with iron.
Cauterium autem cum medicina acuta comburente, est, ut accipias dentem unum allii, et excortices ipsum, et abscindas extremitates eius ex duobus lateribus.	The cautery with a sharp burning medicine is as follows: take one tooth of garlic, peel it, and cut off its ends on both sides.
Deinde scinde locum doloris in tempore cum phlebotomo lato, donec fiat in eo locus sub cute, in quo dens capitur.	Then cut the place of pain in the temple with a wide phlebotome until there is made under the skin a place in which the tooth can be inserted.
Intromitte ergo eum in ipso sub cute, donec occultetur: deinde stringe super ipsum cum puluillo constrictione decenti, et dimitte ipsum quantitate quindecim horarum deinde solue eum, et extrahe allium, et dimitteuulnus duobus diebus, aut tribus: postea pone super ipsum cotum submersum in butyro, donec locus efficiat pus: deinde cura ipsum cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Then insert it under the skin until it is hidden; then bind it over with a suitable bandage made of lint, and leave it for fifteen hours. Then remove it, take out the garlic, and let the wound alone for two or three days. Afterwards place over it a wad soaked in butter until pus forms at the site. Then treat it with ointment until it heals.
Et si uis fac illud cum quibusdam medicinis comburentibus, quas ego scripsi in tractatu duodecimo, de Medieinis adurentibus.	And if you wish to make this with certain medicines that I have written about in the twelfth treatise on burning medicines.
Cauterizatio uero eius cum ferro, est secundum hunc modum.	Cautery of it with iron is done in this manner:
Igni Cauterium, cuius forma haec est.	The form of the cautery is as follows:
Et nominatur Clauilis: quoniam forma capitis eius est sicut forma claui, in quo est quiddam curuitatis, et in medio eius est quaedam eminentia parua.	And it is called 'the claw': because the shape of its head is like that of a nail, having some curvature and a small prominence in the middle.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum, et retine manum tuam: et tu reuolue ferrum paulatim cum uelocitate: et sit quantitas quae aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, sicut medietas eius.	Then place it on the site and hold your hand steady; you should gradually turn the iron with speed, so that the thickness of what is burned is equal to half its width.
Et eleua manum tuam, ut non aduratur arteria, quae est inferius, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And lift your hand, lest the artery beneath be burned and bleeding occur.
Deinde imbibe cotum in aqua salis, et pone super locum, et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus: deinde pone cotum cum butyro: postea cura cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Then soak a wad in salt water and place it on the site; leave it for three days. Then place a wad soaked in butter over it, afterwards treat with ointment until it heals.
Et si uis, cauteriza hanc hemicraniam cum extremitate cultellari secunda Cauterii.	And if you wish, cauterize this half of the head with the second tip of the cautery, like a knife-point.
Et caue ab incisione arteriae in hac hemicrania, non antiqua proprie.	But beware of cutting the artery in this half of the head, as it is not the old-fashioned way.
¶ De modo cauteriezandi in hemicrania antiqua.	On the manner of cauterizing in the old-fashioned way for a half-head.
Caput V.	Chapter Five
Quando curas hemicraniam, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione praecedente, et quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio: et uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei quod diximus ex cauterio primo cum medicina, aut cum cauterio cum igne, tunc oportet ut ignias Cauterium cultellare, donec albificetur postquam signas super locum doloris cum linea, cuius longitudo sit medietas digiti, aut quasi illud: et depone manum tuam uice una, et stringe eam donec incidas arteriam, et peruenias usque ad os.	When you treat a half-head as we have said in the previous treatment and divisions of illnesses, but the treatment does not help, and you see that the illness is not improving with what we have said about the first cautery with medicine or fire cautery, then you must take an iron cautery like a knife-point until it turns white. Then mark the place of pain with a line whose length is half a fingerbreadth or thereabouts; lay your hand on once and press down until you cut the artery and reach the bone.
Verumtamen necesse est tibi, ut caueas a continuatione mandibulae, quae mouetur apud masticationem, ne aduratur latus, aut neruus qui mouet ipsam, unde accidat spasmus.	Nevertheless, it is necessary for you to beware of the continuity of the jawbone which moves during chewing, lest the side or nerve that moves it be burned and spasm result.
Et esto super custotiam, et cautelam de fluxu sanguinis arteriae, quae abscisa est.	And let this be a caution and care for you regarding the flow of blood from the artery that has been cut off.
In abscisione enim eius est timor, et praecipue ei qui ignorat illud quod facit, et non est studiosus, nec expertus: et dimittit operationem cum eo in primis.	For in its cutting there is fear, especially for one who does not know what he does and is neither studious nor experienced. Therefore, let him not undertake the operation first.
Et ego ueniam cum rememoratione regiminis fluxus sanguinis accidentis ex arteria secundum modum suum, et in loco suo huius libri.	And I will come with a reminder of how to manage the flow of blood that occurs from the artery according to its method and in its place in this book.
Quod si uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei hoc Cauterium, et uides corpus infirmi tolerans cauterium in medio capitis, sicut narrauimus, cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	But if you see that the illness does not improve with this cautery and you see the patient's body enduring the cautery in the middle of the head as we have described, then treat the wound until it heals.
Et si uis, administra Cauterium, quod diximus in capitulo extractionis arteriae cum Cauterio habente duos cultellos.	And if you wish, use the cautery that we have mentioned in the chapter on extracting the artery with a cautery having two knife-points.
Est enim cauterizatio melior hac et magis conferens.	For this cauterization is better and more helpful.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Aurium.	On the method of cauterizing for ear pain.
Caput VI.	Chapter 6.
Quando accidit in Aure dolor a frigore, et curatur cum solutiuis, et reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione, et non remouetur dolor, tunc igni Cauterium: et est illud quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma est haec.	When pain occurs in the ear due to coldness and is treated with remedies and other treatments mentioned in our divisions, but the pain is not relieved, then use a fire cautery. The shape of this cautery is as follows:
Deinde puncta cum eo post eius ignitionem in circumitu auris totius, sicut reuoluitur: aut in circumitu utriusque, si simul dolor est in utrisque.	Then make punctures with it after igniting it around the entire ear, as it revolves; or around both if there is pain in both.
Et elonga te cum Cauterio a radice auris parumper, postquam signaueris loca cum encaustro: et sit cauterii quantitas decem punctorum in omni aure, et quasi illa.	And lengthen it with the cautery from the root of the ear somewhat, after you have marked the places with caustic; and let the quantity of the cautery be ten punctures in each ear, like those.
Deinde cura loca, donec sanentur.	Then dress the wounds until they heal.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tortura.	Regarding the method of cauterizing in Torture.
Caput VII.	Chapter VII.
Tortura quae curatur cum cauterizatione, non est nisi ex speciebus, quae accidunt ex phlegmate, secundum quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum.	A torment that is treated with cautery is only of those kinds that happen from phlegm, according to what we have said in the divisions of illnesses.
Et deuita cauterizationem speciei, quae accidit ex exiccatione, et spasmo nerui.	And avoid cauterizing the kind that happens from drying out and spasm of a nerve.
Quando curas hanc speciem torturae cum hyeris, et caputpurgiis, et gargarismis, et non confert curatio tua, tunc oportet ut cauterizes infirmum tribus Cauteriis: uno apud radicem auris, et secundo parum inferius a timpore suo, et tertio apud coniunctionem duorum labiorum.	When you treat this kind of torment with herbs and purges and gargarisms, but your treatment is not helpful, then it is necessary to cauterize the sick person with three cauteries: one at the root of the ear, and a second somewhat below its own time, and a third at the junction of the two lips.
Et pone Cauterium tuum ex contrario partis infirmae.	And place your cautery on the opposite side of the weakened part.
Quoniam mollificatio non accidit, nisi in parte quae apparet sana.	For softening does not happen except in the part that appears healthy.
Et forma cauterizationis est, ut cauterizes ipsum Cauterio in directo extremitatis auris superioris sub cornu capitis parum: et alio in timpore: cuius longitudo sit secundum longitudinem pollicis.	And the form of the cautery is that you should cauterize with it at the direct extremity of the upper ear beneath the horn of the head somewhat; and another on the time: whose length shall be according to the length of a finger.
Et depone manum tuam cum cauterio, donec comburatur quantitas medietatis spissitudinis cutis.	And place your hand with the cautery until it burns up half the thickness of the skin.
Et haec est forma Cauterii, et est species ex cultellari, cuius forma praemissa est: uerumtamen non est subtilior ea parum, sicut uides: et oportet ut sit cultellus in eo superfluae grossitudinis parum.	And this is the form of the cautery, and it is of knife-like shape, whose form is shown beforehand: however, do not make it too thin, as you see; and it is necessary that there be a little excess thickness on the blade.
Deinde cura loca, cum eo quod praecessit: donec sanetur.	Then dress the wounds with what preceded: until they heal.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Apoplexia antiqua.	How to cauterize in ancient apoplexy.
Caput VIII.	Chapter VIII.
QUando antiquatur Apoplexia, et curas eam cum eo quod diximus, et non confert medicatio tua, et infirmus non habet febrem, tunc cauteriza eum quatuor cauteriis super omne cornu capitis sui, et cauterio in medio capitis, sicut diximus, et cauterio in occipitio capitis, secundum quod praecessit: et modus cauterii sit secundum quod praecessit.	When apoplexy becomes chronic and you treat it with what we said, but your treatment is not helpful, and the sick person does not have a fever, then cauterize him with four cauteries on all horns of his head, and one in the middle of the head, as we have said, and one at the back of the head, according to what preceded: and the manner of cautery shall be according to what preceded.
Etiam cauterizatur cum Cauterio super os stomachi: et est magis ultimum.	And he is also cauterized with a cautery on the bone of the stomach; and this is the last one.
Deinde curetur, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then treat him with what preceded.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Obliuione.	On the method of cauterization in Hemiplegia.
Caput IX.	Chapter 9
Oportet ut in potu dentur in primis infirmo hyerae magnae, et pillulae mundificantes cerebrum.	It is necessary that first to the drink of the sick are given great leeches and pills for cleansing the brain.
Deinde rade caput infirmi totum, et pone super occipitium eius emplastrum de synapi descriptum in tractatu emplastrorum: et pone ipsum aliquotiens.	Then shave the head of the sick one entirely, and place on his occiput the plaster made from senna, as described in the treatise on plasters: and apply it repeatedly.
Ipsum namque est modus Cauterii: et fac illud secundum ordinem eundem, quem dixi illic.	For this indeed is the manner of cautery: and do this according to the same order which I said there.
Si ergo sanatur per illud, bonum est.	If therefore he is healed by it, that is good.
Si non: tunc fac ei cauteria tria in posteriori parte capitis sui, quae sint descendentia a superiori parte capitis usque ad inferiorem partem oculi: et pone inter omne cauterium grossitudinem digiti.	But if not: then make him three cauteries on the back part of his head, which are descending from the upper part of the head to the lower part of the eye; and place between every cautery the thickness of a finger.
Deinde cura Cauterium, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then treat the cauteries with what preceded.
Si autem uis additionem, et infirmus est tolerans illud: tunc fac ei Cauterium in medio.	But if you wish an addition, and the sick person is enduring it: then make him a cautery in the middle.
Quod si uis additionem: tunc cauteriza ipsum super duo cornua.	But if you wish another addition: then cauterize him on both horns.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: sitque Cauterium oliuare secundum formam, quae praemissa est.	Then treat him until he is healed: and let the cautery be oiled according to the form which has been shown beforehand.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Paralisi, et mollificatione.	On the method of cauterizing in Paralysis and Softening.
Caput X.	Chapter 10
Oportet ut procedas in mundificatione capitis cum hyeeris, et cum eo quod diximus.	It is necessary that you proceed with cleansing the head with leeches, and with what we said.
Deinde rade caput infirmi: postea cauteriza ipsum cauterio in medio capitis, et cauterio super omne cornu capitis, et cauterio super posterius ipsius, et tribus super spondiles colli.	Then shave the head of the sick one; afterwards cauterize him with a cautery in the middle of the head, and cautery on all horns of the head, and cautery on the back of it, and three cauteries on the spina of the neck.
Si autem indiges in aegritudine mollificatione corporis pluribus illis, et infirmus est tolerans, et aegritudo est fortis: tunc cauteriza ipsum quatuor cauteriis super spondiles dorsi, et ultima cum cauterio, donec comburatur ex cute plurimum eius, et eleua manum tuam.	If however the sick one needs many mollifications of the body due to his illness, and he is bearing it, and his ailment is strong: then cauterize him with four cauteries on the spina of the back, and lastly with a cautery until the skin burns greatly, and lift your hand.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: et sic cauterium Oliuare.	Then treat him until he is healed: and thus [use] the olive oil cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Epilepsia.	And concerning the method of cauterizing in epilepsy.
Caput XI.	Chapter Eleven.
Non Cauterizatur epilepticus, nisi ille cuius epilepsia est ex phlegmate.	No epileptic is cauterized except for one whose epilepsy is from phlegm.
Oportet ergo ut mundifices cerebrum eius in primis cum hyeris, et cum reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione: quando infirmus est magnus, aut est tolerans in accaeptione medicinarum.	It is necessary therefore that you cleanse his brain first with [iron] sponges and with the rest of the treatment which we have mentioned in division when the sick one is great or bears it well concerning accepting medicines.
Si autem est puer, qui non tolerat medicinas, tunc administratur gargarisma, et masticationes mundificantes cerebrum, ante illud diebus multis cum bonificatione ciborum.	But if [he is] a child who does not bear medicines, then gargarisms and cleansing chewing are administered, before that many days with good food.
Deinde rade caput eius, postea cauteriza ipsum Cauterio uno in medio capitis, secundum quod praecessit in modo: et cauterio alio in occipitio eius, et super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio.	Then shave his head; afterwards cauterize him with one cautery in the middle of the head according to what has preceded in method; and another cautery on the back of his head, and cautery on all horns of his head.
Quod si infirmus fuerit fortis, et fuerit tolerans, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauteriis, quae dixi in habente paralisim, et mollificationem corporis super spondiles colli, et spondiles dorsi: et sit Cauterium oliuare secundum modum qui praecessit.	But if the sick one is strong and bears it well, then cauterize him with cauteries which I said in [the case of] one having paralysis, and mollification of the body on the spina of the neck and back: and let the cautery be olive oil according to the method that has preceded.
Si autem infirmus est puer, tunc pone cauterium subtile, secundum hunc modum.	But if the sick one is a child, then place a fine cautery thus.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Melancholia.	And concerning the method of cauterizing in melancholy.
Caput XII.	Chapter Twelve.
Quando caussa melancholiae sunt humiditates corruptae, et phlegma grossum, tunc cauteriza ipsum Cauteriis, quae diximus in habente paralisim.	When the cause of melancholy is corrupted humidities and thick phlegm, then cauterize him with cauteries which we said for one having paralysis.
Et si caussa melancholiae est superfluitas decliuis ad melancholiam, et est corpus infirmi humectum, tunc da ei in potu quod mundificet cerebrum eius, secundum quod praecessit in diuisione: deinde rade caput infirmi, et fac postea tortellam decenter factam ex lino, sicut circulum.	And if the cause of melancholy is an abundance leaning towards melancholy and the body of the sick is moist, then give him to drink that which cleanses his brain according to what has preceded in division: then shave the head of the sick person, and afterwards make a well-made bandage from linen, like a circle.
Deinde pone ipsam in medio capitis: et infirmus sedens quadratus teneatur ab omni parte.	Then place it in the middle of his head: and let the sick person sitting squarely be held on all sides.
Deinde praesenta linimentum.	Then present the ointment.
Et est dignius ex butyro ouium antiquo.	And it is more suitable from old sheep butter.
Et calefac ipsum super ignem calefactione temperata mensura, quam toleret digitus, quando intromittitur in ipsum.	And warm it over a fire with moderate heat, which the finger can tolerate when inserted into it.
Deinde euacua ipsum in medio capitis eius in circulo, et dimitte ipsum donec infrigidetur.	Then pour it onto his head in a circle, and leave it until it cools down.
Fac illud infirmo omni hebdomada semel, cum reliquo regimine eius bono, donec sanetur.	Do this for the sick person once every week with the rest of his good regimen until he is healed.
Aut si uis, cauteriza ipsum faciendo puncta parua plurimum eius, praeter quod teneas manum cum cauterio: imo sit odorando.	Or if you wish, cauterize him by making many small punctures on him, except that which you hold with the cautery: indeed let it smell.
Haec enim species cauterii humectat cerebrum cum qualitate.	This kind of cautery moistens the brain with its quality.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, aut adipe gallinae.	Then place over it a wick impregnated with butter or chicken fat.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aqua descendente ad oculum.	On the method of cauterizing in water descending to the eye.
Caput XIII.	Chapter XIII.
Quando declaratur tibi principium aquae in oculo per signa, quae dixi in diuisione, tunc incipe et pota infirmum, cum eo quod mundificet caput eius.	When it is declared to you where the source of water is in the eye through signs which I said in division, then begin and let the sick person drink with that which cleanses his head.
Et custodi ipsum ab omnibus humiditatibus, et fac eum sedere in balneo, in ieiunio diebus aliquot.	And keep him from all moistures, and make him sit in a bath for several days fasting.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radat caput suum, et cauteriza ipsum in medio capitis sui.	Then order him to shave his head and cauterize him in the middle of his head.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super duo timpora duobus cauteriis, si est incaeptio descensus aquae in duobus oculis simul: aut ex latere uno, si est incaeptio aquae in oculo uno: et abscinde cum cauterio omnes uenas et arterias quae sunt sub cute: et sint cauteria in ea longa in latitudine timporum: et caue a fluxu sanguinis.	Then cauterize him over the two temples with two cauteries if there is an onset of water descent in both eyes at once; or on one side if there is an onset of water in one eye; and cut with the cautery all veins and arteries that are under the skin; and let the cauteries be long in width of the temples; and keep away from bleeding.
Quod si uides aliquid ex eo, tunc abscinde eum statim cum quacumque medicina est possibile: et ego ueniam cum sapientia, quae est in extractione arteriarum, et abscisione earum, et cautela a fluxu sanguinis.	If you see anything from it, then cut him immediately with whatever medicine is possible; and I will forgive with wisdom, which is in the extraction of arteries, and the cutting off of them, and care from bleeding.
Et quandoque cauterizatur in ceruice, sub duobus ossibus, duobus cauteriis ultime productis.	And sometimes he is cauterized on the neck, under two bones, with two cauteries brought out last.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lachrymis antiquis.	On the method of cauterizing old lachrymal passages.
Caput XIIII.	Chapter XIV.
Quando lachrymae oculorum sunt antiquae, assiduae: et sunt super uenas, et arterias quae sunt in manifesto capitis exterius, uerificatur quod illud est ex superfluitatibus frigidis, phlegmaticis: tunc cauteriza cauterio eodem quod narraui in incaeptione aquae descendentis, cauterio in medio capitis, et duobus cauteriis super duo timpora, et duobus cauteriis in ceruice sub duobus ossibus.	If tears from the eyes are old and continuous, and there are veins and arteries visible on the outside of the head, then verify that it is from cold and phlegmatic excesses; then cauterize with the same cautery that I mentioned for the onset of water descent, one in the middle of the head, and two on each temple, and two on the neck under the two bones.
Et si indiges additione, tunc cauteriza ipsum in omni latere caute oculi, super extremitatem supercilii cum cauterio paruo.	And if you need more, then cauterize him carefully on either side of the eye, above the eyebrow's end with a small cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in foetore Nasi.	On the method of cauterizing for stench of the nose.
Caput XV.	Chapter XV.
Quando tu medicaris illud, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert medicatio: tunc propera, et da in potu infirmocochias tribus noctibus: deinde rade caput eius, et cauteriza ipsum cauterio medio, cum cauterio oliuari.	When you are treating that (the stench of the nose), with what we have said in division, and treatment does not help: then hurry, and give him to drink three nights running, cochias; then shave his head, and cauterize him with a middle cautery, with an oil-cautery.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio clauili duobus cauteriis, super duo supercilia sub capillis parum.	Then cauterize him with a nail-cautery with two cauteries, on both eyebrows under the hair just a little bit.
Et custodite ab arteria, ne incidas eam.	And keep away from the artery, lest you cut it.
Et haec est forma cauterii Clauilis.	And this is the form of the nail-cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in mollificatione Palpebrae.	Regarding the method of cauterizing for the softening of the eyelid.
Caput XVI.	Chapter XVI
Quando mollificatur Palpebra oculi ab aegritudine, aut humiditate: tunc cauteriza Palpebram cauterio uno, cum hoc cauterio lunari.	When the eyelid is softened by illness or moisture, then cauterize the eyelid with one cautery, using this crescent-shaped cautery.
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum supra duo supercilia parum duobus cauteriis in omni parte: et elongentur a duobus timporibus: et sit longitudo omnis cauterii, secundum longitudines supercilii: et non ultimes manum tuam cum cauterio, imo secundum quantitatem quod aduritur tertia palpebrae.	And if you wish to, cauterize it above the two eyebrows somewhat with two cauteries in every part: and they will lengthen from two times; and let the length of all cautery be according to the lengths of the eyebrow; and do not bring your hand with the cautery too far, indeed according to the quantity that burns the third eyelid.
Et haec est forma cauterii secundum hunc modum cauterii lunaris.	And this is the form of the cautery according to this method of cauterizing with a crescent-shaped cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Palpebram cum pili inuersantur pungentes oculum.	Regarding the method of cauterizing the eyelid when hairs turn inward and prick the eye.
Caput XVII.	Chapter XVII
Cauterium in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum igne: aut cauterium cum medicina comburente.	The cautery for this is in two ways: either with fire or with a cautery that burns with medicine.
In cauterio autem cum igne, praecipe infirmo ante illud, ut dimittat pilos suos, si est ex illis qui mundant eos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	But before applying the cautery with fire, instruct the patient to remove his hairs if they are of those that he cleanses until they grow long and become even.
Si autem pungunt eum apud ortum suum: tunc constringe oculos eius cum uitta, ut non moueantur, donec nascantur.	But if the hairs prick him at their root, then compress his eyes with a bandage so that they do not move until they grow.
Cum ergo nascuntur et aequantur, tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo: deinde signa super Palpebram oculorum eius cum encaustro, signo quod sit secundum figuram folii myrti: et sit principium signi prope pilos.	When the hairs have grown and become even, then place the head of the patient in your lap; next, mark with a hot iron the eyelid of his eyes, marking a sign that is like the shape of a bay leaf, beginning near the hairs.
Deinde pone cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum.	Then place a cotton pad soaked in egg white or gum arabic on the eye.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then heat the cautery whose form is as follows.
Deinde cauteriza super figuram, quam signasti paulatim in uicibus multis, donec comburatur superficies cutis, quae est sicut figura folii myrti, totam apparentem proprie.	Then cauterize over the figure that you marked gradually in many places until the surface of the skin is burned like the shape of a bay leaf completely.
Et signum sanitatis operis tui est: ut si uideas Palpebram oculi iam contrahi, et pilos eleuari apud puncturam oculi.	And the sign that your operation is successful is if you see the eyelid of the eye already contracting and the hairs raised at the point of cauterization.
Eleua ergo manum tuam tunc: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Therefore, lift up your hand then: and let him go for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur eschara.	Then place upon him a piece of cotton with butter until the eschar is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then dress it with ointment until it heals.
Quod si redeat aliquod ex pilis post horam, et mollificetur palpebra: tunc itera Cauterium super illum locum, sicut fecisti in primis.	But if the hairs return after an hour and the eyelid softens, then cauterize that spot again as you did at first.
Si autem pili sunt in inferiori: tunc cauteriza ipsam, donec eleuetur ad locum suum naturalem: et aequetur ut non pungant pili oculum.	But if the hairs are on the lower side, then cauterize them until they raise to their natural place and become even so that they do not prick the eye.
¶ De modo cauterizandi cum medicina comburente in eodem casu.	Regarding the method of cauterizing with a burning medicine in this same case.
Caput XVIII.	Chapter 18
Est ut praecipias infirmo, ut dimittat pilos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	It is that you should instruct the sick person to let the hairs grow until they lengthen and become even.
Fac ex charta de panno formam folii myrti.	Make from paper on cloth the shape of laurel leaf.
Deinde accipe ex sapone cognito, et ex calce non imbibita ex unoquoque pondus uncia I aut quasi illud: deinde tere ea simul contritione bona, et fac illud cum festinatione, ut non infrigidetur.	Then take from known soap and unslaked lime one ounce each or approximately that amount. Then grind them together well and make it quickly so that it does not cool down.
Deinde ex pande ex eo super chartam quam fecisti sicut formam folii myrti, et pone ipsum super palpebram oculi unius, aut duorum.	Then take from it and spread it over the paper you made in the shape of laurel leaf and place it on the eyelid of one or two eyes.
Et pone sub oculo cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: et caput infirmi sit in sinu tuo.	And place under the eye cotton soaked in egg white, and let the patient's head rest in your lap.
Et pone digitum tuum indicem super medicinam, et preme ipsum parumper.	And put your index finger on top of the medicine and press it gently for a moment.
Et tu moueas ipsum quotiens sentit infirmus mordicationem medicinae: quoniam inuenit eius mordicatio sicut ignis.	And you should move it whenever the patient feels the bite of the medicine, for its bite is like fire.
Dum ergo perseuerat hoc quod ipse inuenit mordicatio, tunc dimitte medicinam, et moue ipsam cum digito tuo.	While that biting sensation persists, then leave the medicine and remove it with your finger.
Cum ergo quiescit mordicatio, tunc remoue medicinam, et ablue oculum cum aqua.	When the biting sensation has ceased, then remove the medicine and wash the eye with water.
Et considera tunc, si uides palpebram eleuari, sicut eleuatur apud contractionem cum igne, aut cum incisione, est bene: et si non, tunc itera super ipsam ex medicina super locum, in quo non imprimit medicina, et non denigrat, donec aequetur operatio tua, et contrahatur oculus.	And then observe whether you see the eyelid raise as it does when contracted with fire or cut, if not, then apply more of the medicine on the spot where it did not mark and darken until your operation is equal and the eye contracts.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur cutis adustionis.	Then place over it cotton with butter until the burnt skin disappears.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento diaphinicon, aut alio, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with a diaphoretic ointment or another one until it heals.
Et necesse est tibi apud operationem, ut custodias ultima custodia, ne in oculum cadat aliquid ex medicina.	And you must be careful during the operation to observe the last precaution, lest any medicine fall into the eye.
Quod si mollificatur palpebra post dies, et pugnat ex capillis aliquid in oculo, tunc itera medicinam super illum locum, qui mollificatur ex palpebra proprie, sicut fecisti in primis.	But if the eyelid becomes softened after some days and something from the hairs fights in the eye, then apply the medicine again on that spot which is softened by the eyelid itself, just as you did at first.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then treat it until it heals.
Et haec est forma folii myrti.	And this is the form of the bay leaf
Et scias, quod oculi hominum diuersificantur in magnitudine, et paruitate.	Know that human eyes differ in size and thinness
Ergo secundum illud sit consideratio tua: et non occultatur uia rectitudinis illi, cui est studium de hac arte.	Therefore, according to this, let your consideration be: the path of correctness is not hidden from him who has a zeal for this art.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Fistula lachrymali.	On the method of cauterizing a lachrymal fistula.
Caput XIX.	Chapter 19
Quando curas Fistulam, cum eo quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc, oportet ut cauterizes ipsam secundum hunc modum.	When you treat a fistula as we have said in the divisions of diseases, and your treatment does not help, then you must cauterize it in this way.
Praecipe infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo, et teneat caput eius minister inter manus suas taliter, ut non moueatur, neque agitetur cum capite suo.	Instruct the sick person to place their head on your bosom and hold it firmly between their hands so that it does not move or shake with their head.
Deinde pone Cotum infusum in albugine oui, aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum eius: deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then place cotton soaked in egg white or mallows mucilage on the eye and then apply the cautery, whose shape is as follows.
Sit concauum, sicut forma cannae pennae uulturis ab extremitate una, cum qua fit Cauterium: et si uis sit penetrans usque ad extremitatem aliam, et si uis sit sursum sic tenta.	It should be concave like the shape of a feather quill from one end to the other, with which the cautery is made. If you want it to penetrate up to the other end or if you want it curved upwards, make it so.
Verumtamen hoc concauum est melius ad opus tuum.	But this concave shape is better for your use.
Deinde exprime fistulam, si est aperta, et extrahe ex ea saniem, et exicca ipsam: et si non est aperta, tunc aperi eam, et extrahe pus eius.	Then express the fistula if it is open and remove its pus and dry it out, and if it is not open, then open it and remove its pus.
Deinde pone tunc super eam Cauterium, quod fit ignitum ualde.	Then place upon it a cautery that has been heated very hot.
Et tene cum eo manum tuam parumper apud Cauterium ab oculo, ad partem nasi, ut non erret manus tua, aut inquietetur infirmus: et ponas Cauterium in adipe oculi, et corrumpas ipsum.	And hold your hand near the cautery, by the eye towards the nose, so that your hand does not slip or disturb the patient, and place the cautery on the fat of the eye and burn it.
Si ergo peruenis in principio Cauterii tui usque ad os, erit bene.	If you reach with your cautery from its beginning up to the bone, it will be well done.
Et si non: tunc itera Cauterium semel, aut bis, si indiges illo: et dimitte illud tribus diebus.	And if not [done], then repeat the cautery once or twice more if needed, and leave it for three days.
Deinde pone Cotum cum butyro, et cura ipsum cum unguento exiccatiuo, donec sanetur.	Then put a cotton pad with butter on it, and dress it with a drying ointment until it heals.
Quod si praeterierint ei quadraginta dies, et non sanatur: tunc pone super ipsum medicinam acutam corrosiuam, donec detegatur os: et rade ipsum secundum quod uenit in capitulo suo.	But if after forty days it does not heal, then put on it a sharp corrosive medication until the bone appears, and shave it according to what is described in its chapter.
Et est modus alius Cauterii fistulae, quem quidam primi dixerunt.	And there is another method of cautery for a fistula which some have spoken about first.
Intende ad locum fistulae, et finde ipsum: deinde pone in ipsam fissuram camahan subtile, id est, Cannulam subtilem, cuius forma haec est.	Pay attention to the location of the fistula and find it; then place within its opening a thin hollow tube, whose shape is as follows.
Et funde in ipsum quantitatem drachmae ex plumbo liquefacto, et tene manum tuam cum Canna retentione bona, et non moueatur infirmus omnino, ut non currat, uel perueniat plumbum liquefactum ad oculum eius.	And pour into it a quantity of melted lead equal to one drachma, and hold your hand with the tube firmly, so that the patient does not move at all, lest the melted lead should run into his eye.
Et oportet ut ponas super oculum infirmi cotum infusum in albumine oui, aut in aqua.	And it is necessary to place over the eye of the patient a cotton pad soaked in egg white or water.
Plumbum enim comburit locum fistulae, et sanat ipsam sanatione mirabili.	For the lead will burn the location of the fistula and heal it with remarkable healing.
Quod si sanatur fistula, cum eo quod diximus ex Cauterio, et curatione, est bonum.	But if the fistula heals along with what we have said regarding cautery and treatment, that is good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est administrare foramen nasi, et reducere fistulam ad cursum nasi, secundum quod ueniet in loco suo sibi proprio.	And if not [healed], then it is necessary to perform the operation on the nasal passage and reduce the fistula back into its proper course according to what will be described in its own place.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fissuris Labiorum.	On the method of cautery for lip fissures.
Caput XX.	Chapter 20
Multotiens accidunt in Labio fissurae, quae nominantur Pili, et praecipue in labiis puerorum.	Fissures occur frequently on the lips, which are called "pili," especially on the lips of children.
Cum ergo tu curas has fissuras, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio, tunc igni cauterium paruum cultellare, secundum hanc formam.	When you treat these fissures, and the treatment we mentioned under "division of diseases" is not effective, then take a small pointed cautery knife shaped like this.
Et sit concauitas eius secundum subtilitatem cultelli.	And let its concave be according to the fineness of a scalpel blade.
Deinde pone ipsum ignitum festinanter in ipsis fissuris, donec perueniat cauterium ad profundum fissurarum.	Then place it quickly and heated on the fissures themselves until the cautery reaches the depth of the fissures.
Deinde cura ipsum cum caeroto, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with wax ointment until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fistula Oris.	On the method of cautery for an oral fistula.
Caput XXI.	Chapter 21
Quando accidit apostema in radice gingiuae, aut in palato, aut in radicibus dentium: deinde facit pus, et rumpitur: postea antiquatur, et currit pus, et fit fistula: deinde curas ipsam, et non confert in ea curatio, tunc oportet ut ignias cauterium secundum quantitatem, quod capiat in fistula.	When an abscess occurs at the root of the gum, or on the palate, or at the roots of the teeth, and then it becomes inflamed and bursts open, after which it hardens and pus runs out, forming a fistula: if you treat it but the treatment is ineffective, then you must heat a cautery according to its size so that it fits into the fistula.
Deinde intromitte ipsum ignitum in foramine fistulae, et tene manum tuam, donec perueniat ferrum ignitum ad profundum eius, et ultimum eius: fac illud semel, aut duabus uicibus.	Then insert it heated into the opening of the fistula, and keep your hand steady until the heated iron reaches the depth and end of it: do this once or twice.
Deinde cura ipsum post illud, cum eo quod diximus de curatione usquequo curetur.	Then treat it afterwards with what we mentioned about treatment until it is healed.
Si ergo abscinditur sanies, et sanatur, erit bonum.	If the pus is cut off and it heals, that will be good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est detegere locum, et auferre os corrupum secundum quod ueniet in capite suo.	But if not, then it is necessary to expose the spot and remove the rotted bone according to how it appears at its head.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Gingiuis, et Dentibus mollificatis.	On the method of cautery for softened gums and teeth.
Caput XXII.	Chapter 22
Quando mollificatur gingiua propter humiditates, et mouentur dentes, et curas eam cum medicinis, et non confert: tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	When the gum becomes softened due to moisture, and the teeth are loose, and you treat it with medicines but they have no effect, then place the patient's head on your lap.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma ueniet post haec, ita ut ponas Cannulam super dentem: et intromitte in ea Cauterium ignitum festinanter: et tene manum tuam parumper, donec sentiat infirmus calorem ignis iam peruenisse ad radicem dentis.	Then take a cautery with the shape that will come later, so that you place a cannula over the tooth, and insert the heated cautery into it quickly: keep your hand steady for a moment until the patient feels the heat of the fire having reached the root of the tooth.
Et eleua manum tuam: deinde itera Cauterium aliquotiens, secundum quod uis.	Then remove your hand, then repeat the cautery several times according to what you desire.
Deinde impleat infirmus os suum aqua salis, et teneat ipsam hora una: et exspuat ipsam.	Then let the patient fill their mouth with salt water and hold it for one hour, then spit it out.
Dens enim motus firmatur, et gingiua mollificata stringitur, et siccatur humiditas corrupta.	For the tooth is strengthened and the gum softened and tightened, and the corrupt moisture is dried out.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Dentium.	Chapter: On the method of cauterizing for toothache
Caput XXIII.	Chapter 23
Quando dolor dentis est propter frigiditatem, aut in ipso est frigus, aut uermis, et non confert curatio cum medicinis: tunc Cauterium in ipso est secundum duos modos: aut Cauterium cum butyro: aut cauterium cum igne.	When toothache is due to coldness, or there is chill within it, or a worm, and medication does not help, then cautery is applied in one of two ways: either with butter, or with fire.
Cauterium autem eius cum butyro est, ut accipias butyrum uaccinum, et bullias ipsum in cochleari ferreo, aut in uenera.	The cautery with butter is made by taking fresh butter and rolling it into balls on an iron spoon or a bronze vessel.
Deinde accipe cotum, et inuolue ipsum super extremitatem tentae.	Then take a thread of cotton and wrap it around the tip of the heated cautery.
Deinde submerge ipsum in butyro bullito: et pone ipsum super dentem dolorosum festinanter, et tene ipsum donec infrigidet: deinde itera ipsum aliquotiens, donec perueniat uirtus ignis ad radicem dentis.	Then immerse the tip of the cautery in melted butter and quickly place it on the painful tooth, holding it until it cools; then repeat this several times until the heat reaches the root of the tooth.
Et si uis, submerge lanam, aut cotum in butyro frigido, et pone ipsum super dentem dolentem: et pone super ipsum ferrum ignitum, donec perueniat ignis ad profundum concauitatis dentis.	And if you wish, immerse wool or cotton in cold butter and place it on the painful tooth; then apply a heated iron to it until the fire reaches the depth of the cavity of the tooth.
Cauterizatio autem eius cum igne est, ut intendas ad cannulam aeris, aut cannulam ferri.	Cautery with fire is done by inserting a red-hot iron probe through an ear cannula or an iron cannula
Et sit in corpore eius quiddam grossitudinis, ut non perueniat acuitas ignis ad os infirmi.	And let there be something thick inside it so that the sharpness of the heat does not reach the patient's mouth.
Deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma ueniet: et pone ipsum super illum dentem: et tene manum tuam, donec infrigidetur Cauterium.	Then take a cautery of the shape that will come later and place it on the tooth; hold your hand steady until the cautery cools.
Fac illud aliquotiens, nam dolor remouebitur, aut in illo eodem die, aut die alio.	Do this several times, for the pain will be removed either on that same day or on another day.
Et oportet in impressione illius Cauterii, ut impleat infirmus os suum buyro bono, et teneat ipsum hora una: deinde exspuat ipsum.	It is necessary, when applying the cautery, for the patient to fill his mouth with good beeswax and hold it there for an hour; then he should spit it out.
Et haec est forma Cauterii.	And this is the shape of the cautery.
Cauteriza cum quacumque extremitate uis secundum quod est possibile: et haec est forma Cannulae.	Cauterize with whichever end you wish, insofar as it is possible; and this is the form of the cannula.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Strophulis.	On the method of cauterizing varicose veins.
Caput XXIIII.	Chapter 24
Quando Strophulae sunt a phlegmate, et ab humiditatibus frigidis, et non sunt obedientes digestioni per mecicinas, et uis digestionem earum uelociter: tunc igni Cauterium concauum, cuius forma est haec.	When varicose veins are filled with phlegm and cold moisture, and do not respond to treatment with medicines, and require rapid digestion, then use a hollow cautery heated with fire, whose shape is as follows.
Habens duas extremitates apertas, ut egrediatur fumus apud Cauterium ab extremitate altera: et pone ipsum ignitum super ipsum apostema semel, et secundo, si indiges illo, donec perueniat ad profundum apostematis.	Having two open ends so that smoke may exit from the cautery at one end, and place it heated on the varicose vein once, or twice if you desire, until it reaches to the depth of the varicose veins.
Quod si apostema est paruum: tunc pone Cauterium secundum quantitatem apostematis.	But if the varicose vein is small, then place the cautery according to its size.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super ipsum cotum infusum in butyro, donec remoueatur quod combussit ignis.	Then leave it for three days, and apply a poultice soaked in butter until what was burned by the fire is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento dentis, donec sanetur forma cannulae.	Then treat it with toothpaste ointment until it heals into the shape of a cannula.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in raucedine uocis, et constrictione anhelitus.	On the method of cauterizing for hoarseness of voice and shortness of breath.
Caput XXV.	Chapter 25
Quando uincunt humiditates super cannale pulmonis, et praecipue quando illud est cum frigiditate complexionis, tunc oportet ut euacuetur infirmus in primis cum medicinis solutiuis.	When excess moisture accumulates on the pulmonary canal, especially when it is accompanied by coldness of temperament, then it is necessary for the patient to be evacuated first with soluble medicines.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum in nocrati apud radicem gutturis in loce depresso: et caue, ne peruenias cum Cauterio ad guttur, neque in cute, nisi quiddam eius.	Then cauterize it at night at the root of the throat in a depressed place, and beware not to come near the throat with the cautery, nor on the skin, except for a little of it.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cauterio alio apud iuncturam colli in ultimo spondili eius ultimando: et sit Cauterium clauile secundum modum, qui praecessit.	Then cauterize it with another cautery at the junction of the neck on the last vertebra of the cervical spine; and let the cautery be like a nail according to the preceding manner.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then treat it together with what preceded until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aegritudinibus Pulmonis, et Tussi.	On the method of cauterizing in cases of lung disease and cough.
Caput XXVI.	Chapter 26
Quando Tussis et aegritudo Pulmonis sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, et infirmus non habet febrem, neque phthisim, et aegritudo antiqua: tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis supra furculam in locis depressis, lenibus, uacuis.	When coughing and lung disease are due to cold moist humors, and the patient does not have a fever or phthisis, nor long-standing illness: then cauterize it with two cauteries above the fork in depressed, soft, empty places.
Et cauterio alio in medio pectoris inter duas mammillas: et sit cauterium cannulae secundum formam quae praecessit.	And with another cautery in the middle of the chest between the two breasts; and let the cautery be like a cannula according to the form that preceded.
Et si uis sit cauterizatio tua punctando cum cauterio, quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma praecessit in punctatione doloris aurium: et sint puncta ex triginta punctis usque quasi ad alia.	And if you wish the cautery to be by pricking with a cautery called "Punctum," whose form preceded in the pricking of ear pain, then let there be punctures from thirty up to almost as many more.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then treat it together with what preceded until it is healed.
Et iam sit cauterium habens tres ramos: secundum hanc formam.	And now let the cautery have three branches: according to this form.
Quare alleuiatur cum eo cauterizatio, quando tu facis cum eo uice una tria Cauteria.	Therefore, alleviate with it by cauterizing thrice in one session.
