¶ De modo cauterizandi in Titillico, in dislocatione Humeri.	On the method of cauterizing in cases of hiccup, in dislocation of the arm.
Caput XXVII.	Chapter 27
Quando dislocatur caput adiutorii caussa humiditatum, et nonfigitur in hora reditus sui a dislocatione sua, donec sit illud ei consuetudo reditionis, deinde dislocatur a paruo motu, qui accidit sicut nos iam testificauimus illud, tunc oportet ut reducas dislocationem in primis.	When the head of the arm is dislocated due to moist humors and does not return to its proper place within an hour after being reduced, until it becomes accustomed to returning, then if it is subsequently dislocated by a slight movement, as we have already testified to this happening, then you must first reduce the dislocation.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, aut super latus sanum.	Then let the patient be placed on their back or on their sound side.
Deinde eleua cutim, quae est in interiori Titillici ad superiora cum digitis manus tuae sinistrae: et si iunctura dislocatur ad interiora.	Then elevate the skin that is at the inner part of the armpit towards the top with your left hand's fingers; and if the joint is dislocated towards the inside.
Deinde igni Cauterium habens duo uerua.	Then take a cautery having two branches heated in fire.
Cuius forma est haec.	Whose form is as follows.
Deinde cauteriza cutim, donec penetret eam usque ad latus aliud, et ueniet figura cauterizationis cum quatuor cauteriis.	Then cauterize the skin until it pierces through to the other side, and the figure of cauterization will appear with four cauteries.
Et quandoque fit cauterizatio cum cauterio habente tria uerua, quare fit figura cauterizationis tunc sex cauteriorum: et sunt uerua secundum subtilitatem tentae.	And sometimes cauterization is done with a cautery having three openings, in which case the figure of cauterization will then be that of six cauteries: and there are openings according to the fineness of the pierced [skin].
Et haec est forma cauterii habentis tria uerua.	And this is the form of a cautery having three openings.
Et quandoque additur super hunc modum unum, quare sunt cauteria octo.	And sometimes one more is added to this manner, making eight cauteries in total.
Deinde pone super cauterium porros contritos cum sale.	Then place crushed garlic mixed with salt on the cautery.
Deinde fac adhaerere infirmum tranquillitati, ut non moueatur membrum tempore aliquo, donec confortetur.	Then ensure that the patient remains still so that the limb is not moved during any part of the procedure until it has healed.
Et si dislocatio est ad superiora, et raro fit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super humerum cauterio clauili, aut cauteriis multis punctando.	And if the dislocation is towards the upper parts (which rarely happens), then cauterize it above the humerus with a awl cautery or by making many punctures with cauteries.
Nam iunctura firmatur, et remouetur humiditas: et sanatur infirmus.	For the union becomes strong and moisture is removed, and the patient is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Stomachum.	Chapter on the Method of Cauterizing the Stomach.
Caput XXVIII.	Chapter 28.
Quando accidunt in Stomacho frigus et humiditates multae, donec extrahant ipsum a complexione sua, et multiplicentur catarri ad ipsum, et assiduas modos curationis, et non confert: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, et extendat crura sua, et manus suas.	When coldness and much moisture occur in the stomach to such an extent that they draw it away from its usual condition, and thick mucus accumulates there, and despite repeated treatments it does not improve: then the patient should be made to lie on their back and extend their legs and arms.
Deinde cauteriza cum tribus cauteriis, cauterio sub cochleari pectoris quantitate digiti unius cum cauterio clauili, et duobus cauteriis inferius a duobus lateribus cauterii unius, donec ueniat figura cauteriorum triangulata.	Then cauterize with three cauteries: one under the breastbone at the size of a finger with an awl cautery, and two below it on either side of the single cautery until the figure of the cauteries forms a triangle.
Et elonga inter utraque ut non coniungantur, quando facient pus.	And space them out so that they do not touch each other, lest they produce pus.
Et sit profunditas cauterii quantitas duarum tertiarum grossitudinis cutis.	Let the depth of the cautery be equal to two-thirds the thickness of the skin.
Et sit figura cauteriorum secundum hanc formam sine additione: et si uis cauteriza cauterio magno in medio stomachi secundum hanc formam: et sit cauterium quo fit hoc cauterium unum secundum figuram circuli secundum hanc formam.	And let the figure of the cauteries be according to this form without addition: and if you wish, cauterize with a large cautery in the middle of the stomach according to this form; and let the cautery used for this cautery be one according to the form of a circle as follows.
Et cauterizatur stomachus punctando ei qui terretur ab hoc cauterio: et est, ut signes super stomachum punctum secundum quantitatem, quam uis cum encaustro: deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio puncti: deinde cura ipsum cum curatione, quae praecessit donec sanetur.	And the stomach is cauterized by pricking it with this cautery for one who suffers from it. And it should be as follows: firstly mark a point on the stomach according to the size that you wish to cauterize with the hot iron; then cauterize it with the cautery of the point; afterwards treat it with the treatment which preceded until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Epar frigidum.	On the method of cauterizing the ear
Caput XXIX.	Chapter 29
Quando accidit in Epate dolor ex frigiditate et humiditate, aut ex uentositate grossa, donec egrediatur a complexione sua naturali egressione superflua, et curatur infirmus, cum eo quod diximus, et non proficit in illo: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam, et signes cum encaustro tria cauteria secundum hanc figuram, et hanc quantitatem eandem super Epar inferius ab hypocundriis, ubi peruenit cubitus hominis: et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium secundum grossitudinem digiti: et sit cauterium secundum longitudinem corporis rectum: et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio multum.	When pain occurs in the liver due to coldness and moisture or coarse wind, until it can naturally eliminate excessiveness through evacuation, and the patient is treated with what we have mentioned but does not improve, then the patient should be made to lie on their back and mark three cauteries according to this figure and this size on the lower ear below the hypocondriae where the elbow reaches; let the space between each cautery be the thickness of a finger, and let the cautery be straight along the length of the body, and do not press your hand too much with the cautery.
Et sit quantitas eius quod aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, quantitas medietatis eius non additum: et sit infirmus stans super pedes suos.	And let the amount that is burned be half the thickness of the skin without addition; and let the patient stand on their feet.
Si autem non est stans, tunc sit iacens, qui iam extendit crura sua, et eleuauit brachia sua.	But if he cannot stand, then let him lie down with his legs extended and his arms raised up.
Haec est forma cauterii.	This is the form of the cautery.
Et tibi quidem possibile est, ut cauterizes ista cauteria cum cauterio cultellari, quando tecum est subtilitas et prudentia in arte.	And it is indeed possible for you to cauterize these cauteries with a scalpel cautery when you have skill and prudence in the art.
Et custodi te, ut non ultime procedas in cauterizatione, et aduratur spissitudo cutis totius, quare aduratur corpus totum, et perueniat ad intestina: quoniam cutis illic est subtilis, scias ergo illud.	And guard yourself so that you do not proceed too far in cauterization and burn the entire thickness of the skin, for then the whole body will be burned and it will reach the entrails; since the skin there is thin, know this.
¶ De modo cauterizandi apostemata Epatis.	On the method of cauterizing boils on the liver.
Caput XXX.	Chapter 30.
Quando accidit exitura, et uis scire, si illud apostema est in carne Epatis, aut in tunica eius: tunc si est in carne Epatis, inuadit infirmum dolor, et grauitas absque acuitate: et si est in tunica Epatis, cum dolore est acuitas uehemens: et uides iam, quia fatigauit medicos eius curatio.	When a boil appears and you want to know whether it is in the liver tissue or in its membrane: then, if it is in the liver tissue, pain afflicts the sick person without sharpness; but if it is in the liver's membrane, there is sharp pain. And now you see that treating it has exhausted its doctors.
Oportet ergo ut resupinet infirmus super ceruicem suam.	Therefore, the patient must lie on their back with their head raised.
Deinde figura locum apostematis cum encaustro: deinde ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	Then outline the location of the boil with a hot iron branding tool that resembles a ray of sunlight.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its shape
Et cauteriza cum eo cauterium unum, donec comburatur cutis tota, et perueniat ad siphac, donec egrediatur sanies tota: deinde cura ipsum curatione exiturarum, donec sanetur.	And cauterize with it once until the entire skin is burned and it reaches the boil's head until all pus comes out; then treat it according to the method for treating boils until it heals.
Et non oportet ut hac cauterii specie utatur, nisi cuius studium in arte medicinae prolongatur: et per cuius manus concurrunt aegritudines istae cum experimento aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super huiusmodi operationem.	And it is not proper to use this cautery method unless one has prolonged study in the art of medicine, and whose hands have performed such operations many times with success. Then indeed should they dare attempt such an operation.
At uero dimittere ipsam, apud me est melius.	But in my opinion it is better to leave it alone.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Pleuresi.	On the method of cauterizing pleurisy.
Caput XXXI.	Chapter 31
Dixerunt antiqui, cauterium cum radicibus aristolochiae ad Pleuresim frigidam secundum hunc modum.	The ancients said that for cold pleurisy, use a cautery with the roots of birthwort (Aristolochia) according to this method.
Et est, ut recipias ex radicibus aristolochiae siccae longae, radicem unam longiorem, quae ex ea inuenitur, et sit sicut grossitudo digiti.	And it is as follows: take one long root of dry birthwort that has the thickness of a finger.
Deinde submerge eam in oleo: et accende ipsam in igne.	Then immerse it in oil and ignite it in fire.
Deinde cauteriza cauterio uno in eo quod est inter continuationem furculae cum collo, et duobus cauteriis paruis sub guidezi parum decliuibus ad partem, quae est sub barba.	Then cauterize once with it between the continuation of the fork and the neck, and twice with small cauteries slightly slanted towards the side that is under the beard.
Et duobus cauteriis etiam in eo, quod est inter costam quintam et sextam decliuibus ad posteriora parumper: et cauterio alio in medio pectoris, et alio supra stomachum.	And twice more with cauteries slightly slanted towards the back between the fifth and sixth ribs; and once with another cautery in the middle of the chest, and once above the stomach.
Et tribus cauteriis a posterioribus: uno in eo quod est inter duas spatulas: et duobus cauteriis a duobus lateribus pectoris, inferius cauterio quod est inter duas spatulas.	And three cauteries from behind: one between the two shoulder blades; and two cauteries on both sides of the chest, with the lower cautery being between the two shoulder blades.
Et non oportet ut comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit in manifesto cutis odorando.	And do not press your hand with the cautery, but let it be plainly seen and smelled on the skin.
Et iam dixerunt quidam antiqui, quod ex hominibus sunt qui utuntur cauterio ex ferro simili radio: et igniunt, et intus mittunt ipsum in eo quod est inter costas, donec perueniatur cum eo ad ipsum apostema, et egrediatur sanies: sicut diximus in apostemate Epatis.	And some of the ancients have said that there are men who use a cautery made of iron like a ray, and ignite it and insert it between the ribs until it reaches the abscess itself, and pus exits; as we have described in the case of liver abscesses.
Sed in hac perforatione cum cauterio est ex timore, quod aut moritur infirmus statim, aut accidit in loco fistula, cui non est sanatio.	But in this procedure with the cautery there is a risk that either the patient will die immediately or a fistula will occur which will not heal.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Splenem Caput XXXII.	Chapter 32: The method of cauterizing the spleen.
Quando tu curas aegritudinem splenis, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua, tunc cauterium in ea est secundum tres modos, qui omnes sunt recti.	When you treat spleen inflammation as mentioned earlier in the section on divisions of diseases, and your treatment does not succeed, then there are three methods of using a cautery, all of which are correct.
Quorum unus est, ut facias tria cauteria, aut quatuor lineando secundum longitudinem splenis secundum figuram cauteriorum Epatis, quorum praecessit figura.	One method is to make three or four cauteries along the length of the spleen according to the shape of the liver cauteries, as shown in the figure.
Et sit inter omne cauterium quantitas grossitudinis digiti, aut plus parum.	And let each cautery be about the thickness of a finger, or slightly more.
Et sit modus cauterii, quem diximus in cauterio epatis aequaliter.	And the method of cautery should be as we have described for cauterizing the liver, equally.
Et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio: et sit infirmus resupinus super dorsum suum.	And do not press your hand with the cautery; and let the patient lie on their back with their face up.
Et modus alius de cauterizatione est: ut ignias cauterium habens duo uerua, quod diximus in capitulo dislocationis humeri: et eleua cutem, quae est in directo splenis, ubi peruenit cubitus infirmi sinister: et sit eleuatio tua qua eleuas cutem secundum latitudinem corporis, ut cadant cauteria secundum longitudinem corporis.	And another method of cautery is to heat a cautery with two edges as described in the chapter on dislocation of the shoulder, lift the skin that is directly over the spleen where the left elbow reaches, and lift it as much as you would raise your hand along the length of the body so that the cauteries fall along the length of the body.
Deinde intromitte duo uerua ignita ualde, donec cum eis penetres cutem a parte altera: deinde extrahe cauterium: fiunt ergo cauteria quatuor.	Then insert the two red-hot edges until you pierce through to the other side of the skin. Then remove the cautery. Thus four holes are made.
Et si uis cauteriza cum cauterio alio habente tria uerua.	And if you wish, cauterize with a cautery having three edges.
Deinde cura cauterium postquam dimittis ipsum emittere pus diebus multis: est enim magis conferens quamque reliqua quae praecesserunt ex curatione.	Then care for the cautery after removing it, allowing it to discharge pus for many days, for this is more beneficial than any previous treatment.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Hydropisi.	On the method of cauterizing hydrops
Caput XXXIII.	Chapter 33
Cauterium non cadit in Hydropisi, nisi ascliti proprie.	A cautery should not be used on hydropic patients unless they are very emaciated.
Quando tu curas Hydropicum cum modis curationis, quos diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, et cauterio uno super stomachum, et cauterio alio super epar, et cauterio super splenem, et cauteriis duobus post dorsum inter spondiles, et uno in directo pectoris, et alio in directo stomachi: et sit quantitas profunditatis cauterii propinqua spissitudini cutis.	When you treat a hydroptic patient with the methods of treatment that we have described previously and the treatment does not help, then it is necessary to cauterize them as follows: four cauteries around the navel, one on the stomach, another on the liver, one on the spleen, two behind the back between the shoulder blades, one on the chest, and another on the stomach. The depth of the cautery should be close to the thickness of the skin.
Deinde dimitte cauterium apertum, ut emittat pus tempore longo.	Then leave the cautery in place so that it may discharge pus over a long period of time.
Et non euacues infirmum a curatione post cauterium cum eo: quod oportet ut aggregentur ei duae intentiones: et festinabit ad ipsum sanatio cum auxilio Dei.	Do not remove the patient from treatment immediately after cautery, but let them remain under care for two intentions. Then healing will come quickly with God's help.
Forma uero cauterii cum quo cauterizatur uenter, sit clauilis: secundum quod praecessit forma eius: et illius cum quo cauterizatur dorsum, sit oliuaris secundum quod praecessit eius forma.	The shape of the cautery used for cauterizing the abdomen should be like a nail, according to its previous form. And the shape of the cautery used for cauterizing the back should be olive-shaped, according to its previous form.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Pedes, et Crura.	On the method of cauterizing feet and legs
Caput XXXIIII.	Chapter 34
Quando apostemantur in Hydropico, et replentur aqua citrina: oportet ut cauterizes super dorsum Pedis in nocrati, quae est inter auricularem et anularem: et eleua manum tuam cum cauterio, et non torqueas ipsum: deinde eleua manum tuam: et non iteres ipsum omnino.	When there are swellings in the feet of a hydroptic patient and they fill with yellow water, it is necessary to cauterize on top of the instep of the foot, at the point between the heel bone and ankle bone. Then lift your hand with the cautery without turning it, then lift your hand again without repeating it at all.
Resudet enim aqua citrina, et sit cauterium secundum hanc formam.	Let yellow water be drawn out, and use a cautery of this shape:
Deinde fac super duo crura duo cauteria in omni crure, et fiat cauterium cum extremitate cultellari cauterii: et fiat cauterium secundum longitudinem cruris, unum sub genu, et alterum inferius eo, circiter medium cruris: et super omnem coxam cauteria duo: et dimitte cauterium apertum absque curatione tempore longo: ut resudet ex eo aliquod aquae: deinde cura ipsum cum reliquis quae diximus.	Then make two cauteries on each leg, one above the knee and another below it near the middle of the thigh. Also make two cauteries on the hip joint. Leave the cautery open without treatment for a long time so that some water may be drawn out from it, then treat it with the rest as mentioned earlier.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in solutione Ventris.	On the method of cauterizing in the swelling of the abdomen
Caput XXXV.	Chapter 35
Quando est solutio uentris ex frigore et humiditatibus, donec debilitet uirtutes retentiuam et digestiuam, quae sunt in stomacho et intestinis: et curatur illud cum modis curationis, et non sanatur: et uides infirmum tolerantem cauterium exuberantis uirtutis, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio magno super stomachum suum, secundum quod praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi cum cauterio circuli, et quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici subtilibus, cum cauterio clauili subtili: et cauterio super alcatin supra alhosos magno, aut duobus cauteriis.	When the swelling of the abdomen is due to cold and dampness that weakens the powers of retention and digestion in the stomach and intestines, treat it with various treatments but without success. If you see a patient who tolerates cauterization despite having excessive vital heat, then cauterize the area above their stomach using a large circular cautery according to the method previously described for cauterizing the stomach. Also apply four subtle cauteries around the navel using a fine awl-shaped cautery and one or two large cauteries on the flanks.
Et si uides humiditates exuberantes, et infirmum tolerantem illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio super pectinem, et cauterio super omne ilium: et fortasse addes duo cauteria parua super stomachum prope magnum.	And if you see excessive dampness in the patient and they tolerate it well, then cauterize them on the pubic region and both hips with a cautery. Also consider adding two small cauteries near the center of the chest.
Est enim curatio proficiens, cuius iuuamentum non errat.	For this treatment is beneficial, its aid does not fail.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Hemorroidas.	On the method of cauterizing haemorrhoids
Caput XXXVI.	Chapter 36
Quando in ano sunt Hemorroides antiquae multae, aut una, et sunt ex humoribus grossis, frigidis, aut humiditatibus corruptis, et curantur cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: tunc cauteriza tribus cauteriis super inferiorem spondilem dorsi sub almeidati parumper triangulatim, et cauterio sub umbilico quasi duobus digitis.	When there are many old haemorrhoids or one large one in the anus that are caused by thick cold humors or corrupted dampness and have not improved with the treatments previously mentioned, then cauterize the lower part of the back near the buttocks triangularly using three cauteries and also cauterize below the navel about two finger widths away.
Et si cogitas, quod stomachus eius infrigidatus sit, et cibus eius non digeratur, et faciem eius uides apostemari, tunc cauteriza eum super stomachum cauterio magno, secundum quod praecessit: et cauterio super Epar eius, et alio super Splenem ipsius, cum cauterio clauili: et dimitte cauterium apertum tempore aliquo: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	And if you think that his stomach is chilled and his food is not being digested, and you see swelling on his face, then cauterize him on the stomach with a large cautery as previously described, and also cauterize over his liver and spleen with a small cautery like a claw. Leave one cautery open for some time, then treat him until he is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi althelul post abscisionem eorum.	On the method of cauterizing the anus after their removal.
Caput XXXVII.	Chapter 37
Quando tu abscindis althelul, tunc ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	When you cut off the hemorrhoids, then heat the cautery that resembles a branding iron.
Deinde intromittite ipsum ignitum in ipsum althelul abscisum: et ultima manum tuam, donec perueniat cauterium ad orificium uenae, ex qua currit sanguis: fac illud semel, aut bis.	Then insert the heated cautery into the cut hemorrhoid and hold your hand firmly until the cautery reaches the opening of the vein from which blood is flowing. Do this once or twice.
Si ergo althelul fuerint multa, tunc cauteriza unumquodque cauterio secundum quod narrauimus.	If there are many hemorrhoids, then cauterize each one with a cautery as we have described.
Deinde cura ea, cum eo quod confert eis ex unguentis, donec sanentur.	Then treat them with suitable ointments until they heal.
Et si cauterizas eum cauterio magno super alcatin, est magis ultimum in iuuamento.	And if you cauterize him with a large cautery on the anus, it is more likely to result in healing.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Fistulam in ano.	On the method of cauterizing a fistula in the anus.
Caput XXXVIII.	When a fistula has been made in the anus, first make sure that its opening communicates directly with the outside through a passage and not through the rectum. Then insert a probe into the fistula until it reaches the rectum or its opening.
Quando non obedit infirmus sectioni et operi quod narrauimus in loco suo, et terretur ab illo, fortasse sanatur cum cauterio.	If the patient does not submit to the incision and operation described earlier and is afraid of it, perhaps he can be healed with a cautery.
Cum ergo accidit alicui Fistula, et antiquatur, currit pus ex ea, et humiditates corruptae.	When a fistula occurs in someone's anus and becomes chronic, pus flows from it along with corrupted humors.
Dignius ergo quod oportet est, ut probes eam cum tenta subtili.	Therefore, it is advisable to examine the fistula using a thin probe.
Deinde cognosce quantitatem profunditatis eius cum tenta.	Next, determine the depth of its opening with a probe.
Deinde ignias cauterium, quod est simile radio.	Then take an iron cautery similar to a branding iron.
Deinde intromit te ipsum ignitum in ipsam Fistulam et quantitatem in qua intrauit clauus.	Then insert the heated cautery into the fistula itself until the key on its handle clicks.
Et itera super eam cauterium, donec comburantur illa omnia corpora corrupta, semel, aut bis, aut ter, secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And continue applying the cautery to it until all corrupted tissues are burned away, once or twice or thrice according to your needs.
Et custodi te ab adustione nerui, si est illic, aut uenae magnae: aut si Fistula uadit ad corpus uesicae, aut ad corpus intestini, tunc custodi te ab istis locis omnibus.	And beware of burning the nerve or a large vein if it is present there; or if the fistula leads to the bladder or the intestines, then be especially careful in those areas.
Et non facias illud, nisi quando fistula est in loco carnoso: et cogitas, quia non est penetrans.	And do not perform this procedure unless the fistula is located in a fleshy area; and consider that it does not pierce through to another part of the body.
Deinde cura locum usquequo sanetur.	Then care for the site until it heals.
Si autem sigillatur locus, et abscinduntur ab eo materiae, et remanet sic tempore longo: tunc scias, quia iam sanatus est integre.	But if the opening closes up, and no more matter comes from it, even after a long period of time: then know that it is already completely healed.
Et si non abscindunt ab eo materiae, tunc scias quia est penetrans, aut in profundo eius est os corruptum, aut quasi illud ex illis: quorum rememoratio ueniet in loco suo.	And if matter does not stop coming from it, then know that either it is passing through to another part of the body, or there is a decayed bone at its bottom, or something else of this kind, which will be discussed later.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Renes.	¶ On the method of cauterizing Kidneys.
Caput XXXIX.	Chapter 39
Quando accidit in Renibus dolor ex frigore, aut ex uentositate grossa, et minuitur propter illud coius infirmi, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum super almethenem super ipsos renes, cauterio super omnem renem cum cauterio clauili, cuius praecessit rememoratio.	When pain occurs in the kidneys due to cold or thick wind, and is thereby weakened, then it is necessary to cauterize over the bladder over the kidneys using a cautery with a claw-like tip, on each kidney.
Et fortasse cauterizamus ipsum secundo in ipso almeidatu.	And perhaps we cauterize it again on the same day.
Quare uenient tria lineata.	Therefore, there will be three scorched lines.
Ergo erunt magis ultima in iuuamento.	Therefore, these are more helpful for relief.
¶ De modo cauteritzandi Vesicam.	¶ On the method of cauterizing the Bladder.
Caput XL.	Chapter 40
Quando accidunt in Vesica debilitas, et mollificatio a frigo re et humiditatibus, donec non retineat infirmus urinam, tunc cauteriza ipsum in inferiori parte suminis super Vesicam, ubi incipiunt pili pectinis, et cauterio a dextra suminis, et alio a sinistra illius: et sit longitudo illius cauterizationis lateris secundum quantitatem nodi pollicis: et cauteriza ipsum cauterio inferiori dorsi, aut duobus cauteriis, si indiges illo: et sit secundum quod praecessit cauterium clauile.	When weakness and softening occur in the bladder due to coldness and dampness, so that the patient cannot retain urine, then cauterize it on the lower part of the pubic area over the bladder, where the pubic hair begins, using a cautery from the right side of the pubis and another from the left; let the length of the cauterization be equal to the size of the joint of the thumb. Then cauterize with a lower dorsal cautery or two if necessary, according to what has been previously described for the claw-like cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Matricem.	How to cauterize the womb.
Caput XLI.	Chapter XL
Quando accidunt in Matrice frigus et humiditates, et prohibetur per illud ab impregnatione, et corrumpuntur menstrua eius, et tardatur prouocatio eorum, et accidit ei apud aduentum eorum dolor, tunc oportet ut cauterizetur tribus cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, sicut diximus in cauterizatione uesicae, et cauterio super alcatim inferius dorso, aut duobus cauteriis: et sit cauterium clauile.	When coldness and dampness occur in the womb, preventing conception and corrupting menstruation, delaying its onset, and causing pain upon their arrival, then it should be cauterized with three cauteries around the navel, as previously described for the bladder cautery, and one on the lower back, or two if necessary: let the claw-like cautery be used.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Ancham in dislocatione.	How to cauterize the anus in cases of displacement.
Caput XLII.	Chapter XLII
Quando effunduntur humiditates mucosae ad pixidem Anchae, et fiunt caussa exitus eius a loco suo: et signum illius est, quod prolongatur crus super alterum, quando comparantur adinuicem: et inuenitur locus dislocationis in eo uacuus.	When mucous moisture flows to the anus and causes its displacement from its proper place, and the sign of this is that one leg is elongated over the other when they are brought together, and the location of the displacement is found empty.
Oportet ergo ut cauterizes infirmum super pixidem Anchae ipsius cauterio simili circulo: postquam tu signas cum encaustro in circumitu pixidis, sicut reuoluitur: et ut cadat ipsa pixis in medio circuli.	Therefore, the sick person should be cauterized around the anus with a cautery having a similar circular shape. After you have marked it with a hot iron around the circumference of the anus, let the cautery fall into the middle of the circle.
Et sit cauterium cuius forma praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi.	And let the cautery used be of the same shape as that used for cauterizing the stomach.
Quod si tibi non est praesens hoc cauterium, tunc cauteriza ipsum tribus cauteriis, cum cauterio oliuari magno: et fiat cauterio profunditas secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis totius.	But if this cautery is not present, then cauterize with three cauteries using a large olive-shaped cautery. Make the depth of the cautery according to the thickness of the entire skin.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then treat it until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Sciatica.	How to cauterize sciatica.
Caput XLIII.	Chapter 43.
Quando accidit dolor in pixide anchae, et sunt caussa illius frigus et humiditates: et curatur infirmus cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, et antiquatur illud: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum ab humoribus grossis cum pillulis foetidis, aut cum pillulis artificialibus, et similibus.	When pain occurs in the hip joint and its cause is coldness and dampness, and the treatment mentioned earlier has been applied without effect, and the condition has worsened: then it becomes necessary to dissolve the thick humors with foul-smelling pills or with artificial pills and similar remedies.
Deinde cauteriza eum.	Then cauterize him.
Et modus cauterii in ea est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum medicinis adurentibus, aut cauterium cum igne.	And the method of cauterization is done in two ways: either with a cautery and burning medicines, or with fire alone.
Cauterium cum igne, est secundum multos modos.	A cautery with fire has many methods.
Quorum unus est, ut cauterizes super pixidem anchae ipsius tribus cauteriis triangulatis, secundum hanc formam.	One of which is to cauterize the hip joint itself with three triangular cauteries in this shape:
Et fac eis profunditatem bonam, uel malam.	And make them either deep or superficial.
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium quantitatis grossitudinis digiti: sitque cauterium oliuare.	And let the space between each cautery be the thickness of a finger; and let the cautery be well-oiled.
Quandoque autem fit cauterium in medio super caput anchae ipsius.	Sometimes, however, the cautery is placed on top of the head of the hip joint itself.
Quare sunt quatuor cauteria.	So there are four cauteries.
Et si uis cauteriza cum circulo, cuius praecessit forma in cauterizatione dislocationis anchae, uno: ut sit circulus continens ancham totam.	And if you wish to cauterize with a circle, whose shape preceded in the cautery of hip dislocation, one should make it so that it completely encircles the entire hip.
Et combure spissitudinem cutis totius.	And burn through the thickness of the skin entirely.
Iste est modus cauterii in Sciatica, quando dolor est adhaerens anchae ipsi, et non extenditur usque ad coxam et crus.	This is the method of cautery for sciatica when the pain is attached to the hip joint itself and does not extend as far as the thigh and leg.
Si autem extenditur usque ad coxam et crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis super coxam, super locum ad quem innuit illic infirmus, in quo est dolor, et cauterio tuo super cauillam quatuor digitis ad partem syluestrem parumper: et sit cauterium cultellare.	But if it extends as far as the thigh and leg, then cauterize it with two cauteries on the thigh, at the place indicated by the patient where the pain is felt, and apply your cautery to the groin four fingerbreadths towards the perineum: and let the cautery be shaped like a knife.
Et sit profunditas cauterii secundum profunditatem spissitudinis cutis.	And let the depth of the cautery be according to the thickness of the skin.
Quod si infirmus innuit quod dolor extenditur usque prope digitos pedis, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic ubi innuit cum cauterio puncti, tribus, aut quatuor, aut pluribus, si indiget illo.	But if the patient indicates that the pain extends as far as the toes of the foot, then cauterize him there where he points with one, two, three, or more cauteries according to what is needed.
Et si innuit dolorem esse sub genu uersus crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic cauterio uno cultellari.	And if he indicates that the pain is beneath the knee towards the leg, then cauterize him there with one cutting cautery.
Et caue tibi in omni cauterizatione tua, ut non ultimes cum cauterio ad hoc ut comburas neruum, aut arteriam magnam, et attrahas per illud super infirmum nocumentum malum, aut contractionem.	And beware in every cautery you perform, that you do not lastingly burn nerves or a major artery, and thereby cause great harm or contraction to the patient.
Et ego quidem iam uidi unum et alium, ex eis qui cauterizauerunt supra cauillam, et ultimauerunt in cauterizatione, et inflatum est crus, donec tumor consecutus est pedem, et perforatus est totus, et corruptus est totus pes: deinde accidit solutio uentris, et mors post illud.	And I have indeed seen one and another among those who cauterized above the vein, and persisted in cautery, and the leg swelled until a tumor reached the foot, and it was entirely perforated and corrupted: then gangrene set in, and death followed.
Quod si dolor est in duabus partibus simul, cauteriza utramque secundum hunc modum.	But if pain is in two parts at once, cauterize both according to this method.
Et sapientes quidam dixerunt in cauterizatione anchae, cuius cauterii iste est modus.	And learned men have said concerning the cautery of the ankle, which is this method's cautery.
Fac simile samio ex ferro, cuius diametrus sit medietas palmi: et sit apud orificium suum secundum grossitudinem nuclei dactyli, aut minus parumper: et intra illud samium sit samium tertium.	Make a similar one from iron, whose diameter is half the size of a palm: and let it be at its opening according to the thickness of a finger's bone, or slightly less; and inside that ring there should be another ring.
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne samium per quantitatem nodi pollicis: et sint samia aperta a duabus partibus: et sit altitudo eorum quasi nodus, aut duo nodi: et fac eis manubrium ex ferro decenter aptatum in samiis.	And let the space that is between each ring be equal to the thickness of a thumb's joint: and let the rings be open on both sides; and let their height be like a joint or two joints; and make them handles from iron fit for the rings.
Et haec est forma eius.	This is its shape.
Deinde igniatur in igne, donec rubeat, et proiiciat scintillas: deinde ponatur super pixidem anchae infirmo accubitato super latus sanum.	Then heat it in fire until it reddens and casts sparks; then place it on the ankle bone of the patient lying on their healthy side.
Cauteriza ergo eum tribus cauteriis rotundis in uice una.	So cauterize him with three round cauteries in place of one.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then let him rest for three days.
Postea emplastra cum butyro: et dimitte uulnus apertum diebus multis.	Afterwards apply poultices with butter; and leave the wound open for many days.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then treat him with ointment until he is healed.
Inquit Albucasis, hac specie cauterii o filii, parum usi sumus, propter terrorem aspectus eius: et propterea, quod paucos inuenimus qui expectent super ipsum.	I say, Albucasis, we have used this type of cautery too little, because of the fear it inspires and because few are found who await its use.
Verumtamen est ex bonis cauteriis ei qui suffert, et inuenit cum eo locum eius.	Yet it is one of the good cauteries for him who endures it, and finds with it its place.
Cauterium autem cum medicinis adurentibus est, ut tu facias duo samia habentia perforatam armillam, in quam descendit cardo portae eius ex aere, aut ferro, longitudo parietis: quorum in altitudinem eorum sint duo nodi, aut quasi ipsi.	However, the cautery with burning drugs is such that you should make two tubes having a pierced ring, into which goes the rod of its door of iron or bronze, the length of the wall: whose height are two knots, or almost so.
Et sit spacium quod est inter utraque quantitas grossitudinis digiti, et sint aperta inferius et superius: et sit quod contineant se adinuicem, secundum hanc formam.	And let the space between them be as thick as a finger, and let them be open at both ends; and let them fit together in this shape.
Deinde depone eam super pixidem anchae, infirmo iacente super latus sanum.	Then place it over the bronze vessel called 'anchae', with the patient lying on his healthy side.
Et comprime manum tuam super pixidem anchae multum.	And press your hand firmly upon the bronze vessel called 'anchae'.
Deinde funde inter duos circulos ex aqua calida, quae sit calefacta cum igne parumper, et tene eam quantitate horae temporalis: et toleret infirmus mordicationem eius, et ipsius adustionem, nam ipse inuenit mordicationem sicut ignis, donec quiescat mordicatio.	Then pour between the two circles hot water that has been heated with fire for a short time, and hold it for an hour's quantity of time: and let the patient endure its bite and burning, for it finds its biting like fire until the biting ceases.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum instrumento, et absterge aquam calidam ab ancha tota cum aqua dulci: deinde dimitte illud tribus diebus.	Then raise your hand with the instrument, and wipe off the hot water from the 'anchae' entirely with sweet water; then leave it for three days.
Et pone super illud butyrum, donec remoueatur nigredo adustionis: et dimitte illud diebus aliquot, et curret ex eo pus.	And put butter on it until the blackness of the burning is removed: and leave it for several days, and then pus will flow from it.
Est enim ultimum in iuuamento.	This is the final treatment.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with ointments until it heals.
Quod si extendatur dolor usque ad coxam, aut crus: fac ei statuam in eo quod continet aquam, secundum quod fecisti in ancha aequaliter.	But if the pain extends to the hip or thigh, make him stand in what contains water, in the same way that you did with 'anchae', equally.
Et iste est modus aquae calidae: et ego iam scripsi eam in tractatu rectificationis medicinarum.	And this is the manner of hot water: and I have already written about it in my book on the correction of drugs.
Sume alcali, et calcis non extinctae amborum ana partem unam: tere utraque, et pone ea in ollam nouam, cuius inferior pars sit perforata foramine uno paruo, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum radius: et pone sub fundo ollae ollam aliam uitreatam: et proiice super alcali et calcem ex aqua dulci, quod submergat utraque per digitum: post quam tu comprimas ea manu tua compressione bona: et dimite ollam, donec descendat aqua acuta inferiori parte ollae uitreatae.	Take alkali and unslaked lime both in equal parts; grind each of them, and put them into a new pot with one small hole at the bottom according to the size of the rod that enters it. And place underneath the pot another earthenware pot. Then pour onto the alkali and lime from sweet water until both are immersed by one finger's breadth. After which you press them with your hand with a good pressure, and leave the pot until the sharp water has descended into the lower part of the earthenware pot.
Deinde aggrega illam aquam totam, et proiice eam super aliam calcem: et cola, donec renouetur.	Then gather up all that water and pour it upon another lime; and knead until renewed.
Ipsa enim erit tunc fortis acuitatis ualde, quae administratur in multis operationibus medicinae, et in cauterizatione reliquorum membrorum.	For it will then be of great sharpness, which is administered in many operations of medicine, and in the cautery of other members.
Quoniam efficit operationem ignis ipsius.	Because it effects the operation of fire itself.
Et ex medicinis sunt, cum quibus cauterizantur ancha, etiam sicut tesisie, et mel anacardi, et calx cum sapone, ita quod utraque sint permixta. ¶	And among medicinals are those with which ulcers and also as theisies are cauterized, even as storax and almond honey, and lime with soap, so that both may be well mixed.
Et Galenus quidem narrando retulit, cuiusdam uiri ex antiquis curationem, qua curatus est dolor anchae et uenae sciaticae: et magnificauit esse eius ualde.	And indeed Galen relates the story of an old man who was cured by this remedy for the pain in his ulcer and sciatic vein; and he greatly praised it.
Et dixit, quia non indiguit alia curatione, et quia sanatus est ex uice una, donec retulit, quia ipse fortasse intrauit balneum delatus, et exiuit ex eo iam sanus.	He said that no other remedy was needed and that he was cured in one application. Indeed, perhaps he went to the bath carried [in] and came out already healed.
Et est, ut accipiatur ex seitaragi uiridi: et si non inuenitur uiride, sumatur siccum, recens: et teratur multum cum aliquanto adipe, et ponatur super ancham, ubi est dolor, aut crus, aut in coxa: et ligetur, et dimittatur quantitate trium horarum, aut per quantitatem quod sentiat infirmus sedationem adustionis.	And it is taken from green senna; and if not found green, the dried one may be taken. And grind much with some grease, and apply upon the ulcer or thigh or hip where there is pain; and bind it, leaving it for the space of three hours, or until the patient feels the soothing effect of the cautery.
Deinde intromitte eum in balneum.	Then let him enter into the bath.
Cum ergo roridum fit corpus eius, intromitte ipsum in solium.	When his body has become damp, let him enter upon a seat.
Nam dolor recedit, et sanatur.	For the pain will depart and be healed.
Et scias, quia non oportet ut utatur aliquis cauterio cum istis medicinis, nisi post euacuationem corporis.	And know that one should not use any cautery with these medicines unless after evacuation of the body.
Et Dioscorides qui dem dixit, quod stercus caprarum, quando cum eo cauterizatur uena sciatica, confert ei: et fit cauterium secundum hunc modum.	And Dioscorides said that goat dung, when used with it to cauterize the sciatic vein, benefits it: and a cautery is made in this manner.
Sumatur lana, et imbibatur oleo antiquo, et ponatur super locum profundum, qui est inter pollicem pedis, et inter focile, et est propinquior focili.	Wax is taken, soaked in old oil, and placed on the deep spot between the big toe and the heel, closer to the heel.
Deinde accipe stercus caprarum siccum, et inflamma ipsum in igne, donec fiat carbo.	Then take dry goat dung and ignite it in fire until it becomes coal.
Deinde pone ipsum super lanam, et dimitte ipsum, donec extinguatur.	Then place it on the wax, and leave it until it goes out.
Deinde itera illud.	Do this again.
Non cesses ergo facere illud, usquequo perueniat sensus super mediatione usque ad ancham, et quiescat dolor.	Do not cease doing this until sensation reaches the ankle and pain subsides.
Et iste modus cauterii nominatur cauterium Vaccinum.	And this method of cautery is called 'Vaccine cautery'.
¶ De cauterizatione doloris Dorsi.	Chapter on Cauterizing Back Pain.
Caput XLIIII.	Chapter 44
Quandoque accidit dolor in Dorso ex caussis multis, aut a casu, aut a percussione, aut euacuatione superflua, et illis similibus, ex infusione materiei frigidae, et humidae: et cauterium quidem non cadit, nisi in hac specie sola, quae fit ex infusione materiei frigidae.	Sometimes pain occurs in the back due to many causes, such as from accident, blow, evacuation of excess matter, and similar things, from infiltration of cold and moist material. Indeed, cautery is not used except in this single case that results from infiltration of cold material.
Oportet ergo post euacuationem infirmi cum pillulis foetidis, et eis similibus, ut fiant super Dorsum, ubi est dolor, tres lineae secundum latitudinem almeidati ipsius, postquam signas cum encaustro in omni linea quinque cauteria, aut plura secundum quantitatem quae uenit ex tolerantia infirmi uirtute eius: et fiat cauterizatio cum cauteriopuncti.	Therefore, after evacuating the patient with fetid pills and similar things, make three lines on the back where there is pain according to its width. Then mark each line with a hot iron five times or more according to the quantity that comes from the tolerance of the sick person's strength. And cauterize with a cautery point.
Et si uis, cauteriza tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor, cum cauterio clauili mediali, secundum hanc formam.	And if you wish, cauterize with three or four cauteries using the middle claw cautery according to this pattern.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in incaeptine Gibbositatis.	Chapter on the Method of Cauterizing a New Swelling.
Caput XLV.	Chapter 45
Multotiens accidit haec aegritudo infantibus paruis.	This condition often occurs in young infants.
Et signum incaeptionis eius in pueris est: quod accidit super eum strictura in anhelitu apud eleuationem, et motum: et inuenis in ultima spondilium Dorsi et nodorum eius, quod iam incaepit eminere super reliquos spondiles.	And the sign of its onset in children is: that shortness of breath occurs upon elevation and movement, and you find at the end of the spine of the back and its knots that it has begun to rise above the other spines.
Cum ergo uides illud, et uis facere illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio quod sit circulus secundum hanc formam.	Therefore, when you see this, and wish to perform this procedure, then cauterize it with a branding iron that is round in this shape.
Et capiat cauterium super omnem partem spondilis aequaliter: et si uis cauteriza in circumitu spondilis cum cauterio puncti duas lineas, aut tres: et sint puncta propinqua adinuicem.	And let the branding iron be placed equally upon all parts of the spine; and if you wish to cauterize around the spines with a branding iron, make two lines or three of dots, and let the dots be close together.
Deinde cura locum, donec sanetur cum eo quod diximus.	Then care for it until it heals according to what we have said.
Et caue, ne administres cauterium in gibbositate, quae fit in spasmo nerui.	And beware lest thou apply the branding iron to the gibbosity which occurs in spasm of the nerve.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Podagra, et doloribus iuncturarum.	On the manner of cauterizing in Gout and joint pains.
Caput XLVI.	Chapter 46.
Quando dolores iuncturarum sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, quae effunduntur ad cuiuslibet membra corporis, tunc quando accidunt dolores in pedibus, de consuetudine medicorum est, ut nominent illud Podagram proprie.	When joint pains are caused by cold humors that flow to any part of the body, then when such pains occur in the feet, it is customary among physicians to call this 'Gout' properly.
Cum ergo curatur Podagra frigidae caussae cum modis curationis, et non remouentur dolores, tune cauterium remouet eos.	But when gout caused by cold humors is treated with various remedies and the pain persists, then cautery will remove it.
Et est, ut cauterizes eum post euacuationem in circumitu iuncturae pedum, cauteriis multis: et sit cauterium Oliuare.	And you should cauterize him after evacuation around the joint of the foot with many cauteries; and let the branding iron be olive-shaped.
Cuius haec est forma.	This is its shape:
Et si indiges ut punctes super faciem pedis, tunc fac cum cauterio puncti.	And if you wish to make dots on the surface of the foot, then do so with a branding iron.
Quod si ascendunt dolores usque ad genua, aut reliquas iuncturas, et multotiens accidit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super omne genu tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor ab omni parte, cum hoc eodem cauterio Clauili.	But if the pain ascends to the knee or other joints, and this often happens, then cauterize it all around the knee with three or four cauteries using the same branding iron called 'the Claw'.
Si autem necessaria sunt tibi plura hoc cauterio, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	If however more are necessary for you using this cautery, then cauterize as needed.
Et non submergas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit circiter spissitudinem cutis tantum.	And do not immerse your hand with the branding iron, but let it be about the thickness of the skin only.
Si autem ascendunt dolores ad genua, et dorsum: tunc administra quod diximus ex cauterio in capitulo suo.	But if the pain ascends to the knee and back, then apply what we have said concerning cautery in its chapter.
Quod si dolores sunt in manibus tantum, tunc puncta in circumitu focilium, sicut reuoluuntur duae lineae.	If the pains are only in the hands, then make incisions around the joints as if two lines were turning around them.
Si autem remanet ex doloribus in digitis, tunc puncta eos, super omnem nodum punctum, et super pectinem manus.	But if there remains pain in the fingers, then make incisions on them over every joint and over the palm of the hand.
Si autem ascendunt dolores post dies ad cubitos, aut ad humeros, tunc cauteriza utrosque ab omni parte.	But if the pains ascend after some days to the elbows or shoulders, then cauterize both sides on all parts.
Et non euacues infirmum ex regimine bono, ex recaeptione medicinarum.	And do not let the patient be discharged from good care and taking of medicines.
Nam si bonum fiat regimen, et euacuetur phlegma, sanabitur auxilio Dei cum isto cauterio.	For if good care is given and phlegm is removed, it will be healed with the help of God along with this cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Rupturis.	Chapter on the Method of Cauterizing for Ruptures.
Caput XLVII.	Chapter 47.
Quando accidit Ruptura in inguinibus, et descendit intestinum, aut zirbum ad testiculum, et est illud incipiens propinquum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo dimittere comestionem in die suo.	When a rupture occurs in the groin and the intestine or bladder descends to the testicle, and it is just beginning to be close: then it is necessary that you instruct the patient to abstain from food on that day.
Et utatur ex lenientibus, quo descendat stercus a uentre suo.	And let him use laxatives so that feces may come down from his belly.
Deinde sedeat inter manus tuas super dorsum suum: et praecipe ei, ut teneat anhelitum suum, donec egrediatur, uel appareat zirbum, aut intestinum.	Then let him sit between your hands on his back: and instruct him to hold his breath until the bladder or intestine comes out or appears.
Deinde reduc ipsum digitis tuis, et signa cum encaustro sub Ruptura super os pectinis, cum signo cuius extremitas sit similis medietati circuli ad superiora corporis.	Then reduce it with your fingers, and mark with the cautery below the rupture on the pubic bone, with a mark whose upper end is like half of a circle.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma, donec ueniat album, et proiiciat seintillas.	Then heat the cautery whose shape is like this until it becomes white and throws off sparks.
Deinde reduc intestinum, aut zirbum ad concauitatem suam.	Then reduce the intestine or bladder to its own concavity.
Deinde ponat minister manum suam super locum, ut non exeat intestinum: et tu iam aperuisti inter crura infirmi, et posuisti sub eo puluinar, et seruiens alius super crura eius, et alius super pectus eius qui tenet manus.	Then let the assistant put his hand on the place so that the intestine does not come out: and you have already opened between the legs of the patient, and placed a cushion underneath him, and another servant is on his legs, and another on his chest who holds his hands.
Deinde depone cauterium super ipsum signum, manu tua cum cauterio stante recta.	Then place the cautery on that mark with your hand holding it upright.
Et tene ipsum, donec cum eo consequaris os: aut itera cum eo uice alia, si non consecutus fueris cum eo in prima usque ad os.	And hold it until you reach the bone: or repeat the process again if you did not reach the bone on the first attempt.
Et prudenter obserua ab exitu intestini in hora cauterizationis tuae, ne comburas ipsum, et eueniat per illud super infirmum aut mors, aut malicia magna.	And carefully observe that the intestine does not exit during your cautery operation, lest you burn it and cause harm or serious mischief to the patient.
Et scias, quod quando tu non consequeris cum cauterio os, non confert operatio tua.	Know that if you do not reach bone with the cautery, your operation is ineffective.
Et oportet ut sit cauterium infantium subtile, secundum mensuram eorum.	And it is necessary that the cauteries for children be thin and suitable to their size.
Deinde cura cum reliquis unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then apply it with the other ointments until it heals.
Et sit infirmus iacens super dorsum suum quadraginta diebus, donec sigilletur uulnus.	And let the patient lie on his back for forty days until the wound is healed.
Et oportet, ut ponas nutrimentum eius longitudine temporis curationis eius, quod leniat uentrem eius: ut non exeat intestinum apud conamen et egestionem.	And it is necessary that you give him food appropriate to the length of his treatment so that it softens his stomach and prevents the intestine from protruding during evacuation.
Deinde quando uult surgere post quadraginta dies, tunc administra ligamentum decenter factum, et teneat ipsum quadraginta diebus aliis.	Then when he wants to get up after forty days, then apply a well-made bandage and let him hold it for another forty days.
Et minoretur a labore, et repletione cibi et potus, et uocibus uehementibus.	And lessen his work, his food and drink intake, and violent coughing.
Nam quando utitur hoc regimine, ita sanatur sanatione integra.	For when he follows this regimen, he will be healed completely.
Et ego dicam curationem Rupturarum cum incisione in capitulo suo.	And I shall speak of the treatment of ruptures with incision in its chapter.
Quando autem Rupturae accidunt in reliquo uentre, et sunt incipientes, et uis ut non addantur, tunc cauteriza Rupturam eius cauterio rotundo secundum quantitatem eius: et sit illud quod aduritur ex tunc sicut tertia eius.	But when ruptures occur elsewhere in the abdomen and are beginning to worsen, cauterize the rupture with a round cautery according to its size; let that which is burned be like one third of it.
Deinde cura ipsum, cum eo quod diximus: et non addetur.	Then treat it with what we have mentioned and it will not worsen.
Et iam dixerunt quidam primi: ut cauterizetur Ruptura cum cauterio triangulato, secundum hanc formam.	And some of the first ones said that a rupture should be cauterized with a triangular cautery, in this shape.
Postquam signatur cum encaustro, et ponitur linea quae est per latitudinem in latere superiori Rupturae, et linea altera ad inferius.	After it is marked with the cautery, place a line across its width on the upper side of the rupture and another line below it.
Et depone manum tuam in medio cum cauterio clauili.	And place your hand in the middle with the key-shaped cautery.
Sed cauterium primum est facilius et melius.	But the triangular cautery is easier and better.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in doloribus propter casum, aut percussionem.	And concerning the manner of cauterizing in pains due to falls or blows.
Caput XLVIII.	Chapter XLVIII.
Quando accidit in quibusdam membris a casu, aut percussione dolor: et perseuerat ille dolor tempore longo, et non confert in eo curatio cum medicinis: tunc oportet ut cauterizetur cum cauterio Puncti.	When it happens that certain members are affected by pain due to a fall or blow, and the pain persists for a long time without being relieved by medical treatment, then it is necessary to cauterize with the punctual cautery.
Et sit cauterium omnis membri cauterium secundum magnitudinem eius, et ipsius paruitatem, et debilitatem eius, et ipsius uirtutem, et locationem torsionis, et doloris ex eo.	And let the cautery be of a size suited to the magnitude and thickness and weakness and strength and position of the twist and pain arising from it.
Si ergo sanatur ex cauterio primo, est bene.	If therefore healing occurs from the first cauterization, that is good.
Si non: tunc itera super ipsum cauterium.	But if not, then repeat the cautery upon it.
Quoniam de consuetudine horum dolorum est, ut permutentur ex membro ad illud quod appropinquat ei.	For it is customary for these pains to change from one member to that which is near it.
Quare oportet ut consequaris eos cum cauterio, donec sanetur infirmus.	Therefore you must pursue them with the cautery until the sick part is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lepra.	And concerning the manner of cauterizing in Leprosy.
Caput XLIX.	Chapter XLIX.
Leprosi autem quandoque iuuantur cauterio iuuamento maximo.	But lepers are sometimes benefited by a cautery to an extraordinary degree.
Et praecipue species Leprae, quae fit propter putrefactionem phlegmatis et melancholiae: cum ergo uis cauterizare ipsam considera.	And especially the kind of leprosy which arises from the corruption of phlegm and bile; therefore when you wish to cauterize it, consider.
Si ergo Lepra est ineipiciens, et curasti eam cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non descendit, neque stat: et times super infirmum, quod comprehendat corruptio super totam complexionem eius: tunc cauteriza eum super caput quinque cauteriis: uno in medio capitis noto, et secundo inferius eo uersus frontem apud finem capillorum, et duobus super duo cornua, et uno posterius super nucea ceruicis.	If therefore the leprosy is beginning and you have treated it with what we said concerning division and it does not subside nor stay; and you fear that corruption may spread over his entire complexion: then cauterize him on the head with five cauteries: one in the middle of the head, and a second below it towards the forehead at the end of the hair, and two on the two horns, and one behind on the nape of the neck.
Et ultima manum tuam cum cauterio parumper, donec imprimat in os impressionem paruam, et dislocentur ex eo cortices: ut alleuietur expiratio uaporum grossorum ex eo, et cauteriza cauterio etiam super ipsum splenem, secundum quod praecessit.	And press your last hand with the cautery briefly until it makes a slight impression on the bone and causes the scales to be broken off from it: so that the breathing of thick vapors may be alleviated from him; and cauterize with the cautery also upon the spleen according to what precedes.
Sin autem Lepra iam sparsa est super infirmum, et apparet manifeste: tunc oportet ut cauterizes cum istis cauteriis, quae diximus in capite, et cauterio super extremitatem nasi, et duobus cauteriis super duas maxillas, et duobus cauteriis super spondiles colli, et sex super spondiles dorsi, et uno magno super alhahosos apud gran caudae et uno supra ipsum, in ipso almeidati: et duobus super anchas: scilicet super omnem ancham uno, et duobus super genua: uno super omne genu, et duobus super humeros, et duobus super cubitos, et duobus super teneritudines pectoris sui: et cauteriza ipsum super omnem iuncturam, ex iuncturis digitorum manuum suarum, et pedum suorum: et cauteriza super omnem calcaneum pedum suorum, et focilia manuum suarum.	But if the leprosy is already spread over the sick person and appears manifestly: then you must cauterize with those cauteries which we mentioned in the head, and one on the tip of the nose, and two on each cheekbone, and two on the shoulder blades of the neck, and six on the shoulder blades of the back, and one large one over the buttocks near the great tail, and one above it in the middle of the buttocks: and two on the hips, that is on all the hip joints with one cautery each; and two on the knees, one on all the knees, and two on the elbows, and two on the soft parts of his chest, and cauterize him over every joint of the fingers of his hands and feet, and cauterize also over all the heels of his feet and palms of his hands.
Et caue tibi a neruis qui sunt super postremum calcanei, ut non comburas eos.	And beware of the nerves that are on the heel, so as not to burn them.
Et quandoque cauterizatur cauterio super os pectinis, et alio super os stomachi, et alio super epar.	Then you may cauterize with a cautery over the breastbone, and another over the belly bone, and another over the liver.
Et scias, quod quanto plus addis cauterium, est magis iuuamentum, et magis conferens.	And know that the more you increase the cautery, the greater is its benefit and effectiveness.
Et scias, quod infirmus non inuenit in cauterio dolorem, sicut inueniunt ipsum sani: propterea, quod corpus eius iam stupefactum est.	And know that the sick person does not feel pain from the cautery as much as healthy people do, because his body is already numbed.
Et oportet ut sint cauteria ex magnitudine, et paruitate secundum membra et iuncturas: secundum quod praecessit ex speciebus ferramentorum.	And it is necessary that the cauteries be of appropriate size and thinness according to the members and joints, as was mentioned in the kinds of instruments.
Deinde cura cauterium ex farina herbi cum melle, et reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then care for the cauteries with a mixture of herb flour and honey, and other treatments until they heal.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Stupore.	And how to cauterize in Stupor.
Caput L.	Chapter 50.
Quando stupet aliquod membrum, et curatur cum medicinis, et oleis, et emplastris, et non sanatur, tunc cauteriza ipsum membrum stupefactum cauteriis, secundum quod meretur magnitudo membri, aut paruitas eius.	When a member is paralyzed and treated with medications, oils, and poultices but does not recover, then cauterize the paralyzed member with cauteries appropriate to its size or smallness.
Et sit cauterium tuum intrans in spissitudinem cutis parumper.	And let your cautery enter only slightly into the thickness of the skin.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with ointment until it heals.
Et quandoque cauterizatur ad quiddam stuporis, qui accidit manui, et pedi, in spondilibus dorsi apud exitum neruorum, qui mouent illud membrum: et remouetur stupor.	And when numbness occurs in the hand or foot, and on the spine at the exits of the nerves that move those limbs, the numbness will be removed.
Verum non praesumat super illud, nisi qui est sapiens in anatomia membrorum, et egressione neruorum mouentium corpus.	But let none attempt it except one who is wise in anatomy and the exit of moving nerves.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Albaras.	Chapter On The Method Of Cautery In Albucasis.
Caput LI.	Chapter 51.
Quando antiquatur Albaras, et non confert in eo aliquid ex ingeniis medicinae: tunc cauteriza super ipsam cauterio profundo parumper, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis, donec remoueatur albedo, et mutetur color eius.	When Albucasis is old and does not respond to any medical treatments, then apply the cautery deeply for a short time according to the thickness of the skin until its whiteness is removed and its color changes.
Deinde cura ipsum cum farina herbi, et lentis cum oleo rosa, et foliis arnoglossae, et sanguine columbae, et sanguine hyrundinis: de unoquoque sit pars una: misceantur haec omnia, et liniantur super pannum, et adhaereant loco, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with flour of barley and lentils with rose oil, and leaves of mallows, and pigeon blood, and lark's blood; let each ingredient be one part. Mix all these together and spread them on a linen cloth, letting them adhere to the place until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Cancro.	Chapter On The Method Of Cautery In Cancer.
Caput LII.	Chapter 52.
Quando Cancer est incipiens, et uis ipsum sistere: tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio circuli in circuitu eius, sicuti reuoluitur.	When cancer is beginning and it seems possible to stop it: then cauterize its circumference with a circular cautery, as it revolves.
Sapientes autem dixerunt, ut cauterizetur cauterio ultimo in medio.	But wise men have said that it should be cauterized lastly in the middle.
Mihi autem non uidetur illud: quoniam timeo quod ulceretur: et ego iam uidi illud aliquotiens.	But to me, this does not seem so, because I fear that it may ulcerate. And I have seen this happen many times.
Et rectius est, ut cauterizetur in circumitu eius cum circulo, sicut diximus: aut cauteriis multis.	And it is better to cauterize its circumference with a circle as we have said, or with many cauteries.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Adubelati.	Chapter On The Method Of Cautery In Aboil.
Caput LIII.	Chapter 53.
Quando aliquis habet Adubelati, et tardatur in maturatione, aut propter superfluitatem facientem eam, aut propter aetatem infirmi, quando est decrepitus pauci sanguinis, aut propter tempus, et uis festinare in maturatione Adubelati, tunc cauteriza in circumitu eius cum cauteriis paruis multis punctando.	When someone has an aboil and it is delayed in maturing, either because of excess blood causing it or because of the patient's age or weakness, or because of time, and you wish to hasten its maturation: then cauterize around it with many small cauteries, pricking frequently.
Deinde dimitte eam.	Then leave it alone.
Nam ipsa festinabit cum maturatione.	For it will mature by itself.
Si autem uis perforationem eius cum cauterio, tunc igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma.	But if you wish to perform a cautery on its opening, then heat the cautery, which has this shape:
Et depone ipsum in medio Adubelati, donec penetret cutem: et sit cauterium ab eo quod sequitur infirmus, ut alleuietur cursus puris.	And place it in the middle of the aboil until it pierces the skin: and let the cautery be from what follows, so that the course may be relieved by pure evacuations.
Deinde cura ipsum donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in malo corrodente.	On the method of cauterizing a malignant ulcer.
Caput LIIII.	Chapter 52
Corrodens non est nisi corruptio in membro ambulans, et corrodit ipsum: sicut ignis comedit ligna sicca.	A corrosive ulcer is nothing but corruption in the flesh that moves about and consumes it: like fire that devours dry wood.
Si ergo uides corrodentem in loco qui toleret cauterium cum igne, tunc igni cauteria multa, clauilia parua et magna, secundum quod conueniet illi loco in quo est corrodens.	Therefore, if you see a corrosive ulcer in a place that can tolerate cautery with fire, then heat many cauteries, both small and large, according to what suits the location where the ulcer is.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum ab omni parte donec eradices corruptionem totam, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid penitus.	Then cauterize it on all sides until you have entirely eradicated the corruption, so that nothing remains of it at all.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super loca cauterizata sulphur tritum cum oleo, donec eradicentur escharae omnes, et omnis corruptio.	Then leave it alone for three days, and apply powdered sulfur mixed with oil to the cauterized areas until all scabs and corruption are eradicated.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguentis generantibus carnem.	Then care for it with ointments that promote flesh growth.
Si ergo uides, quod post tres dies caro nascitur natiuitate sana, in qua non est corruptio, est bonum.	Therefore, if you see that after three days healthy new flesh has grown, without any corruption, then it is good.
Et si non: tunc itera cauterium super illud quod remansit ex locis corruptis.	But if not, then repeat the cautery on what remains of the corrupted areas.
Et corrodens medicatur quandoque cum medicina acuta.	And a corrosive ulcer is sometimes treated with caustic medicines.
Ipsa namque surgit loco cauterii.	For it arises in the place where the cautery was applied.
Verumtamen cauterium cum igne est uelocioris iuuamenti: et ego quidem iam dixi cauterizationem eius cum medicina acuta in diuisione: accipe ergo eam illic quando ea indiges.	However, cautery with fire is a quicker remedy. And indeed I have already mentioned the cautery of it with caustic medicines elsewhere in this book: therefore take it there when you need it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Clauis, et Verucis.	On the method of cauterizing nails and warts.
Caput LV.	Chapter 55
Multotiens accidit in inferioribus partibus pedum haec aegritudo: et est res grossa, filtrata, quae laedit pedem.	Often in the lower parts of the feet this illness occurs, which is a thick, filtered substance that harms the foot.
Et cauterium quidem in eis est secundum duos modos: cauterium cum igne, et cauterium cum aqua calida.	And cautery for them is done in two ways: cautery with fire and cautery with hot water.
Quantum autem cum igne est, ut ignias cauterium concauum simile pennae uulturis: quod fiat ex ferro, secundum quantitatem quod contineat clauum ab omni parte: et sit subtilium marginum.	But when using fire, the cautery should resemble a hawk's feather quill made of iron, according to the size that contains the nail on all sides, and have thin edges.
Deinde depone ipsum ignitum super clauum.	Then place the heated cautery onto the nail.
Deinde reuolue manum cum cauterio in circumitu claui, donec perueniat cauterium ad profunditatem claui: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, donec incipiat emittere pus.	Next, roll your hand with the cautery around the nail until it reaches the depth of the nail. Then leave it for three days until it begins to discharge pus.
Deinde emplastra ipsum cum maluis syluestribus, contritis cum sale: et dimitte emplastrum super ipsum in nocte.	Then apply a poultice made from crushed forest mallows with salt and leave it on overnight.
Ipse enim eradicabitur ex radicibus suis.	For it will be eradicated from its roots.
Deinde cura locum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	Then apply a wound-healing ointment until it heals.
Quod si sunt non conuersi, et multotiens accidunt in superficie corporis, praecipue in manibus et pedibus: tunc administres in eis cauterium cum aqua calida: et est, ut accipias cannulam ex aere, aut ferro, aut ex penna uulturis: et depone eam super clauum, aut althelul.	If they are not converted and often occur on the surface of the body, especially in hands and feet, then use cautery with hot water. Take a cannula made of bronze or iron or hawk feather and place it onto the nail or corn.
Deinde proiice in cannulam ex aqua calida quantitatem paucam: retine manum tuam, et tu reuolue eam cum compressione manus tuae parumper, ut imprimatur margo cannulae in radice claui, et inueniat aqua calida uiam ad profundum, ad radicem claui: et expectet infirmus parumper super mordicationem aquae calidae hora una.	Then pour a small amount of hot water into the cannula. Hold your hand steady and roll it gently with the pressure of your hand so that the edge of the cannula is impressed on the root of the nail, allowing the hot water to reach deep down to the root of the nail. Then wait for about an hour until the pain from the hot water subsides.
Deinde dimitte ipsum, nam clauus eradicatur cum radicibus suis.	Then leave it alone, for the nail will be eradicated with its roots.
Ita fac cum eis uno post unum, donec uenias super omnes qui ex eis sunt in corpore.	Do this one at a time until you have treated all of them on the body.
Deinde cura eos postquam eradicantur, cum eo quod generat carnem ex unguentis.	Then care for them after they are removed with that which generates flesh from ointments.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tremore.	On cauterizing in trembling
Caput LVI.	Chapter 60
Quando accidit alicui Tremor ex frigore in neruo, aut ex febre quartana, aut alio: tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis, aut quinque super spondiles dorsi, et inter omnem spondilem cauterio, et in pectore eius cauterio, et super stomachum eius cauterio.	When trembling occurs due to coldness in the nerve, or quartan fever, or any other cause: then it is necessary to cauterize it with four cauteries, or five over the spines of the back, and between every spine with a cautery, and on his chest with a cautery, and on his stomach with a cautery.
Tremor enim quiescit cum cauterio oliuari, et festinat sanitas aegritudinis frigidae.	For trembling ceases when cauterized with an oil-based cautery, and the health of the cold ailment hastens.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Albathir.	On cauterizing Albatheir
Caput LVII.	Chapter 61
Quandoque expelluntur in corpore Albathir foedae, id est, pustulae, quae fiunt a materiis grossis corruptis.	Sometimes harmful Albathir are expelled from the body, namely pustules, which arise from corrupted coarse materials.
Oportet ergo in primis cum apparent, ut cauterizentur super omne caput pustulae cauterio subtili cum ligno myrti, cuius extremitas accensa est cum igne.	Therefore, when they first appear, they should be cauterized with a fine cautery of myrtle wood at the head of each pustule while its end is burning with fire.
Aut cum radice aristolochiae longae.	Or with the root of long aristolochia.
Aut cum cauterio lenticulari.	Or with a lenticular cautery
Et quandoque cauterizantur ademenul, in principio expulsionis suae secundum hunc modum: et non augentur: et disrumpitur superfluitas faciens eos, et sanatur ex eis.	And sometimes they are cauterized little by little at the beginning of their expulsion according to this method, and they do not increase; and the excess causing them is ruptured, and healing occurs from them.
Verumtamen oportet ut fiat illud post euacuationem cum phlebotomia.	But it should be done after evacuation with phlebotomy.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fluxu sanguins ex arteria in uulnere.	On cauterizing in a flow of blood from an artery in a wound
Caput LVIII.	Chapter 62рада
Multotiens accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, quae incisa est apud uulnus, quod accidit extrinsecus, aut apud incisionem apostematis, aut cauterium membri, et similia eis: et fit difficile abscindere eum.	Very often there is a flow of blood from an artery that is cut at a wound which occurs externally, or at the incision of an abscess, or cautery of a member, and similar things. And it is difficult to stop it.
Cum ergo accidit alicui illud, tunc propera cum manu tua ad orificium arteriae, et pone super ipsum digitum tuum indicem: et stringe eum multum, donec obsessus sit sanguis sub digito tuo, et non egrediatur ex eo aliquid.	Therefore, when this happens to someone, then quickly place your hand over the opening of the artery and put your index finger on it. And press it strongly until the blood is blocked under your finger and nothing flows out from it.
Deinde pone in ignem cauteria oliuaria parua, et magna numero plura: et suffla super ea, donec fiant ignita ualde.	Then place a small olive oil lamp on the fire, and many others besides, and blow on them until they are very well lit.
Deinde accipe ex eis unum, aut paruum, aut magnum, secundum uulnus et locum, in quo disrupta est arteria, et depone cauterium super ipsam uenam, post quam tu remoues digitum tuum festinanter: et tene cauterium, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Then take one of them, either small or large according to the wound and location where the artery is severed, and place the cautery on that vein. Then quickly remove your finger, and hold the cautery until the bleeding stops.
Quod si expellatur cum eleuas digitum ab orificio arteriae, et extinguis cauterium, tunc accipe cauterium aliud festinanter, ex cauteriis quae in igne sunt praeparata.	But if blood is expelled when you remove your finger from the opening of the artery, then quickly take another cautery from those that are prepared on the fire.
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum uno post aliud, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Do not cease doing this with one after another until the bleeding stops.
Et caue, ne comburas neruum qui est illic, et accidat super infirmum malicia alia.	And beware lest thou burn the nerve which is there, and cause some other harm to the patient.
Et scias, quod quando ex arteria fluit sanguis, tunc non est possibile abscindere ipsum: praecipue quaudo arteria est magna, nisi cum uno quatuor modorum.	And know that when blood flows from an artery, it is not possible to stop it except by one of four methods, especially if the artery is large.
Aut cum cauterio, sicut diximus.	Or with a cautery, as we have said.
Aut cum extractione, quando non est extracta.	Or with ligation when it has not been ligated.
Nam quando extrahitur, contrahuntur extremitates eius, et abscinditur sanguis.	For when it is extracted, its ends contract and the bleeding stops.
Aut ligetur cum filo ligatione forti.	Or it may be tied with a strong ligature thread.
Aut ponantur super ipsum medicinae de proprietate, quarum est abscindere sanguinem, et stringatur cum puluinari constrictione decenti.	Or medicines of proper nature to stop bleeding should be applied over it, and it should be bandaged with a suitable compress.
Qui autem administrat abscisionem eius cum ligamento, et strictura cum panno, aut positione rerum comburentium, et similium, non confert ei penitus, nisi raro.	But whoever performs the ligation or binding with a thread and constriction with cloth, or application of burning substances, etc., does him no good at all unless rarely.
Si autem accidat alicui illud, et non sit ei praesens medicus, neque medicina: tunc incipiat cum positione digiti indicis super orificium uenae ipsius, sicut narrauimus, et constrictione eius ualde, donec obsessus sit sanguis a superiori parte uulneris, et super arteriam.	But if such thing happens to someone and there is no physician present nor medicine, then one should begin by placing the index finger on the opening of the vein as we have described, and pressing it very strongly until the blood is blocked from above the wound and over the artery.
Et digitus non remoueatur, desuper ipsum cum aqua frigida uehementis frigoris semper, donec congeletur sanguis, et ingrossetur, et abscindatur.	And do not remove the finger until the blood is chilled and thickened by cold water continually applied from above, so that it may be cut off.
