Et interim consideret in eo, quid indiget ex cauterio, aut ex medicina.	Meanwhile, one should consider what cautery or medicine is needed for it.
¶ Partis Primae Finis.	End of the First Part.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars II.	Albucasis' Book of Surgery, Second Part.
¶ De Incisione, Perforatione, et Phlebotomia in uulneribus, et his similibus.	Concerning Incision, Piercing, and Bloodletting in Wounds, and Similar Conditions.
Iam Diximus in Capitulo Primo, omnem aegritudinem in qua conueniens est cum igne cauterium et medicina comburente, et occasiones eius, ipsius caussas, et instrumenta eius, et formas cauteriorum.	We have already spoken in the First Chapter about every ailment in which it is fitting to use fire cautery and burning medicine, their occasions, causes, instruments, and forms of cauteries.
Et posui illic capitula a uertice usque ad pedem.	And there I set forth chapters from head to foot.
Et ego procedam in hoc capitulo illa eadem uia: ut alleuietur super quaerentem quaesitum eius.	And I will proceed in this chapter along the same path, so that he who seeks may find what is sought.
Et antequam incipiam illud, oportet ut addiscatis o filii, quod in hoc capitulo est ex terrore illud quod est in capitulo primo de cauterizatione.	And before I begin this, O sons, it is necessary for you to know that what is in this chapter about cauterization is similar to what is in the first chapter.
Et propter illud oportet, ut sit cautela in eo uehementior, quoniam in operatione quae est in hoc capitulo, multotiens cadit euacuatio cum sanguine, cum quo stat uita apud apertionem uenae, aut incisionem super apostema, aut apertionem exiturae, aut curationem uulneris, aut extractionem sagittae, aut incisionem super lapidem, et illis similia: ex quibus omnibus associatur tremor, et timor, et cadit in pluribus eorum mors.	And therefore it is necessary that caution be greater in this, for in the operation which is in this chapter, there often occurs evacuation with blood, with which life stands at the opening of a vein, or incision over an abscess, or opening of an exit, or cure of a wound, or extraction of an arrow, or incision over a stone, and similar things: from all of which trembling and fear arise, and many of them result in death.
Et ego moneo uos, ne cadat super uos illud in quo est haesitatio, nam quandoque cadunt ad uos in hac arte modi hominum cum modis infirmitatum.	And I warn you that this should not happen to you, for sometimes men of different kinds come to you with different ailments in this art.
Ex eis enim est qui irascitur cum aegritudine sua, et est leuis apud eum mors: propter uehementiam eius quod inuenit ex infirmitate sua et longitudine eius maliciei.	For among them are those who become angry with their illness and find death easy to bear on account of the vehemence of what they have found from their ailment and the length of their suffering.
Et cum aegritudine est ex timore quod significat mortem.	And with illness there is fear which signifies death.
Et ex eis est, qui dat tibicensum suum, et ditat te cum eo, sperans sanitatem, et aegritudo eius est perniciosa.	And among them are those who offer their wealth and feast you with it, hoping for health, but their illness is deadly.
Non ergo oportet ut consentiatis ei qui uenit ad uos ex eis, cuius modus est talis.	Therefore, do not agree with him who comes to you from among them, whose manner is such.
Et sit cautela uestra uehementior, quam cupiditas et uestra rapacitas.	And let your caution be more vehement than your greed and avarice.
Et non praesumatis super aliquid ex illo, nisi post scientiam certam, quae uerificat apud uos illud ad quod peruenit successio laudabilis.	And do not presume upon anything from him, except after certain knowledge which verifies it among you, with commendable success.
Et utimini in curatione omnium infirmorum uestrorum, prognosticatione et indicatione de eo ad quod conuenienter sit salus.	And use in the treatment of all your illnesses prognosis and indication concerning that to which health is suitably directed.
In illo namque est uobis adiutorium super acquisitionem famae et gloriae, et memoriae et laudis.	For in this there is for you assistance towards acquiring fame and glory, and remembrance and praise.
Inspiret uobis Deus o filii, intellectum suum, et non auferat uobis directionem et inspirationem: quoniam illud est in manu eius.	May God inspire you, O sons, with His understanding, and not take away from you guidance and inspiration; for that is in His hand.
Et ego quidem ordinaui hoc Capitulum distinguendo per capitula, secundum quod praecessit in capitulo Cauterii, a ceruice usque ad pedes: ut alleuietur uobis quaesitum quod uultis ex eo, et quo indigetis.	And I have arranged this chapter by dividing it into chapters according to what has preceded in the chapter on cautery, from the neck down to the feet; so that you may find easily what you seek from it and of which you stand in need.
¶ De curatione Aquae quae aggregatur in capitibus puerorum.	Chapter: On the Treatment of Water which Collects in the Heads of Children
Caput I.	Chapter 1
Scias, quod haec infirmitas multotiens accidit pueris apud partum: aut quando stringit obstetrix caput pueri absque leuitate.	Know that this ailment often occurs in children at birth or when the midwife squeezes the child's head without gentleness.
Et quandeque accidit etiam ex caussa occulta quae non scitur.	And sometimes it happens even from an unknown cause which is not known.
Et ego quidem non uidi hanc aegritudinem in aliis quam in pueris: et ad omnem quem ex eis uidi properauit mors: propter illud ergo uisum est mihi dimittere operationem in ea.	And I have not seen this illness in anyone except children, and death came quickly to all whom I saw afflicted with it. Therefore, it seemed to me necessary to set down the treatment for it.
Et ego quidem uidi ex eis puerum, cuius caput impletum erat aqua, et caput magnificabatur in omni die, donec non poterat sedere super seipsum, propter magnitudinem capitis sui: et humiditas augmentata fuit, donec mortuus est.	And I have seen a child whose head was filled with water and grew larger each day until he could no longer sit up on his own because of the size of his head; and the moisture increased until he died.
Et haec quidem humiditas, aut aggregatur inter cutem et os: aut aggregatur sub osse super sifac.	And this fluid collects either between the skin and bone or beneath the bone over the brain.
Et operatio in illo, si est humiditas inter cutem et os, et apostema est paruum, tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis fissura una in latitudine: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo nodi, donec currat humiditas.	And the operation for this condition is as follows: if there is fluid between the skin and bone and a small abscess has formed, then you should make an incision in the middle of the head, about two fingers' width wide, until the fluid flows out.
Et haec est forma spatumilis.	This is the method for treating hydrocephalus.
Si ergo humiditas est magis augmentata, et apostema est maius, tunc pone eas duas fissuras, secundum formam hanc.	But if the fluid has greatly increased and there is a large abscess, then make two incisions according to this pattern.
Et si humiditas est sub osse, et signum eius est, quod uides commissuras capitis apertas ab omni parte: et aqua deprimitur quando comprimis eam manu tua ad interiora, et non occultatur tibi illud: tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis tribus fissuris, secundum hunc modum.	But if the fluid is beneath the bone and its sign is that you see the sutures of the head opened on all sides, and water appears when you press it with your hand, then make three incisions in the middle of the head, according to this method.
Et post incisionem extrahe humiditatem totam.	And after making the incisions, remove all the fluid.
Deinde stringe fissuras cum pannis et puluillis.	Then close the incisions with linen cloths and poultices.
Deinde embroca illud desuper cum uino et oleo usque ad diem quintum.	Then apply a dressing of wine and oil to it from above until the fifth day.
Deinde solue ligamentum, et cura uulnus cum tentis, et unguentis.	Then remove the bandage on the fifth day, and treat the wound with linen cloths and ointments.
Et non dimittas stringere caput cum aequalitate.	And do not cease binding the head evenly.
Et ciba infirmum omni cibo sicco paucae humiditatis, usquequo confortetur membrum, et sanetur.	And feed the patient dry food with little moisture until the member is strengthened and healed.
Et modus alius incisionis est, ut consideres ubi apparet magnitudo apostematis, et collectio aquae.	And another method of incision is to observe where the size of the abscess appears and where water collects.
Quoniam quandoque est in occipitio plus, aut in sincipite, aut in dextra, aut in sinistra.	For sometimes it is more abundant at the back of the head, or on top, or on the right side, or on the left side.
Ascende ergo cum incisione ubi apparet tibi apostema et impletio aquae: et scinde illud secundum quod tibi possibile est.	Therefore, make your incision where you see the abscess and the collection of water appear, and cut it according to what is possible for you.
Et obserua, ne incidas arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis, et moriatur infirmus ex illo fluxu cum euacuatione humiditatis.	And beware that you do not cut an artery, lest there be a flow of blood and the patient dies from this bleeding along with the evacuation of fluid.
¶ De incisione Arteriarum quae sunt post aures.	Concerning the Incision of Arteries which are Behind the Ears.
Caput II.	Chapter 2
Quando accidunt alicui catarri ad oculos, aut ad pectus, et antiquatur illud, et non confert curatio medicinarum: tunc magis ultima curatio est in illo, incisio harum duarum arteriarum.	When catarrh occurs in someone's eyes or chest, and it becomes chronic and does not yield to medical treatment, then incision of these two arteries is the final course.
Oportet ergo quando uis incidere eas, ut radat infirmus caput suum.	Therefore, when you wish to cut them, you should have the patient turn their head.
Deinde frica locum cum panno aspero, ut appareant arteriae.	Then wipe the area with a rough cloth so that the arteries become visible.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum, cum quolibet panno suo.	Then the patient should tie their neck with any cloth they have.
Deinde considera, ubi pulset uena.	Then observe where the pulse of the vein beats.
Et loca utriusque sunt loca quae sunt post aures depressa: et raro occultatur, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	And their locations are the areas behind the ears which are sunken: and they are rarely concealed unless in certain individuals.
Deinde signa cum encaustro super utraque: et incide utramque cum spatumili utrimque acuro, incisione perueniente ad os: et fiat illud per latitudinem capitis.	Then mark with a hot iron on both sides and cut each one with a sharp knife, cutting through to the bone, and let it be made across the width of the head.
Et si uis, intromitte spatumile sub arteria, et incide eam ad superiora cum incisione.	And if you wish, insert a spatula under the artery and cut towards its upper part with an incision.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quasi duo digiti iuncti.	And let the length of the incision be about two joined fingers.
Nam quando inciditur uena, egreditur sanguis egressione pulsatili, qui salit ad interiora saltu frequenti.	For when the vein is cut, blood issues forth with a pulsating flow that leaps frequently towards the interior parts.
Si autem arteria non apparet sensui, tunc oportet ut mensures ab aure quantitatem spacii trium digitorum.	But if the artery does not appear apparent to the senses, then you should measure from the ear the quantity of space equal to three fingers.
Deinde signa cum encaustro, et finde usque ad os.	Then mark with a hot iron and cut until it reaches the bone.
Et illud quod oportet emittere ex sanguine, est VI uncia et fortasse emittis ex eo plus, aut minus.	And what should be emitted from the blood is six ounces, but perhaps you may emit more or less than this amount.
Totum illud secundum quantitatem quae apparet tibi ex uirute infirmi et repletione arteriae eius.	All of this according to the quantity that appears to you depending on the strength of the patient and the fullness of their artery.
Deinde considera ad uulnus.	Then observe the wound.
Tunc si remanet ad os ex sifac aliquid, tunc incide illud, ut non accidat apostema calidum: tunc stringe uulnus cum liciniis ex panno lini.	If there remains anything on the bone from the spatula, then cut it off so that no hot abscess occurs. Then bind the wound with linens made of linen cloth.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with ointment until it heals.
¶ De extractione arteriarum, quae sunt in timporibus.	On the extraction of arteries that are in the temples
Caput III.	Chapter III
Quando accidit homini hemicranea antiqua, aut catarri acuti propter humiditates acrimoniales, et caliditate in lacertis timporum, aut soda antiqua, uehemens, et similia illis: et medicatur cum modis curationis medicinae, et non confert illud: tunc experti sumus in his aegritudinibus extractionem arteriarum ex timporibus, aut cauterizationem earum, sicut narrauimus.	When it happens to a person that they have an old headache, or sharp catarrhs due to acrid humidity and heat in the temples, or old soda, violent, and similar things: and medical treatment is applied with methods of medicinal care but it does not help, then we have found in these conditions extraction of arteries from the temples, or cauterization of them, as we have described.
Et modus operationis in extractione earum, est, ut radat infirmus pilos qui sunt in timporibus, et intendat ad arteriam apparentem in timpore.	The method of operating for extracting them is: the patient should remove the hairs that are on the temples and expose the visible artery in the temple
Ipsa namque ostenditur tibi ex pulsu suo, et raro occultatur nisi in paucis hominibus, aut uehementia frigoris.	For indeed it reveals itself to you by its own pulsation, and rarely is hidden except in a few people or cases of extreme cold.
Quod si occultatur tibi, tunc stringat infirmus caput suum cum quolibet panno suo: deinde frica locum cum panno aspero.	If it is hidden from you, then the patient should bind their head with any cloth they have, and then rub the place with a rough cloth.
Aut uapora locum cum aqua calida, donec appareat tibi apparitione manifesta.	Or heat the place with hot water until it appears to you in clear manifestation
Deinde accipe spatumile, quod paulo ante formaui.	Then take the scalpel which I prepared earlier
Deinde excoria cum eo cutem cum facilitate, donec peruenias ad arteriam.	Then gently remove the skin with it until you reach the artery
Deinde proiice in eam uncinum, et extrahe eam ad superiora, donec extrahas eam ex cute, et facias eam euadere ex tunicis quae sunt sub ea ab omni parte.	Then insert a hook into it and extract it upwards until you pull it out of the skin, and make it emerge from all the tissues that are under it on every side.
Si autem arteria est subtilis: tunc inuolue eam cum extremitate uncini.	If however the artery is small, then wrap it with the end of the hook
Deinde incide ex ea partem secundum quantitatem qua elongentur extremitates eius, et contrahantur, et non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	Then cut off from it as much length as its ends will stretch and contract without causing blood flow
Nam si non inciditur, et si non abscinditur, non ascendit sanguis penitus.	For if it is not cut nor severed, the blood will not completely rise.
Deinde euacua ex sanguine ana VI unci, usque ad .III.	Then squeeze out from the blood six ounces by means of a syringe up to three ounces
Quod si arteria est magna: tunc oportet ut liges eam in duobus locis ex filo duplo, forti, ex serico: aut ex chordis alhohod, ut non properet ad ipsam putrefactio ante consolidationem uulneris, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	But if the artery is large, then you should tie it in two places with a strong double thread made of silk or gut so that corruption does not precede the healing of the wound and blood flow occurs.
Deinde incide superfluitatem, quae est inter duo ligamenta.	Then cut into the bulging area between the two ligatures.
Fac illud in illa hora, aut post horam aliam.	Do this either immediately or at another time.
Et si uis, cauteriza eam cauterio usque ad os, cum cauterio cultellari: donec incidantur extremitates eius, et stabit loco eiusdem operis.	And if you wish, cauterize it with a cutting cautery until its ends are cut off and the wound is closed.
Et est melius opus, nisi si infirmus habet febrem, autest calefactae complexionis.	And it is better to do so unless the patient has a fever or is of hot temperament.
Quoniam cauterium est ex eis, quae iuuant ad finiendas humiditates.	For cautery is among those things that help to finish off moisture.
Ergo est melius iuuamentum.	Therefore it is better for healing.
Et oportet post extractionem arteriarum, ut impleatur locus cotto antiquo: et ponantur super ipsum puluilli decenter facti.	And after the removal of arteries, the location should be filled with cooked old salt; and a plaster made of flour should be applied over it.
Et post solutionem curetur cum medicinis siccis, quae faciunt nasci carnem, et cum liciniis, donec sanetur.	And afterwards, treat it with dry medicines that promote the growth of flesh and with bandages until it heals.
Quod si interim dum operaris accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, tunc propera ad abscindendum eum cum cauterio, aut ut impleas locum cum zegi: et stringe manum tuam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	But if bleeding occurs from the artery during the operation, then quickly cauterize it with a hot iron or fill the area with lint and press your hand tightly until the bleeding stops.
Quod si nihil ex illis est tibi praesens, tunc pone super locum digitum tuum, donec congeletur sanguis.	But if neither of these is available to you, then place your finger on the spot until the blood coagulates.
Et embroca locum cum aqua uehementis frigoris, donec quiescat acuitas, et stringatur secundum quod oportet.	And cool the area with ice-cold water until the inflammation subsides and it is bandaged appropriately.
Et ex eo quod est leuius et facilius extractione arteriae, est, ut cauterizes uenam cum hoc cauterio habente duos cultellos: sitque acuitas duorum cultellorum similis almagdatem.	And for a lighter and easier method of removing the artery, use a cautery with two blades, each having a sharp edge like an almond.
Verumtamen sunt multo minoris acuitatis, quam duo cultelli.	But they are much less sharp than two blades.
Quoniam si sunt acutae, sicut duo cultelli, properat utrisque frigus: et non incidunt carnem cum uelocitate.	For if they are as sharp as two blades, both will become cold quickly and will not cut the flesh quickly.
Cum ergo in eis est aliquantulum grossitudinis, tenetur in eis calor ignis, et abscinditur caro uelociter: cum hoc ergo opus est melius omni opere, et leuius, et facilius.	Therefore, because of their slight thickness, the heat of the fire is retained within them and flesh is cut quickly with this method, which is better than any other method, lighter, and easier to perform.
Et sit spacium quod est inter duos cultellos quantitas grossitudinis digiti, postquam tu signas duo loca cum encaustro: et depone utrosque ignitos ualde, donec perueniant ad os, et incidant uenam in duobus locis: ut elongetur quod est inter extremitates eius.	And let the space between two knives be equal to the thickness of a finger; after marking two places with cauterization: and place both burning strongly until they reach the bone, and cut into the vein at two points: so that what is between its ends may be elongated.
Nam non consolidantur cum hoc cauterio penitus.	For they are not completely sealed with this cautery.
Et haec est forma cauterii.	And this is the form of the cautery.
¶ De cura cursus lachrymarum acutarum assiduarum ab oculis.	Chapter: On the Treatment of Persistent Sharp Eye Pain
Caput IIII.	Chapter Four
Quando sunt lachrymae assiduae, et est cursus earum ex uenis, quae sunt super craneum capitis exterius: et non confert in eis aliquid curationis medicinae cum medicinis, et uides faciem infirmi iam rubere, et sentit in fronte sua deambulationem, sicut est deambulatio formicarum: et oculi eius sunt extenuati, humidi, ita quod iam corrosi sunt pili eorum cum corrosione: et calefactae sunt palpebrae eius ex acuitate lachrymarum: tunc antiqui indiguerunt in curatione earum hac operatione, et denominauerunt eam curationem, cum Ense.	When there are persistent tears and their course comes from veins that are on the outside of the skull of the head, and no cure is achieved with medications applied to them; and you see the face of the patient becoming red, and they feel a crawling sensation on their forehead like the movement of ants; and the eyes are thin, wet, so much so that the lashes have been eaten away by corrosion; and the eyelids are hot from the sharpness of the tears: then ancient practitioners sought this operation for the cure of such cases, and they named it "the treatment with an iron.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere pilos qui sunt in fronte sua.	And it is necessary to order the patient to shave the hairs that are on their forehead.
Deinde incide in fronte tres fissuras aequedistantes secundum longitudinem frontis: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo digiti, et fissura una sit aequedistans longitudini nasi in medio frontis, et secunda secundum longitudinem parumper a motu lacertorum, et tertia a parte altera: et caue ab incisione arteriarum quae sunt in duobus lateribus: et elonga manum tuam a continuatione duarum mandibularum, et sit spacium omnis incisionis quantitas trium digitorum coniunctorum: et sit tibi frustum spongiae praeparatum, aut panni siccati multi, cum quibus exsicces sanguinem.	Then make three incisions in the forehead equally spaced along its length; let each incision be about two fingers long, with one being equidistant from the nose at the middle of the forehead, and the second a little further from the movement of the eyebrows, and the third on the other side. Beware not to cut into the arteries that are on both sides. And keep your hand away from the continuation of the two jaws; let the distance of all incisions be equal to three connected fingers; and have ready a piece of sponge or dry cloths with which to absorb the blood.
Deinde intromitte spatumile duarum acutarum extremitatum, cuius mox sequens est forma.	Then insert the spatula of two pointed ends whose shape is as follows:
Ab incisione quae est a parte timporis, usque ad incisionem secundam: et excoria cum eo totam cutem, quae est inter duas incisiones, cum sifac, quod est super os.	From the first incision at the temple to the second incision: and remove with it the entire skin that is between the two incisions along with the sinew which is above the bone.
Deinde fac illud etiam ab incisione media usque ad incisionem secundam.	Then do this also from the middle incision up to the second incision.
Deinde extrahe hoc spatumile, et intromitte in incisionem primam iterum instrumentum aliud, quod nominatur cultellare acutum, ab una parte lene, non acutum ab altera parte.	Then extract this spatula and insert into the first incision another instrument called the sharp scalpel, blunt on one side, not sharp on the other.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its shape.
Et pone latus eius acutum uersus carnem annexam cum cute, et latus eius lene uersus os: et impelle ipsum, donec perueniat ad fissuram mediam: et abscinde cum eo omnia uasa, quae descendunt a capite ad oculos: praeter quod continuetur incisio usque ad illud quod apparet de cute.	And place its sharp edge towards the attached flesh with skin and its blunt edge towards the bone; and push it until it reaches the median fissure; and cut away with it all vessels that descend from the head to the eyes except for what is connected by the incision up to where skin appears.
Deinde fac illud in fissura media usque ad fissuram aliam.	Then do this in the median fissure up to the other fissure.
Et postquam currit ex sanguine quantitas aequalis, exprime loca ex frustis sanguinis coagulati.	And after an equal amount of blood flows out, express the places from clotted blood fragments.
Deinde pone in omnem fissuram licinium ex cotto ueteri, et pone super eos puluillos imbibitos in uino, et oleo, aut aceto.	Then place strips of old linen in every fissure and put on top of them wool pads soaked in wine, oil, or vinegar.
Et uide ut non accidat apostema calidum.	And see to it that no hot abscess occurs.
Et in die tertia solue ligamentum, et administra infusionem multam cum aqua tepida.	And on the third day, dissolve the stitches and apply a generous lotion with warm water.
Deinde cura illud ex unguento basilicon, et reliquis quibus curantur uulnera: usquequo sanetur.	Then dress it with balsam ointment and other remedies used for wounds until it heals.
¶ De cura lachrymarum acutarum et catarrorum ad oculos ex interioribus capitis.	Chapter On the Treatment of Acute Lachrymation and Cataracts in the Eyes from Internal Head Conditions
Caput V.	Chapter Five
Quando accidunt alicui catarri acuti, acres, assidui: et uides oculos eius extenuatos, paruos, et iam debilitatus est aspectus eorum: et palpebrae ulceratae, et cadunt pili ex eis, et in profundo capitis est dolor acutus, laedens, et sternutatio consequens: tunc sume ex istis accidentibus, quod illae materiae, et catarri non ueniunt, nisi ex uenis multis.	When acute cataracts occur to someone - sharp, persistent tears and you see their eyes are narrowed, small, and now weakened in appearance; eyelids ulcerated with hair falling out, and there is acute pain deep in the head causing coughing: then know that these materials and cataracts do not come from a few veins.
Et melior curatio in eis est haec.	And this is the best treatment for them.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere frontem suam.	And it is necessary to order the patient to shave their forehead.
Deinde incide in eam fissuram unam in medio frontis, aut alterius parumper per latitudinem, et incipe cum fissura a timpore sinistro ad timpus dextrum: et sit incisio usque ad os: et elonga manum tuam a lacertis timporum, qui mouentur apud masticationem: donec quando detegitur os: et exsiccabis totum sanguinem cum spongia.	Then make an incision in the middle of the forehead, or slightly to one side, and begin with the incision from the left temple to the right; it should be cut down to the bone. And extend your hand away from the temples that move during chewing until the bone is exposed. Then dry up all the blood with a sponge.
Tunc separa inter duo labia fissurae cum cotto ueteri, aut cum liciniis ex lino.	Then separate the two lips of the incision with a hot probe or linen wicks.
Deinde stringe desuper cum puluillis: et imbibe puluillos cum uino et oleo, ut non accidat apostema calidum.	Then bind it from above with bandages and moistened them with wine and oil so that no hot inflammation occurs.
Et quando soluis illud, et uides quod apostema calidum iam imminuitur: tunc oportet ut frices os, donec incipiat in eo nasci caro.	And when you loosen it and see that the hot swelling has begun to decrease, then you must scrape the bone until flesh begins to grow on it.
Deinde cura ipsum cum regimine exiccatiuo quod facit nasci carnem: sicut si accipias ex farina tritici partes duas, et ex colophonia quatuor partes: et praepares ex eis emplastrum, et administretur ad natiuitatem carnis in istis uulneribus.	Then treat it with a dry regimen that promotes the growth of flesh, such as this: take two parts of wheat flour and four parts of colophony, prepare an ointment from them, and apply it to the place where flesh is growing in these wounds.
¶ De cura eius quod cadit in Aurem.	[On the Treatment of Earache]
Caput VI.	Chapter 6
Omne Quod in Aurem cadit, est una quatuor specierum: aut lapis mineralis, aut simile lapidi, sicut ferrum, et uitrum: aut est ex planta, sicut est cicer, et fabae: aut est res fluxibilis, sicut aqua, et acetum, et eis similia: aut aliquod animal.	All things that fall into the ear are of four kinds: either a mineral stone, or something similar to stone, such as iron and glass; or it is from a plant, such as chickpeas and beans; or it is a fluid substance, like water and vinegar and the like; or some kind of creature.
Quando ergo cadit in aurem lapis, aut genus lapidis ex eis quae non adduntur, neque crescunt in aure, expone Aurem soli: si ergo uides lapidem, tunc distilla in Aurem aliquid ex oleo uiolato, aut sisamino.	When a stone or some similar substance that does not adhere or grow in the ear falls into it, expose the ear to the sun. If you see the stone, then instill some violet oil or myrrh into the ear.
Deinde administra extractionem eius, et fac sternutare cum condisi, et opila nares apud aduentum sternutationis, postquam tu ponis in circumitu auris frusta ex pannis, aut lana, et extendis aurem ad superiora.	Then perform the extraction and cause sneezing with condimentum. Plug the nostrils during sneezing. After that, place wads of cloth or wool around the ear and pull the ear upward.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum hac cura.	For it often comes out with this treatment.
Si autem non egreditur, tunc administra extractionem eius cum Gesti, id est, Pizigarolis subtilibus: cuius forma est haec.	But if it does not come out, then perform its extraction with the Gesti, that is, fine forceps; whose shape is as follows.
Si ergo egreditur cum gesti, est bonum.	If indeed it comes out with the forceps, it is good.
Et si non, tunc administra extractionem eius cum uncino caeco subtili paucae duplicationis.	And if not, then perform its extraction with a fine bent hook of little thickness.
Si ergo non egreditur per illud, tunc fac cannulam ex aere, et intromitte extremitatem cannulae in foramen auris multum, et opila quod est in circumitu cannulae cum caera mollificata cum oleo, ut non sit uento uia nisi cannulae: deinde extrahe cum uento tuo attractione forti.	If even then it does not come out, then make a cannula from bronze and insert its end into the ear deeply, and plug what is around the cannula with softened wax mixed with oil so that there may be no way for wind except through the cannula: then extract it by means of your strong breath attraction.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus.	For often it comes out with what we have described.
Si autem non egreditur hoc modo: tunc accipe ex helkalimbat, aut ex uisco, id est, gluten praeparato, cum quo capiuntur aues, rem modicam: et pone ipsum in extremitate radii postquam tu inuoluis super eam cotum decenter positum: deinde intromitte ipsum in foramen auris cum facilitate, postquam tu exiccas aurem ab humiditate.	But if it does not come out even this way: then take a little of helkalimbat or gluten prepared with which birds are caught: and place it on the end of the rod after you have properly wrapped cotton over it: then insert it into the ear opening gently, after you have dried the ear from moisture.
Si ergo non egreditur cum omnibus quae narrauimus, tunc propera ad scindendum, antequam accidat apostema calidum, aut spasmus.	If therefore it does not come out with all that we have described, then hasten to make an incision before there occurs a hot boil or spasm.
Et modus fissurae est, ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis in cephalica: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum mensuram uirtutis eius.	And the manner of incising is thus: first perform bloodletting on the patient at the cephalic vein and extract from him a certain amount of blood according to his strength.
Deinde fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et conuerte aurem eius ad superiora, et finde fissuram paruam in radice auris apud adipem eius in loco depresso ipsi: et sit fissura lunaris figurae, donec peruenias ad lapidem: deinde aufer eum cum eo, quod est tibi possibile ex instrumentis.	Then make the patient sit between your hands and turn his ear upwards, and make a small incision at the root of the ear near its fat in the depressed place; and let the incision be crescent-shaped until you reach the stone: then remove it with whatever instruments are possible for you.
Deinde sue fissuram ab hora tua cum uelocitate, et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then quickly suture the wound from your side with care, until it heals.
Quod si res cadens in aurem est ex uno granorum, quae crescunt, et inflantur: tunc administra extractionem eius.	But if what falls into the ear is one of those grains which grow and swell up, then perform its extraction.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc accipe spatumile tenue, subtile, secundum hanc formam.	But if it does not obey you for coming out, then take a thin, fine spatula according to this shape.
Et administra cum eo abscisionem illius speciei ex granis, quae cadunt in aurem, et non facias illud, quando tu cogitas, quod illud granum iam humectatum est per uaporem auris, donec ponis ipsum frusta multa: deinde extrahe ea cum uncinis, aut cum gesti subtili, aut cum suctione, sicut diximus, nam extractio eius alleuiatur.	And administer with it the removal of that kind from the grains which fall into the ear, and do not do this when you think that grain has already been moistened by the vapor of the ear until you put in many pieces: then remove them with hooks, or with a fine probe, or with suction, as we have said, for its extraction is eased.
In aqua autem quae ingreditur in aurem, oportet ut utatur infirmus sternutatione cum condisi in primis: et iam impleuit aurem suam cum aliquanto cotto ueteri: et est iacens super illam aurem, in qua est aqua.	But the water which enters the ear, it is necessary for the patient to use sneezing at first: and now he has filled his ear with some warm old oil: and he lies down on that ear in which there is water.
Si ergo egreditur per illud, est bonum.	If therefore it goes out through that (ear), it is good.
Et si non: tunc accipe lapides multos, secundum longitudinem digiti, tenues, lenes, et calefac eos cum igne parumper, et intromittat infirmus ex eis unum in foramen auris suae: et saliat super pedem suum unum ex illa parte, et percutiat cum lapide alio super lapidem qui est in aure.	And if not: then take many stones, according to the length of a finger, thin, soft, and warm them briefly with fire, and let the patient insert one among them into the opening of his ear: and let him jump on one foot from that side, and strike with another stone on the one which is in the ear.
Non ergo cesset facere illud cum lapide et lapide, donec egrediatur tota aqua.	Therefore he should not cease doing this with stone and stone until all water comes out.
Et iam egreditur aqua ita, ut accipias ex parpyro, aut ex iunco unum, et intromittas extremitatem eius unam in aurem: et accendas extremitatem alteram cum igne, donec comburatur plurimum eius.	And now water comes out thus, so that you take one from a feather or from a reed and insert its extremity into the ear: and light fire to its other extremity until it burns much.
Deinde itera iuncum alium, et fac illud multotiens, donec egrediatur tota aqua: et extrahe ipsam cum cannula secundum quod praemissum est in lapide.	Then repeat with another reed and do this many times until all water comes out: and remove it with a cannula as was said before about the stone.
In extractione autem animalis intrantis in eam, si est parui corporis, ut pulex, et ei simile, cura ipsum sicut dixi in diuisione.	But in removing an animal entering into it, if it is of small body, like a louse and the like, treat it as I said in division.
Sed si est corporis magni, quod appareat sensui: tunc administra extractionem eius cum gesti, et uncinis: et res eius est facilior omnibus, quae tenentur in aure.	But if it is of large body which appears to the sense: then administer its removal with a probe and hooks: and its matter is easier than all things held in the ear.
In extractione autem uermis generati in aure, quando curas eum cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et in tractatu distilationum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut aspicias aurem in sole.	But in removing a worm generated in the ear, when you treat it with what we said in division and in the treatise on distillations, and your treatment does not help: then it is necessary to look at the ear in the sun.
Si ergo apparet illic aliquid ex uermibus, tunc extrahe illud cum gesti, aut cum uncinis subtilibus.	If therefore something from among worms appears there, then remove it with a hook, or with fine forceps.
Si autem non apparet illic aliquid, tunc accipe cannulam, cuius haec est forma, stricta inferius, ampla superius: et intromitte extremitatem subtilem in aurem secundum quantitatem quod tolerat eam infirmus: deinde suge cum ea suctione forti.	But if nothing appears there, then take a cannula, which has this shape: narrow below, wide above; and introduce its fine extremity into the ear according to how much it can tolerate it in the sick person: then suck out with strong suction through it.
Fac illud multotiens, donec egrediantur omnes uermes.	Do this many times until all the worms come out.
Si autem non obediunt tibi ad exitum, tunc opila circumitum cannulae cum caera, sicut dixi in lapide.	But if they do not obey you to come out, then seal around the cannula with wax, as I said in the case of a stone.
Quod si non egrediuntur cum eo quod diximus: tunc administra distillationes quas iam experti sunt antiqui in interfectione uermium: et inuenies illud in tractatu distillationum.	But if they do not come out with what we said, then administer the distillations which the ancients have already proven effective in killing worms; and you will find it in the treatise on distillations.
Et sit effusio tua qua effundis olea et medicinas in aurem cum hoc instrumento, cuius forma depicta est hic.	And let your pouring out of oil and medicines into the ear be done with this instrument, whose shape is depicted here.
Sicut uides fac ipsum ex argento, aut aere, inferius strictum, in quo sit foramen paruum, amplum superius.	As you see, make it from silver or bronze, narrow below, having a small hole, wide above.
Sit ergo ut impellens quod est in concauitate cannulae, sit ex aere decenter factum.	Therefore let the plug which fits into the hollow of the cannula be well-made of bronze.
Et si uis, accipe radium, et inuolue in extremitate eius cottum inuolutione decenti: deinde proiice oleum, aut succum, aut quod uis ex istis medicinis in cannulam: et ipsa sit in aure: deinde intromitte radium cum cotto desuper, et exprime ipsum manu tua compressione temperata, donec impellatur oleum in concauitate auditus, et sentiat ipsum infirmus interius: et illud quod infunditur in aurem, sit iam calefactum cum igne parumper: et caue ne sit res quae distillatur in eam frigida ualde: medicinae enim non tolerant illud.	And if you wish, take a rod and wrap cotton on its extremity with proper wrapping; then pour oil or juice, or whatever of these medicines you wish into the cannula, while it is in the ear; then introduce the rod with cotton from above, and press it gently with your hand until the oil reaches the concavity of the ear, so that the sick person feels it inside. And let what is poured into the ear be warmed for a short time over fire, and be careful not to pour anything too cold into it: for medicines do not tolerate that.
¶ De cura opilationis accidentis Auri.	On the treatment of accidental perforation of the ear.
Caput VII.	Chapter VII
Quandoque egrediuntur quidam infantes ex uentribus matrum suarum non perforati.	Sometimes children are born from their mothers' wombs not pierced.
Et iam accidit etiam quibusdam hominibus opilatio in meatu Auris a uulnere, aut carne nata in ea.	And it has happened to some people that the ear is perforated by an injury or a birthmark of flesh therein.
Et haec opilatio quandoque fit in profundo foraminis Auris, quam non consequitur uisus: et quandoque accidit ad exteriora foraminis parum, et consequitur eam uisus.	And this perforation sometimes occurs in the deep hole of the ear, which is not visible; and sometimes it happens near the outer opening of the earhole, and is visible.
Illa ergo quae accidit in profundo Auris, et quam non comprehendit aspectus, est in pluribus dispositionibus difficilis sanationis.	Therefore, that which occurs in the depths of the ear, and which the eye cannot see, is in many cases difficult to cure.
Et in illa quam consequitur uisus, oportet ut ponas Aurem infirmi in sole, et aspicias in ea: tunc si uides opilationem apparentem, aperi eam cum spatumili subtili, cuius forma est haec quae sequitur, sit extremitas eius in qua sit quaedam latitudo parua, cuius quaedam pars sit acuta: et reliquum spatumile sit duarum laterum lenium: ut non laedat aurem.	And regarding that which is visible, you must place the sick person's ear in sunlight and examine it. If you see an apparent perforation, open it with a fine, pointed probe of such shape as follows: its tip should be slightly broad, with one part being sharp; the rest of the probe should have two smooth sides so as not to harm the ear.
Si ergo opilatio est a carne nata in meatu auris: tunc tene eam cum uncino subtili, et incide eam cum facilitate uehementi, donec auferatur tota caro.	If the perforation is caused by a birthmark of flesh in the ear canal, then grasp it with a fine hook and cut it off quickly and forcefully until all the flesh is removed.
Quod si opilatio est in profundo auris: tunc accipe radium subtilem, lenem, et calefac ipsum cum igne parumper: deinde mitte ipsum in meatum auris.	If the perforation is deep within the ear, then take a thin, smooth probe and heat it slightly with fire. Then insert it into the ear canal.
Si ergo senseris opilationem cum eo, quod inuenit infirmus cum grauitate auditus, conare apertionem eius cum facilitate: et caue, ne uulneres neruos auris.	If you feel the perforation with the probe and the patient experiences discomfort due to hearing loss, carefully attempt to open it; but beware lest thou wound the nerves of the ear.
Deinde pone in aurem licinium secundum quantitatem amplitudinis foraminis, quod inuoluisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud aliquot diebus, donec sis securus de consolidatione uulneris.	Then place a wisp of linen into the ear according to the size of the opening you have widened, soaked in Egyptian ointment. Do this for several days until you are sure that the wound has healed.
Aut accipe licinium, et infunde ipsum in aqua rosata, et pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, et utere ipso.	Or take a wisp of linen, dip it into rosewater, and sprinkle upon it some ground iris powder; use this.
Quod si uides aurem iam apostemari: tunc oportet ut extrahas licinium, et permittas ipsum cum licinio alio, quod inuolues in caeroto quod sit factum cum oleo rosato, donec sedetur apostema calidum: deinde cura ipsum usquequo sanetur.	If you see that the ear is now inflamed, then remove the linen wisp and allow it to cool with another one wrapped in a dressing made with rose oil until the inflammation subsides. Then treat it until it heals.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis: tunc submerge spongiam, aut pannos in aqua frigida, et pone super eam aurem: et utere reliqua curatione, quae abscindit fluxum sanguinis praedicta in tractatu distillationum.	If blood flow occurs, then dip a sponge or cloth in cold water and apply it to the ear. Use the remaining treatment described in the treatise on distillation to stop the bleeding.
¶ De cura Altheli palpebrarum.	Concerning the Treatment of Swelling of the Eyelids.
Caput VIII.	Chapter 8
Isti Althelil qui accidunt in Palpebris oculi, quandoque sunt humidi, et sunt sicci.	Eyelid swellings occur when they are moist or dry.
Oportet ergo ut teneas eos cum tenaliis: aut cum uncino, et incidas eos cum spatumili a radicibus suis.	Therefore, hold them with forceps or tweezers and cut them at their roots using scissors.
Deinde pone super loca zegi tritum.	Then apply crushed barley groats to the wounds.
Si autem ex eis fluat sanguis, tunc cauteriza eos cum cauterio lenticulari subtili.	But if blood flows from them, then cauterize the wounds with a fine lenticular cautery.
Et cauterizare eos, est melius post incisionem.	And it is better to cauterize them after cutting.
Multotiens enim redeunt quando remanet ex radicibus suis aliquid.	For they often return when something remains from their roots.
Et quando cauterizantur cum igne, comburuntur illae radices, et non redeunt.	And when they are cauterized with fire, those roots are burnt and do not return.
¶ De cura Grandinum palpebrarum oculi.	Concerning the Treatment of Puffiness of the Eyelids.
Caput IX.	Chapter 9
Multotiens accidit in palpebris aliquid quod assimilatur Crandini in fortitudine sua, et sua duricie, et propter illud nominatur Grando: et est aggregatio humiditatis grossae in palpebra superiore, et palpebra inferiore.	It often happens that there is something like hailstone (grando) in the eyelids due to its hardness and roughness, which is a collection of coarse humidity in the upper and lower eyelids.
Operatio ergo in eis est, ut consideres tunc, si est Grando procedens in eo, quod apparet de palpebra, et mouentur ad omnem partem, et res eius est facilis.	Therefore, if it appears that there is a hailstone-like swelling protruding from the eyelid and moves easily in all directions, then...
Finde ergo super eam fissura per latitudinem.	Make an incision along its width.
Deinde excoria eam ab omni parte cum facilitate, donec euadat.	Then strip it away gently from all sides until it comes out completely.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncino, et abscinde ipsam.	Then suspend it with tweezers and cut it off.
Si autem non praeparatur tibi abscisio eius, nisi postquam tu penetras palpebram cum incisione parumper, tunc nocet infirmo illud in aliquo.	But if you cannot remove it unless after making a small incision into the eyelid, then that will harm the patient somewhat.
Quod si fissura est magna: tunc aggrega ipsam cum sutura: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	If the incision is large, then close it with stitches and treat it until it heals.
Et si est parua, non superueniet tibi malum ex ea.	But if it is small, no harm will come to you from it.
Vnguentum enim restaurat ipsam, et incarnat eam.	For the ointment restores it and makes it flesh again.
Et si grando est decliuis ad interiora auris uersus superficiem intrinsecam, tunc inuersa palpebram, et suspende grandinem cum uncino: praeter quod indigeas incisione, et preme eam ab omni parte.	And if there is a stone inclining towards the inner ear from the surface, then invert the eyelid and hook out the stone; apart from this you may need an incision, pressing it on all sides.
Quod si elongatur palpebra per incisionem, non nocet illud in aliquo.	If the eyelid is elongated by the incision, no harm will come of it.
Deinde ablue oculum post incisionem grandinis, cum aqua salsa: et cura locum cum eo quod incarnat, donec sanetur infirmus.	Then rinse the eye after removing the stone with salt water and treat the place with flesh-making [ointment] until the sick is healed.
¶ De cura Axirnath palpebrarum.	On the care of the eyelids.
Caput X.	Chapter 10.
Axirnath est adeps qui generatur in tunicis palpebrae superioris: et plurimum quidem accidit illud pueris: et ipsum grauat oculos eorum, et accidunt eis catarri in matutinis, et non possunt intueri lumen solis, propterea, quod lachrymae properant ad eos, et propter illud uides eos discumbere super facies suas semper, et super eas dormiunt, et sunt palpebrae eorum sub superciliis humidae, quas iam cooperuit inflatio: et eminentia quidem Axirnath apparens est oculo, et quando tu premis locum cum digitis tuis, sentis Axirnath inter eos.	Axirnath is a fatty substance that is produced in the tunics of the upper eyelid, which occurs most frequently in children. It weighs down their eyes and causes them to have morning catarrh, so that they cannot look at the light of the sun because tears flow upon them, and therefore you see them always lying on their faces and sleeping on them, with their eyelids moist under the eyebrows, which are now covered by swelling; and indeed the prominence of Axirnath appears to the eye, and when you press the place with your fingers, you feel Axirnath between them.
Et modus operationis eius est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the way to operate is for the patient to lay his head on your lap.
Deinde accipe pannum lini, et praepara in eo licinia, et fac ex illo licinio circulum secundum quantitatem quod continet Axirnath ab omni parte.	Then take a linen cloth and prepare threads from it, and make from this thread a circle according to the size of that which contains Axirnath on all sides.
Deinde pone eum super eam, et preme cum digitis tuis ab omni parte, ut aggregetur Axirnath in medio circuli.	Then place it upon [the eyelid] and press with your fingers on all sides so that Axirnath collects in the middle of the circle.
Deinde finde in medio illius humiditatis cum spatumili incidente fissuras per latitudinem, et non sit fissura maior illa quae fit in phlebotomia in profundo.	Then make an incision in the midst of that moisture with a scalpel making cuts crosswise, and let not the cut be greater than that made in blood-letting in depth.
Aut oportet ut findas cutem totam, donec peruenias ad Axirnath in pluribus enim dispositionibus procedit Axirnath ex fissura secundum formam frusti pinguedinis albae.	Or else it is necessary to incise the skin entirely until you reach Axirnath, for in many cases Axirnath proceeds from the cut like a slice of white fat.
Extrahe ergo eam cum panno, quem infiltrasti inter digitos tuos ad exteriora: et tu reuoluis manum tuam ad dextram et sinistram, donec dispergatur: et caue, ne addas in fissura, ut non peruenias cum spatumili ad oculum, et laedas eum.	Therefore remove it with a cloth which you have moistened between your fingers outside; and you turn your hand to the right and left until it is dispersed; and beware that you do not add anything into the cut lest you reach with the scalpel to the eye and wound it.
Si autem non appareat tibi Axirnath in principio fissurae, tu addas in fissura parum cum facilitate, donec procedat Axirnath.	But if Axirnath does not appear at the beginning of the incision, you should gently insert a little more until Axirnath comes forth.
Deinde extrahe eam, sicut diximus.	Then remove it, as we have said.
Deinde submerge pannos in aceto et aqua, et pone eos super locum, et stringe eum cum puluillis.	Next immerse cloths in vinegar and water, and place them on the location, and bind it with bandages.
Et ex hominibus sunt qui terunt salem, et ponunt ipsum in concauitate fissurae, ut liquefiat quod remansit ex illa humiditate.	And among men there are those who grind salt, and put it into the hollow of the incision so that what remains of that moisture may be dissolved.
Deinde cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals.
Si autem accidat in loco apostema calidum, tune cura ipsum cum emplastris sedatiuis, donec sanetur.	But if a hot boil appears in the place, then treat it with soothing plaster until it heals.
¶ De modis Ataxmir oculi, id est, cum palpebra mollificatur oculi, unde fit ut rugetur sicut non debet.	Chapter on Methods of Treating Styes (Ataxmir) of the Eye.
Caput XI.	Chapter 11
Quando nascuntur in palpebris oculi pili additi praeter cursum sub pilis naturalibus, et antiquantur: tunc ipsi nocent oculo, et faciunt accidere modos aegritudinum, sicut lachrymas assiduas, et mollificationem palpebrarum, et albuginem, donec fit illud caussa destructionis oculi.	When extra hairs are born on the eyelids of the eye beyond their natural course and adhere: then they harm the eye and cause various diseases to occur such as constant tearing, inflammation of the eyelids, and whiteness until it becomes a cause of destruction for the eye.
Et Ataxmir quidem oculi curatur secundum quatuor modos.	And styes (Ataxmir) of the eye are treated according to four methods.
Aut per cauterium cum igne.	Or by cautery with fire.
Aut cum medicina acuta, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo cauterii.	Or with acute medicine, as prescribed in the chapter on cautery.
Aut curatur Ataxmir per incisionem et suturam.	Or styes are treated by incision and suturing.
Aut per cannas, secundum quod ego dicam.	Or by cupping, as I will describe.
Oportet ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	You must place the patient's head on your lap.
Deinde conuerte palpebram oculi manu tua sinistra.	Then turn the eyelid of the eye with your left hand.
Si ergo conuertitur, bonum est.	If it turns, that is good.
Et si non: intromitte acum in eam, in qua sit filum ab inferiori parte palpebrae, et fac penetrare acum cum filo desuper, et sit illud prope pilos ipsos, id est, prope marginem palpebrae, in quo nascuntur pili: et trahe filum ad superiora cum palpebra, et conuerte eam cum radio.	And if it does not turn: insert a needle into it, where there is thread from the lower part of the eyelid, and cause the needle to penetrate with the thread from above, and let it be near the hairs themselves, that is, near the margin of the eyelid, in which the hairs grow: and pull the thread upwards with the eyelid, and turn it with a spatula.
Deinde finde in interiori parte palpebrae sub pilis additis cum spatumili incidente a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus.	Then find inside the eyelid under the hairs added with a spatula incident from the greater lacrimal to the lesser lacrimal.
Deinde extrahe filum, et pone sub palpebra puluillum paruum ex cotto, aut panno: deinde signa super palpebram cum encaustro, quod sit sicut figura folii myrti.	Then pull out the thread, and place under the eyelid a small piece of cotton or cloth. Then mark above the eyelid with cauterization, which should be like the shape of a myrtle leaf.
Verumtamen oportet, ut fit figura secundum quantitatem et eleuationem palpebrae: quoniam iam diuersificatur illud in hominibus.	But it is necessary that the figure be made according to the quantity and elevation of the eyelid: because it varies greatly among people.
Ex eis enim est, qui indiget ut incidatur ex palpebra quantitas magna, secundum quantitatem quae mollificatur a palpebra.	For those who require a large incision from the eyelid, according to the amount that is softened by the eyelid.
Deinde cum spatumili finde super duas lineas quas signasti, et incipe a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus, et sit fissura una prope pilos naturales, sicut est grossitudo radii.	Then with the spatula find above the two lines which you have marked, and begin from the greater lacrimal to the lesser lacrimal, and let there be one slit near the natural hairs, like the thickness of a needle.
Deinde intromitte uncinum in uno duorum angulorum cutis.	Then insert a hook into one of the two angles of the skin.
Deinde excoria ipsam totam.	Then strip off all of it.
Deinde aggrega cum sutura duo labia, cum acu et filo lana subtili: et absterge sanguinem, et fac adhaerere quod superfluit ex filis super duo supercilia, cum quibusdam rebus inuiscantibus, si uis facere illud: et si non, non cures.	Then bring together with sutures the two lips with a needle and fine wool thread: and wipe away the blood, and make it adhere that which overflows from the threads over the two eyebrows, with certain adhering substances if you wish to do so. And if not, do not worry about it.
Deinde dimitte suturam et fila usque ad tres dies, aut quatuor: postea cura illud.	Then leave the suture and threads for three days or four: afterwards care for it.
Et si uis, dimitte uulnus absque sutura, et cura ipsum cum eo, quod exsiccat et constringit.	And if you wish, leave the wound without a suture, and cure it with that which dries and contracts it.
Nam palpebra eleuatur apud sigillationem uulneris et aggregationem eius: sed futura est melior.	For the eyelid will be raised at the time of cauterization of the wound and its union: but the future one will be better.
Hunc modum curandi Ataxmir docuerunt antiqui.	This method of treatment was taught by the ancients called Ataxmir.
Verumtamen in eo est sollicitudo super infirmum, et est ex bona operatione, et non est in eo timor.	But there is concern about the sick person in it, and it comes from a good action, and there is no fear in it.
Et modus alius est in Ataxmir etiam: et est, ut signes super palpebram figuram, quae sit sicut figura folii myrti, sicut narrauimus.	And there is another method according to Ataxmir: which is to mark on the eyelid a shape like that of a myrtle leaf, as we have described.
Deinde eleua palpebram cum tribus uncinis separatis, aut aggregatis, secundum formam hanc quae sequitur, deinde incide quod superfluit cum forficibus paruis, secundum hanc formam, cum aequalitate incisionis.	Then raise the eyelid with three separate or joined hooks according to this following shape. Then cut off what is superfluous with small forceps, according to this shape, with equal cuts.
Si autem non est tibi possibile tenere uncinum, et non aequatur illud: tunc accipe acum in qua sit filum, et intromitte ipsum in medio figurae: et intromitte filum aliud prope lachrymale maius, et filum secundum prope lachrymale minus: et aggrega inter digitos tuos fila cum aequalitate.	But if it is not possible for you to hold the hook and equalize it, then take a needle with thread on it and insert it into the middle of the shape. Then insert another thread near the larger lachrymal duct and another thread near the smaller one, and hold the threads between your fingers with equality.
Deinde eleua manum tuam eleuatione aequali: et eleua cutem super quam est signatum cotum, sicut narrauimus.	Then raise your hand with equal elevation and raise the skin above which is marked out, as we have described.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then join the two lips of the wound with stitching and care for it until it heals.
Si uero accidat apostema apud incisionem tuam, aut fissuram tuam: seda illud apostema cum caeroto, et his similibus, ex unguentis sedantibus.	But if swelling occurs at your incision or cut, cauterize it with caustic and similar medicines from soothing ointments.
Et quandoque accidit palpebrae etiam, ut conuertantur pili eius.	And sometimes it happens that the eyelids become turned inward so that their hairs face outward.
Oportet ergo ut utaris in ea quod diximus in incisione: sed sutura utrisque magis est artificialis.	Therefore you should use what we have said for the incision, but stitching is more necessary on both sides.
¶ De cura Ataxmir cum cannis.	§ On the treatment of Ataxmir with reeds.
ET Est, ut conuertas palpebram, et scindas fissuram quae est deintus, secundum quod narraui.	And it is to turn over the eyelid and split open the fissure that is inside, as I have described.
Deinde arte fac duas cannas, aut duo ligna subtilia: quarum longitudo sit secundum longitudinem palpebrae, et latitudo earum sit minor latitudine spatumilis: et tu iam incidisti in extremitatibus utriusque ab utrisque partibus ubi tenes fila.	Then skillfully make two reeds or thin sticks. Their length should be equal to the length of the eyelid and their width less than the width of a fingerbreadth. And you have already cut them at both ends where you hold the threads.
Deinde aggrega utramque cum subtilitate super illud quod superfluit ex palpebra oculi, et stringe duas cannas ab utrisque partibus strictura forti, et dimitte eam diebus aliquot.	Then gently place both of them on top of the eyelid's excess and tightly tie them at both ends with a strong knot. Leave it like this for several days.
Cutis enim stricta morietur, et denigrabitur, et putrefiet, donec cadet per se.	For the skin being bound will die, darken, and decay until it falls off by itself.
Si ergo tardatur, tunc incide eam cum forficibus.	If it is delayed [in falling off], then cut it with forceps.
Deinde cura eam, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals.
Cum ergo consolidatur, eleuatur palpebra: et non pungunt pili.	When it has solidified, raise the eyelid, and hairs will not sting [the eye].
Et haec est forma duarum cannarum, quas facies secundum hanc figuram, et quantitatem in longitudinem et latitudinem.	And this is the shape of the two reeds that you should make according to this figure and measurement in length and width.
¶ De eleuatione pilorum pungentium in oculo cum acu.	§ On raising stinging hairs from the eye with a needle
Caput XII.	Chapter 12
Operatio in illo est, ut accipias acum subtilem, et intromittas in eam filum ex serico subtile, lene.	The operation is as follows: Take a fine needle and insert into it a thread of soft silk.
Deinde aggreges extremitates eius, et nodes utramque nodo subtili ualde: et sit longitudo filorum palmus unus.	Then tie its ends with two fine knots, making the length of the threads one palm [about 7-8 inches].
Deinde compone in Alinxotati filum aliud subtile sub eo in breui, et noda extremitates eius si uis.	Then place another thin thread underneath it briefly and tie its ends if you wish.
Deinde ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo, et sit prope solem ut declaretur operatio: quoniam est operatio subtilis, uel minuta.	Then have the patient place their head in your lap facing the sun so that the operation may be well lit since it is a delicate and precise procedure.
Deinde intromitte acum cum alinxotati in radicem palpebrae, et fac eam penetrare in palpebram festinanter, donec extrahas eam desuper pilum naturalem.	Then insert the needle with its thread into the root of the eyelid and quickly pierce it through until you extract a natural hair from above.
Deinde trahe pilum usque supra alinxotati: et intromitte in alinxotati illum pilum: si est unus, aut duo, aut tres, non plures.	Then pull the hair up along with the thread and insert it into the thread. If there is one or two or three hairs, that's enough; no more than that.
Deinde trahe manum tuam cum eo, donec egrediatur pilus cum alinxotati in palpebra cum pilo naturali.	Then pull your hand along with it until the hair comes out of the eyelid together with the thread and the natural hair.
Si autem trahatur alinxotati, et non egrediatur pilus cum ea: trahes alinxotati ad inferiora, cum filo quod tu composuisti in ea, donec egrediatur alinxotati ex foramine superiori, et uideas eam uisione oculi: tunc enim trahes alinxotati, et filum: et extrahe utraque, et claude oculum: et dimitte ipsum clausum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec adhaereat pilus loco suo, et nascatur super ipsum caro.	But if the thread is pulled but no hair comes out with it, then pull the thread down along with the one you composed in it until the thread emerges from above and you see it through the eye. Then pull both the thread and the silk and remove them both, close the eye, and leave it closed for two or three days until the hair adheres to its place and flesh grows over it.
Quod si pilus est breuis, tunc aut associa ei pilum longum ex pilis naturalibus, et eleuatur cum eo: aut dimitte ipsum, donec elongetur post spacium, et tunc eleua ipsum.	If the hair is short, then either attach a long hair made from natural hairs to it and raise them both together, or leave it alone until it grows longer, and then raise it.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae accidit in palpebra superiori.	On the Treatment of Silkworm Disease Which Occurs on the Upper Eyelid.
Caput XIII.	Chapter 13.
Quando accidit oculo haec Alxatrati, nominatur Leporina.	When this condition occurs in the eye, it is called "leporina" (rabbit disease).
Et haec Alxatrati est aut naturalis, aut accidentalis.	And this silkworm disease is either natural or accidental.
Accidentalis ergo fit ex consolidatione uulneris, aut sectionis, aut cauterii, et similium illis.	Accidental silkworm disease occurs from the consolidation of a wound, or incision, cautery, and similar causes.
Et modus operationis in ea est, ut tu findas illam consolidationem, et ut separes labia eius, et ponas in eo quod est inter ea licinium ex lino, et liges eam, donec sanetur.	And the method of treatment for it is to find that consolidation and separate its lips, then place a linen wick soaked in oil between them, and bind it until it heals.
Et non oportet, ut utaris in curatione eius rebus quae exiccant et constringunt: nam si tu facis illud, redit Alxatrati deterior quam fuit: imo utere in ea rebus quae mollificant, sicut foenumgraecum: et embroca cum aqua, in qua cocta sit althea, semen lini: et unguento dyaquilon, quod liquefactum sit cum aliquo ex oleis: et inuolue cum eo licinium, et cura cum eo.	And do not use drying and constricting agents in its treatment, for if you do so, the silkworm disease will worsen. Instead, use softening agents such as fenugreek, and mix it with water in which marshmallow seeds have been cooked. Also, use dyaquilon ointment mixed with some oil and wrap a linen wick in it for treatment.
Et thesaurus curationis tuae est, ut coneris omni ingenio, ut non consolidetur, secundum formam quae fuit in primis.	And the treasure of your treatment is to strive by every means possible that no consolidation occurs again according to its original shape.
Et haec quidem operatio quam diximus, non est nisi quaedam rectificatio Alxatrati, ut non redeat forma loci secundum quod fuit omnino.	And indeed this operation we have described is merely a correction of the silkworm disease so that its original shape does not return entirely.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae fit in palpebra inferiori, et est rugatio uel contractio sursum ad dextrum et sinistrum.	On the Treatment of Silkworm Disease Which Occurs on the Lower Eyelid and is a Wrinkle or Contraction Upward Towards the Right or Left.
Caput XIIII.	Chapter XIV.
Haec Alxatrati quae fit inferius, est quae uere nominatur Alxatrati.	This, which occurs below, is truly called Alxatrati.
Et est naturalis, et est accidentalis.	And it is natural, and it is accidental.
Et accidentalis fit ex uulnere, aut fissura, aut cauterio, et illis similibus.	And the accidental kind happens from a wound, or a cut, or a burn, and similar things.
Et uia operationis in ea est, ut accipias acum, in qua sit filum duplum, et tingas eam in carnem, et facias eam penetrare a lachrymali sinistro usque ad lachrymale dextrum, donec perueniat filum in duabus extremitatibus carnis.	And the way to operate on it is: take a needle with a double thread and stain it with flesh, and make it pierce from the left tear duct until it reaches the right, so that the thread comes out at both ends of the flesh.
Deinde extende carnem ad superiora cum acu, et incide eam cum spatumili lato.	Then stretch the flesh upwards with the needle and cut it with a wide-mouthed scissors.
Si ergo redit figura palpebrae secundum quod oportet, est bonum.	If therefore the shape of the eyelid returns as it ought to be, then it is good.
Et si non, accipe radium, et pone ipsum in fissuram, et conuerte cum eo palpebram: et finde duas fissuras in latere interiore palpebrae, et sint extremitates duarum fissurarum ex duobus angulis incisionis, donec concurrant et fiat ex eis angulus: donec quando aggregantur fiat figura earum haec figura, et est litera lauda graeca.	But if not, take a rod and place it in the slit, and turn the eyelid with it. Then make two cuts on the inner side of the eyelid, and let the ends of the two cuts meet to form an angle until they converge into this shape: which is the Greek letter lambda.
Deinde aufer illam carnem per quantitatem, quod est latus eius acutum inferius, ab eo quod sequitur palpebram.	Then remove that flesh by the amount of its sharp lower edge from what follows the eyelid.
Deinde aggrega partes separatas: sue eam cum filo lanae.	Then join the separated parts together: either with thread and wool.
Deinde cura eas cum eo quod diximus, de medicinis mollificantibus, et liciniis, donec sanentur.	Then care for it with what we have said about softening medicines and bandages until they heal.
Et si Alxatrati accidat ex fissura, et sutura, aut cauterio: tunc oportet ut findas fissura plana sub pilis palpebrarum, etiam secundum quod praecessit.	And if alxatrati occurs from a cut or stitching or burning, then you must make a flat cut under the eyelashes, following what has gone before.
Deinde separa inter duo labia cum licinio, secundum quod diximus.	Then separate between the two lips with a bandage, as we have said.
Et summa sermonis de cura Alxatrati, quando est desuper, aut inferius, est, ut currat in ea operatio, secundum quod praeparatur ex forma Alxatrati.	And in summary, the treatment of alxatrati whether it is above or below is that the operation should follow the form of alxatrati as prepared.
Ipsa namque est multarum diuersitatum in forma: et artifex prudens praeparat ingenium cum quocunque modo est possibile ei, donec redire faciat figuram ad formam naturalem, aut prope eam, et ipsemet infirmus, secundum quod conuenit ei ex operatione et instrumentis in plurimis dispositionibus.	For indeed it has many diverse forms, and a skillful artist prepares his ingenuity with whatever method is possible to him until he brings back the figure to its natural form or close to it, and himself weakens according to what suits him from the operations and instruments in many dispositions.
¶ De adhaerentia palpebrae oculi cum coniunctiua, aut cornea.	About the adhesion of the eyelid with the conjunctiva or cornea.
Caput XV.	Chapter XV.
Quandoque accidit haec consolidatio multis hominibus, ita ut consolidetur palpebra superior cum albedine oculi, et prohibeat ipsum ab operationibus suis naturalibus.	It often happens that this solidification occurs in many people, such that the upper eyelid becomes solid with the whiteness of the eye and prevents it from its natural operations.
Oportet ergo quod intromittas extremitatem radii sub palpebra, et eleues eam sursum: aut extendas eam cum uncino: deinde incide adhaerentiam cum spatumili subtili, quod non sit cum acuitate incisionis spatumilium, imo sit obtusum parumper: ut non inquietetur infirmus apud operationem, et remoueatur spatumile, et laedat oculum cum acuitate sua: et sit incisio tua quasi tu excories illam adhaerentiam cum facilitate, donec quando redit palpebra secundum formam suam naturalem, et sanetur adhaerentia tota.	Therefore, you should insert the tip of a needle under the eyelid and lift it up or extend it with a hook: then cut the adhesion with a spatula that is not sharp at its edge but rather blunt for a moment: so that the patient is not disturbed during the operation, and the spatula is removed, and does not harm the eye with its sharpness. And your incision should be as if you are scraping off that adhesion easily until when the eyelid returns to its natural form and the adhesion is completely healed.
Funde tunc in oculum aquam salsam, cum aqua ablue ipsum: aut distilla in ipsum ex sief facto, ex ziniar dissoluto cum aqua.	Then pour salt water into the eye, rinse it with water: or distill onto it from a sieve made by dissolving tin with water.
Deinde separa inter palpebram et oculum cum licinio lini: et pone super oculum lanam infusam cum albugine oui: et post diem tertium utere sief, et cum solidatiuis, donec sanetur.	Then separate between the eyelid and eye with a linen thread: and place over the eye wool soaked in egg white: and after three days use it again, and with consolidatives until it is healed.
¶ De incisione ungulae et eminentiae carnis lachrymarum.	About incising the nail and the protuberance of tear skin.
Caput XVI.	Chapter XVI.
Scias, quod ungula est secundum duos modos.	You should know that a nail is in two ways:
Aut est neruosa: et est similis sifac duro, subtili.	Either nerve-like: and it is similar to the sinew of an ass, hard and thin.
Aut est non neruosa, similis humiditati congelatae albae: quae quando tangit cam ferrum, aut conaris capere eam cum uncino, abscinditur, et non figitur in ea uncinus.	Or it is not nerve-like, similar to frozen white moisture which when touched by iron or hooked by a hook breaks off and the hook does not stick to it.
Et utraeque species non incipiunt, nisi a lachrymali maiore, usquequo uadit paulatim, donec cooperit uisum, et prohibet lumen, et motum oculi.	And both kinds do not begin unless from the greater tear duct until gradually they reach to cover sight and prohibit light and movement of the eye.
Et modus operandi in incisione eius est: ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the manner of operation for its incision is: that the sick person places their head on your lap.
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et eleua palpebram manu tua.	Then open their eyes and lift the eyelid with your hand.
Deinde collige ungulam cum uncino paucae duplationis, et extende eam ad superiora.	Then grasp a claw [forceps] with a small hook and extend it upwards.
Deinde accipe acum, et intromitte in eam pilum ex pilis equi, et bouis, aut uaccae: et sit filum forte, et duplica extremitatem acus parumper, et fige eam in medio ungulae: et penetra eam cum acu, et liga cum filo ungulam, et extende eam ad superiora: et excoria cum pilo latus ungulae quod sequitur pupillam, ac si tu serres eam cum pilo usque ad postreimnum eius.	Then take a needle and insert into it a thread made from horse, ox, or cow hair; make the thread strong and double the tip of the needle briefly, and fix it in the middle of the claw; then pierce through with the needle and tie the claw with the thread, extend it upwards; and scrape off with the thread the side of the claw that follows the pupil, as if you grasp it with the thread up to its end.
Deinde incide residuum in radice lachrymalis cum spatumili subtili, aut cum forficibus paruis: et dimitte carnem lachrymalis naturalem, ut non accidat ex incisione eius cursus lachrymarum assiduus.	Then cut the remaining part at the root of the lachrymal duct with a fine spatula or small forceps, and leave the natural flesh of the lachrymal duct so that its course is not constantly disrupted by the incision.
Et quandoque extenditur ungula cum uncino solo: aut cum filo, sicut diximus.	And sometimes the claw is extended only with a hook or with a thread, as we have said.
Deinde excoriatur cum spatumili leni, cuius haec est forma.	Then scrape it off gently with a spatula, of which this is the shape:
Et caue, ne tangat spatumile tunicam corneam, et accidat in ea ruptura, et perforetur pupilla.	And beware lest the spatula touch the corneal tunic and cause a rupture or perforation of the pupil.
Deinde post incisionem, proice in oculum aliquid salis contriti, aut ex sief facto ex ziniar, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Then after the incision, sprinkle some powdered salt or sulfur into the eye and leave it until the following day.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet, usquequo sanetur.	Then treat it with what is necessary until it heals.
Quod si ungula est non neruosa, et non potes intromittere in eam acum, neque figitur in ea uncinus, tunc multotiens curatur haec species ungulae cum medicinis, et sanatur sicut narraui in diuisione.	But if the claw is not nerve-like and you cannot insert a needle into it or fix a hook on it, then this kind of claw is treated many times with medicines until it heals, as I have described in the division [of the book].
Quod si uis incidere eam, tunc aperi oculum infirmi, et accipe spatumile subtile, lene, debilis acuitatis, secundum hanc formam.	But if you wish to cut it, then open the eye of the sick person and take a fine, gentle, blunt spatula according to this shape.
Et rade ungulam desuper rasione cum subtilitate.	And scrape gently from above with precision.
Quod si uides quod ipsa rarificatur et confringitur, et imprimit in eam rasio, tunc distilla ex hora tua in oculum ex sief facto ex ziniar, aut ex sief rubeo, aut sale trito: et opila oculum usque ad diem alium.	But if you see that it is becoming hollowed out and broken up, and the scraping impresses upon it, then instill into the eye from your hourglass either of camphor or red lead, or ground salt; and bandage the eye until the next day.
Deinde itera super ipsam operationem, donec remoueatur totum eius.	Then repeat the same procedure until all of it is removed.
Nisi contrarium sit tibi in oculo apostema calidum: tunc enim dimitte ipsam, et cura apostema, donec sanetur.	But if you find that there is a warm abscess in the eye, then leave it alone and treat the abscess until it heals.
Deinde itera operationem super ipsam cum rasione, donec sanetur.	Then repeat the procedure upon it with caution until it heals.
Eminentia autem carnis lachrymalis, si nocet in oculo nocumento magno, suspendatur cum uncino, et incide ex ea partem eius: et non ultimes incisionem, ut non accidat cursus lachrymarum.	However, if the prominence of the lacrimal caruncle is causing great harm to the eye, it should be suspended with a hook and cut away from its part; but do not make the final cut so as not to interrupt the flow of tears.
Deinde stilla in lachrymale sief rubeum, aut factum ex ziniari, donec sanetur.	Then instill into the lacrimal duct camphor or made from galbanum until it heals.
¶ De incisione Alguardenic, et carne nata in oculo.	On the Incision of a Pterygium and Fleshy Growth on the Eye.
Caput XVII.	Chapter 17.
Nascitur quandoque in quibusdam oculis hominum caro rubea composita, uel superposita, donec cooperit pupillam, aut appropinquat, aut stringit super palpebras, et fortasse conuertit palpebras ad exteriora: et assimilatur rosae balaustinae.	A red fleshy growth sometimes arises in the eyes of certain people, covering or approaching the pupil, or drawing close to and even attaching itself to the eyelids, perhaps turning them outward; it resembles a mushroom.
Et operatio in ea etiam est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the procedure for this is that the patient should place their head in your lap.
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et collige illam carnem totam cum uncinis conuenientibus ad illud: et tene illud cum forcipe uno, aut gesti.	Then open the eyes and gather up all of that flesh with appropriate hooks; hold it with forceps or tweezers.
Deinde incide carnem in primis, donec finiatur totum eius cum incisorio.	Then cut into the flesh first until all of it is severed with a knife.
Et caue ab oculo, ut non laedas ipsum apud operationem: et sit incisio tua qua ipsam incidis, aut cum spatumili, quod narrauimus in incisione ungulae: aut cum forficibus paruis, cum quibus colligitur asebel, secundum quod ueniet forma eius post hoc capitulum.	And be careful not to injure the eye during the operation; let your cut be either with a spatula, as described in the cutting of the nail, or with small forceps, with which the eyelid is held according to what will come later in this chapter.
Cum ergo completur incisio tua, et remouetur tota alguardenici, tunc imple oculum ex sale contrito: aut distilla in eum puluerem rubeum, et similia illi ex medicinis corrosiuis: et pone super oculum deforis cottum cum albugine oui: ut securetur ab apostemate calido.	After your cut is completed and the entire algaradenica has been removed, then fill the eye with ground salt or distill into it red powder and similar corrosive medicines. And place over the eye externally a poultice of cotton with egg white so that it may be secured from hot inflammation.
Quod si remanet ex alguardenici aliquid, et dominatur tibi sanguis calidus, et times apostema calidum: tunc dimitte oculum, et cura ipsum cum eo quod sedat apostema.
