But if some of the algaradenica remains and you are troubled by hot blood and fear a hot inflammation, then leave the eye alone and treat it with what allays inflammation.
Deinde itera super ipsum cum operatione, donec sanetur.	Then repeat the procedure on it until it is healed.
Et similiter fac cum carne addita quae accidit in oculo ex hac specie.	And do likewise for any flesh that happens to be added in the eye of this type.
Verumtamen oportet, ut alienes curationem omnis oculi debilis ex uia naturali, aut ex uia accidentali, operando cum ferro: et non intromittas manum tuam in aliqua harum operationum, donec uideas, quod illud membrum est tolerans illam operationem.	But it is necessary that you not undertake any operation on an unhealthy eye by the natural way or the accidental way using iron until you see that that member can endure that operation.
¶ De collectione Sebel ex oculo.	On the Extraction of a Foreign Body from the Eye.
Caput XVIII.	Chapter 18
Sebel sunt uenae rubeae quae texuntur super oculum, et prohibent uisui operationem suam: et debilitant oculum cum longitudine dierum.	A foreign body is a red vein that covers over the eye and hinders its vision and weakens the eye with the passage of days.
Necesse est ergo tibi in primis, ut consideres, si oculus in quo est Sebel, est fortis, et non est in eo aegritudo aliqua, praeter Sebel: tunc collige Sebel eius.	Therefore it is necessary for you to first examine whether the eye in which there is a foreign body is strong and not affected by any other ailment besides the foreign body. Then extract its foreign body.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo.	And it is necessary that you instruct the sick person to place their head on your bosom.
Deinde suspende illas uenas cum uncino uno, aut duobus secundum prudentiam tuam: et sit uncinus subtilis duplationis, secundum hanc formam, aut sint duo uncini gradat in corpore uno, secundum hanc formam.	Then suspend those veins with one or two hooks according to your discretion; and let the hook be slender and doubled in this shape, or let there be two hooks graduated on one body in this shape.
Deinde collige cum forficibus subtilibus illas uenas cum subtilitate, et absterge sanguinem hora post horam, donec uideas illas uenas remoueri ex oculo, et resoluuntur: et caue ne laedas oculum cum extremitatibus spatumilis.	Then carefully grasp those veins with fine forceps and remove blood little by little until you see those veins removed from the eye and resolved. And be careful not to injure the eye with the edges of the spatula.
Et sit operatio tua in meridie coram sole, et sis firmus in operatione tua ualde: ut non incidas nisi illas uenas.	And let your operation take place at midday before the sun, and be very steady in your operation so that you do not prick except those veins.
Et cum tu expleueris, tunc distilla in oculum sief uiride, aut rubeum: ut sua acuitate corrodat quod remansit ex sebel.	And when you have finished, then drip into the eye either green or red [dye], so that its sharpness may corrode what remains of the sebaceous matter.
Si autem non est tibi possibile colligere illud totum in illa hora, tunc emplastra oculum cum eo, quod sedat dolorem oculi: et dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sedetur dolor eius: et securetur ab apostemate calido: deinde itera super ipsum secundum modum eundem, donec sanetur.	But if it is not possible for you to remove the whole of it in that hour, then apply a plaster to the eye with something that alleviates eye pain. And let him rest for several days until his pain subsides and he is secure from hot inflammation. Then repeat on him according to the same method until he is healed.
Et haec est forma forficis.	And this is the shape of the forceps.
¶ De reductione Arissati ad nasum.	Chapter: Reduction of a Dislocation of the Nose.
Caput XIX.	Chapter 19.
Nominant medici Arissati Fistulam, quam curas cum cauterio, aut cum medicina acuta comburente, secundum quod praecessit eius narratio.	The physicians call it 'Fistula,' which you treat either with a caustic or with burning medicine, according to its previous description.
Et si non sanatur, tunc non est ingenium in ea: nisi ut findas super apostema apud natiuitatem eius, et extrahas totam humiditatem quae est in eo et pus, donec detegatur os.	And if it does not heal, then there is no cure for it except that you cut over the swelling at its beginning and draw out all the moisture and pus that is in it until the bone is exposed.
Cum ergo detegitur os, et uides in eo corruptionem, aut nigredinem, tunc rade ipsum cum instrumento, cuius forma est haec.	When therefore the bone is exposed, and you see decay or blackness in it, then scrape it with an instrument whose shape is as follows:
Et nominatur Asperi capitis.	And it is called 'Aspersory.'
Fiat ex ferro indo, et sit caput eius rotundum sicut azir, quod sit punctatum punctatione limae, aut punctatione aliskilferi punctatione subtili: et pone ipsum super locum corruptum ossis.	It should be made of hard iron, and its head should be round like a pea, which is pierced with a fine point either by a file or an awl. And place it on the corrupted part of the bone.
Deinde reuolue ipsum inter digitos tuos, et tu preme manum tuam parumper, donec scias quod illa corruptio iam rasa est: et fac illud aliquotiens.	Then revolve it between your fingers and press your hand gently until you know that the decay is scraped away. And do this several times.
Deinde restaura locum cum medicinis exiccatiuis stipticis.	Then restore the place with drying astringent medicines.
Si ergo consolidatur locus, et nascitur in eo caro, et abscinditur cursus saniei: et remanet quadraginta diebus, et non renouatur, et non apostematur, et non accidit in eo accidens: tunc scias quia iam sanatus est.	If therefore the place is consolidated and flesh grows there and the flow of pus is cut off, and it remains for forty days without reappearing or swelling up, then know that it is already healed.
Et si non, tunc non est in eo ingenium, nisi reducere fistulam ad foramen nasi, secundum hanc formam.	And if not, then there is no cure except to reduce the fistula to the nasal aperture according to this method.
Et est, ut detegas ab osse secundo cum ferro, aut cum medicina acuta: et cum detectum est os, tunc accipe terebrum secundum hanc formam, sit extremitas ferrea, triangulata: et lignum eius sit pyramis extenuata usque ad extremitatem, sicut uides.	And this is how you bare the bone with iron or with a sharp medicine. And when the bone is laid bare, then take an awl of this shape, its extremity being triangular and made of iron, and let its wood be tapered to a point as shown.
Deinde pone illud super os ipsum: et sit illud prope lachrymale: et elonga manum tuam ab oculo parum.	Then place it on the bone itself and let it be near the tear duct and extend your hand away from the eye a little bit.
Deinde reuolue manum tuam cum terebro, donec penetret os, et sentiat illud infirmus: per hoc quod inuenit uentum exire ex eo, quando tenet manum suam super nasum suum.	Then turn your hand with the awl until it pierces the bone and the patient feels it. And this will happen when air begins to flow out from there while he holds his hand over his nose.
Ergo tunc restaura locum cum medicinis stipticis exiccantibus, sicut docui te.	Therefore then dress the wound with drying astringent medicines as I have taught you.
Cum ergo nascitur caro, et induratur locus: tunc materia quae effundebatur ad exteriora, redit ad nasum: est ergo leuius illud super infirmum.	But when flesh grows and the wound hardens, then the material that was flowing outwards will return to the nose. Therefore this is easier for the patient.
¶ De reductione eminentiae Oculi.	Chapter on the Reduction of a Protruding Eye.
Caput XX.	Chapter 20.
Quando eminet Oculus cum totalitate sua, et non accidit in uisu nocumentum, neque diminutio: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum: deinde phlebotomes eum: postea ponas uentosas in ceruice absque scarificatione, sed cum suctione.	When the eye protrudes entirely and there is no harm to its sight or diminution, then you must treat the patient. Then perform bloodletting on him, after which apply cupping glasses to his neck without incising but with suction.
Deinde pone super Oculum linimentum quod fit ex acacia, et aloe, et olibano, et sarcocolla.	Then place over the eye an ointment made from acacia, aloe, olibanum, and sapricol.
Deinde stringe Oculum desuper super emplastrum cum puluillis multis.	Then bind the eye tightly over the plaster with many bandages.
Et modus puluillorum est: ut accipias pannos lenes, multos, et duplicetur omnis pannus ex eis super quatuor: fac ex eis multos: deinde pone eos unum super alium, secundum quantitatem qua indiget Oculus: deinde stringe super ipsos cum panno duro strictura forti.	And the method of the bandages is this: take soft cloths, many of them, and fold each one over four times. Make many such folds. Then place them one upon another according to the amount needed by the eye. Then bind them tightly with a hard cloth using strong binding.
Et itera uentosas cum suctione sine scarificatione.	And perform cupping therapy without incisions.
Deinde aufer uentosas, et dimitte oculum strictum die et nocte.	Then remove the cups and leave the eye tightly bound day and night.
Si autem ligamentum iterum mollificatur, tunc oportet ut stringatur multum: deinde aufer ligamentum post diem et noctem, sicut diximus.	But if the bandage becomes loose again, it must be tightened greatly. Then remove the bandage after a day and night, as we have said.
Si ergo uides oculum iam redisse uuae tunicae, est bonum: et si non, tunc itera emplastrum, et puluillos, et stricturam, et uentosas, donec sanetur.	If you see that the eye has returned to its normal appearance, it is good. But if not, then repeat the poultice and bandages, and cupping until it is healed.
¶ De incisionie Vuae tunicae.	Chapter on Incision of the Vein.
Caput XXI.	Chapter 21.
Quando accidit disruptio in tunica Vuea, deinde eminet et procedit extra palpebras sicut granum Vuae, et foedatur forma hominis propter illud, et uis incidere illud: tunc operatio in eo est, secundum quod narro: et est, ut intromittas acum in radice Vuae ab inferiori ad superiorem partem.	When a break occurs in the vein, then it swells and protrudes outside the eyelids like a grain of pomegranate, disfiguring the face. If you wish to cut it, then the operation is as follows: first insert a needle into the root of the vein from below upwards.
Deinde intromitte acum aliam in qua sit filum duplum a parte lachrymalis, et fac eam penetrare: et dimitte acum primam secundum dispositionem suam.	Then insert another needle on the lacrimal side with a double thread and make it pass through. Leave the first needle as it is.
Deinde incide locum fili dupli, et liga cum eo partem Vuae in circumitu acus: et stringe eam multum.	Then cut the location of the double thread, tie the vein with it around the needle, and tighten it greatly.
Deinde extrahe acum, et pone super oculum lanam infusam in albugine oui: et dimitte eum, donec cadat filum cum Vua.	Then remove the needle, place wool soaked in egg white on the eye, and leave him until the thread falls off with the vein.
Deinde cura oculum cum eo, quod confortat ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then treat the eye with things that strengthen it until the wound heals.
Et quandoque stringitur Vua ab omni parte cum circulo ex panno, donec addat oculus eminentiam magnam.	And sometimes the vein is tied on all sides with a cloth circle until the eye swells greatly.
Deinde perforetur cum spatumili subtili, quod perueniat ad profundum oculi, et currat humiditas albuginea, et descendat oculus, et ingrediatur statim: deinde stringe eum, donec sanetur.	Then pierce it with a fine trocar that reaches deep into the eye until the aqueous humor flows out and the eye sinks down. Then immediately bind it until it heals.
¶ De curatione Alcomnati.	A Treatise on the Treatment of Hemorrhoids.
Caput XXII.	Chapter 22.
Haec Aegritudo quae nominatur Alcomnati, non, est nisi sanies, quae aggregatur in oculo, similis aquae descendenti, et non est ipsa.	This disease called hemorrhoids is nothing but a collection of blood that forms in the eye like descending water, but it is not itself water.
Et modus operandi in ea est, ut facias sedere infirmum super sedem praeparatum, uel directum.	And its treatment involves having the patient sit on a prepared or raised seat.
Deinde accipe caput eius manibus tuis a partibus duabus, et moue ipsum, donec uideas saniem peruenire ad inferiora oculis tuis.	Next, take hold of his head with both your hands and move it until you see the blood flow down to below his eyes.
Deinde figatur, et non descendat, et absoluatur lumen: et uideat infirmus res sicut uidebat: et si non descendit inferius, scias quia est aqua.	Then tie it off so that it does not flow down and the light is restored. If [the blood] does not flow down further, know that it is water.
Si autem non praeparatur descensus saniei cum eo quod diximus, tunc fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas.	But if the descent of the blood has not been prepared as described above, then have the patient sit between your hands.
Deinde accipe spatumile subtile, et finde cum eo supra panniculum corneum parumper apud continuationem coniunctiuae cum tunica cornea in corona, donec egrediatur sanies.	Then take a fine trocar and insert it slightly into the corneal limbus at the junction of the conjunctiva with the cornea until blood flows out.
Cum ergo egreditur, tunc distilla in oculum aquam calidam in qua miscuisti mel: aut aquam in qua iam bullisti foenumgraecum et mel: deinde curetur cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	When it does flow out, then instill into the eye warm water in which you have mixed honey. Or use water in which you have boiled fenugreek and honey. Then treat [the patient] with the rest of the treatment until it heals.
¶ De cura aquae, quae descendit in oculo, uel cataracta.	On the Treatment of Water that Descends into the Eye or Cataract.
Caput XXIII.	Chapter 23.
Iam Diximus species aquae in diuisione, et quae conuenit ad perforandum sermone declarante et exponente, tunc accipe illud idem secundum sanitatem.	We have already discussed the types of water and what is suitable for piercing, explaining it clearly. Then take that same substance according to its usefulness.
Tunc ergo oportet ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas quadratum, oppositum lumini, prope solem: et liga oculum eius sanum, et stringe eum ualde: deinde palpebram oculi eius manu tua dextra, si oculus in quo est aqua, est oculus sinister: aut manu tua sinistra, si oculus est dexter.	Then have the patient sit squarely between your hands facing the light near the sun. Tie up his healthy eye and press it strongly. Then with your right hand lift the eyelid of his left eye if it is the left eye that has water, or use your left hand for his right eye.
Deinde accipe manu tua dextra almagda, si oculus est sinister: aut manu tua sinistra, si oculus est dexter.	Then take an almond with your right hand if it is the left eye, or with your left hand if it is the right eye.
Deinde pone extremitatem almagda prope coronam per grossitudinem radii in ipsa albedine oculi apparente lachrymalis minoris: deinde impelle almagda cum uirtute: et tu reuoluis cum eo manum tuam, donec penetret in albuginem oculi: et sentias, quod almagda iam peruenit ad rem uacuam.	Then place the end of the almond near the crown at the thickness of the eye's radius where the white of the smaller lacrimal appears. Then push the almond with force and turn your hand with it until you feel that the almond has reached the empty part of the eye.
Et oportet, ut sit mensura itineris almagda ad profundum, mensura spacii quod est a pupilla usque ad finem nigredinis: et est corona oculi.	And the measure of the path of the almond into the depth should be equal to the space from the pupil to the end of the blackness of the eye, which is the crown of the eye.
Uidebis enim ea in ipsa pupilla uisione oculi, propter claritatem tunicae corneae.	For you will see it clearly through the vision of the pupil due to the clarity of the corneal membrane.
Deinde pone almagda usque ad locum in quo est aqua.	Then place the almond until it reaches the location where the water is.
Deinde preme ipsum inferius uice una post aliam.	Then press it down repeatedly, once after another.
Si ergo descendit aqua statim, tunc infirmus uidet illud super quod aperit uisum suum statim, et almagda in oculo suo.	If water comes out immediately, then the patient will see clearly at once what they opened their sight upon, and the almond will be inside his eye.
Deinde quiescas paululum.	Then rest a little.
Si ergo descendat aqua, tunc depone eam secundo, praeter quod egrediatur almagda.	If water comes out, then place it again second time, except that the almond should not come out.
Quando ergo figitur, et non ascendit: tunc extrahe almagda cum facilitate: et tu reuoluis manum tuam paulatim.	When it is stuck and does not rise up, then gently pull out the almand with your hand, turning it gradually.
Deinde dissolue in aqua aliquid ex sale claro gemmae: et ablue cum eo oculum deintus.	Then dissolve some clear salt of a gemstone in water and wash the eye with it inside.
Deinde pone extra oculum totum stuppam, aut lanam infusam oleo rosato, et albugine oui: et liga cum eo oculum sanum.	Then place over the entire eye wadding or wool infused with rose oil and egg white, and tie it with the healthy eye.
Nos autem, et illi qui sunt nostri temporis, ponimus super eum ciminum tritum cum albumine oui.	We, however, and those of our time, place powdered cinnamon mixed with egg white upon it.
Quod si non obedit tibi almagda ad introitum in oculum propter duriciem suam, quoniam ex hominibus est, cuius oculus est durus ualde: tunc oportet ut accipias spatumile, quod nominatur Alberid, cuius haec est forma.	But if almagda does not obey you when entering the eye due to its hardness, since it is made from human skin and the eye is very hard: then you should take a spatula called Alberid, which has this shape.
Pefora ergo cum eo ipsam coniunctiuam tantum, et non ultimes manum tuam in foramine: et non est nisi ut facias uiam ad almagda locum subtilem.	Therefore insert it only with the joined tip, and do not put your hand through the hole; for there is nothing else to do but make a way for the almagda to its subtle place.
Deinde intromitte almagda, secundum quod diximus.	Then introduce the almagda, as we have said.
Et apud complementum operis tui, praeparetur infirmo dormitorium decenter factum, in quo dormiat super dorsum suum in domo tenebrosa: et prohibeatur ab omnibus motibus, et a tussi: et pone cibum eius illud quo lenitur natura eius: et non moueat caput suum dextra, neque sinistra omnino.	And when the operation is complete, let the patient's bedchamber be prepared neatly, where he should lie on his back in a dark room; and prohibit him from all movements, and coughing; and give him food that soothes his nature; and do not move his head to the right or left at all.
Et sit ligamentum secundum dispositionem suam usque ad diem tertium.	And let the bandage remain in its position until the third day.
Deinde solue illud in illa domo tenebrosa, et experire uisum eius: et fac eum uidere res.	Then remove it in that dark room, and examine his vision; and make him look at objects.
Deinde reduc ligamentum usque ad diem septimum.	Then replace the bandage until the seventh day.
Et non oportet ut faciat illud in hora curationis, aut post incisionem statim: imo oportet, ut alienes illud: propterea quod aqua ascendit uelociter per aspectum uehementem.	But it is not necessary to do this during the hour of treatment or immediately after the incision; on the contrary, it is necessary that he avoid this, because water rises quickly through a vehement gaze.
Si autem accidit apostema calidum: tunc oportet ut soluas oculum ante septimum: et rectifica illud cum eo quod sedat apostema, donec sedatur: tunc absolue ipsius uisum, et pone super faciem eius orale quo regatur uisus eius sub eo diebus aliquot, ipso existente in illa domo tenebrosa.	If however an inflamed abscess occurs, then it is necessary to remove the bandage before the seventh day; and correct it with something that allays inflammation until it subsides; then without his knowledge, place over his face a bandage that regulates his sight for several days thereafter, while he remains in that dark room.
Deinde egrediatur a domo gradatim, et conuersetur in casis suis.	Then let him gradually leave the house and return to his usual habits.
Et scias, quod in zaltea non excusatur discipulus a uisione aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super operationem.	And know that in surgery, the student is not always excused from seeing; then he may dare to attempt the operation.
Et iam quidem peruenit ad nos quidam ex illis qui sunt de Alayrach, qui dixit, quod factum fuit in Alayrach magdan perforatum, quo sugitur aqua.	And now indeed there has come to us one of those who are from al-Andalus, who said that a perforated tube was made in al-Andalus through which water is drawn.
Verum ergo non uidi aliquem in terra uostra, qui fecerit illud: neque legi illud in aliquo ex libris antiquorum: et est possibile, ut sit illud nouum.	Therefore I have not seen anyone in your land who has made it (the instrument): nor have I read about it in any of the ancient books; and it is possible that this is something new.
Et istae sunt formae specierum ex magda, ut stet super ea qui ea ignorat.	And these are the forms of the kinds of tubes, so that one who does not know them may understand them.
Fiant ex aere proprie: et sint extremitates eorum cum hac eadem subtilitate triangulatae, et extremitas acuta.	Let them be made of bronze properly; and let their extremities be sharpened to this same fineness, and the tip be pointed.
Formae magda.	Forms of tubes.
¶ De cura Carnis natae in naso.	Chapter: On the treatment of flesh growing in the nose.
Caput XXIIII.	Chapter 24.
Quandoque nascuntur in naso Carnes diuersae additae, ex quibus est aliquid quod assimilatur scorpioni multorum pedum: et ex ea est caro cancerosa, lapidea, fusci coloris: et ex ea est quae est caro lenis, non fusci coloris.	Sometimes different kinds of flesh are born in the nose, among which is some that resembles a many-legged scorpion, and from this there is fleshy tissue like stone, dark-colored; and there is also that which is soft flesh, not dark-colored.
In ea ergo quae ex istis carnibus est lenis, non fraudulenta, neque cancerosa, oportet ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas oppositum soli, et aperi nares eius, et proiice uncinum in illas carnes: deinde trahe eas ad exteriora, et incide quod comprehendisti ex eis cum spatumili subtili acuto a parte una, donec scias quod caro tota iam ablata est.	Therefore, with regard to that which is soft flesh from these kinds of flesh, not fraudulent nor cancerous, you should make the patient sit between your hands facing the ground, and open their nostrils, and insert a hook into those fleshes: then pull them towards the outside, and cut what you have grasped from them with a fine sharp spatula from one side until you know that all the flesh has been removed.
Quod si remaneret aliquid ex ea cuius abscisio non est possibilis: tunc rade illud cum uno instrumentorum subtilium cum facilitate, donec non remaneat ex eo aliquid.	But if something remains from that which cannot be cut off: then shave it with one of the fine instruments easily until nothing remains of it.
Si autem sanguis tibi dominatur, aut accidat apostema calidum: tunc oppone ei per id quod oportet: aut est ex apostematibus malignis, tunc propera cauterizando eum, donec abscindatur sanguis, et auferantur omnes carnes.	But if blood dominates you (the patient), or if a hot abscess occurs: then apply to it what is necessary; or if it is from malignant abscesses, then hurry in cauterizing him until the blood is stopped and all the flesh is removed.
Deinde proiiciatur in nasum post incisionem acetum, et aqua, aut uinum.	Then pour vinegar into the nose after cutting, and water, or wine.
Si autem aperitur nasus, et procedat ex eo humiditas usque ad palatum, tunc scias quia iam sanus est.	If however the nose opens and moisture comes forth from it to the palate, then know that he is now healthy.
Si uero non penetrat humiditas, secundum quod oportet, tunc scias quod intra ipsum est caro nata in superioribus ossibus naris, ad quae non peruenit cum incisione instrumentum.	But if moisture does not penetrate as it should, then know that there is flesh born inside the upper bones of the nose which the instrument did not reach with its incision.
Tunc ergo oportet, ut intromittas filum lini cui sit quaedam grossitudo, et noda in eo nodos multos: et pone inter omnem nodum quantitatem digiti, aut minus: et ingeniet infirmus, ut mittat extremitatem unam fili in nasum cum radio, aut cum quo possibile est ei postquam fecerit ipsum simile azer: et trahat odoratum suum, donec perueniat usque ad caassum, et egrediatur super guttur suum.	Then it is necessary that you insert a thread of linen which has some thickness and many knots tied in it: place between every knot the quantity of a finger or less. And have the patient lie down so that he may put one end of the thread into his nose with a probe, or whatever is possible for him after having made it like this. And let him draw his breath until it reaches the back of his throat and comes out over his Adam's apple.
Et multotiens quidem faciunt simile huic Attomi pueri in scholis: et est res facilis ei, qui uult.	But indeed many boys do similar things to this in schools: and it is easy for him who wishes.
Deinde pone duas extremitates fili, extremitatem unam quae egreditur super nasum, et alteram quae remansit in naso.	Then place two ends of the thread, one that comes out over the nose and the other that remains in the nose.
Deinde ac ministra serraturam carnis cum nodis qui sunt in filo.	And then have a pair of scissors ready along with the knots on the thread.
Fac illud donec scias quod carnes iam sunt cum nodis fili.	Do this until you know that the flesh is caught with the knots of the thread.
Deinde extrahe filum: et pone in nasum post abstersionem sanguinis licinium quod imbibisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud tribus diebus, aut plus, donec unguentum corrodat totum quod remansit ex carnibus.	Then remove the thread and place into the nose, after wiping away the blood, a linen cloth soaked in Egyptian salve. Do this for three days or more until the salve has eaten away all that remains of the flesh.
Deinde pone in fine rei in nasum cannulam de plumbo, diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	Then place at the end of the matter a lead tube into the nose for several days until it heals.
Si autem indiget curatione quae exiccet, utere illa.	If however treatment that dries is needed, use that.
Ad caputpurgium faciendum, cum quo distillantur olea, et aliae medicinae in nasum, fac illud ex argento, aut aere: quod sit simile lampadi paruae, apertum sicut conchula: et meatus eius similiter.	For making a head-purge funnel through which oils and other medicines may be dripped into the nose, make it of silver or bronze, like a small lamp with an opening like a shell, and similarly shaped.
Et si uis fac cannulam clausam, sicut canna.	And if you wish to make a closed tube, like a reed.
Et conchula instrumenti ad caputpurgium faciendum, sit plena, detecta: cui sit manubrium in postremo eius, cum quo teneas ipsam, quando calefacis in ea oleum, aut quod uis ex succis, et rebus fluxibilibus.	And the shell of the instrument for making a head-purge should be full and open, with a handle at its end by which you may hold it when heating oil or whatever other liquid or flowable substance you wish.
Et haec est forma instrumenti.	And this is the shape of the instrument.
¶ De cura Thelul nasi.	On the treatment of a deviated nose.
Caput XXV.	Chapter 25.
Multotiens nascitur in extremitate nasi Thelul, et magnificatur, et augmentatur cum diebus, donec foedus fit aspectus eius.	A crookedness in the tip of the nose is often born and grows greater with time until its appearance becomes unsightly.
Et propter illud oportet, ut in cidas illud in principio apparitionis eius, et eradices totum eius.	And therefore it is necessary that you cut off this growth at its earliest appearance and remove all of it.
Deinde pone super locum, aut cauterium, aut medicinam comburentem quae stat loco eius.	Then place upon the site either a cautery or a burning medicine to remain in its place.
Si ergo tardatur incisio eius, donec magnificetur, tunc considera, si est lapideum, durum, fusci coloris, pauci sensus: tunc non tangas ipsum cum ferro: quoniam apostema est cancerosum.	But if the incision is delayed until it becomes large, then consider whether it is stony, hard, dark in color, and insensitive; then do not touch it with iron, for it is a cancerous ulcer.
Multotiens enim uidi, qui incidit hmoni apostema, et accidit ex eo malicia magna super illum qui ipsum habebat.	For I have often seen that those who cut into such an ulcer suffer great harm as a result.
Et si apostema est lenis tactus, non fusci coloris, et uides quod incisio possibilis est in toto eius, tunc euacua infirmum, et incide ipsum sine timore, absque pauore: et cura locum cum eo quod exiccat et constringit, donec sanetur.	But if the ulcer is soft to the touch, not dark in color, and you see that it can be cut into entirely, then evacuate the patient and cut into it without fear or trembling; then treat the site with something that dries and contracts until it heals.
¶ De sutura nasi, et labii, et auris.	On the suture of the nose, lip, and ear.
Caput XXVI.	Chapter 26.
Scias Quia quando accidit solutio continuitatis in una harum cartilaginum, parum confert in ea operatio, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	You should know that when the continuity of one of these cartilages is severed, it does little good to operate on it unless in certain people.
Oportet ergo quando accidit alicui aliquid ex illo, ut consideres, si est uulnus recens cum sanguine suo: et tunc aggrega duolabia uulneris cum sutura: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Therefore, when something happens to someone such that one of these cartilages is severed, you should first consider whether it is a fresh wound with its own blood; then join the two sides of the wound together with stitches, and then treat it until it heals.
Et si solutionis continuitatis labia iam separata sunt, et facta est unaquaeque pars sana: tunc oportet ut excories omnem partem a cute sua apparente, donec sanguinetur.	But if the lips of the wound are already separated and each part has healed on its own, then you must shave off all the skin that is visible until it bleeds.
Deinde aggrega duo labia cum sutura, et stringe ea, et pulueriza super ipsum sanguinem draconis, et olibanum trita: et pone supra pulueres frustum emplastri diafinicon, et alicuius alterius ex emplastris consolidatiuis: et dimitte ipsum ligatum duobus diebus, aut tribus.	Then join the two lips together with stitches and tie them down; powder dragon's blood and ground frankincense over it; place a piece of diafinicon plaster and another strengthening plaster on top; leave it tied for two or three days.
Deinde solue ipsum, et permuta medicinam: et dimitte ipsum, donec abscindantur fila per se.	Then untie it and change the dressing until the threads fall off by themselves.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with ointment until it heals.
Modus autem suturae est, ut aggreges solutionem continuitatis, aut cum acubus, sicut narrauimus in sutura uentris: aut aggrega solutionem cum filo, sicut feci te scire.	The method of stitching is this: either join with a continuous suture or with interrupted sutures as we have described for abdominal wound closure; or join with a suture using thread as I have taught you.
¶ De extractione nodorum labiorum.	On the Extraction of Swellings on the Lips.
Caput XXVII.	Chapter 27.
Multis Quidem hominibus accidunt plaerumque in interioribus labiorum suorum apostemata dura similia granis herbi: et quaedam eorum minora, et maiora.	Many people often get hard lumps similar to grains of millet on the insides of their lips, some small and others large.
Ergo oportet ut conuertas labium, et findas super omnem nodum eius, et suspendas ipsum cum uncino, et incidas ipsum ab omni parte.	So you should turn over the lip and pierce each node with a needle; then suspend it with a hook and cut into it from all sides.
Deinde impleas locum post incisionem zegi trito, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Then fill the space after cutting with powdered zedoary until the bleeding stops.
Deinde colluatur cum aceto, et curetur locus cum eo, in quo est stipticitas, usquequo sanentur uulnera.	Then sprinkle it with vinegar and treat the area with it until the wounds heal.
¶ De incisione carnis natae super gingiuam.	On Incising Tissue Born on the Gums.
Caput XXVIII.	Chapter 28.
Multotiens nascitur super gingiuam caro addiat, quam antiqui nominant abuluss.	Frequently, additional flesh is born over the gums, which the ancients call 'abulus'.
Oportet ergo ut suspendas eam cum uncino: aut teneas eam cum forcipibus, et incidas eam apud radicem suam, et dimittas saniem currere, aut sanguinem.	So you should suspend it with a hook or hold it with forceps and cut it at its root; then let the pus or blood flow.
Deinde pone super locum zegi tritum, aut alios pulueres stipticos, exiccatiuos.	Then apply powdered zedoary or other drying powders to the area.
Quod si redit illa caro post curationem, nam multotiens redit, tunc incide eam secundo, et cauteriza ipsam: ipsa namque non redit post cauterium.	But if that flesh returns after treatment - for it often does return - then cut it a second time and cauterize it; for it will not return after the cautery.
¶ De rasione Dentium cum ferro.	On Extracting Teeth with Iron Instruments.
Caput XXIX.	Chapter 29.
Quandoque aggregantur in superficiebus Dentium ab interiori et extetiori parte, et inter gingiuas cortices asperi, turpes, et quandoque denigrantur, et citrini fiunt, et uirides, donec peruenit ex illo corruptio ad gingiuam, et foedi fiunt dentes per illud.	Sometimes tartaraccumulates on the surfaces of teeth both inside and out, and between the gums there are rough, ugly, blackened, yellowed, or greenish layers until corruption reaches the gum and the teeth become foul through it.
Oportet ergo ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et caput eius in sinu tuo, et rade molam et dentem, in quo apparent tibi cortices, et res similis arenae: donec non remaneat ex eis aliquid, et similiter fac de nigredine, et uiriditate, et citrinitate, et aliis donec mundentur.	Therefore you should make the sick person sit between your hands and put their head on your lap, and scrape off with a file the tartar from the tooth where you see layers like sand until nothing remains of them. And do likewise for blackness, greenness, yellowness, and other stains until they are cleaned.
Si ergo auferatur quod in eis est a principio rasionis, bonum est: et si non, tunc itera super eos rasionem die alio, secundo, et tertio, donec ad ultimum perueniat studium in eo quod uis.	If you remove what is at first rationally possible, that is good. But if not, then repeat the process on another day, secondly and thirdly, until finally it achieves your desired goal.
Et scias, quod dens indiget rasoriis diuersarum formarum, multarum figurarum: secundum quod praeparatur operationi tuae: proptera, quod rasorium quo raditur dens ab inferiori parte, est aliud a rasorio quo raditur inter dentes, secundum formas alias.	And know that teeth require razors of various shapes and sizes according to what is prepared for your operation. For the razor used to scrape below the tooth is different from the one used between teeth due to their different shapes.
Et istae formae rasoriorum sint apud te praeparatae, quas uides.	And these shapes of razors should be prepared by you as you see them.
¶ De extractione doloris Dentium.	Chapter on the Extraction of Toothache.
Caput XXX.	Chapter 30.
Oportet ut cures Dentem a dolore suo cum omni ingenio, et tardes in eradicatione eius.	It is necessary to treat the tooth from its pain with all skill and be slow in extracting it.
Non est enim quod uicem eius suppleat quando eradicatur: quoniam est substantia sublimis: donec quando non est excusatio de eradicatione eius, tunc oportet quando cogitur infirmus eradicare ipsum, ut firmetur, et certificetur apud te dens dolens.	For there is no substitute for it when extracted, as it is a noble substance. Therefore, until there is no excuse for extracting it, then it is necessary to extract the tooth when compelled by pain so that it may be steadied and assured at your hand.
Multotiens enim decipit infirmum dolor, et putat quia est in dente saha et eradicat ipsum: deinde non recedit dolor, donec eradicetur dens infirmus.	For pain often deceives the sick person into thinking it is in a sound tooth and they extract it. Then pain does not cease until the sick tooth is extracted.
Nos enim iam uidimus illud ex operatione phlebotomatorum.	We have already seen this through the practice of bloodletting.
Cum ergo certificatur apud te dens dolens ipsemet, tunc oportet ut scarifices in circumitu dentis cum spatumili, in quo sit quiddam uirtutis, donec soluatur gingiua ab omni parte: deinde moue ipsum digitis tuis, aut cum forcipibus subtilibus in primis paulatim, donec concutias ipsum.	When the painful tooth is assured at your hand itself, then you should circumcise around the tooth with a spatula containing some power until the gum is loosened on all sides. Then move it gently with your fingers or fine forceps gradually until it wobbles.
Deinde loca tunc in eo forcipes magnos locatione bona, et caput infirmi inter genua tua: quod iam bene tenuisti, ita quod non moueatur: deinde trahe dentem secundum rectitudinem, ut non frangas ipsum.	Then place the large forceps well on that spot and have the sick person kneel between your thighs; grasping firmly so that it does not move. Then pull out the tooth in a straight line to prevent breaking.
Si ergo non egreditur, tunc accipe aliquod illorum instrumentorum, et intromitte ipsum sub eo ab omni parte cum facilitate, et conare motionem eius, sicut fecisti in primis.	But if it does not come out, then take one of those instruments and insert it under it on all sides with ease. Then try to move it as you did at first.
Si autem dens est perforatus, aut corrosus: tunc oportet ut impleas illud foramen panno: et stringas ipsum cum extremitate radii subtilis, ut non frangatur in hora constrictionis tuae super ipsum cum forcipibus.	If the tooth is pierced or eaten away, then you should fill that hole with cloth and bind it tightly with a fine thread so that it does not break during your tightening with forceps.
Et oportet, ut exquisite agas cum scarificatione in circumitu gingiuae ab omni parte multum.	And you must carefully make incisions around the gum on all sides.
Et custodi fortitudinem tuam, ut non frangas ipsum, et remaneat pars eius, et redeat super infirmum ex ea malicia quae sit maior dolore eius primo.	But guard your strength so that you do not break it and leave a part of it, which would return upon the sick person with greater pain than before.
Et caue, ne facias illud quod ignorantes faciunt phlebotomatores in festinatione sua, et audacia ipsorum super eradicationem eius, praeter quod administrent illud quod narrauimus.	And beware of doing what ignorant bloodletters do in their haste and rashness, which exceeds what we have described.
Multotiens enim faciunt euenire super homines infirmitates magnas, quarum difficiliores sunt ut frangantur, et remaneant radices eius omnes, aut quaedam earum: aut ut extrahant ipsum cum quibusdam ossibus mandibulae: sicut testificati sumus multotiens illud.	For often they bring great ailments upon people whose teeth are difficult to break, leaving all or some of their roots, or extracting them along with certain jawbones. This we have witnessed many times.
Deinde colluatur post eradicationem eius cum uino, aut cum aceto et sale.	Then rinse it with wine or vinegar and salt after extraction.
Quod si accidat fluxus sanguinis ex locis (multotiens enim accidit) tunc tere aliquid ex zegi, et imple cum eo locum: et si non, cauteriza ipsum si non confert tibi zegi.	If bleeding occurs from that spot (which often happens), then grind some myrrh and fill the place with it. And if this does not suffice, cauterize it.
Formae forcipum subtilium quibus mouetur dens in primis, sint longarum extremitatum, breuis manubrii, grossi, ut non duplicentur quando cum eis premitur super dentem: sint sicut uides grossorum manubriorum, donec quando stringis cum eis, non dent seipsas, neque duplicentur: breuium extremitatum, et sint ex ferro indo, aut ex faled decenter facti, directarum extremitatum: et in eorum extremitatibus sint dentes, quorum quidam ingrediantur in quosdam, et stringant constrictione decenti, forti.	The shape of the fine forceps used to move teeth should be long at the ends, short at the handle, thick so that they do not double when pressed on the tooth. They should resemble the thick handles you see, so that when squeezed together with them, they do not cut themselves or double over. The ends should be short and made of polished iron or well-made bronze, straight at their tips. And there should be teeth on their ends which fit into each other and grip tightly.
Et quandoque fiunt extremitates sicut forma oris auis quae nominatur ciconia, et sunt fortis constrictionis.	And sometimes the ends are made like the shape of a bird's mouth called 'ciconia', and they have a strong gripping power.
¶ De eradicatione Dentium, et extractione ossium mandibularum fractorum.	Chapter on the Extraction of Teeth and Fractured Mandible Bones.
Caput XXXI.	Chapter 31.
Quando remanet apud eradicationem Dentis qui frangitur aliquid, tunc oportet ut ponas super locum cotum cum butyro die uno, aut duobus diebus, donec mollificetur locus: deinde intromitte ad ipsum algasti, aut forcipes: quorum extremitates assimilantur ori auis quae nominatur ciconia.	When extracting a tooth that is broken off at the root, you should first apply butter to the area for one or two days until it becomes softened. Then insert an elevator or forceps into the spot whose ends resemble the beak of a bird called 'ciconia'.
Forma autem haec est forcipum.	This is the shape of these forceps:
Sint extremitates eorum factae sicut lima deintus: aut sicut aliskilfegi.	Their ends should be shaped like a file inside, or like an awl.
Si ergo non obedit tibi ad exitum cum istis forcipibus, tunc oportet, ut caues super radicem, et detegas carnem totam, et intromittas instrumentum quod nominatur Palanca parua, cuius forma est haec.	If the tooth does not yield to extraction with these forceps, then you should make an incision over the root, remove all flesh, and insert a small instrument called a 'Palanca' whose shape is as follows:
Sit breuis extremitatis, grossae parumper: et non sit imbibitum, ut non frangatur.	It should be short at the end, somewhat thick, and not hollow so that it does not break.
Si ergo egreditur radix per illud, est bonum: et si non, iuuare oportet cum istis instrumentis aliis quorum formae sunt istae.	If the root comes out through this (instrument), that's good. But if it does not, you should aid with other instruments whose shapes are as follows:
Forma primi triangulatae extremitatis, in qua est quaedam grossitudo.	The first one has a triangular shape at the end with some thickness.
Forma triangulatae extremitatis subtilis.	The second has a thin triangular shape at the end.
Etiam iuuatur cum hoc instrumento habente duos ramos, cuius haec est forma.	And you should also aid with this instrument having two branches whose shape is as follows:
Et cum aliis instrumentis et ferramentis quae praecesserunt in rasione dentium.	And with other instruments and tools which preceded in the order of teeth.
Etiam sit iuuamentum cum hoc instrumento quod assimilatur uncino magno, huius formae, triangulatae extremitatis tortae, in qua est quiddam grossitudinis, ut non frangatur: et sit non imbibitum.	And there is also aid with this instrument resembling a large hook whose shape is triangular at the twisted end with some thickness so that it does not break; and it should not be hollow.
Et scias, quod instrumenta dentium sunt multa: et similiter reliqua instrumenta non computantur, et artifex prudens, subtilis in arte sua inuenit per se ipsum instrumentum, secundum quod significant ei operatio et aegritudines ipsae.	And know that there are many instruments for teeth, nor are other instruments counted; and a skilled craftsman, subtle in his art, finds the instrument himself according to what operation and diseases dictate.
Quoniam ex agritudinibus sunt ad quas non dixerunt antiqui instrumentum, propter diuersitatem specierum earum.	Because there are diseases for which no instruments have been mentioned by the ancients due to the diversity of their kinds.
Si autem frangatur os ex mandibula, aut ex aliis ossibus oris, aut putrefit: tunc perscrutare super ipsum in loco suo cum eo quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis et forcipibus quae dixi in extractione radicum, et iuuare cum gesti, cuius forma est haec.	But if the bone breaks from the jawbone or other bones of the face or putrefies: then examine it carefully in its place with suitable instruments and forceps which I mentioned for tooth extraction, and assist accordingly. Its shape is as follows.
Sit in eo quiddam grossitudinis paulatim, ut stringatur, uel teneatur cum eo os, et non fugiat et uadat, donec egrediatur os: et restaura locum cum medicinis conuenientibus ad illud.	Let there be some thickness gradually so that it may grasp or hold the bone without slipping or escaping until the bone comes out; and restore the site with suitable medications.
Si autem in osse est putredo parua, tunc rade ipsum a putredine sua, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	But if there is a small amount of putrefaction in the bone, then scrape it away from its putrefaction and treat it until it heals.
De serratura Dentium eminentium super alios.	On the extraction of prominent teeth above others.
Caput XXXII.	Chapter 32.
Quando Dentes eminent non secundum cursum suum naturalem, foeda fit per illud forma: et praecipue quando accidit illud in mulieribus, et puellis, scilicet uenalibus.	When teeth protrude not according to their natural course, it becomes unsightly thereby, especially when this happens in women and girls, that is, the venal ones.
Oportet ergo ut consideres.	It is therefore necessary for you to consider.
Nam si dens est natus post dentem alium, et non locatur, uel est possibilis eius serratura, neque limatura ipsius: tunc eradica ipsum: et si est annexus cum dente alio, tunc incide ipsum cum isto instrumento, cuius haec est forma.	For if a tooth has been born after another and does not fit, or its extraction is possible but not its polishing: then uproot it; and if it is attached to another tooth, then cut it with this instrument whose shape is as follows.
Est simile rostro paruo, et fit ex ferro indo, acutae extremitatis ualde.	It resembles a small beak and is made of soft iron with a very sharp point.
Et sit incisio tua qua ipsum incidis in diebus multis, et propter duriciem dentis, et ut non commoueatur alius ex dentibus.	And your incision should be made over many days, and because of the hardness of the tooth, and so that no other tooth is moved.
Si autem est eminens expositus limaturae suae: tunc lima ipsum cum lima ex indo, cuius forma est haec.	But if it is prominent enough to be polished, then polish it with a file made of soft iron whose shape is as follows.
Sit totum ex indo, et manubrium eius minutorum punctorum ualdae, sicut lima cum qua fiunt acus: cum quo limetur dens paulatim in diebus multis cum facilitate, ut non commoueatur dens, et cadat: deinde leni ipsum, in fine rade ipsum cum quibusdam rasoriis.	Let it be entirely of soft iron, and let its handle be thick with small holes like the file used for making needles. With this, the tooth should be polished gradually over many days with ease so that the tooth is not moved or falls out. Then gently scrape it, finally smoothing it with certain razors.
Quod si est dens, ex quo frangatur pars, et laedit linguam: tunc oportet ut limes eum etiam, donec auferatur asperitas illius fractionis, et aequetur: et applanetur, et non laedat linguam, neque corrumpat sermonem.	If it is a tooth from which a piece has broken off and hurts the tongue, then it is necessary to polish it with a file until the rough edge of the fracture is smoothed out and made even, so that it does not hurt the tongue nor interfere with speech.
¶ De retatione Dentium cum filis auri.	On the Extraction of Teeth using Gold Threads.
Caput XXXIII.	Chapter 33.
Quando accidit Dentibus anterioribus concussio et commotio a percussione, aut casu: et non potest infirmus stringere super illud quod comedit ut non cadat: et curasti eos cum medicinis stipticis, et non ualuit curatio: tunc ingenium in eis est, ut stringantur cum filo auri: quoniam argentum fit uiride, et putrefit post dies: sed aurum nunquam mutatur.	When there is concussion and disturbance of the anterior teeth due to impact or accident, and the patient cannot bite without the food falling out, even after treatment with astringent medicines, then it is advisable to fasten them with gold thread, because silver turns green and decays after some time, but gold never changes.
Et sit filum medium in subtilitate et grossicie secundum quantitatem quod capiat inter Dentes.	And let the thread be of medium fineness and thickness according to the size that can fit between the teeth.
Et forma quidem retationis est, ut accipias filum, et intromittas duplum eius inter duos dentes sanos: deinde texeas cum duabus extremitatibus fili inter dentes motos, siue unus sit, aut plures, donec peruenias cum tela usque ad dentem sanum alterius partis.	And the method of extraction is as follows: Take the thread and insert its double between two healthy teeth. Then tie it with both ends of the thread between the loose teeth, whether one or more, until you reach a healthy tooth on the other side.
Deinde itera texturam usque ad partem a qua incaepisti: et stringe manum tuam cum subtilitate et sapientia, donec non remoueatur prorsus: et sit constrictio tua qua stringis filum, apud radices dentium, ut non euadat.	Then repeat the tying until you reach the side where you began. And tighten your hand with gentleness and wisdom until it is not moved at all, and let your grip on the thread be near the roots of the teeth so that it does not slip out.
Deinde incide extremitates fili superfluentes cum forficibus: et aggrega utrumque, et conuerte eas cum gesti: et occulta ipsas inter dentem sanum et dentem motum, ut non laedat linguam: deinde dimittatur ita strictum dum remanet.	Then cut off the excess ends of the thread with forceps and bend both parts towards each other. Hide them between the healthy tooth and the loose tooth so that they do not hurt the tongue. Then leave it tied like this.
Si autem soluitur, aut inciditur, stringe eos cum filo alio, et stabit cum eo taliter tempore toto.	If it loosens or breaks, tie them together with another thread and it will remain stable in that way for the whole period of time.
Et haec est forma Dentium, et figura retationis duorum dentium sanorum, et duorum dentium motorum, sicut uides.	This is the form of Teeth, and the figure of how to retain two healthy teeth and two loose teeth, as you see them.
Et quandoque fit, ut redeat dens unus, aut duo post casum urriusque in locis suis, et retentur sicut narrauimus, et remaneant: et non facit illud nisi artifex, prudens, et expertus.	And sometimes it happens that one tooth or two return to their places after falling out, and are retained as we have described, and remain so. And this is done only by a skilled and experienced artist.
Et quandoque aptatur aliquod ex ossibus uaccinis: et fit ex eo sicut forma dentis, et ponitur in loco, ex quo munitur dens et stringitur, sicut diximus: et remanet, et seruitur cum eo tempore longo.	And sometimes a piece of the jawbone is prepared and made into the shape of a tooth, and placed in its position where it supports and holds the tooth in place as we have said, and remains there for a long time.
¶ De incisione ligamenti quod accidit sub lingua, et prohibet loquelam.	On cutting the ligament that occurs under the tongue and hinders speech.
Caput XXXIIII.	Chapter 34.
Quandoque ligamentum hoc quod accidit sub lingua, est aut naturale, cum quo nascitur homo, aut accidentale, a uulnere quod iam consolidatum est.	This ligament which occurs under the tongue is either natural, with which man is born, or accidental, from an injury that has already healed.
Et operatio in eo est, ut aperias os infirmi in capite eius in sinu tuo, et eleua linguam eius: deinde incide illud ligamentum neruosum per latitudinem, donec soluatur lingua a retentione sua.	The operation for this is to open the mouth of the patient in your lap and lift up his tongue. Then cut through that nerve ligament from side to side until the tongue is released from its restraint.
Quod si in eo fuerit quiddam duriciei et nodationis, et fuerit illud ex consolidatione uulneris: tunc proiice in illud uncinum, et finde illud per latitudinem, donec incidas ligamentum, et soluatur nodatio.	But if there is something hard and knotted in it, and this is from the healing of a wound, then insert a hook into it and cut through it from side to side until you have cut through the ligament and released the knot.
Et caue, ne sit fissura in profundo carnis, et incidas arteriam illic, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And beware lest there be a deep cut in the flesh and you cut into an artery there, causing blood to flow freely.
Deinde colluatur in uestigio incisionis cum aqua rosata, aut cum aceto, aut aqua frigida.	Then rinse the wound with rosewater or vinegar or cold water at the site of the incision.
Deinde pone sub lingua licinium ex lino, quod teneat infirmus in omni nocte: ut non consolidetur secundo.	Then place under the tongue a linen pad which the patient should hold in place every night so that it does not heal again.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis, tunc pone super locum zegi tritum.	If however bleeding occurs, then apply powdered myrrh to the spot.
Si uero uincit te sanguis, tunc cauteriza locum cum cauterio lentiginoso, quod conuenit ad illud: deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	But if blood overcomes you, then cauterize the spot with a lentigo cautery which is suitable for it; then treat it with the rest of the treatment until it heals.
¶ De extractione Ranulae quae fit sub lingua.	On the Extraction of a Cyst that Forms Under the Tongue.
Caput XXXV.	Chapter 35.
Quandoque accidit sub lingua apostema quod assimilatur Ranae paruae, prohibens linguam ab operatione sua naturali: et fortasse magnificatur adeo, donec implet os.	It sometimes happens that a swelling resembling a small frog forms under the tongue, preventing it from functioning naturally, and perhaps grows so large that it fills the mouth.
Et operatio in eo est, ut aperias os infirmi coram sole: et considera apostema.	And the operation is this: open the patient's mouth before the sun and examine the cyst.
Si ergo uides ipsum fusci coloris, aut nigri, durum, cui non inuenit infirmus sensum: tunc non tangas ipsum, quoniam est cancer.	But if you see that it is of a dark or black color, hard, and insensitive to the patient, then do not touch it, for it is cancer.
Et si est decliue ad albedinem, in quo est humiditas, tunc proiice in ipsum uncinum, et incide ipsum cum spatumili subtili, et libera ipsum ab omni parte.	But if it leans towards whiteness and has moisture, then insert a hook into it, cut it open with a fine scalpel, and free it from all sides.
Quod si uincit te sanguis in hora tuae operationis, tunc pone super ipsum zegi tritum, donec abscindatur sanguis: deinde redi ad operationem tuam, donec extrahas ipsum cum complemento eius.	But if bleeding defeats you during your operation, then apply powdered myrrh to it until the bleeding stops; then return to your operation until you remove it along with its base.
Deinde colluatur cum aceto et sale: et cura ipsum reliqua curatione conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then dress it with vinegar and salt, and treat it with appropriate care until it heals.
¶ De curatione apostematis duarum Amigdalarum.	On the Treatment of Swellings of the Two tonsils.
Caput XXXVI.	Chapter 36.
Quandoque accidunt inter guttur godad, id est, glandulae, quae similantur algodad, quae accidunt deforis: et nominantur duae Amigdalae: quas quando curas cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non sanantur, tunc considera.	Sometimes swellings occur between the throat, that is, the glands which resemble almonds and appear externally, known as the two tonsils. When you treat them with what we have said in division and they do not heal, then examine them.
Si ergo est apostema durum, fusci coloris, pauci sensus: tunc non tangas ipsum cum ferro.	If however it is hard, of a dark color, and insensitive, then do not touch it with an iron.
Et si est rubei coloris, et radix eius est grossa: tunc non tangas ipsum etiam cum ferro, timens fluxum sanguinis, imo dimitte ipsum, donec maturetur.	But if it is red in color and its root is thick, then do not touch it even with an iron, fearing bleeding, indeed leave it until it ripens.
Et tunc aut perforabis ipsum: aut rumpetur per se.	And then you will pierce it; or it will burst by itself.
Et si est albi coloris, rotundum, et est radix eius subtilis: tunc oportet ipsum incidi.	If it is white in color, round, and its root is thin, then it is necessary to cut into it.
Et operatio in ipso est, ut consideres ante operationem suam, si quieuit apostema eius calidum quiete completum, aut imminuitur quadam diminutione: tunc ergo fac sedere infirmum coram sole, et caput eius sit in sinu tuo: et aperi os eius, et accipiat seruiens inter manus suas, et premat linguam eius inferius cum instrumento, cuius haec est forma.	And the operation on it is that you should consider before performing it whether the swelling has completely subsided in its heat or diminished somewhat: then let the patient sit facing the sun, and place his head on your lap. Open his mouth, and have an assistant take hold of his tongue with both hands, pressing down on it from below with an instrument shaped thus:
Fiat ex argento, aut aere, quod sit subtile sicut cultellus.	It should be made of silver or bronze, thin like a knife.
Cum ergo premis cum eo linguam, et ostenditur tibi apostema, et cadit super ipsum uisus tuus: tunc accipe uncinum, et fige ipsum in amigdalam, et extrahe eam ad exteriora quantum potes, praeter quod trahas cum ea aliquid ex tunicis.	When you press down on the tongue with it and the swelling becomes visible to you, then take a hook and fix it onto the tonsil, and pull it out as far as possible without pulling along with it any of its coverings.
Deinde incide eam cum instrumento, cuius haec est forma quae sequitur.	Then cut into it with an instrument shaped thus:
Assimilatur forficibus: uerumtamen extremitates eius sint curuatae, ita quod orificium cuiusque earum est in directo alterius acute: unde cura ut sit ex ferro indo, aut alfuled imbibitum.	It resembles a pair of forceps; however, its tips should be curved such that the opening of each lies directly opposite the point of the other. Make sure it is made of annealed iron or steel.
Si autem non est praesens hoc instrumentum, tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili, cuius haec est forma.	But if this instrument is not available, then cut into it with a spatula shaped thus:
Sit acutum a parte una, non acutum a parte altera.	It should be sharp on one side and not sharp on the other.
Et postquam incidis amigdalam unam, incide alteram secundum hanc eandem speciem incisionis.	And after cutting into one tonsil in this manner, cut into the other according to the same pattern of incision.
Deinde post incisionem gargarizet infirmus cum aqua frigida, aut cum aceto et aqua.	Then after the incision, let the patient gargle with cold water or with vinegar and water.
Si autem accidat ei fluxus sanguinis, gargarizet cum aqua in qua bulliti sunt cortices granatorum: aut folia myrti, et similia illis ex stipticis, donec abscindatur fluxus sanguinis: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	But if bleeding occurs, let him gargle with water in which pomegranate peels have been boiled or with leaves of myrtle and other similar astringents until the bleeding stops. Then take care of him until he is healed.
Et quandoque nascuntur in gutture apostemata alia, praeter amigdalas duas.	And sometimes, besides the two tonsils, other swellings are born in the throat.
Incide ergo ea secundum quod dixi in incisione duarum amigdalarum aequaliter.	Therefore, cut them as I said in the cutting of the two tonsils equally.
Et ego quidem iam medicatus fui mulierem ex apostemate, quod natum erat inter guttur eius, quod trahebat ad fuscedinem, pauci sensus, quod iam fere clauserat guttur: et mulier respirabat a meatu stricto, et iam prohibuerat ei comestionem, et potum aquae: et iam peruenerat ad mortem, si remansisset uno die, aut duobus diebus.	And indeed I had already treated a woman for an abscess that had grown between her throat which was pulling towards strangulation with few symptoms, it had almost closed off the throat. And the woman breathed through a narrow passage and had already been prohibited from eating and drinking water, and she would have died within one or two days if left untreated.
Et apostema tantum ascenderat, quod emiserat duos ramos, donec exierant super duo foramina nasi.	And the abscess had risen so high that it sent forth two branches which came out over both nostrils.
Properaui ergo festinanter, et fixi in unum eorum uncinum.	So I hurried and fixed a hook into one of them.
Deinde traxi ipsum, et tracta ex eo est portio magna.	Then I pulled it, and a large portion came out from it.
Deinde abscidi eam, ubi comprehendi ex foramine nasi.	Then I cut off that part where it was gripped by the nostril.
Deinde feci illud ei quod processit ex foramine nasi altero.	Then I did to her what had come out of the other nostril.
Deinde aperui os eius, et pressi linguam eius: et postea fixi uncinum in ipsum apostema: deinde abscidi ex eo partem eius, et non cucurrit ex eo nisi sanguis paucus: absolutum est ergo guttur mulieris, et incepit statim bibere aquam, deinde accepit ex cibo.	Then I opened her mouth and pressed down her tongue. And afterwards, I fixed a hook into the abscess itself. Then I cut off part of it and only a little blood came out from it. Therefore, the woman's throat was cleared, and she began immediately to drink water, then took food.
Non ergo cessaui incidere ex illo apostemate multotiens tempore longo: et apostema succedebat loco eius quod incidebam, donec prolongatum est nimis et cum ea illud.	So I did not cease cutting from that abscess many times over a long period until the abscess became too prolonged along with it.
Ingeniaui ergo, et cauterizaui apostema inter guttur.	I then ligatured and cauterized the abscess between the throat.
Stetit ergo ab additione: deinde ambulaui a parte, et non sciui quid fecit Deus cum ea post me.	So it ceased from growing more. Then I left her side, not knowing what God did with her afterwards.
¶ De incisione apostematis uuulae.	On the incision of a swelling on the cheek.
Caput XXXVII.	Chapter 37.
Quando descendit catarrus ad uuulam, et apostematur, et est long: tunc ipsa nominatur perpendicularis: et si est in inferiori parte grossa, rotunda, tunc ipsa nominatur uua.	When catarrh descends to the cheek and swells up and is elongated, then it is called a perpendicular swelling. And if it is thick and round below, then it is called a wen.
Quando curatur cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: et uides quod apostema calidum quieuit ab ea, et est subtilis: tunc oportet ut incidas eam.	When treated with what we said in division and the treatment does not help; and you see that a hot swelling has remained there and is thin, then it is necessary to make an incision.
Et quae ex ea est aggregata rotunda, et non est ei longitudo, et est sanguinea, aut fusci coloris, aut nigri, et non est ei sensus: tunc oportet ut deuites incisionem eius.	And that which is gathered around it, round and without length, and is bloody or dark colored or black, and has no sensation, then you should avoid cutting into it.
In ea enim est timor super infirmum.	For there is fear of harming the sick person in this.
Oportet ergo quando uides eam secundum modum quem dixi ex albedine, et longitudine sua, ut facias sedere infirmum coram sole: et premas linguam eius cum instrumento, cuius praecessit narratio: deinde fige uncinum in uuam, et trahe eam inferius: et incide eam cum uno duorum instrumentorum quae dixi in incisione duarum amigdalarum.	It is therefore necessary that when you see it according to the manner which I said from its whiteness and length, you make the sick person sit facing the sun; and press his tongue with an instrument about which there will be a description; then insert a hook into the wen and pull it downwards; and cut it open with one of the two instruments that I mentioned for the incision of the tonsils.
Et oportet ut non incidas ex ea, nisi illud quod additur super naturalem terminum sine additione.	And you should not cut into it except what is added beyond the natural limit without adding anything.
Nam si tu incidis ex ea plus, laedes uocem et sermonem.	For if you cut more than this, you will injure the voice and speech.
Deinde post incisionem utere eo quod narrauimus in incisione duarum amigdalarum: et cura eam, donec sanetur.	Then after the incision, use that which we have described for the incision of the tonsils; and treat it until it heals.
Si autem terretur infirmus ab incisione: tunc oportet ut utaris ingenio in cauterizatione eius absque timore et pauore.	But if the sick person fears the incision, then you should use your skill in cauterizing it without fear or trembling.
Et modus cauterii in ea non est, nisi cum aqua acuta: et est, ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	And the method of cauterization on it is not except with sharp water; and this is how you should place the head of the sick person in your bosom.
Deinde preme linguam eius cum instrumento quod diximus.	Then press his tongue with the instrument which we mentioned.
Deinde accipe ex aqua quam dixi tibi in capitulo cauterizandi, et confice cum ea calcem non extinctam, et pone eam non spissam, neque subtilem, et imple ex ea concauitatem huius instrumenti, cuius haec est forma.	Then take some of the water which I told you about in the chapter on cauterization, and dip a not extinguished lime into it; place it neither thickly nor thinly; and fill up the hollow of this instrument with it, which has this shape:
Sit extremitati eius in qua ponitur medicina concauitas, sicut concauitas cochlearis radii.	Let its extremity, where the medicine is placed, be concave like the concavity of a cooking pot.
Et pone instrumentum cum medicina super uuulam ipsam: et infirmus sit iacens super latus suum, ut currat saliua ex ore eius ex intrinseca medicina, ut non descendat ex ea ad guttur ipsius aliquid, et laedat ipsum.	And place the instrument with the medicine on top of his throat, and let the patient lie on his side so that the salty liquid from the internal medicine may flow out of his mouth, preventing anything from entering his throat and causing harm.
Deinde tene manum tuam cum medicina.	Then hold your hand containing the medicine.
Et tu ex primas eam super uuulam quantitate medietatis horae, donec uideas eam iam denigratam, et sedatam mordicationem medicinae.	And you should apply it to his throat in quantities of half an hour each until you see that the wound has been darkened and the bite of the medicine has subsided.
Et si uis ut accipias cotum, et inuoluas ipsum super extremitatem radii, et infundas cotum cum medicina, et intromittas radium cum coto in cannulam desuper, donec adhaereat cotum super uuulam.	And if you wish to use a sponge and wrap it over the extremity of the stick and pour the medicine into the sponge and insert the stick with the sponge from above until the sponge adheres to the throat.
Fac illud multotiens, donec consequaris quod uis de cauterizatione uuae.	Repeat this many times until you achieve your desired cauterization of the wound.
Deinde dimitte eam: ipsa namque arescit et cadit post tres dies, aut quatuor.	Then let it go; for it dries up and falls off after three or four days.
Quod si indiges ut iteres medicinam, itera ipsam: et post cauterizationem absterge in circumitu uuae cum coto imbibito in butyro, et mundifica cum eo quod est in circumitu eius ex medicina: et colluatur cum aqua frigida.	But if you need to repeat the medicine, do so; and after cauterization, wipe around the wound with a sponge soaked in butter, and cleanse it with what remains of the medicine around it; and rinse it with cold water.
Et curetur extrinsecus cum embrocis, et deintus cum gargarismis, donec sanetur.	And let it be treated externally with embrocations, and internally with gargarisings until it heals.
Haec ergo species curationis est salubrior incisione et longinquior a timore.	This method of treatment is healthier than an incision and far from causing fear.
Et quandoque curatur uuula etiam cum eo quod est subtilius quam cauterium et incisio: curatur enim cum suffumigatione, secundum hunc modum.	And sometimes the throat is also cured by something more subtle than cautery or cutting: for it is cured by fumigation in this manner.
Sume calamentum, et hyssopum, et origanum, et rutam, et sseah, et chamomillam, et abrotanum, et similia eis ex herbis: et aggrega ea omnia, aut quaedam eorum in olla, et submergantur cum aceto, et bulliant: et olla sit lutata cum luto decenter: et sit in medio ollae foramen, super quod componatur instrumentum concauum secundum hunc modum.	Take some calamentum, and hyssop, and oregano, and rue, and sseah, and chamomile, and abrotanum, and similar herbs: and gather them all together, or some of them in a pot, and submerge them with vinegar, and let them boil; and the pot should be well-luted with mud: and there should be a hole in the middle of the pot, over which a concave instrument is placed in this manner.
Fiat ex argento, aut aere: et intromittatur extremitas, in qua est granatum, in os infirmi, donec ascendat uapor ad uuulam super cannulam, donec obscuretur uuula multum.	Let it be made of silver or bronze: and its extremity, where there is a pomegranate shape, should be inserted into the sick person's mouth until steam rises to their throat through the cannula until their throat becomes much obscured.
Deinde itera super ipsam multotiens, donec arescat.	Then repeat this many times until it dries.
Et caue, ne facias hanc curationem in principio aduentus apostematis.	And beware, lest thou perform this cure at the beginning of an aposteme's onset.
Plaerumque enim addit in apostemate: et non oportet ut facias illud nisi apud declinationem apostematis eius calidi.	For often it adds to an aposteme: and one should not do this unless when there is a decrease in the aposteme's heat.
Si autem non est praesens tibi hoc instrumentum, tunc accipe cannam, et compone in extremitate eius corticem oui: ut non comburatur os infirmi: quoniam cortex oui prohibet uaporem comburere os: et haec est ex bona curatione cum salute.	But if this instrument is not present with thee, then take a reed and compose on its extremity the skin of an egg: so that the sick person's bone may not be burned; for the egg skin hinders the steam from burning the bone: and this is good treatment with health.
¶ De extractione spinarum, et ossium de gula.	On the Extraction of Thorns and Bones from the Throat.
Caput XXXVIII.	Chapter 38.
Multotiens adhaeret in gutture os, aut spina piscis, aut aliud.	Often a bone or fish spine adheres in the throat.
Oportet ergo ut extrahas quod ex eis est apparens super quod cadit uisus, postquam premis linguam cum instrumento apud solem, et declaratur tibi quod est in gutture.	Therefore, thou shouldst extract that which is apparent among them upon which sight falls, after pressing the tongue with an instrument towards the sun, and it is declared unto thee what is in the throat.
Et quod non apparet tibi et occultatur in gutture, oportet ut facias uomere infirmum antequam digeratur cibus in stomacho.	And that which does not appear to thee and is hidden in the throat, it is necessary to cause the sick person to vomit before digestion begins in the stomach.
Fortasse enim egredietur res annexa per uomitum.	For perhaps the attached thing will come out through vomiting.
Aut deglutiat infirmus frustum napi, aut radicem lactucae, aut deglutiat buccellam panis sicci: aut accipiat frustum spongiae marinae siccae lenis: et liga ipsum in filo, deinde deglutiat ipsum.	Or let the sick person swallow a piece of cabbage leaf, or a radish root, or swallow a dry bread crust; or let him take a piece of soft dry marine sponge and tie it on a thread, then swallow it.
Cum ergo peruenit ad locum ubi sunt spinae, aut os, et extrahitur, tunc egreditur.	And when it reaches the place where there are spines, or bones, and is pulled out, then it comes out.
Si ergo non egreditur cum eo quod diximus: tunc utere instrumento ex plumbo secundum hanc formam.	But if it does not come out with what we have said: then use an instrument made of lead in this shape.
Sit grossius quam Radius parumper, et in extremitate eius sit curuitas, quam intromittat in guttur suum cum facilitate: et ipse habeat caput suum eleuatum sursum.	Let it be thicker than a finger for a moment, and at its end let there be a curvature which he introduces into his throat with ease; and himself have his head raised up.
Et caueat a tactu suae epiglotis, ut non accidat ei tussis, et impellat cum eo os, aut spinam, aut intromittat ipsum medicus manu sua.	And let him guard against touching his epiglottis so that he does not cough, and pushes with it the bone or spine, or the physician introduces it by hand.
Verum quod infirmus intromittat, hoc est melius: propter scientiam suam de loco rei annexae: et impellat inferius, aut trahat manum suam cum instrumento sursum, totum illud secundum quantitatem quae praeparatur ei, donec egrediatur.	But what the sick person introduces is better: because of his knowledge about the place where the thing is attached; and he pushes it downwards or pulls his hand upwards with the instrument, all that according to the length prepared for him until it comes out.
¶ De extractione Sanguisugae.	On the Extraction of Leeches.
Caput XXXIX.	Chapter 39
Quando medicatur sanguisuga cum eo quod dixi in diuisione ex curatione cum medicinis, et non confert, tunc considera in gutture infirmi coram sole, siue apud solem postquam premis linguam eius cum instrumento quod narraui tibi.	When the leech is applied with what I said in division regarding treatment with medicines and it does not function, then examine the throat of the sick person before the sun, or after pressing its tongue with the instrument which I have told you about.
Si ergo cadit uisus tuus super sanguisugam, extrahe eam cum uncino paruo, aut cum gesti subtilibus decenter.	If therefore your sight falls upon the leech, extract it with a small hook, or with suitable tweezers skillfully.
Quod si non est possibile cum eis: tunc accipe cannulam concauam, et intromitte eam in guttur infirmi usque prope guttur: deinde intromitte in concauitatem cannulae ferrum ignitum cum igne.	But if it is not possible with them, then take a hollow cannula and introduce it into the throat of the sick person up to near his throat; then introduce into the concavity of the cannula a glowing iron with fire.
Fac illud multotiens: et abstineat infirmus ab aqua tota die.	Do this many times and let the sick person abstain from water all day long.
Deinde accipiat uitreatam plenam aqua frigida, et aperiat os eius in ea: et colluat os suum cum ea, et non deglutiat ex ea aliquid: et moueat aquam una hora post aliam cum manu sua.	Then let him take a vessel full of cold water and open his mouth in it; and let him hold his mouth with it and not swallow anything from it; and move the water once every hour with his hand.
Sanguisuga enim ilico cum sentit aquam cadit.	For indeed, the leech at once falls upon sensing water.
Si autem non egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus, tunc suffumiga infirmum cum cimicibus, aut cum asa cum instrumento quod narraui in suffumigatione uuulae.	But if it does not come out with what we have described, then fumigate the sick person with chameleons or with hens using the instrument that I have mentioned for fumigating the ear.
Fac illud multotiens, quoniam ipsa cadet.	Do this many times until indeed it falls off.
Et modus operationis in suffumigatione est, ut accipias ollam, in qua sint prunae uiuae cum igne: et olla sit cooperta cum coopertorio, in cuius medio sit foramen: et componatur in illo foramine extremitas instrumenti.	And the manner of operation in fumigation is that you should take a pot with live coals inside and covered with a cover, in whose middle there is an opening; and place the extremity of the instrument upon that opening.
Deinde proiice suffumigationem, et ponat infirmus os suum in extremitate cannulae, et claudat os suum, ut non egrediatur suffumigatio, donec scias quod suffumigatio iam peruenit ad sanguisugam.	Then throw the fumigation, and let the sick person place his mouth at the extremity of the tube, closing his mouth so that the fumigation may not escape until you know that the fumigation has reached the leech.
Nam sanguisuga statim cadet.	For indeed, the leech will fall off immediately.
Quod si non cadit, tunc itera suffumigationem multotiens.	But if it does not fall off, then repeat the fumigation many times.
Et toleret infirmus sitim, et comedat salsa, et allia, et non bibat aquam.	And let the sick person endure thirst and eat salt and garlic, but do not let him drink water.
Necesse est ergo ut egrediatur cum hoc regimine.	Therefore it is necessary that he bring forth with this regimen.
Et haec est forma instrumenti cum quo extrahitur sanguisuga ex gutture, quando cadit super ipsam uisus.	And this is the form of the instrument with which the leech is extracted from the throat when it falls upon sight.
Est simile forcipibus, sicut uides: nisi quia est ei haee curuitas quae intromittitur ad guttur.	It resembles tongs as you see; except that it has this curvature which is inserted into the throat.
Et extremitas eius similis ori auis quae nominatur ciconia, in quo est asperitas limae: quando comprehendit aliquid, non dimittit ipsum omnino.	And its extremity is like the beak of a bird called the stork, with the roughness of a file; when it grasps something, it does not let it go at all.
¶ De apertione Apostematum, et eorum sectione, et cura in genere.	On the Incision and Treatment of Abscesses.
Caput XL.	Chapter 40
Apostematum species sunt multae, multorum modorum, secundum quod uenit rememoratio eorum, scilicet unius, et unius in hoc libro: et sunt diuersae in perforatione eorum, et sectione ipsorum ex duobus modis.
