There are many kinds of abscesses, of many different sorts, but the memory of only one or two will be recalled here in this book; and they differ in their piercing and incising from two methods.
Quorum unus est ex specie apostematis in seipso, et eo quod comprehendit ex humiditatibus.	One method is according to the kind of abscess itself and what it contains of moistures.
Et modus secundus est propter loca, in quibus accidit ex corpore.	And the second manner is due to the places on the body where it occurs.
Quoniam apostema accidens in capite, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in ano: et apostema accidens in loco carnoso, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in iuncturis: et unicuique eorum est iudicium suum ex operatione.	For an abscess occurring on the head is different from one occurring on the anus, and an abscess occurring in flesh is different from one occurring in joints; each has its own judgment based on its nature.
Et ex apostematibus sunt quae non oportet ut perforentur, nisi post maturationem saniei in eis, et complementum eius: et ex eis sunt, quae oportet ut perforentur, dum sunt cruda, et non maturantur secundum complementum.	There are also abscesses that should not be incised except after the ripening of the pus within them and its completion. And there are those which must be incised while they are still raw and do not ripen as desired.
Sicut apostemata quae sunt propinqua iuncturis.	Like abscesses that are near joints.
Quoniam apostema quando accidit prope iuncturam, et prolongatur esse eius, donec putrefit quod est in circumitu eius fortasse corrumpuntur ligamenta, aut nerui illius iuncturae: quare est caussa propior contractionis illius membri.	For when an abscess occurs near a joint and extends to the point where it causes corruption of the surrounding tissues, it may also damage the ligaments or nerves of that joint. Therefore, there is a greater risk of contraction of that limb.
Aut est apostema apud membrum principale: quoniam si tu tardas perforationem eius, donec maturetur, nocebit uel illi, uel per illud membro principali.	Or an abscess on a major limb: if you delay its incision until it ripens, it will harm either that limb or the whole body through that main member.
Aut est prope anum, perfora ergo ipsum immaturum: et non oportet, ut perfores, apostema crudum, non completae digestionis, nisi quod est prope anum, ut non putrefiat profundum, et longetur ad interiora ani, et fiat fistula, aut fiat in termino eius quod non sanatur.	Or it is near the anus; therefore, incise it while it is still immature. Do not incise a raw abscess that has not completed digestion unless it is near the anus, lest it becomes deep and extends to the internal parts of the anus, resulting in a fistula or a condition that does not heal.
Oportet ut scias horam perforationis apostematis, quod maturatum est secundum complementum: et est apud sedationem doloris, recessionem febris, et diminutionem rubedinis, et pulsationis, et acuitatem capitis apostematis: et reliqua signa.	You should know the appropriate time to incise an abscess that has ripened completely by its signs, which include alleviation of pain, decrease in fever, reduction in redness and swelling around the abscess, dulling of its pulsation, sharpness of the head of the abscess, and other such indications.
Et oportet, ut facias eandem perforationem in inferiori loco apostematis, et uehementioris eminentiae: et sit perforatio uadens in longitudine corporis, si apostemata sunt in partibus manuum et pedum, et locis lacertorum, et chordarum, et neruorum, et arteriarum, et ad ultimum in omnibus locis aequalibus, quibus non est reflexio.	And it is necessary to make the incision on the lower and more prominent part of the abscess. The incision should be made along the length of the body if the abscesses are located on the hands, feet, arms, thighs, nerves, arteries, or any other equal parts where there is no reflection.
In illis autem quae reflectuntur, uade cum perforatione secundum illud membrum.	In those that are reflected upon, proceed with the incision according to that limb.
Quando uero apostema est in locis carnosis: tunc melius est ut dimittas perforationem eius, donec confirmetur eius digestio, sicut diximus secundum complementum.	However, when an abscess is located in fleshy areas, it is better to delay the incision until its digestion is well established, as we have already discussed.
Quoniam si tu perforas ipsum ante illud, prolongatur cursus uirus ex eo, et est multae sordis et sordiciei, et fortasse indurantur labia eius, et profunditas eius.	For if you incise it before that time, the course of the pus will be prolonged from it, and there will be much dirtiness and foulness, and perhaps its lips will remain open and its depth will not heal.
Et quaedam apostemata perforantur secundum latitudinem corporis apud necessitatem: aut secundum illud quo indiget membrum.	Some abscesses are incised across the width of the body when necessary, or according to the limb that requires it.
Et oportet, ut administres in apostematibus paruis perforationem paruam, et in apostematibus magnis perforationem amplam: aut sectiones multas per similitudinem magnitudinis apostematis.	And it is necessary to make a small incision for small abscesses and a large one for large ones. Or multiple incisions may be made depending on the size of the abscess.
Et sunt ex apostematibus, in quibus oportet ut concauetur cutis: et incidatur quando iam facta est sicut pannus, et facta est in termino, quod iam mortua est: sicut illud quod accidit in multis, ut dubelet, et bubonibus.	There are also abscesses in which it is necessary to hollow out the skin and make an incision when it has already become as thin as a cloth and has reached its peak ripeness, like those that occur in many cases of doubting and buboes.
Et ex eis sunt quae secantur sectione habente tres angulos.	And among them are those that should be incised with a three-angled cut.
Et ex eis est, ex quo inciditur sicut figura folii myrti.	Among these is one where the incision is made like the shape of a bay leaf.
Sicut apostema inguinum.	As the groin abscess.
Et ex eis sunt in quibus administratur sectio rotunda, et sectio lunaris: et similes eis ex sectionibus.	And among them are those where a round incision and a crescent-shaped incision are made, as well as others that resemble these incisions.
Illud uero cui non est caput, sicut sunt apostemata lenia superficialia, oportet ut perfores ipsum perforatione superficiali, uel plana tantum.	But those without a head, such as soft superficial abscesses, should be incised with a superficial or flat cut only.
Et oportet, quando apostema est grossum, et iam collegit saniem multam, et perforas ipsum, ut non properes et extrahas pus totum in illa hora: imo extrahe ex ipso partem eius.	And when an abscess is thick and has already collected much pus, it is necessary to incise it slowly and not rush to remove all the pus at once, but rather to remove only a portion of it.
Deinde opila apostema usque ad diem alium.	Then apply dressings to the wound until the next day.
Deinde extrahe quiddam ex pus iterum.	Then extract some more pus again.
Fac illud multotiens secundum gradationem, donec egrediatur: praecipue si infirmus est debilis uirtutis, aut mulier praegnans, aut puer paruus, aur senex decrepitus: spiritus enim animalis ab animali multotiens resoluitur cum egressione saniei: et fortasse moritur infirmus, et tu non percipis.	Do this gradually many times until all the pus has come out, especially if the patient is weak in strength, or a pregnant woman, or a young child, or an elderly person; for the vital spirits are often spent along with the evacuation of pus, and sometimes the patient may die and you not perceive it.
Caue ergo hoc capitulum cautela magna.	Therefore beware of this chapter with great caution.
Et post perforationem tuam, qua ista perforas apostemata, oportet ut abstergas uulnus: et considera.	And after your incision to drain the abscesses, it is necessary to cleanse the wound and observe.
Si ergo est uulnus apostematis paruum, aut est sectio plana, tunc administra licinia ex lino, aut coto antiquo.	If the wound from an abscess is small or if the incision is straight, then apply a linen or old cotton wick.
Et si est apostema magnum, et fissurae perforationis multae sunt, oportet tunc ut intromittas in omnem fissuram licinium, donec perueniant adinuicem.	And if the abscess is large and there are many incisions, then it is necessary to insert a wick into each incision until they meet.
Et si in apostemate abscidisti partem cutis, aut in circumitu concauasti eam: tunc oportet ut impleas eam coto ueteri, aut sicut quando texitur pannus, aut raditur lanugine lini absque humiditate: et stringe ipsum usque ad tertium diem.	And if you have removed a piece of skin from the abscess or hollowed it out around it, then fill it with old cotton or pack it like bandages without wetting it, and secure it for three days.
Deinde proiice ipsum, et cura illud cum eo quod oportet ex unguento, donec sanetur.	Then remove it, and treat the wound as necessary with an appropriate ointment until it heals.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis in hora tuae operationis, tunc administra aquam frigidam, et acetum, postquam imbibitur in eis pannus: et ponis ipsum super locum fluxus sanguinis multotiens.	But if there is a flow of blood during your operation, then apply cold water and vinegar, after they have been imbibed on cloths, many times to the place of the bleeding.
Si autem perseuerat fluxus sanguinis, tunc oportet ut administres regimen, et curationem, et pulueres, quae narraui in locis multis huius nostri libri, et ex diuisione.	But if the bleeding persists, then it is necessary to apply medications and treatments and powders which are described in many places throughout this book and their divisions.
Si autem est in tempore hyemis, et locus apostematis est multorum neruorum: tunc oportet ut infundas puluillos cum uino, et oleo calidis: et ponas eos super loca.	But if it is during winter and the abscess is in an area with many nerves, then pour powdered plant materials mixed with warm wine and oil onto cloths and apply them to the area.
Et si fuerit in aestate, et loca sunt carnosa: tunc oportet ut ponas puluillos imbibitos in aqua, et oleo, aut eum uino et oleo, et totum illud frigidum.	And if it is during summer and the area is fleshy, then apply powdered plant materials soaked in water, oil, or a mixture of wine and oil, ensuring that all are cold.
Donec quando erit dies tertius, sicut diximus, tunc oportet ut soluas apostema, et abstergas ipsum, et administres in curatione eius quod ei conuenit, donec sanetur.	Until the third day comes, as we have said, then you should drain the abscess and clean it, and administer appropriate treatment until it heals.
Hoc est ergo quod necessarium est ex cognitione curationis apostematum uniuersaliter.	This is therefore what is necessary to know universally about treating abscesses.
Secundum semitam uero distinctionis, iam dixi de omni apostemate, qualiter est uia ad curationem eius capitulatim singulariter.	But following the path of distinction, I have already spoken generally about every type of abscess and how each one should be treated specifically.
¶ De sectione apostematum quae accidunt in cute capitis.	On the incision of abscesses that occur on the skin of the head.
Caput XLI.	Chapter XLII
Accidunt in cute capitis apostemata parua, et sunt ex speciebus Nodorum, quos continent tunicae, quae sunt eis sacci: quasi ipsa sint hausolati gallinae.	Small abscesses occur on the skin of the head and are of the type called "nodules," which are contained within sacs that resemble little pouches or wattles of a chicken.
Et ipsorum species sunt multae.	And there are many types of them.
Ex eis sunt pingues: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditatem similem limo: et ex eis quae continent humiditatem similem frisatis et pultibus: et eis similibus, et ex eis sunt, quae sunt lapidea dura.	Among them are fatty ones, those containing mud-like moisture, those containing fried and powdered substances, similar ones, and those that are like stones in hardness.
Et in sectione omnium, et ipsorum extractione non est timor, dum apud ipsorum sectionem non facit contrarietatem arteria.	And there is no fear in cutting into or extracting any of them, as long as an artery does not lie counter to the incision.
Et operatio in sectione eorum est, ut experiaris ea cum instrumento, cuius forma uenit post haec, quod nominatur Intromissum, donec scias quid contineat.	And when cutting into these, you should use an instrument called the "intromitter," the shape of which is depicted below, to determine what they contain.
Nam si est illud quod continet humiditas, tunc seca ipsum sectione secundum longitudinem sectione superficiali: secundum hanc formam.	For if it contains moisture, then cut it lengthwise along its surface like this: __|
Et incipe cum sectione ex linea b. ad lineam, g. Cum ergo euacuatur humiditas, tunc excoria kistin quae continet illam humiditatem, et non dimittas ex ea aliquid penitus.	Begin the incision from point B to point G, allowing the moisture to drain out. Then scrape out and remove entirely all that contains this moisture without leaving any residue.
Multotiens enim redit, si remanet ex ea aliquid.	For if anything remains of it, it will return many times over.
Deinde submerge cotum in unguento aegyptio, si est praesens: et si non, in aqua et sale: et imple cum eo uulnus, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Then immerse the wound in Egyptian ointment if it is available; otherwise, use water and salt. Fill the wound with this mixture and leave it alone until the next day.
Ipsum enim corrodet quod remansit ex kisti.	For what remains of the kystis will corrode it (the wound).
Deinde itera super ipsum cotum cum aegyptio secundo, et tertio, et si indiges illo, donec confidas quia non remanserit ex kisti aliquid, tunc enim cura uulnus cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then repeat applying the Egyptian ointment for the second and third time, until you are confident that no remnant of the kystis remains. Then dress the wound with the ointment until it heals.
Quod si apostema continet nodum pinguem: tunc seca ipsum secundum hanc formam, sectione habente formam crucis: et proiice uncinos inter duolabia sectionis, et excoria ipsum ab omni parte: et conare uirtutem tuam in extractione tunicae quae continet ipsum.	If the boil contains a fatty node, then cut it according to this shape, with an incision having the form of a cross. Then insert hooks between the lips of the incision and tear it out from all sides. And strive with all your might to remove the membrane that contains it.
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi arteria, tunc fac illud quod narrabo tibi post.	But if an artery opposes you, then do what I will tell you afterwards.
Et similiter fac in apostemate, si est lapideum, ex sectione, et curatione eadem, secundum quod diximus.	And likewise, act upon a boil that is stony by making an incision and treating it in the same way as described above.
Et sectio super apostema lapideum est facilior: quoniam est pauci sanguinis et humiditatis.	The incision over a stony boil is easier because it contains little blood or moisture.
Et quandoque sunt quaedam horum apostematum quae sunt in capite in quibusdam hominibus, cum quibus penitus non est humiditas.	Sometimes there are certain boils that occur on the head of some people with absolutely no moisture present.
Quod est: quia ego secui super apostema in capite mulieris uetulae, et inueni apostema sicut lapis solidus et durus, asper, albus, qui non poterat frangi: et si percuteretur cum eo aliquis proiiciendo, uulnerat ipsum.	This means that once I made an incision on a boil on the head of an elderly woman, and found the boil to be like a solid, hard, rough, white stone, which could not be broken apart. And if someone were to strike it with force, they would wound themselves.
In aliis uero apostematibus accidentibus in capite, praeter haec scilicet apostemata quae accidunt in capitibus puerorum, et apud radices aurium, sectio eorum omnium sit sectio superficialis.	But in other boils occurring on the head, except those which occur on children's heads and around the roots of the ears, all should be incised superficially.
Vel pone perforationem eorum semper ab inferiori parte eorum, ut alleuietur cursus saniei ad inferiora.	Or make a perforation in them always from their lower part, so that the flow of pus may be eased towards below.
Deinde cura ea cum eo quod conuenit eis ex curatione.	Then treat them with whatever is suitable for their treatment.
¶ De sectione Strophularum in collo.	On the Incision of Swellings in the Neck.
Caput XLII.	Chapter 42
Multotiens acccidunt ista apostemata in collo, et sub assellis, et inguinibus: et quandoque accidunt in reliquo corpore.	Swellings often occur in the neck, armpits, and groin; sometimes they also appear elsewhere on the body.
Et super illa quae ex eis accidunt in collo, sunt unum, et multa: et generantur ab inuicem: et omnis Strophula ex eis est intra tunicam propriam ei, sicut est in nodis et apostematibus capitis, sicut narrauimus.	And those that occur on the neck are one, and many; they originate from each other, and every boil among them is enclosed within its own skin, as in knots and swellings of the head, as we have described.
Et species harum Strophularum sunt multae.	The varieties of boils are numerous.
Et ex eis enim sunt lapideae: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates: et ex eis sunt malignae, quae non obediunt curationi.	Among them are stony ones; and among them are those that contain fluids; and among them are malignant ones that do not yield to treatment.
In illa ergo quam ex eis uides bonae dispositionis in tactu, cuius manifestum est propinquum colori cutis, et mouetur ad omnem partem, et non est annexa cum neruis colli, neque cum guidegi, neque cum arteria, neque est profunda: oportet ut seces eam sectione superficiali a superiori parte ad inferiorem partem corporis ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. et excoria eam ab omni parte: et extende duo labia cutis cum uncino, aut cum uncinis multis, si indiges illo, sicut diximus in apostematibus capitis, et extrahe eam paulatim.	Therefore, if you see one among them that is well-formed to the touch, its color close to that of the skin, movable towards every part, not attached to any nerves or tendons, nor arteries, and not deep: then you should cut it open from above downwards along a straight line using a scalpel, and remove it entirely from all sides. Then extend the two edges of the skin using hooks, or many hooks if necessary, as we have described for swellings on the head, and extract it gradually.
Et est super cautelam, ut non incidatur uena, aut neruus.	And be careful not to cut any vein or nerve.
Et sit spatumile non acutum ualde: ut non addat tibi manum tuam cum incisione, aut inquietet infirmum, et incidas quod non est necesse.	And let your scalpel be blunt rather than sharp, so that you do not harm yourself with the cut or disturb the patient unnecessarily by cutting something that is not needed.
Si autem incidis uenam, aut arteriam, aut prohibet te ab operatione, tunc pone in uulnus zegi tritum, aut quosdam pulueres qui abscindunt sanguinem, et stringe uulnus, et dimitte ipsum, donec quiescat acuitas apostematis, et mollificetur uulnus: uel incipit et uult putrefieri.	But if you cut a vein or artery, or if it prevents you from performing the operation, then place powdered myrrh or some other absorbent powder on the wound to stop the bleeding, and tie up the wound. Then leave it alone until the inflammation subsides and the wound begins to heal or shows signs of becoming infected.
Nam sanguis abscinditur tuncia Redi ergo ad operationem tuam, donec compleas.	For blood is cut off by a bandage, therefore return to your operation until you have completed it.
Deinde inquire digito tuo indice, si remansit aliquid ex Strophulis aliis paruis: ergo incide eas, et munda eas.	Then examine with your index finger if there are any remaining small boils. If so, cut them open and cleanse them.
Quod si est in radice Strophulae uena magna: tunc oportet ut non incidas illam Strophulam ex radice sua: imo oportet ut liges eam cum filo duplato forti, et dimittas eam donec cadat per se absque nocumento.	But if there is a large vein at the root of the boil, then do not cut open that boil from its root. Instead, you should tie it with doubled strong thread and leave it alone until it falls off by itself without harm.
Deinde imple uulnus coto ueteri, quod iam submersisti in unguento aegyptio.	Then fill the wound with old cotton which you have already soaked in Egyptian ointment.
Deinde cura ipsum.	Then care for it [the wound].
Si inciditur Strophula tota, tunc oportet ut aggreges labia duo uulneris: et suas ipsum statim, postquam uides quia prorsus non remansit superfluitas.	If the boil is cut open entirely, then you should bring together both lips of the wound and sew them up immediately, once you see that there is no excess flesh remaining.
Si autem uides quod remansit superfluitas propter magnitudinem Strophulae, tunc oportet ut intendas ad incidendam radicem eius, et extrahendam eam: et administra suturam quam diximus.	But if you see that there is excess flesh remaining due to the size of the boil, then you should proceed to cut its root and remove it, and perform the stitching that we have mentioned.
Et quae ex Strophulis continet humiditates, perfora illam perforatione superficiali: ut appareat tibi locus maturitatis eius: et pone perforationem ab eo quod sequitur inferius corporis, sicut diximus.	And if a boil contains fluids, make a superficial puncture in it so that you may see the location of its maturity. Then place the puncture below what follows next on the body, as we have said.
Deinde administra post perforationem licinia cum unguento, et similia eis, ut corrodat quod remansit ex corruptione, donec quando uides uulnus iam mundatum esse: tunc cura ipsum cum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	Then apply a bandage with ointment after the puncture and similar ones afterwards so that it may eat away at what remains of the corruption until you see that the wound is now clean. Then care for it with flesh-generating ointment until it heals.
¶ De sectione Epiglotis ab apostemate intra guttur accidente.	On the Incision of the Epiglottis When Obstructed by a Swelling in the Throat
Caput XLIII.	Chapter 43
Dixerunt antiqui hanc sectionem in Epigloti, et non uidi aliquem in terra nostra, qui eam fecerit: et haec est scriptura sermonis eorum.	The ancients have spoken of this procedure for the epiglottis, but I have not seen anyone in our land who has performed it. This is what they have written about it:
In habentibus autem synanchiam, oportet ut deuitetur sectio Epiglotis: cum non fiat iuuamentum per illud: propterea, quod omnes uenae et pulmo sunt infirmi.	But in those who have apoplexy, the incision of the epiglottis should be avoided because no benefit can come from it. This is because all the veins and lungs are weak [in such cases].
In illis uero qui habent apostema calidum in ore, aut gutture, aut duabus amigdalis, quando non est aegritudo in cannali, oportet uti sectione Epiglotis, ad fugiendum ex perditione quae fit ex praefocatione.	But in those who have a hot swelling in the mouth or throat or on both tonsils, when there is no inflammation in the windpipe, it is necessary to perform an incision of the epiglottis in order to avoid destruction from suffocation.
Oportet ergo quando uolumus illud, ut secemus Epiglotim sub tribus circulis Epiglotis, aut quatuor, sectione parua per latitudinem, in eo quod est inter duos circulos per quantitatem, quod sit sectio in sifac, non in cartilagine: et iste quidem locus est conueniens sectioni, quoniam est priuatus carne, et uasa sanguinis ab eo sunt longinqua.	Therefore, when we wish to do so, we should cut the epiglottis under three or four circles with a small cut across its width where it is between the two circles. The cut should be made into the muscle, not the cartilage. This location is suitable for cutting because it is devoid of flesh and the blood vessels are far away from it.
Quod si medicator est timidus, tunc oportet ut extendat cutem gutturis cum uncino.	But if the operator is fearful, then he should extend the skin of the throat with a hook.
Deinde findat cutem, donec quando peruenit ad cannalem: deuitet uas sanguinis, si uidet ex eis aliquid.	Next, let him open the skin until he reaches the canal; let him avoid the blood vessel if he sees any of them.
Deinde secet sifac quod narrauimus: et significatur super sectionem cannalis ex phlegmate quod egreditur ex ea, cum eo quod disrumpitur, et abscisione uocis.	Then let him cut the muscle which we have mentioned; and it is indicated that upon the cutting of the canal there will be an outflowing of phlegm from it along with what is torn apart, accompanied by loss of voice.
Et dimitte uulnus apertum tempore aliquo.	And leave the wound open for some time.
Cum ergo remouetur hora in qua timetur praefocatio, aggrega duo labia uulneris cutis, et sue ipsam solam absque cartilagine.	When the time of danger from suffocation has passed, bring together the two lips of the wound of the skin and sew it up alone without the cartilage.
Deinde administra medicinas quae faciunt nasci carnem, usquequo sanetur.	Then apply medicines that promote flesh growth until the wound heals.
Inquit Albucasis.	Says Albucasis.
Summa huius sermonis quem narrauimus, expositio non est, nisi quando uident, quod aliquod horum apostematum iam opilauit guttur infirmi: et sublimatus est infirmus super mortem, et uult intersecari anhelitus eius: uadunt ad secandum Epiglotim, ut respiret infirmus super locum uulneris quadam respiratione, et saluetur a morte: et propter hoc praeceperunt dimittere uulnus apertum, donec consumatur malicia aegritudinis, et est malicia eius tribus diebus, et quasi ipsa: tunc ergo praecaeperunt suere uulnus, et curare ipsum, donec sanetur.	The sum of this discussion which we have narrated is that it is not useful unless when they see that some of these swellings has already obstructed the throat of the sick; and if the sick person becomes elevated above death, and wishes to cut his epiglottis in order for the sick person to breathe upon the place of the wound with a certain respiration, and to be saved from death; therefore they have commanded that the wound should be left open until the mischief of illness is consumed, and its mischief lasts for three days or thereabouts. Then they have ordered that the wound should be sewn up and cared for until it heals.
Et illud quod uidi per me ipsum est, quod una ancilla accaepit cultellum, et misit cum in guttur suum, et incidit cum eo partem cannalis pulmonis.	And I myself have seen that a servant girl took a knife and put it into her own throat, and thereby cut into the opening of the lung.
Et uocatus sum ad curationem eius, et inueni eam mugire, sicut est mugitus mortui.	And when called to treat her, I found her moaning like one who is about to die.
Detexi ergo a uulnere, et inueni sanguinem qui egressus fuerat ex uulnere paruum.	Therefore, I opened the wound and found that the blood issuing from it was scanty.
Confisus ergo sum, quod ipsa non absciderat uenam, neque guidegi: et uentus egrediebatur ex uulnere.	I realized then that she had not severed the vein nor tied it off; wind was escaping through the wound.
Properaui ergo, et sui uulnus, et curaui ipsum, donec sanum est: et non accidit ancillae aliquid, nisi raucedo in uoce: et rediit post dies ad meliorem dispositionum suarum.	I then dressed the wound myself and treated it until it healed. Nothing happened to the maidservant except that her voice became hoarse; she returned after some days to better health.
Hinc ergo dico: quod in sectione Epiglotis non est timor.	Therefore, I say that there is no fear in cutting into the epiglottis.
¶ De sectione Herniae gutturis.	Chapter on Cutting for a Goiter.
Caput XLIIII.	Chapter 43
Hoc Apostema nominatum Hernia gutturis, est apostema magnum, secundum colorem corporis: et est in mulieribus multum.	This swelling called a goiter of the throat is a large abscess, similar in color to the body itself, and it occurs frequently in women.
Et est secundum duos modos: aut enim est naturale: aut est accidentale.	And it occurs in two ways: either it is natural or it is accidental.
In naturali certe non est ingenium.	Certainly there is no inherent disposition to it.
Accidentale uero est secundum duos modos: quorum unus est similis nodis pinguibus.	An accident, however, occurs in two ways: one of which is similar to fatty tumors.
Et modus alter, est similis apostemati quod fit ex nodatione arteriae.	And the other way is similar to an abscess that results from a ligation of an artery.
Et in ipso est timor, et non oportet ut praesumptio fiat ad ipsum cum ferro, nisi in eo quod est paruum: et tu proba ipsum, et inuestiga ipsum cum Intromisso.	And there is fear involved with this one; it should not be cut into with a knife unless it is small. Instead, probe it and examine it with an introducer.
Si ergo inuenis ipsum simile nodo pingui, et non est suspensum cum aliqua uenarum: tunc seca ipsum, sicut secantur nodi: et extrahe ipsum cum eo quod continet ex kisti, si est in kisti: et si non, tunc perscrutare totum eius.	If you find it similar to a fatty tumor and not suspended from any vein, then cut into it as you would a fatty tumor. If it is contained within a cyst, remove it along with the contents of the cyst; if not, then examine all of it carefully.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod oportet ex curatione, donec sanetur.	Then dress the wound with what is necessary for treatment until it heals.
¶ De sectione super species Nodorum.	Chapter on Cutting into a Swelling.
Caput XLV.	Chapter 45
Nodorum multae sunt species, et ego iam dixi omnes species eorum in diuisione: et oportet ut narrem hic differentiam inter Nodum, et Exituram: cum sit dubitationem faciens.	There are many kinds of swellings (nodules), and I have already mentioned all their types in the division. Here, however, I will describe the difference between a nodule and an abscess, as there is often doubt between them.
Dico ergo, quod cum Exitura est caliditas, et febris, et dolores uehementes, donec sedatur ebullitio superfluitatis, et completur putrefactio: tunc enim quiescunt febris et calor.	I say that when an abscess is hot and causes fever and severe pain until the bubbling of the excess matter subsides and the decay completes itself, then the fever and heat cease.
Cum Nodo uero non est caliditas, neque febris, neque dolores, et continet eos kistis sifachin, qui est eis saccus proprius, et est secundum colorem corporis: et est incaeptio eorum sicut cicer, et fit sicut batecha, et maior et minor.	But when there is no heat or fever or pain and the swelling contains them like a cyst, which is its own sac and is colored like the body; and it begins like a chickpea and becomes like a grape, both large and small.
Et sunt secundum duas species: aut pingues: aut continent humiditatem.	And they are of two kinds: either fatty or containing moisture.
Et colores humiditatis sunt multi, secundum quod dixi in diuisione.	And the colors of the moisture are many, as I have said in the division [of humors].
Oportet ergo, quando peruenis ad curationem Nodi, ut experiaris eum, et inquiras ipsum in primis cum instrumento quod nominatur Intromissum, secundum quod ueniet forma eius in capitulo quod est post hoc.	Therefore, when you arrive to treat an abscess, it is necessary that you examine it and first inquire about it using the instrument called the Introducer, according to what will come forth regarding its shape in the following chapter.
Et modus inquisitionis apostematum, et Nodorum omnium est, ut accipias hoc instrumentum, et intromittas ipsum in humidiorem locum, quem inuenis in apostemate: et tu reuolue digitos tuos cum eo paulatim, donec scias quod instrumentum iam penetrauit cutem.	And the method of examining boils and all abscesses is to take this instrument and insert it into the softer place that you find on the boil; and slowly turn your fingers with it until you know that the instrument has pierced the skin.
Deinde ultima manum tuam secundum mensuram magnitudinis apostematis.	Then place your hand according to the measure of the size of the boil.
Deinde extrahe Intromissum, et considera illud quod egrediur in uestigio eius.	Then remove the Introducer and observe what emerges from its trail.
Si ergo egreditur humiditas currens, quicunque color sit: tunc seca ipsum sectione superficiali, secundum quod dixi in reliquis apostematibus.	If, therefore, running moisture of any color comes out, then cut it with a superficial incision, as I have said for other boils.
Et si non egreditur humiditas in uestigio Intromissi, tunc scias quia est pinguis: seca ergo super ipsum sectione habente formam crucis, secundum formam hanc, sicut docui te: et suspende ipsum cum uncinis, et excoria cutem ab omni parte cum facilitate: et custodi kistin si potes super illud, ut extrahas ipsam sanam cum Nodo.	But if no moisture comes out in the trail of the Introducer, then know that it is fatty; therefore cut it with an incision in the shape of a cross, according to the form I have taught you: and suspend it with hooks, and remove the skin from all sides with ease: and guard the cyst if possible over it, so that you may remove it whole with the abscess.
Si autem disrumpitur kistis apud operationem, et non est possibile extrahere ipsam sanam, multotiens enim accidit illud, tunc extrahe ipsam frustatim, donec non remaneat ex ea aliquid.	But if the cyst breaks during the operation and it is not possible to remove it whole, for this happens very often; then remove it in pieces until nothing remains of it.
Nam si remanet ex ea aliquid parum, aut multum, redit Nodus secundum plurimum.	For if something small or large remains of it, the knot returns again most frequently.
Quod si uincit te, et remanet ex eo parum: tunc imple uulnus apud completionem tuam, quibusdam pulueribus corrosiuis acutis: et stringe uulnus, et pone supra ipsum quod sedet apostema calidum, et cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	But if it defeats you and leaves only a small amount behind, then fill the wound at its completion with certain sharp corrosive powders, and bind the wound; then place something warm that attracts pus on top of it, and treat it along with the rest of the treatment until it heals.
Si ergo est Nodus magnus, tunc sue duo labia eius, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat.	But if there is a large knot, then separate its two lips and cure it along with what is fleshy.
Si autem est tibi contraria uena pulsatilis, aut non pulsatilis: tunc propera, et imple locum zegi trito, et dimitte ipsum strictum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec putrefiat uulnus, et quiescat ebullitio sanguinis: deinde redi ad incidendum illud quod remansit ex Nodo.	But if there is an opposing pulsating or non-pulsating vein, then hurry and fill the wound with triturated pitch, and leave it bound for two or three days until the wound putrefies and the boiling of blood stops; then return to cutting what remains of the knot.
¶ De foris instrumentorum pro sectione et perforatione.	Regarding external instruments for cutting and boring.
Caput XLVI.	Chapter 46
EX Eis sunt formae Intromissorum, et sunt trium specierum.	Among these are the forms of Intromittentia, and they are of three kinds.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et ex eis est medium, et ex eis est paruum.	For among them is the large one, and among them is the medium one, and among them is the small one.
Fiant ex ferro alfulud quadratarum extremitatum decenter, ut festinent introitum in apostemate.	They should be made of iron with square ends skillfully crafted to facilitate entry into the abscess.
Et istae sunt formae Experientium, et no, id est, perforantia: et unum eorum nominatur beris, idest, peforans: et sunt trium specierum.	And these are the forms of Experientia, that is, boring instruments; and one of them is called "beris," that is, a borer; and they are of three kinds.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et medium, et paruum.	For among them is the large one, the medium one, and the small one.
Conueniunt, ut inuestigentur per ea apostemata, et exiturae, et fistulae, et bubones ab eo quod inter ea est ex ossibus.	They are suitable for investigating abscesses, fistulas, and boils by means of them that lie between the bones.
Et aliis fiunt rotunda, tersa, lenia, sicut acus magnae quibus subsellia suuntur, ex citrino scilicet, aut ex aere, aut ferro, aut argento.	And others are made round, smooth, and gentle like large needles with which seats are prepared, namely from citrus wood or from bronze, iron, or silver.
Et meliora eorum sunt quae fiunt ex citrino.	And the best among them are those made from citrus wood.
Et fiunt Experientia etiam de plumbo nigro, quae conueniunt ut per ea experiantur fistulae, quarum concauitate sunt reflexiones, ut reflectantur cum lenitate sua cum illis reflexionibus.	And experiments are also done with black lead, which it is fitting to use for testing fistulas whose depth is such that reflections may be directed gently along with them.
Et sunt iterum trium specierum.	And there are again three species of them.
Quoniam ex eis sunt longa, ex eis media, et ex eis breuia, secundum quantitatem amplitudinis fistulae et stricturae eius.	Because among them there are long ones, medium ones, and short ones, according to the size of the fistula's opening and its narrowing.
Forma Vncinorum, et sunt multarum specierum.	The shape of the curettes, and they are of many kinds.
Quoniam ex eis sunt simplices, scilicet quibus est curuitas una: et sunt trium specierum sicut uides, Magni, Medii, et Parui.	For there are simple ones, namely those with one curve; and they are three kinds as you see, Large, Medium, and Small.
Et ex eis sunt Vncini caeci: et sunt trium specierum.	And among them are blind curettes: and they are of three kinds.
Et ex eis sunt uncini habentes duas curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et ex eis sunt uncini habentes tres curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et omnes isti sunt necessarii in loco suo.	And among them are curettes with two curves, and they are of three kinds; and those with three curves, also of three kinds; and all these are necessary in their proper place.
Et istae sunt formae Scalpellorum, quibus secantur et excoriantur Nodi, et apostemata: et sunt trium specierum: quoniam ex eis est magnum, medium, et paruum.	And these are the shapes of knives used for cutting and scraping nodes and boils; they are of three kinds: large, medium, and small.
Eorum extremitates quibus fit sectio sunt acutae, extremitates aliae sunt non acutae: et non ponuntur taliter, nisi ut cum eis fiat iuuamentum in excoriatione Nodorum apud timorem incisionis uenae, aut nerui: et ut sanetur per ea infirmus, et inueniat tranquillitatem parumper ex adustione quam inuenit apud excoriationem apostematis.	Their tips used for cutting are sharp; the other tips are not sharp. And they are placed thus only so that with them there may be assistance in scraping nodes near the fear of cutting a vein or nerve, and so that by means of them the patient may heal and find temporary relief from burning which he experiences at the time of scraping a boil.
Istae sunt Magda, et sunt specierum trium.	These are the magdas, and they are of three kinds.
Fiunt ex aere, et sunt similia Radio, cum quo fit alcohol: et in extremitate lata est puncta Spatumilis occultata: et in ea currit ad interiora, et ad exteriora quando uis, sicut uides.	They are made of bronze and resemble brass, with which alcohol is made. They have a broad extremity with hidden punctures like a sieve; through them it runs inward or outward as you please, as you see.
Forma Spatumilium quae absconduntur inter digitos apud perforationem apostematum: et non percipiunt ea infirmi: et sunt trium specierum, magnum, medium, et paruum.	The shape of the spathulae used for concealing between the fingers during the puncture of boils; they are not perceived by the patient. They are of three kinds: large, medium, and small.
Fomae Ventosarum cum quibus abscinditur fluxus sanguinis: et sunt trium specierum, magnae, mediae, et paruae.	The shapes of ventouses used for cutting off the flow of blood; they are of three kinds: large, medium, and small.
Fiant ex aere, aut citrino, rotundae, ad longitudinem parumper, sicut uides: et sint ad subtilitatem.	They should be made of bronze or glass, round in shape, somewhat elongated, as you see fit; and they should be made thin.
Et oportet ut sint istae species Ventosarum apud te magnae, et paruae: ut abscindas per eas sanguinem cum uelocitate apud necessitatem, et tunc quando non est tibi praesens medicina.	And it is necessary that you have these kinds of ventouses in your possession, both large and small, so that you may cut off blood quickly when needed, and especially when medicine is not readily available.
Verumtamen non utaris eis in abscisione sanguinis in omni loco corporis, et non utaris nisi in locis carnosis: sicut lacertis cruris, et coxae, et lacertis brachiorum, et mammillarum, et uentris, et inguinum, et similibus eis, ex lacertis carnosis, humidis.	But do not use these ventouses for cutting blood in every part of the body; rather, use them only on fleshy places such as thighs, hips, forearms, breasts, belly, groin, and similar areas with moist flesh.
Et quandoque fiunt ex eis instrumenta parua alia similia corticibus fisticorum, secundum suam formam: quibus abscinditur sanguis quando fluit ex loco phlebotomiae, aut apud incisionem uenae, aut arteriae: et quandoque fiunt ex eis rotundae secundum hanc formam.	And sometimes other small instruments are made from them, resembling the bark of figs in shape; these are used for cutting blood when it flows from a phlebotomy site or an incision of a vein or artery. And sometimes they are made round like this:
¶ De cura Mammillarum hominum quae mammillis mulierum assimilantur.	On the treatment of breasts in men, which resemble those of women.
Caput XLVII.	Chapter 47
Quandoque inflantur Mammillae quorundam hominum apud complementum somni (id est, cum incipiunt pollui in somno) donec similantur mammillis mulierum: et remanent apostemosae foede.	Sometimes the breasts of some men become swollen during REM sleep (that is, when they begin to dream), resembling those of women, and remain offensive tumors.
Qui ergo abhorret illud, oportet ut secet super mammillas sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Deinde excoria pinguedinem totam.	Therefore, whoever finds this repulsive should make a lunar-shaped incision over the breasts, as shown in the diagram, then excoriate all the fat.
Postea imple uulnus ex medicamine incarnatiuo.	Then fill the wound with a flesh-colored medication.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Next, approximate the two lips of the wound with sutures and care for it until it heals.
Si autem declinat mammilla ad inferiora, et mollificatur propter magnitudinem suam, sicut accidit mulieribus: tunc oportet ut findatur in duobus lateribus suis superioribus duabus sectionibus similibus figurae lunari, quarum unaquaeque continetur cum altera apud fines utriusque, donec sit linea maior continens minorem, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Postea excoria cutem quae est inter duo labia, et aufer pinguedinem, et administra quod diximus de sutura et pulueribus, quod est necessarium ex curatione, donec sanetur.	But if the breast points downward and becomes soft due to its size, as happens with women, then it should be incised on both of its upper sides with two crescent-shaped incisions that meet at their ends to form a larger line containing a smaller one, as shown in the diagram. Then excoriate the skin between the two lips and remove the fat, and apply sutures and powders as mentioned earlier for healing purposes until it heals.
Si autem non comples incisionem eius quod oportet te incidere, propter inquietudinem infirmi, aut propter fluxum sanguinis: tunc oportet ut impleas uulnus coto submerso unguento corrosiuo, et dimitte ipsum, donec corrodat illud quod remansit ex pinguedine.	But if you do not complete the incision that you ought to make, due to the disturbance of the patient or because of bleeding, then you should fill the wound with cotton soaked in corrosive ointment and let it sit until it dissolves any remaining fat.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then treat it until it heals.
¶ De perforatione apostematis, quod accidit sub Titillico.	Regarding the puncturing of an abscess, which occurs under the armpit.
Caput XLVIII.	Chapter XLVIII
Ista apostemata quae accidunt sub Titillico, sunt ex speciebus Strophularum dura, quae continet kistis, et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates.	These abscesses that occur under the armpit are due to hard species of strophulants containing cysts and those that contain humidities.
Quae ergo sunt ex eis quae continent humiditates, oportet ut secentur sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam, ex linea b. ad lineam, g. cum ergo euacuatur totum quod est in apostemate ex sanie, tunc imple ipsum coto ueteri, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Therefore those that contain humidities ought to be incised with a crescent-shaped incision following this form: from line b to line g. And when all the pus in the abscess has been evacuated, then fill it with old cotton and leave it until the next day.
Deinde auferatur cotum, et curetur cum unguento conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then remove the cotton and treat it with an appropriate ointment until it heals.
Quod si apostema fuerit ex specie nodorum Strophularum, tunc scinde super ipsum, sicut diximus in sectione super Strophulas aequaliter.	But if the abscess is of the type containing hard strophanthus nodes, then incise upon it as we have described for strophanthus lumps equally.
Si autem extenditur uulnus in hoc ut emittat pus, tunc administra in eo cauterium, secundum quod diximus in eo quod praemissum est.	But if the wound extends so that it discharges pus, then apply a cautery to it according to what was mentioned earlier.
¶ De sectione apostematis quod accidit propter Arteriam et Venam.	Regarding the incision of an abscess that occurs due to an artery and vein.
Caput XLIX.	Chapter XLIX
Quando disrumpitur Arteria, et consolidatur cutis quae est supra eam, tuno multotiens accidit inde apostema: et similiter accidit Venae etiam, ut accidat in ea apostema et inflatio.	When an artery is ruptured and the skin above it becomes consolidated, then often an abscess forms from it; similarly, this also happens with a vein, so that an abscess and swelling occur there.
Et signa quibus cognoscitur, quod apostema et inflatio sint propter Arteriam et Venam, sunt: quoniam, quando apostema est propter arteriam, est longum, aggregatum in profundo corporis: et quando impellis apostema digits tuis, sentis quasi sit ei stridor.	And the signs by which it is recognized that an abscess and swelling are due to an artery or vein are these: for when an abscess is due to an artery, it is long and situated deeply in the body; and when you press the abscess with your fingers, you feel as if there were a hissing sound.
Et illud quod est propter Venam, est rotundum in manifesto corporis.	And that which is due to a vein is round and prominent on the surface of the body.
Et sectio super hoc apostema est error, et praecipue quod est sub ascellis, et inguinibus, et collo, et in locis multis corporis: et est magnum ualde.	And incision over this abscess is an error, especially if it is under the armpits, groin, neck, and many other parts of the body; and it is very large indeed.
Oportet ergo ut deuitetur eius cura cum ferro, et quod ex eis etiam est in extremitatibus, aut in capite, oportet ut deuitetur.	Therefore, such abscesses should be treated without using a knife, and likewise those which are on the extremities or on the head.
Super illud ergo quod ex eis est ex inflatione orificii Arteriae, finde in cute sectione in longitudine.	Therefore, concerning that which arises from an abscess due to the dilation of the mouth of an artery, make a longitudinal incision in the skin.
Deinde aperi sectionem cum uncinis, postea Arteriam: et libera eam ex tunicis, donec detegatur.	Then open the incision with hooks, and afterwards the artery; and free it from its sheaths until it is exposed.
Deinde intromitte sub ea acum, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, et stringe Arteriam cum filo duplo in duobus locis, secundum quod docui te in extractione duarum Arteriarum quae sunt in timporibus.	Then insert a needle under it and make it pierce through to the other side, and tie the artery with double thread in two places, according to what I have taught you concerning the tying of the two arteries that are in the temples.
Deinde punge locum, qui est inter duo ligamenta cum spatumili, donec egrediatur sanguis qui est in eo totus, et soluatur apostema.	Then prick the place between the two ligatures with a pointed cautery until all the blood which is there comes out, and the abscess is dissolved.
Deinde administra curationem quae generat pus, donec cadant ligamenta: postea cura illud cum unguentis conuenientibus ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then apply treatment that produces pus until the ligatures fall off; afterwards treat it with suitable ointments until it heals.
Quod si fuerit apostema propter sectionem Venae, tunc oportet ut teneas manu tua quod tibi possibile est ex apostemate cum cute.	But if the abscess is due to a cut vein, then you should hold with your hand as much of the skin near the abscess as possible.
Deinde intromitte acum sub loco quem tenuisti manu tua, et fac eam penetrare: et sit in ea filum duplum, donec extrahas ipsum ex latere altero.	Then insert a needle under the place which you held with your hand and make it pierce through; and let there be a double thread on it until you draw it out from the other side.
Deinde liga cum ipso apostema ligamento bono: secundum quod dixi tibi in ligamento uuae, a duabus partibus cum duabus extremitatibus fili.	Then tie it with the aposteme with good ligature: according to what I told you about tying a vein, from two parts with two ends of thread.
Si autem times quod extrahatur filum, tunc intromitte acum aliam cum filo alio sub apostemate toto apud incisionem acus: preme, et stringe fila tua in quatuor locis.	But if you fear that the thread may come out, then insert another needle with another thread under the aposteme throughout at the incision of the needle: press and tie your threads in four places.
Deinde seca apostema in medio sui, donec quando egreditur quod in eo est: tunc incide superfluitatem cutis, et dimitte quod ligatum est ex ea.	Then cut the aposteme in its middle until when it comes out what is inside it: then incise the excess skin and let what is tied come out from it.
Deinde pone super ipsum puluillum quem submersisti in uino, et oleo.	Then put on it powder which you have immersed in wine and oil.
Deinde administra curationem, quae fit cum liciniis et unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then apply treatment with linens and ointments until it heals.
¶ De apostemate quod accidit ex torsione Neruorum.	On an aposteme which occurs from twisting of nerves.
Caput L.	Chapter 50
Sicut accidit apostema in Arteria et Vena, similiter accidit apostema in Neruis: quod accidit in eis percussio, aut accidit a labore superfluo, et similibus: et fit plurimum illis in locis adiutoriorum, aut calcanei, et in omni loco in quo mouentur iuncturae: et est apostema graue.	Just as an aposteme occurs in Artery and Vein, likewise an aposteme occurs in Nerves: which happens to them from a blow, or happens from excessive labor and similar things; and it mostly happens to them in the joints of the arms or the heel, and in any place where articulations move: and it is a grave apostema.
Similatur color eius reliquo corpori, et est in pluribus dispositionibus absque dolore: et quando stringitur cum uehementia, sentit in eo infirmus simile stupori.	Its color is similar to the rest of the body, and it is in most cases without pain: but when it is pressed violently, the sick person feels a kind of numbness.
Et non est apostema aggregatum in profundo corporis, imo est sub cute, et ipsum mouetur ad omnem partem, et non uadit ad anteriora, uel ante, neque retro ad posteriora.	And it is not an aposteme aggregated within the depths of the body, rather it is under the skin, and it moves in every direction, but does not proceed towards anterior or posterior parts.
Quod ergo ex eis est in iuncturis, non oportet ut inuadatur cum ferro.	Therefore what occurs from them in joints should not be approached with iron (i.e., surgery).
Fortasse enim accidet contractio.	For perhaps contraction will occur.
In illo autem quod ex eis est in capite, aut in fronte, finde cutem cum spatumili.	But in that which occurs from them in the head or forehead, use a lancet to find the skin with a space between.
Si ergo est apostema paruum, tunc tene ipsum cum forficibus, et abscinde ipsum a radice.	If therefore it is a small aposteme then hold it with forceps and cut it off from its root.
Et si est magnum, tunc suspende ipsum eum uncino, et excoria ipsum: deinde aufer ipsum, et aggrega uulnus cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	And if it is large then suspend it with a hook and scrape it out: then remove it and join the wound with stitches: and care for it until it heals.
¶ De sectione apostematis, quod accidit in uentre.	On the Incision of an Abscess that Occurs in the Abdomen.
Caput LI.	Chapter 51.
Accidunt quibusdam hominibus multotiens in uentribus eorum, et in reliquis corporibus ipsorum, thelil, quae nominantur Fungalia, per similitudinem ipsorum cum fungis.	It happens to some people many times that in their bellies and other parts of their bodies, swellings called "Fungalia" grow, resembling mushrooms in appearance.
Quorum radix est subtilis, et ipsorum caput est grossum, et conuersa sunt labia eorum.	Their root is thin, but their head is large, with reversed lips.
Et est ex eis paruum: et est ex eis quod magnificatur ualde.	And among them there are small ones and also those that greatly enlarge themselves.
Et ego quidem iam uidi uirum, et in uentre eius erant duo thelil, quae erant magis quam rebus aliis similia fungis: non erat differentia inter ea, alba, minutae radicis, et inuersabantur labia eorum, et findebantur, et humiditas currebat ex eis semper.	And indeed I have seen a man whose belly had two swellings resembling mushrooms more than anything else: there was no difference between them except that they were white and had small roots, and their lips turned inward and joined together, and moisture continually flowed from them.
Incidi ergo ea, et inueni in pondere unius quasi X et VIII uncia et in altero quasi VI uncia Et operatio in incisione eorum est, ut consideres tunc, si infirmus est humidus, et color thelil est albus, humidum, subtilis radicis: tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili lato, et sint in praesentia tua cauteria in igne.	Therefore I cut them and found that one weighed about ten and eight ounces and the other about six ounces. And the operation for cutting them is as follows: first consider if the patient is humid and the color of the swelling is white, moist, with a thin root. Then cut it open with a broad knife, and have cauteries ready in the fire.
Multotiens enim expellitur apud sectionem eius sanguis multus: propera ergo si te uincit sanguis, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	For often much blood is expelled at its cutting, therefore be prepared if you are overcome by the blood, then cauterize it.
Quod si uides infirmum pauidum et timidum ab incisione cum ferro, tunc accipe filum ex plumbo decenter factum, et stringe cum eo athelul: cuius modus est quem diximus, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	But if you see the patient afraid and fearful of being cut with iron, then take a thread made from lead well made, and tie it around the swelling in the manner we have described, and leave it for two days.
Deinde adde in strictura plumbi.	Then add to the tightening of the lead.
Non ergo cesses stringere plumbum, quotiens imprimit in thelil, donec abscindatur, et cadat per se absque labore.	Do not cease tightening the lead whenever it presses into the swelling until it falls off by itself without effort.
Si autem thelil grossae fuerit radicis, tunc in incisione eius est quiddam timoris et pauoris: praecipue quod est in uentre.	But if the swelling has a large root then there is some fear and anxiety in its cutting, especially those that are in the belly.
Verumtamen possibile est, ut incidas medietatem eius.	However, it is possible to cut half of it.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum, ut non redeat.	Then cauterize it so that it does not return.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then dress the wound until it heals.
Et caue ne praesumas incidere thelil quod est fusci coloris, pauci sensus, foedi aspectus: ipsum enim est apostema cancerosum: et ego ueniam cum rememoratione Cancri post hoc.	And beware not to presume to cut a swelling that is dark in color, has little sensation, and has an offensive appearance, for it is a cancerous abscess. And I will speak more on cancer after this.
¶ De cura eminentiae Vmbilici.	On the Treatment of Hernia.
Caput LII.	Chapter 52.
Fit eminentia Vmbilici ex caussis multis.	A hernia occurs due to many causes.
Aut ex fissuris sifac, quod super uentrem est: et exit ex eo althub, aut intestinum, secundum quod accidit in reliquis rupturis.	Or it may be due to tears of the diaphragm above the belly and through this hole, either the omentum or intestine protrudes, as happens in other ruptures.
Aut ex sanguine qui fluit ex Vena, aut ex Arteria, secundum quod praemissum est.	Or it may be due to blood flowing from a vein or artery, as has been mentioned before.
Aut ex uentositate coartata in eo.	Or due to constricted wind (flatulence) in the intestines.
Si autem est propter fissuram sifac, et exitum thirbi: tunc est color apostematis similis colori corporis: et est lene, absque dolore: et apparet diuersi situs.	If it is due to a tear of the diaphragm and the hernial ring, then it has the appearance of an abscess with the same color as the body, it is soft without pain, and appears in different positions.
Et si est propter egressionem intestini, tunc est situs eius, cum eo quod narrauimus, uehementioris diuersitatis.	And if it is due to the protrusion of intestine, then its position varies more widely than what has been described above.
Cum ergo tu premis ipsum digitis tuis, occultatur: deinde redit, et fortasse est cum eo sonitus: et magnificatur multum apud introitum balnei, et laborem uehaementum.	When you press it with your fingers, it disappears and then returns. Sometimes there is a sound associated with this, and the swelling becomes very large at the entrance of the hernial ring, causing great pain.
Si uero est propter humiditatem, est lene, tunc non occultatur quando premis ipsum manu tua, neque constringium, neque additur.	But if it is due to fluid accumulation, it is soft and does not disappear when pressed by hand nor does it become hard or increase in size.
Quod si est propter sanguinem, tunc cum istis signis apparet apostema ad nigredinem de cliue.	If it is due to blood, then along with these signs, an abscess forms that appears blackish-blue.
Si autem est propter carnem natam: tunc est apostema graue, grossum, durum, et figitur secundum quantitatem unam.	But if it is due to flesh (omentum) protruding, then the swelling is hard, large, and fixed in place with a definite size.
Si uero est propter uentositatem, tunc tactus eius est lenis.	If it is due to wind (flatulence), its touch is soft.
Et operatio in illo est, ut consideres tunc, si eminentia umbilici est propter sanguinem Arteriae, aut Venae, aut uentositatem: tunc oportet ut prohibearis a curatione eius.	And the operation for this condition is to consider whether the hernia is due to arterial or venous bleeding or wind. If so, you should refrain from treating it.
Nam in illo est timor et pauor, sicut docui te in capitulo, in quo dixi apostemata propter arteriam et uenam.	For there is fear and fright involved, as I explained to you in the chapter where I discussed swellings caused by artery and vein.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est propter intestinum, aut zirbum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo, quatenus teneat anhelitum suum, et stet stans extensus.	But if the swelling is due to an intestine or bowel, then you must instruct the patient to hold their breath and stand upright with their arms extended.
Deinde signa cum encaustro in circumitu umbilici totius.	Then mark the entire circumference of the navel with a cautery.
Postea praecipe ei, ut resupinetur inter manus tuas super dorsum suum.	Next, tell them to lie down on their back between your hands.
Deinde circunda cum spatumili lato in circumitu umbilici super locum quem signasti cum encaustro.	Then wrap a wide cloth around the navel at the point you marked with the cautery.
Postea extende medium apostematis ad superiora, cum uncino magno.	Next, extend the swelling upwards using a large hook.
Deinde liga eum in circumitu forti cum filo, aut cum chorda de serico ligamento firmo: et sit nodus ligamenti alenxotati.	Then tie it firmly around with thread or strong silk cord; let the knot be tied tightly.
Deinde aperi medium apostematis extensum supra ligamentum.	Then open the extended middle of the swelling above the ligature.
Si ergo inueneris ipsum iam captum a ligamento: tunc extrahe alenxotati, et intromitte in ipsum digitum indicem, et impelle intestinum ad interiora uentris: et si inueneris zirbum, tunc accipe ipsum cum uncino, et incide superfluitatem eius.	If you find that it is already held captive by the ligature, then remove the tight tie and insert your index finger into it; push the intestine back inside the abdomen. If you find a bowel obstruction, take hold of it with the hook and cut away any excess fluid.
Si autem contraria est tibi arteria, aut uena: tunc circunda ipsum multum.	But if an artery or vein is opposed to you, then tie it tightly around.
Deinde redi ad operationem tuam.	Then return to your procedure.
Et accipe duas acus, et intromitte in eis duo fila fortia: et intromitte duas acus in circumitu quem fecisti circa apostema in modum crucis, quas facis penetrare.	And take two needles and insert into them two strong threads; insert the two needles around the opening you made around the swelling like a cross, making them penetrate.
Deinde stringe apostema in quatuor locis super acus: et si uis, aufer acus, et dimitte locum, donec putrefiat caro extensa: et cadat per se: aut incide ipsam quando subtiliatur et putrefit.	Then tie the swelling at four points over the needles; if you wish, remove the needles and leave the area until the exposed flesh rots and falls away by itself, or cut it open when it becomes thin and rotten.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet ex unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with appropriate ointments until it heals.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est ex carne nara in eo, aut ex humiditate: tunc oportet ut concaues apostema, sicut diximus.	But if the swelling of the navel is due to fatty tissue or moisture, then hollow out the swelling as we have said.
Et extrahas sanguinem, aut humiditatem, quam inuenis in eo.	And draw forth the blood or moisture that you find within it.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod solidat locum.	Then apply to it something which will consolidate the wound.
¶ De cura CANCRI.	Chapter on the Treatment of CANCER
Caput LIII.	Chapter 53
Iam diximus in diuisione species Cancri, et qualiter est uia ad curationem eius cum medicinis: et cauendum ab eo cum curatione eius cum ferro, ut non ulceretur: et diximus Cancrum generatum in matrice, et cautelam a curatione eius.	We have already spoken of the division of types of cancer and how to approach their treatment with medicines; we have also warned about avoiding using iron during treatment so that it does not cause an ulcer. We have mentioned cancer originating in the uterus and the caution required in treating it.
Et dixerunt antiqui, quod quandoque Cancer est in loco, ubi possibilis est eius eradicatio: sicut Cancer qui est in mammillis, aut in coxa, et eis similibus, ex membris locatis ad extrahendum totum eius: praecipue quando est incipiens paruus.	And the ancients have said that sometimes cancer can occur in a location where it is possible to remove it entirely, such as cancer in the breasts or thighs and similar limbs, by extracting all of it. This is especially true when the cancer is small and just beginning.
Quando uero antiquatur, et est magnus, non oportet ut appropinques ei.	But if it has grown large and become chronic, then do not attempt to approach it with a scalpel.
Ego enim non potui sanare ex eo aliquem: neque uidi alium ante me qui peruenerit ad illud.	For I have not been able to cure anyone of this condition, nor have I seen anyone before me who has succeeded in treating it.
Et operatio in eo, quando est locatus sicut diximus, est, ut praecedas, et soluas infirmum ex cholera nigra aliquotiens.	And the treatment for such a case when located as we have described is to make an incision and dissolve the diseased tissue with black bile, sometimes repeatedly.
Deinde phlebotoma ipsum si inuenis cum repletione manifesta.	Then perform bloodletting on it if you find it noticeably swollen.
Deinde praepara infirmum praeparatione, in qua locetur cum operatione.	Then prepare the patient for surgery and proceed with the operation accordingly.
Deinde proiice in Cancrum uncinos qui conueniunt ei.	Then cast upon the cancer hooks that are suitable for it.
Postea concaua ipsum ab omni parte cum cute, secundum perscrutationem, donec non remaneat aliquid ex radicibus eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere, et non abscindas ipsum uelociter, imo exprime loca, et absterge sanguinem grossum totum manu tua, aut cum quo possibile est ibi ex instrumentis.	Then hollow out the cancer from all sides along with its skin, carefully examining it until no trace of its roots remains. Allow blood to flow freely and do not cut it off hastily; instead, compress the area and remove thick blood using your hand or an appropriate instrument.
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi fluxus sanguinis grossi ex incisione arteriae, aut uenae: tunc cauteriza uenam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	But if you encounter resistance from the flow of thick blood due to cutting an artery or vein, then cauterize the vein until the bleeding stops.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with the remaining treatment until it heals.
¶ De cura Hydropisis.	Chapter on the Treatment of Hydrops
Caput LIIII.	Chapter 52
Iam narrauimus in diuisione species Hydropisis, et qualiter fit aggregatio aquae: et signa omnis speciei, et curationem eius cum medicinis.	Now we have spoken about the division of types of Hydrops and how water accumulates; signs of each type, and their treatments with medicines.
Et illa quae curatur cum ferro, non est nisi species asclitis sola: et non approximatur cum ferro speciei timpanitis: neque speciei hyposarcae penitus: nam illud mortale est.	And that which is treated with iron is only the solitary type of ascites; it does not approach with iron the species of tympanites nor at all that of hypogastrium, for that is deadly.
Quando tu iam medicatus es hanc speciem Hydropisis timpanitis cum medicinis, et non contulit medicatio tua: tunc considera.	When you have already treated this type of Hydrops with tympanites using medicines and your treatment has not helped, then consider
Nam si infirmo iam consecuta est debilitas, aut est cum eo infirmitas alia praeter Hydropisim: sicut si sit cum eo tussis, aut uentris solutio, et similia illis: tunc caue ne mediceris ei cum ferro: quoniam est timor illud.	For if the patient has already become weak or there is another illness besides Hydrops present, such as coughing, diarrhea, or similar ailments; then beware of treating him with iron, for it is fearful.
Si autem uides infirmum exuberantis uirtutis, neque est cum eo aegritudo praeter Hydropisim solam: et non est puer, neque senex: tunc modus operationis in eo est, ut tu eleues infirmum stantem inter manus tuas, et minister post ipsum exprimat uentrem eius manu sua impellendo aquam ad inferiorem partem pectinis.	But if you see the patient is strong and there is no other illness besides Hydrops alone; and he is neither a child nor an elder; then the way to operate on him is, having raised the patient standing between your hands, let your assistant press his belly with his hand, pushing the water towards the lower part of the chest.
Deinde accipe spatumile spinosum, secundum hanc formam.	Then take a pointed spatula in this shape:
Sit duarum partium acutarum, longum, acutae extremitatis sicut Spatumile.	It has two pointed ends and is long with a sharp tip like a spatula.
Verumtamen in eo sit quiddam breuitatis paulatim, ut non pertranseas cum eo apud operationem usque ad intestinum, et laedas ipsum.	But let it have some slight shortness little by little so that you do not pierce through to the intestine during the operation and hurt him.
Deinde considera.	Then consider
Nam si est generatio Hydropisis ex parte intestinorum, tunc oportet ut elongeris cum sectione ab umbilico quantitate trium digitorum, ad inferiora in directo eius supra pectinem.	For if there is a generation of Hydrops from the intestines, then you must lengthen your incision from the navel three fingerbreadths downwards towards its lower part above the chest.
Si uero generatio Hydropisis est propter aegritudinem epatis: tunc sit sectio tua sinistra ab umbilico tribus digitis.	But if there is a generation of Hydrops due to an illness of the liver, then your incision should be three fingers to the left of the navel.
Et si generatio eius est propter splenem, tunc sit sectio in latere dextro: et non oportet etiam ut sit sectio in latere super quod uult iacere infirmus, ut non currant superfluitates ad illum locum debilem.	And if its generation is due to the spleen, then the incision should be on the right side; and it is also not necessary that there should be an incision on the side where the patient wishes to lie down, so that no overflows run towards that weak place.
Deinde perfora cum instrumento cutem totam.	Then pierce the entire skin with an instrument.
Deinde intromitte in illam sectionem, et eleua manum tuam cum Spatumili inter cutem, et sifac, quasi tu excories ipsum: et sit quantitas quae excoriatur quantitas unguis, aut circiter ilud.	Then insert your hand into that incision with a spatula between the skin, and scrape as if you were scraping it out: let the amount that is scraped out be approximately the size of a fingernail.
Deinde perfora sifac, donec perueniat Spatumile ad locum uacuum: et est locus aquae.	Then pierce the spleen until the spatula reaches the empty space; and that is the location of the water [peritoneal cavity].
Deinde extrahe ipsum, et intromitte in foramen instrumentum, cuius haec est forma.	Then remove it and insert into the opening an instrument of this shape:
Et est simile cannulae: fit ex argento, aut aere, aut aurichalco, lene, tersum: cui in inferiori parte sui est foramen paruum, et in lateribus eius sunt tria foramina, duo ab una parte, et unum a parte altera: et facia est extremitas eius incisa, secundum modum incisionis calami, sicut uides: in extremitate eius superiore est armilla.	And it is like a cannula: made of silver or bronze or brass, smooth and polished; at its lower part there is a small opening, and on its sides are three openings, two on one side and one on the other; and its tip is cut in the manner of a reed, as you see; at its upper end there is a ring.
Nam quando instrumentum peruenit ad aquam, tunc ipsa descendit statim super instrumentum, ergo euacua ex aqua in hora quantitatem mediam.	For when the instrument reaches the water, it sinks immediately onto the instrument; therefore, empty out half of that amount of water in one hour.
Quoniam si tu euacuas ex ea plus quam oportet, in hora fortasse moritur infirmus per resolutionem spiritus sui animalis: aut accidit ei syncopis quae appropinquat morti.	For if you evacuate more than is necessary from it, the patient may perhaps die within an hour due to a collapse of his vital spirits; or he may suffer syncope which approaches death.
Verum euacua ex ea secundum quantitatem uirtutis eius, et secundum quod significant tibi dispositiones infirmi ex uirtute pulsus eius, et ex bonitate eius.	But evacuate according to the amount of its strength, and according to what the conditions of the patient indicate to you from the strength of his pulse, and his overall constitution.
Deinde extrahe instrumentum, et retine aquam.	Then remove the instrument and retain the water.
Quod est, quia retinetur statim propter cutem quae retinet foramen quod est super sifac: de quo narraui, ut perfores ipsum secundum illum modum.	Which is because it will be retained immediately due to the skin which retains the opening that is over the spleen: about which I have spoken, so that you may pierce it in that manner.
Deinde itera instrumentum die altero, si uides infirmum tolerare illud: et extrahe etiam ex aqua quantitatem paruam.	Then repeat the procedure on the following day if you see that the patient can tolerate it; and also remove a small amount of water from the peritoneal cavity.
Fac illud diebus aliquot sine timore, et custodi te ab errore: donec non remaneat ex aqua nisi parum.	Do this for several days without fear, taking care not to err until only a little water remains in the peritoneal cavity.
Si autem times super infirmum, et dimittis ex aqua rem multam: tunc cura ipsum cum sepultura in harena calida, et sudore multo in balneo et sole, et expectet super sitim: et cura ipsum cum medicinis exiccatiuis, donec sanetur: et cauteriza super stomachum, et epar, et splenem, post extractionem aquae: secundum quod narraui in eo quod praecessit.	But if you fear for the patient and let too much water remain, then care for him with hot sand burial and abundant sweat in a bath and sunlight, and wait until he is thirsty. Then treat him with drying medicines until he is healed, and cauterize his stomach, liver, and spleen after the water has been removed, according to what I have described earlier.
¶ De cura infantium qui nascuntur locis urinae eorum non perforatis.	On the treatment of infants born with incomplete urethral opening.
Caput LV.	Chapter 56
Quando egreditur aliquis infantium ex uentre matris suae, et caput mutonis eius est non perforatum, aut est foramen strictum, aut in non suo loco.	When an infant is born from his mother's womb and the head of his penis is not perforated, or the opening is too small, or it is not in its proper place.
Oportet ergo succurrere cum perforatione eius statim cum nascitur cum Spatumili subtili ualde, secundum hanc formam.	Therefore, you should immediately come to his aid with a very fine spatula made according to this shape.
Deinde pone in foramine clauum subtilem ex plumbo, et liga ipsum: et tene ipsum tribus diebus, aut quatuor.	Then place a thin lead pin into the opening and tie it; hold it there for three or four days.
Quando ergo uult urinam emittere, remoueatur, et mingat.	When he wants to urinate, remove the pin and let him do so.
Deinde reduc ipsum.	Then replace the pin.
Et si tu non ponis plumbum, iam possibile est, ut urina quae incedit super locum, non permittat ipsum claudi.	And if you do not use lead, it is possible that urine flowing over the area will not allow the opening to close.
Ille autem cuius foramen est strictum, medicatur cum plumbo, sicut diximus, diebus multis, donec amplificetur.	But one whose opening is too small should be treated with lead as described above for many days until it becomes wider.
Illi autem in quibus est foramen in non suo loco, laeduntur.	Those who have an opening not in its proper place are harmed.
Quod est, quia ex eis qui nascitur, foramen est apud finem capitis uirgae: quare non potest mingere ad anteriora, donec eleuat uirgam manu sua ad superiora.	This means that in those who are born with the opening at the end of the glans penis, they cannot urinate forwards until they raise the penis by hand upwards.
Neque est ei generatio, propterea, quod sperma non potest peruenire ad matricem secundum rectitudinem: et est aegritudo foeda ualde.	Nor can such a one reproduce because sperm cannot reach the womb correctly, leading to severe impotence.
Et modus operationis in illo est, ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum.	The procedure for this is as follows: have the patient lie on his back.
Deinde extende caput uirgae eius manu tua sinistra extensione uehementi, et incide caput capitis uirgae ex loco priapi, cum acumine, aut spatumili acuto: sicut est incisio calami, aut sicut tu radis aliquid, ut medium eius ueniat simile capiti uirgae: et ut cadat foramen in medio secundum quod oportet.	Then extend the glans penis with your left hand using great force, and make an incision at its tip with a sharp needle or scalpel, like cutting the end off of a reed, so that the opening comes out in the middle as it should.
Et caue tibi apud operationem tuam a fluxu sanguinis.	And be careful during your procedure to avoid blood flow.
Multotiens enim accidit illud.	For this often happens.
Oppone ergo ei cum eo quod abscindit sanguinem, et cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	Therefore apply something to stop the bleeding and care for the wound until it heals.
¶ De Albather quae accidunt in praeputio et capite uigae, et corruptione, nigredine, et adhaerentia.	Regarding cases of swelling in the foreskin and glans, as well as putrefaction, blackness, and adhesions.
Caput LVI.	Chapter 56.
Multotiens accidunt istae Albather in uirga, et est eminentia carnis foedae.	Swelling often occurs on the penis, which is an enlargement of corrupted flesh.
Et ex ea alia est maligna, et alia non maligna.	And among these swellings, some are malignant and others are not.
Non malignam ergo oportet ut suspendas cum uncino subtili, et abscindas eam, donec mundes eam totam.	So you should hang the benign one with a fine hook and cut it away until you have cleaned it entirely.
Deinde pone super eam cotum submersum in unguento aegyptio.	Then apply a compress soaked in Egyptian ointment on top of it
Deinde cura ipsum post illud cum unguento dyafinicon, donec sanetur.	And care for the wound afterwards with dye-finicon ointment until it heals.
Quod si Albather est maligna, foedi coloris, tunc oportet ut administres in ea cauterium post incisionem eius et ipsius rasionem.	But if the swelling is malignant and of foul color, then you should apply a cautery after making an incision into it and removing its cause.
Si autem Albather est in praeputio captiui, non circumcisi, et est pars Albather inter praeputium, et pars eius extra: tunc oportet ut auferas Albather, quae est intus in primis, donec quando consolidatur, tunc cura ipsum exterius: quoniam quando tu curas eam simul, non securatur praeputium quin preforetur.	But if the swelling is on the foreskin of an uncircumcised person and part of it is inside the foreskin while another part is outside, then you should first remove the inner portion of the swelling until it solidifies, then care for the outer portion: because if you treat them both at once, the foreskin will not heal without a hole.
