Et iam accidunt etiam in testiculis, et praeputio nigredo et corruptio.	And now we come to cases of blackness and putrefaction occurring in the testes and foreskin.
Oportet ergo, ut tu concaues totum quod iam denigratum est, et quod uult corrumpi, aut iam corruptum est.	Therefore you should hollow out everything that has already turned black or is about to rot or has already rotted.
Deinde line super ipsum post illud cum melle quod iam concussum est cum farina corticum granatorum, et herbi tritorum cribellatorum.	Then apply over it a poultice made from beaten-up honey mixed with ground pomegranate seeds and sieved herbs.
Deinde cura illud cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with the rest of the treatment until it heals.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra cauterium cum cauterio lunari, secundum hanc formam.	But if bleeding occurs, then apply a lunar-cautery cautery, according to this shape.
Cauterium enim est iuuatiuum ad duas dispositiones simul, scilicet ad fluxum sanguinis, et uulnus quando corrumpitur.	For the cautery is beneficial for two dispositions at once, namely for bleeding and when a wound becomes corrupted.
Quod si corroditur caput uirgae, et destruitur totum in hora: tunc oportet ut intromittas in meatum priapi cannulam ex plumbo, ut mingat infirmus super eam.	But if the head of the probe is consumed and destroyed entirely within an hour, then it is necessary to insert into the urethra a lead catheter so that the patient may urinate upon it.
In adhaerentia uero praeputii cum capite uirgae, et haec quidem adhaerentia non accidit, nisi in eo cuius praeputium est sanum, et non exigitur super ipsum circumcisio: et quandoque accidit adhaerentia propter uulnus, aut apostema: oportet ergo ut excories eam cum Spatumili obtuso, donec soluatur ligamentum, et liberetur caput uirgae ab omni parte.	Now concerning adhesion of the foreskin to the head of the probe, such adhesion does not occur except in one whose foreskin is healthy and does not require circumcision. And sometimes it occurs due to a wound or an abscess. Therefore, you should remove it with a blunt spatula until the band releases and the head of the probe is freed on all sides.
Quod si est difficile discernere ea exquisite, tunc oportet ut excories aliquid ex capite uirgae, et ex praeputio.	But if it is difficult to distinguish them exactly, then you should remove some from the head of the probe and from the foreskin.
Quod est, quia praeputium quando est subtile, fortasse perforatur propter subtilitatem suam uelociter.	That is, because when the foreskin is thin, it may be quickly punctured due to its thinness.
Deinde separa inter praeputium, et caput uirgae cum panno lini subtili, qui iam madefactus est in aqua frigida, ut non adhereant iterum.	Then separate between the foreskin and the head of the probe with a thin linen cloth that has already been moistened in cold water so that they do not adhere again.
Deinde curetur cum uino stiptico, donec consolidetur.	Then it should be treated with astringent wine until it solidifies.
¶ De mundificatione infantium, et curatione ex errore eis accidente.	On the cleansing of infants and treatment for errors that occur to them.
Caput LVII.	Chapter 57
Circumcisio non est solutio continuitatis, sicut reliqua uulnera: uerumtamen cum sit ex operatione nostra, uoluntate nostra, et usus eius sit in pueris proprie, est necesse ut signemus in ea operationem meliorem, et uiam leuiorem perducentem ad salutem.	Circumcision is not the solution to continuity like other wounds, but since it is an operation performed by us willingly and used properly in children, it is necessary that we mark a better operation and an easier path leading to health.
Dico ergo, quod antiqui non dixerunt circumcisionem in aliquo suorum librorum: quoniam non utuntur in legibus suis, et non est nisi quod acquisiuimus per experimentum.	I say therefore that the ancients did not mention circumcision in any of their books because they do not use it in their laws and it is only something that we have acquired through experience.
Quod est, quia ego inueni maiorem partem artificum, et phlebotomatorum uti mundificatione, circumcidendo cum nouacula, et cum forficibus: et utuntur alfecati, et ligaudo cum filo, et incisione cum ungula.	That is, because I have found that most artisans and bloodletters use cleansing by circumcising with a razor or forceps, and they also use cauterization and ligation with thread, and incision with a nail.
Et ego quidem iam probaui omnes istos modos, et non inueni meliorem mundificatione cum forficibus, et ligamento cum filo.	And indeed I have already proven all these methods, but found no better cleansing than that using forceps and ligation with thread.
Quoniam in mundificatione cum nouacula, multotiens effugit cutis.	Because when cleansing with a razor, the skin often slips away.
Quoniam cutis praeputii duas habet tunicas: ergo forsitan inciditur cutis superior, et temanet tunica inferior: cogitur ergo ad incisionem ad incidendum alteram, et dolorem futurum.	Because the foreskin has two layers of skin: therefore perhaps only the upper layer is cut, and the lower layer remains; so he is forced to make another incision to cut the other, causing future pain.
Et cum mundificatione quae fit per alfecati, id est, digitalis, quo utuntur sutores, non securatur incisio extremitatis uirilis membri: quoniam fortasse ingreditur in foramen eius.	And with cleansing that is done by cauterization, that is, digitally, which surgeons use, the incision of the tip of the male member is not secure because perhaps it may enter its opening.
In mundificatione autem cum ungula, fortasse euadit ferrum, et corrumpit operationem tuam: et cutis quidem pueri est breuis natura, et multotiens nascuntur taliter, quod non indigent mundificatione: et iam uidi illud.	But with cleansing using a nail, perhaps the iron may slip out and spoil your procedure; indeed the skin of an infant is naturally short and many are born in such a way that they do not require cleansing, as I have seen.
Mundificationis autem cum forficibus, et ligamento cum filo, bonum experimentum detexit mihi: quoniam forfices sunt proportionalis incisionis: propterea, quod acuitas quae est superius, est sicut acuitas quae est inferius.	But cleansing with forceps and ligation with thread has proven good to me because the forceps is proportionate to the incision; thus the sharpness that is above is like the sharpness that is below.
Cum ergo premis manum tuam, proportionantur duae acuitates, et incidunt secundum operationem unam in tempore uno: et fit compressio simili figura, continens cutem uirgae ab omni parte, cum qua non cadit error omnino.	Therefore when you press your hand thus, the two sharpnesses are proportionate and make one incision together at once; and a compression of similar shape is formed, enclosing the skin of the foreskin on all sides without any error.
Et modus operationis propriae est, ut facias extimare, puerum praecipue, si est ex eis qui intelligunt parumper, quod tu non facis, nisi quod ligas filum in uirga sua tantum: et dimittas ipsum usque ad diem alium.	And the method of operation is this: especially for a boy who understands little, you should make him understand that you are doing nothing but tying a thread around his penis; and you should leave him until the next day.
Deinde fac eum gaudere et laetari omnimodo quo possibile est tibi illud, ex eo quod recipit intelligentia sua.	Then cause him to rejoice and be glad in every way possible for him, according to his understanding.
Deinde fac eum stare inter manus tuas praeparatae staturae, et non sit sedens: et occulta forfices in manica tua, aut sub pede tuo, ne uideat eos puer omnino, neque aliquid ex instrumentis.	Then make him stand between your prepared hands, and not sitting; hide the forceps in your sleeve or under your foot so that the boy sees nothing of them nor any other instruments.
Deinde intromitte manum tuam ad uirgam eius, et suffla in cutem, et trahe eam sursum, donec egrediatur caput uirgae.	Then insert your hand toward his penis and blow on the skin and pull it upwards until the head of the penis emerges.
Deinde mundifica ipsam ex eo quod aggregatur in ea sordicie.	Then cleanse it from the filth that has gathered upon it.
Deinde liga locum signatum cum filo duplo.	Then tie the marked spot with doubled thread.
Postea liga inferius eo parumper ligamentum secundum.	Then bind somewhat lower than this with another bandage.
Deinde tene cum indice tuo, et pollice locum ligamenti inferioris retentione bona, et incide inter duo ligamenta.	Then hold the place of the lower binding with your index finger and thumb with good tension, and cut between the two bindings.
Deinde eleua cutem sursum uelociter, et extrahe caput uirgae.	Then lift up the skin quickly and extract the head of the penis.
Deinde dimitte sanguinem currere paulatim (est enim melius) et pone puluerem desuper: et super puluerem pannum in quo expansus est uitellus oui decocti in aqua rosata, concussum cum oleo ros. Recenti bono: et dimitte eum super ipsum usque ad diem alium: et cura ipsum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then let the blood flow gradually (for this is better), and put powder on top; then place a cloth on which has been spread the liver of a sheep cooked in rosewater, shaken with rose oil. And recently apply this good treatment until the next day; and continue the remaining treatment until it heals.
Forma autem forficis ad mundificationem haec est.	The shape of the forceps for cleansing is as follows:
Sint hebetes duae extremitates, et sint incidentes: ne egrediatur in eis ramus claui: et sit longitudo duarum acuitatum, sicut longitudo duorum manubriorum aequaliter.	Let the two ends be blunt and incurved so that the branch of the claw does not slip out; and let the length of the two points be equal to the length of the two handles equally.
Error uero cadens in mundificatione est: quoniam fortasse effugit cutis intrinseca tota, aut pars eius apud incisionem.	The error that often occurs during cleansing is that perhaps the inner skin may slip away entirely or part of it at the incision.
Ergo oportet, ut extendas eam ex hora tua cum ungue tuo ante apostemationem loci: et incidas eam secundum aequalitatem.	Therefore, you should stretch it out with your fingernail before cauterization and cut it evenly according to its length.
Quod si non potes tenere eam cum ungue tuo, tunc extrahe eam cum uncino, et incide eam.	If you cannot hold it with your fingernail, then extract it with a hook and cut it.
Si autem praeterierint ei tres dies, et remanet quod est sub uirga inflatum, apostematum: tunc dimitte illud, donec sedetur apostema calidum, et excoria illud cum facilitate, et incide illud secundum quod praeparatur tibi: et caue tibi a capite uirgae.	But if three days pass and there remains something under the penis that is swollen with inflammation, then let it alone until the inflammation becomes hot; then excoriate it gently and cut it according to how it presents itself; but beware of cutting the head of the penis.
Non enim nocebit ei illud.	For this will not harm him.
Cura ergo illud cum eo quod consolidat uulnus ex pulueribus, quos narrauimus in tractatu de pulueribus: et si inciditur ex cute supra mensuram, et euadit ad superiora, non nocet ei illud etiam.	Therefore treat it with the substances that we have mentioned in our book on powders that promote wound healing. But if by chance you cut too deep and damage any underlying tissue, it will not cause harm either.
Cura ergo illud cum eo quod diximus, donec sanetur.	Therefore treat it with what we have said until it heals.
¶ De extractione Vrinae retentae in uesica.	On the removal of a retained foreign body in the bladder.
Caput LVIII.	Chapter 58
Urinae retentio in uesica, fit ab opilatione facta ex lapide, aut sanguine congelato, aut pus, aut carne nata, et similibus illis ex eis quae diximus ex modis curationis in diuisione.	Retention of urine in the bladder occurs due to blockage caused by a stone, congealed blood, pus, or flesh that has grown there, and similar substances resulting from the methods of treatment that we have mentioned earlier.
Et si non soluitur Vrina, et uides retentionem eius esse propter Lapidem, qui iam est in collo uesicae: tunc oportet ut sit infirmus super genua sua curuatus.	And if the urine does not dissolve and you see that its retention is due to a stone located at the neck of the bladder, then it is necessary for the patient to be positioned on their knees.
Deinde componantur pedes eius super dorsum eius, et extendat uentrem suum ex superiori parte dorsi eius, et stringat infirmus anhelitum suum quantum possibile est ei.	Then position his feet over his back and stretch out his belly from the upper part of his back. Let the patient hold his breath as much as possible for him.
Cogitur ergo cum collo uesicae ad expulsionem Lapidis ad posteriora: quare absoluitur Vrina.	Therefore press with your finger on the neck of the bladder towards the back in order to expel the stone, whereupon the urine will be released.
Quod si non soluitur cum eo quod diximus, et uehemens sit res super infirmum: tunc oportet ut administres extractionem eius cum instrumento, quod nominatur siringa, cuius haec est forma Sit ex argento, et sit subtile, lene, concauum sicut cannula pennae auis in subtilitate radii, longum in similitudine palmi unius et medii: cui sit cannula subtilis in capite eius.	But if it does not dissolve with what we have said and the situation is urgent for the patient, then you must perform its extraction using an instrument called a syringe. Its form should be as follows: It should be made of silver, thin, smooth, and concave like a quill's nib in its fineness; long like the length of one and a half hands' breadths; and it should have a fine cannula at its tip.
Et modus exitus Vrinae per ipsum est, ut accipias filum duplicatum, et liges in extremitate eius lanam, aut cotum, ligatura bona: et intromittas extremitatem fili in inferiori parte Siringae: et incide cum forficibus si superfluit aliquid ex lana, uerum intromitte in cannulam cum uehementia, sicut alzer.	And the way to extract urine through it is as follows: Take a doubled thread and tie wool or cotton at its end with a good ligature. Insert the tip of the thread into the lower part of the syringe. If any excess wool protrudes from the syringe, cut it off with forceps. Then insert the cannula forcefully, like blowing through a straw.
Deinde inunge siringam cum oleo, aut cum butyro, et albugine oui: et fac sedere infirmum super sedem, et embroca uesicam, et ipsius uirgam cum oleis humidis, et oleo oliuae, et aqua tepida.	Then fill the syringe with oil or butter and egg white. Make the patient sit on a chair, uncover their groin area, and apply olive oil and warm water to the penis along with the ointment.
Deinde intromitte siringam in uirgam cum facilitate, donec perueniat ad radicem uirgae.	Then insert the syringe into the penis gently until it reaches the root of the penis.
Deinde dupla ipsam superius a parte umbilici.	Then press upwards on both sides above the navel.
Deinde impelle siringam intra ipsam, donec perueniat ad Vesicam, et sentiat eam infirmus iam peruenisse ad rem uacuam: et non fit hoc secundum hunc ordinem, nisi quoniam meatus, in quo uadit, est in quo est tortuositas.	Then push the syringe into it until it reaches the bladder, and the patient feels that it has reached an empty space. This is not done according to this order unless there is a bend in the path through which it passes.
Deinde extende filum cum lana paulatim.	Then gradually pull out the thread with wool attached.
Vrina enim sequetur lanam.	For urine will follow the wool.
Deinde extrahe eam, et fac currere Vrinam per uiam urinae: et itera siringam, et non cesses facere illud, donec euacuetur uesica, et inueniat infirmus alleuiationem.	Then remove it and allow urine to flow through its usual path. Repeat the process with the syringe until the bladder is empty and the patient finds relief.
¶ De qualitate clisterizationis uesicae cum Clepshydra.	On the quality of washing the bladder using a water clock.
Caput LIX.	Chapter 59
Quando accidit in uesica ulcus, aut sanguis in ea congelatur, aut coartatur in ea pus, et uis distillare in eam aquas et medicinas: tunc fiat cum instrumento quod nominatur Clepshydra, et haec est forma eius.	When an ulcer occurs in the bladder or blood congeals there, or pus becomes trapped and water and medicines cannot be poured into it, then use an instrument called a "water clock," and this is its shape.
Est enim surda, id est, clausa.	For it is closed at one end.
Et in eo sunt tria foramina, duo ex parte una, et unum ex parte altera, sicut uides.	And there are three holes in it, two on one side and one on the other side as shown.
Et locus concauus, in quo est illud quod impellit, sit secundum quantitatem quod opilet ipsum sine additione, donec quando trahitur cum eo aliquid, ex humiditatibus attrahatur: et quando impellitur, cum eo expellatur ad longinquum: secundum quod facit clepshydra, qua proiicitur naphta, id est, ignis graecus in praeliis martis.	And the concave place where the thing that pushes is located should be according to its size without any addition so that when it is pulled with it some moisture is drawn from it. And when it is pushed with it, it should be expelled far away just like a water clock which throws out naphtha, i.e., Greek fire in battles.
Cum ergo uis proiicere humiditates in uesicam, intromitte extremitatem clepshydrae in humiditatem, et trahe cum eo quod impellit ad superiora, humiditas enim trahitur in concauitatem clepshydrae.	Therefore, when you wish to throw moisture into the bladder, insert the end of the water clock into the moisture and pull with it what pushes upwards, for the moisture is drawn into the concave part of the water clock.
Deinde intromitte extremitatem eius in uirgam, secundum quod narrauimus in siringa.	Then insert its extremity into the urethra as we have described regarding the syringe.
Deinde impelle humiditatem cum eo quod impellit illa namque humiditas peruenit ad uesicam statim, ita quod sentit eam infirmus.	Next, push the moisture with what pushes it, for that moisture will immediately reach the bladder so that the patient feels it.
Forma clisteris subtilis quo clisterizatur uesica.	The shape of a fine clyster used to enema the bladder.
Fiat ex argento, aut auricalco: cuius caput altius sit simile alcama paruo, et sub eo sinus inter quem cadat ligamentum.	It should be made from silver or gold: whose head is higher and resembles a small jar, and beneath it there is a hollow into which the ligature falls.
Deinde accipe uesicam arietis, et pone in ea humiditatem, qua uis clisterizare uesicam.	Then take the bladder of a ram and place in it the moisture with which you wish to enema the bladder.
Deinde liga eam inter duos sinus ligatura forti cum filo duplo: et calefac illam humiditatem parumper super ignem.	Next, tie it between two hollows with a strong ligature using doubled thread; and warm that moisture briefly over a fire.
Deinde intromitte extremitatem clisteris in uirgam, postea stringe manum tuam super uesicam cum humiditate strictura decenti, donec sentiat infirmus, quod illa humiditas iam peruenit ad uesicam.	Then insert the end of the clyster into the urethra, afterwards press your hand tightly over the bladder with an appropriate amount of moisture until the patient feels that the moisture has reached the bladder.
Si autem non est tibi praesens uesica, tunc accipe frustum pergameni, et fac ex eo circulum, et perfora ipsum ab omni rotunditate sua.	But if you do not have a present bladder, then take a piece of parchment and make from it a circle, and pierce it throughout its entire circumference.
Deinde intromitte filum forte in illis foraminibus, sicut reuoluuntur.	Then insert a strong thread through those holes as they revolve.
Deinde aggrega circulum, sicut aggregatur alsofratu: postquam tu ponis in eo illud quod uis ex humiditatibus, et oleis, et aquis.	Then gather the circle together like a drawstring purse; after which you place therein what you wish from moistures, oils, and waters.
Deinde liga ipsum in instrumento: et fac cum eo sicut fecisti cum uesica ex expressione cum manu tua, donec perueniat humiditas ad uesicam.	Then tie it into the instrument: and do with it as you did with the bladder by expressing it with your hand until the moisture reaches the bladder.
¶ De extractione Lapidis.	On the Extraction of a Stone.
Caput LX.	Chapter 60
Iam diximus in diuisione species Lapidis, et curationem eius cum medicinis: et dixi differentiam inter Lapidem generatum in renibus, et uesica, et signa illius totius: et dixi Lapidem in quo cadit operatio cum manu et sectio: et est Lapis generatus in uesica proprie: et ille qui figitur in uirga: et ego sum narrans illud cum expositione manifesta et abbreuiatione.	Now we have spoken about the division of kinds of stone and its treatment with medicines, and I have mentioned the difference between a stone generated in the kidneys and bladder, and the signs of each kind, and how to operate on it with the hand and cutting instrument. The stone generated in the bladder is particularly so, and also one that lodges in the urethra. And now I will describe this with clear explanation and abbreviation.
Dico ergo, quod Lapis generatus in uesica, plurimum accidit pueris.	I say therefore that a stone generated in the bladder mostly happens to children.
Et ex signis eius est, quod urina egreditur ex uesica similis aquae in subtilitate sua: et apparet in ea harena alba, et fricat infirmus uirgam suam, et laborat cum ea, et multotiens pendet.	And among its signs are that urine exits the bladder like water in its fineness, and there appears in it white sand, and the sick person rubs his penis frequently, and experiences pain with it, and often hangs himself.
Deinde erigitur, et egreditur cum eo anus in multis eorum.	Then he raises up, and something comes out with it from his anus in many cases.
Et est facilis sanatio puerorum, ex eo usquequo consequuntur quatuordecim annos.	And the cure of children is easy as long as they have not reached fourteen years of age.
Et est difficilis in senibus.	And it is difficult in the elderly.
In iuuenibus autem est media, in eo quod est inter illud: et eius cuius Lapis est maior, curatio facilior: et si paruus, est econuerso illius cura.	But in young people it is of medium difficulty, between these two cases. And the cure for one whose stone is large is easier, but if it is small then its cure is more difficult.
Cum ergo peruenimus ad curationem, oportet in primis, ut mundificemus infirmum cum clisteri, quod extrahat totum stercus quod est in intestinis suis: ipsum enim quandoque prohibet inuentionem Lapidis apud inquisitionem.	Therefore, when we come to the treatment, it is necessary first to cleanse the sick person with a clyster that will remove all the feces that are in his bowels, for sometimes this prevents the discovery of the stone during examination.
Deinde accipiatur infirmus cum pedibus suis, et concutiatur, et moueatur ad inferiora: ut descendat Lapis ad profundum uesicae, aut saliat de loco alto aliquotiens.	Then the sick person should be taken with his feet and shaken, and moved towards his lower parts so that the stone descends to the bottom of the bladder or falls from a high place sometimes.
Deinde fac eum sedere inter manus tuas praeparatum, et manus eius sint sub coxis ipsius, ut fiat uesica tota decliuis ad inferiora.	Then have him sit between your hands prepared, and his hands under his hips so that the bladder is entirely inclined towards its lower parts.
Deinde perquire eum, et tange eum extrinsecus.	Then examine him externally and touch him there.
Si ergo sentis Lapidem in spacio, tunc propera statim cum sectione super ipsum.	If you feel a stone in the passage, then promptly proceed with incision above it.
Quod si non cadat sub tactu tuo omnino, tunc oportet ut abstergas digitum indicem cum oleo manus sinistrae, si infirmus est puer: aut digitum medium si est iuuenis completus: et intromittas ipsum in anum suum, et perquire de Lapide, donec stat sub digito tuo: et conuerte eum paulatim ad collum uesicae.	But if it does not fall out with your touch at all, then you must cleanse your index finger with the oil of your left hand if the patient is a boy; or your middle finger if he is an adult, and insert it into his anus to search for the stone until it is under your finger, and gradually turn it towards the neck of the bladder.
Deinde preme super ipsum cum digito tuo, et impelle ipsum ad exteriora aduersus locus, cuius sectionem uis: et praecipe ministro, ut premat uesicam manu sua, et praecipe alii ministro, ut extendat testiculos manu sua dextra ad superiora: et alia manu sua, ut remoueat cutem, quae est sub testiculis in parte a loco in quo est sectio.	Then press upon it with your finger and push it towards the exterior at the location where you wish to make an incision; and instruct an assistant to press on the bladder with his hand, and instruct another assistant to extend the testicles upwards with his right hand while removing the skin that is below them at the place of the intended incision.
Deinde intromitte Spatumile incidens, cuius forma haec est.	Then introduce the spatula-shaped instrument, whose shape is as follows.
Et finde in eo quod est inter anum et testiculos, et non in medio, ad latus natis sinistrae: et sit sectio super ipsum lapidem, et digitus tuus sit in ano: et fiat sectio transuersa, ut sit sectio exterius ampla, et interius stricta, secundum quantitatem quod sit possibile egressio Lapidis ex ea non maior.	And find the point between the anus and the testicles, not in the middle, but on the left side facing the births; let the incision be made upon the stone itself, with your finger remaining inside the anus, and make the incision transverse so that it is wide externally and narrow internally, according to what is possible for the exit of the stone from it not being greater.
Fortasse enim comprimit digitus, qui est in ano Lapidem apud sectionem, et egreditur absque difficultate.	Perhaps indeed the finger which is in the anus will compress the stone at the site of incision, and it will come out without difficulty.
Et scias, quod ex Lapide est cui sunt anguli et margines, quare fit difficilis exitus eius propter illud.	And know that a stone with angles and edges makes its exit difficult because of this.
Et ex eo est lenis, similis glandulae, et rotundus: et fit facilis egressus eius.	And one which is smooth, like a gland, and round makes for easy exit.
Ei ergo cui sunt anguli, et margines, adde in fissura.	Therefore, if it has angles and edges, add to the incision.
Quod si non egreditur ita, tunc oportet ut ingenies super ipsum: aut stringas super eum cum gesti decenter, cuius extremitas sit sicut Luna, quae stringat super Lapidem, et non euadat ab ea: aut ut intromittas sub eo instrumentum subtile, curuatae extremitatis.	But if it does not come out thus, then you must hook onto it; or tie it with a thread tied skillfully, whose end is like the crescent moon that will tie around the stone and not slip off of it; or introduce beneath it an instrument with a curved tip.
Si autem non potes super cum, tunc amplifica foramen parumper.	But if you cannot get over it, then widen the opening slightly.
Quod si uincit te aliquid ex sanguine, abscinde ipsum cum zegi.	And if something from the blood defeats you, cut it with a scalpel.
Si uero lapis est plus quam unus, tunc impelle in primis magnum ad os uesicae.	But if the stone is larger than one, then first introduce a large bougie into the urethra.
Deinde incide super ipsum.	Then cut upon it.
Postea impelle paruum post illud: et similiter fac si sunt plures duobus.	Afterwards insert a small one after that; and do likewise if there are more than two.
Quod si magnus est ualde, tunc ignorantia est ut seces super ipsum sectione magna.	But if it is very large, then it is ignorance to make an incision too small upon it.
Quoniam accidit infirmo una duarum rerum, aut ut moriatur, aut accidit ei distillatio urinae assidua: proptera, quia non consolidatur locus omnino.	For one of two things happens to the patient: either he dies, or continuous dripping of urine occurs because the location does not become completely consolidated.
Verum administra expulsionem eius, donec egrediatur: aut ingenia in fractura eius cum forficibus, donec extrahas eum frustatim.	But administer its expulsion until it comes out; or hook into its fragments with forceps until you extract them piece by piece.
Cum ergo compleueris operationem tuam, tunc imple uulnus thure, et aloe, et sanguine draconis: et stringe ipsum, et pone super ipsum pannum infusum oleo et uino, aut oleo rosato, et aqua frigida: ut sedetur apostema calidum.	And when you have completed your operation, then fill the wound with frankincense, aloe, and dragon's blood; and tie it, and place upon it a cloth soaked in oil and wine, or rose oil, and cold water so that the hot inflammation may subside.
Deinde resupina infirmum super collum suum, et non soluas ligamentum, usque ad diem tertium.	Then make the patient lie on his back with his head supported, and do not loosen the bandage until the third day.
Cum ergo solueris ipsum, embroca locum cum aqua, et oleo multo.	And when you remove it, wash the location with water and much oil.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento dyafinicon, et unguento basilicon, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with ointment of diaphanicon and ointment of basilicum until it heals.
Si autem accidit in uulnere apostema calidum additum, et corrosi, et illi similia: sicut si congeletur sanguis in uesica, et prohibeatur ex eo urina: et cognoscitur illud ex egressione sanguinis cum urina.	But if inflammation with burning and similar conditions occur in the wound, such as if blood clots in the urethra and urine is prevented from flowing, and this is recognized by the exit of blood mixed with urine.
Intromitte ergo digitum tuum in uulnus, et extrahe illum sanguinem.	Therefore introduce your finger into the wound and extract that blood.
Nam si remanet, prouocat ad corruptionem uesicae, et putrefactionem eius.	For if it remains, it causes inflammation of the urethra and its decay.
Deinde ablue uulnus cum aceto, et aqua, et sale: et oppone omni speciei cum eo quod conuenit ex curatione, usquequo sanetur.	Then wash the wound with vinegar, water, and salt, and apply to it whatever is suitable for healing until it heals.
Et oportet in horis curationis totius, ut liges duas coxas, et aggreges, caussa medicinarum quae ponuntur super locum.	And it is necessary that during the time of treatment, you should tie two bandages together and attach them, so that the medicines placed on the site remain in place.
Quod si lapis est paruus, et sit in meatu uirgae, et figitur in eo, et prohibetur urinae exitus: tunc cura ipsum cum eo quod narro antequam peruenias ad sectionem.	If there is a small stone in the urethra and it becomes stuck and obstructs urine flow, then treat it with what I have mentioned before you proceed to surgery.
Multotiens enim a sectione excusaris per hanc curationem, iam enim probaui illud.	For often you will be spared from surgery through this treatment, as I have proven it.
Et est, ut accipias Perforatorium ex ferro alferico, cuius haec est forma, triangulatae extremitatis, acutum, fixum in ligno.	And take a perforator made of iron with the following shape: triangular at one end and sharp, fixed onto wood.
Deinde accipe filum, et liga cum eo uirgam sub lapide ut non redeat ad uesicam.	Then take a thread and tie it to the urethra below the stone so that it does not slip back into the bladder.
Deinde intromitte ferrum perforans in uirgam cum facilitate, donec perueniat Perforatorium ad ipsum lapidem: et reuolue Perforatorium manu tua in ipso lapide paulatim: et coneris perforationem eius, donec facias ipsum penetrare a parte altera.	Then insert the perforator into the urethra gently until it reaches the stone. Then rotate the perforator with your hand on the stone gradually until you make a hole through it.
Urina namque absoluitur statim.	For urine will be immediately relieved.
Deinde preme manum tuam super illud quod remansit ex lapide ab exteriori parte uirgae.	Then press your hand over what remains of the stone on the outside of the urethra.
Ipse enim frangitur, et egreditur cum urina, et sanatur infirmus.	For it will break apart and exit with urine, and the patient will be healed.
Si autem non praeparatur tibi haec curatio, propter aliquid quod prohibet ab illo: tunc liga filum sub lapide, et filum aliud supra lapidem.	But if this treatment is not possible due to some obstacle, then tie a thread below the stone and another one above it.
Deinde seca super lapidem in ipsa uirga inter duas ligaturas.	Then cut through the urethra above the stone between the two threads.
Deinde extrahe ipsum.	Then remove the stone.
Postea solue ligamentum, et mundifica sanguinem congelatum, qui fit in uulnere.	Afterwards untie the thread and clean the congealed blood that forms in the wound.
Et non est necessarium ligamentum fili sub lapide, nisi ut non redeat ad uesicam: et ligamentum aliud desuper, nisi ut quando soluitur filum post egressionem lapidis, redeat cutis ad locum suum, et cooperiat uulnus: et propter illud necesse est tibi illud quando ligas filum superius, ut eleues cutem ad superiora, ut redeat apud complementum tuum, et cooperiat uulnus, sicut diximus.	And it is not necessary to tie a thread below the stone unless to prevent it from slipping back into the bladder. And another thread above is not necessary unless when the thread is untied after the stone has exited, the skin returns to its place and covers the wound. Therefore, when tying the upper thread, you must lift the skin upwards so that it returns to its original position and covers the wound as we have said.
¶ De extractione Lapidis mulierum.	On the Extraction of Stones from Women.
Caput LXI.	Chapter 61
Parum generatur Lapis in mulieribus.	Stones are rarely formed in women.
Si autem accidat alicui earum lapis, tunc difficilis est curatio, et prohibetur propter modos multos.	But if a stone happens to one of them, then the cure is difficult and hindered by many methods.
Vnus eorum est: quod mulier fortasse est uirgo.	One among them is that perhaps the woman is a virgin.
Et secundus est, quia tu non inuenis mulierem quae detegat seipsam medico, quando est casta, aut ex habentibus maritos.	And secondly, because you will not find a woman who reveals herself to a physician when she is chaste or among married women.
Tertius est, quia tu non inuenis mulierem bene scientem hanc artem, praecipue operationem cum manu.	Thirdly, because you will not find a woman well-versed in this art, especially the manual operation.
Et quartus est longinquitas a loco lapidis: quare indiget sectione profunda, et in illo est timor.	And fourthly, there is the remoteness of the stone from its location, requiring a deep incision, and causing fear.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad illud, tunc oportet ut accipias mulierem medicam, bene scientem: et parum inuenitur.	But if necessity demands this procedure, then it is necessary to take a woman physician who knows well; but such are rarely found.
Si uero priuaris ea, tunc quaere medicum castum, subtilem, et praesenta mulierem obstetricem bene doctam in re mulierum, aut mulierem quae in hac arte innuit partem artis: fac ergo eam praesentem, et praecipue ei, ut faciat totum quod praecipis ei ex inquisitione super lapidem.	But if you cannot find such a woman, then seek out a chaste, skilled physician and bring with him a midwife well-versed in women's matters or another woman who has experience in this art. And ensure that she is present throughout the procedure, especially when she performs all tasks according to your instructions regarding the stone examination.
In primis quod est, ut aspiciat si mulier est uirgo: tunc oportet ut intromittat digitum in anum eius, et quaerat lapidem.	Firstly, have her examine whether the woman is a virgin; then she should insert her finger into the woman's anus and search for the stone.
Si ergo inuenit ipsum, coartet eum sub digito suo, et tunc praecipe obstetrici, ut intromittat digitum suum in uuluam infirmae, et inquirat super lapidem, postquam ponit manum suam sinistram super uesicam, et comprimit eam compressione bona.	If she finds the stone, she should hold it with her finger and then instruct the midwife to insert her finger into the weakened vagina and search for the stone after placing her left hand over the bladder and applying gentle pressure.
Si ergo inuenit lapidem, tunc oportet ut gradatim moueat eum ab orificio uesicae ad inferiora cum summa uirtutis suae, donec perueniat cum eo ad radicem coxae.	If she finds the stone, then it is necessary that she gradually moves it from the opening of the bladder downwards with all her strength until she reaches its root at the hip.
Deinde secet super eum apud oppositionem medietatis uuluae apud radicem coxae, ex quacunque parte praeparatur ei, et sentit lapidem in illa parte: et digitus eius non remoueatur a lapide, coartans sub eo: et sit sectio parua in primis.	Then she should cut above it on the opposite side of the midpoint of the vulva at the root of the hip from whichever side the stone presents itself, and sense the stone in that part; and her finger should not be removed from the stone while pressing beneath it; and the incision should initially be small.
Deinde intromittat radium super illam sectionem.	Then she shall insert a speculum into that opening.
Si ergo sentit lapidem, tunc addat in sectionem secundum quantitatem proportionatam quod lapis egreditur ab ea.	If she feels the stone, then she should increase the size of the incision according to the amount by which the stone protrudes from it.
Et scias, quod species lapidis sunt multae.	Know that the shapes of stones are many.
Ex his enim est paruus, et magnus, lenis et asper, longus, et rotundus habens ramos.	Among these there is a small one and a large one, smooth and rough, long and round with branches.
Scias ergo species eius, ut significetur tibi per hoc super illud quod uis.	Therefore know the shape of it, so that you may understand by this which stone you wish to remove.
Si ergo uincit te sanguis, tunc adde in loco zegi tritum, et tene ipsum hora una, donec abscindatur sanguis.	If bleeding overcomes you, then add spongy powder made from the skin of an onion and hold it in place for one hour until the bleeding stops.
Deinde redi ad operationem tuam, donec egrediatur lapis: et fac, ut praepares tecum ex instrumentis, quae dixi in extractione lapidis in uiris, ut adiuueris per ea in operatione tua.	Then return to your procedure until the stone exits; and make sure that you have with you the instruments which I mentioned for extracting stones from the bladder so that you may aid yourself with them during this operation.
Quod si uincit te fluxus sanguinis, et scis quod expulsio sanguinis est ex arteria quae incisa est: tunc pone puluerem super locum, et stringe eum cum puluillis strictura decenti: et non mutes illud: et dimitte lapidem, et non extrahas ipsum.	But if the flow of blood overcomes you and you know that the bleeding is coming from an artery which has been cut, then place powder on the location and tie it with a suitable ligature; do not move it; and leave the stone alone and do not attempt to remove it.
Fortasse enim morietur mulier infirma.	For indeed the weak woman may die.
Deinde cura uulnus.	Then dress the wound.
Cum ergo sedatur acuitas sanguinis post dies, et putrefit locus, tune redi ad operationem tuam, donec egrediatur lapis.	When the flow of blood has subsided after several days and the area has begun to putrefy, then return to your procedure until the stone exits.
¶ De sectione suiper Herniam aquosam.	On the Incision for a Hydrocele.
Caput LXII.	Chapter 62
Ramex aquosa non est, nisi aggregatio humiditatis in sifac albo, quod est sub cute testiculi continente ouum: et nominatur sifac.	A watery tumor is not present unless there is a gathering of moisture in the white sac which is under the skin containing the testicle; and this is called the tunica vaginalis.
Et quandoque est in panniculo proprio sibi, quem praeparauit ei natura in parte oui, donec putetur: quod est ouum aliud, et est cutis testiculi inter sifac album, quod diximus: et non fit illud nisi raro.	And sometimes it is in its own little bag, which nature has prepared for it in the part of the testis until it appears; this is like a separate testis, and is the skin of the testis between the white tunica vaginalis we mentioned earlier. This happens only rarely.
Et generatio quidem huius ramicis, est ex debilitate quae accidit testiculis: quare effunditur ad eos haec materia.	The formation of this collection occurs due to weakness that befalls the testicles; therefore, this material accumulates towards them.
Et quandoque accidit ex percussione super testiculos.	And sometimes it happens due to a blow to the testicles.
Et haec humiditas est habens colores multos.	This moisture has many colors.
Aut enim est color eius decliuis ad citrinitatem, aut est sanguineus rubeus, aut faeculentus, niger, aut est aquosus albus, et est illud quod est plus.	It may be yellowish or bloody-red in color, or dark and foul-smelling, or it may be white and watery. This last type is the most common.
Et signa quibus scitur ubi sit aggregatio aquae, sunt ista.	The signs by which one knows where the watery collection is located are as follows:
Nam si est in sifac albo quod diximus, tunc apostema est rotundum ad longitudinem parumper sicut figura oui: et non apparet testiculus, quoniam humiditas continet eum ab omni parte.	If it is in the white tunica vaginalis we mentioned earlier, then the swelling will be round and not much elongated like an egg shape; and the testis itself will not be visible because the moisture surrounds it on all sides.
Et si est humiditas in panniculo proprio sibi, tunc apostema est rotundum cum parte oui, et propter hoc extimat homo quia est ouum aliud.	But if the moisture is in its own little bag, then the swelling will be round with a part of the testis, making one think that there is an additional testis.
Et si humiditas est inter cutem testiculorum et sifac album, tunc cadit sub sensu.	And if the moisture is between the skin of the testes and the white tunica vaginalis, then it will be felt by touch.
Quando ergo uis cognitionem coloris humiditatis, tunc experire colorem humiditatis in apostemate cum Intromisso quadrato, cuius forma praecessit.	Therefore, if you wish to know the color of the moisture, use a square instrument to probe the swelling and observe its color.
Secundum illud ergo quod egreditur in uestigio Intromissi, iudica de illo quod est inter ipsum.	Based on what comes out at the point where the instrument was inserted, you can judge what is inside.
Cum ergo uenimus ad curationem cum ferro, tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo, ut phlebotometur si possibile est ei illud, et uides corpus eius plenum.	When we come to the treatment using an iron instrument, then you should order that the patient be bled if possible, and observe whether his body is full.
Deinde resupinetur super dorsum suum super rem altam parum, et pone sub eo pannos multos.	Then he should lie on his back over a raised object slightly high, and put many cloths underneath him.
Deinde sede tu super sinistram eius, et praecipe ministro, ut sedeat a dextra eius, qui extendat uirgam eius ad unum duorum laterum cutis testiculorum, et ad partem mirach uentris.	Then you should sit on the left of him and order your assistant to sit on his right side, who should stretch out his hand towards one of two sides of the skin covering the testicles, and towards the area below the navel.
Deinde accipe spatumile latum, et seca cutem testiculorum ex medio per longitudinem, usque prope pectinem: et fiat sectio secundum rectitudinem aequedistantis lineae quae diuidit cutem testiculorum, donec perueniat ad sifac album comprehendens: et excoria ipsum et obserua, uel caue ex hoc, ut seces ipsum: et sit excoriatio tua qua ipsum excorias, ex parte quae suspenditur cum ouo plus: et subtiliter scrutare cum excoriatione secundum quantitatem quod tibi possibile est.	Then take a wide spatula and cut the skin of the testicles from the middle along its length up to near the pubic hair: and make the incision according to the straightness of an equidistant line that divides the skin of the testicles, until you reach the white scrotum enclosing it: and tear off its foreskin and observe whether there is a wound or take care not to cut it; and let your tearing be on the side that hangs with the egg more: and examine it carefully with the tear according to the amount that is possible for you.
Deinde perfora sifac plenum aqua perforatione ampla, et extrahe totam aquam.	Then pierce the full scrotum with a wide piercing instrument and draw out all the water.
Deinde separa inter duo labia sectionis cum uncinis, et extende sifac ad superiora, et non tangas cutem testiculorum comprehendentem: et incide sifac qualitercunque est possibile tibi incidere ipsum, aut cum totalitate sua, aut frustatim, praecipue latus eius subtile.	Then separate between the two lips of the incision with hooks and stretch out the scrotum upwards and do not touch the skin enclosing the testicles: and cut the scrotum however it is possible for you to cut it, either with its entirety or in pieces, especially its thin side.
Nam si tu non exquisite perscrutaris, in incisione eius non fit securitas, quin aqua redeat.	For if you do not carefully examine, in cutting it there is no security that the water will not return.
Si autem procedit ouum exterius a cute sua in hora operationis tuae: tunc quando compleueris sectionem sifac, reduc ipsum.	But if the egg protrudes outside its skin during your operation, then when you have completed the incision of the scrotum, push it back.
Deinde aggrega duo labia cutis testiculorum cum sutura.	Then join together the two lips of the skin covering the testicles with stitches.
Deinde cura ipsum sicut reliqua uulnera, donec sanetur.	Then treat it like other wounds until it heals.
Quod si inuenis ouum corruptum ex nigredine alia, tunc oportet ut liges uasa, quae sunt suspensorium, timens fluxum sanguinis.	But if you find the egg corrupted by another blackness, then you should tie the suspending vessels, fearing blood flow.
Deinde abscinde testiculum cum suspensorio, et extrahe ouum: postea cura illud cum eo quod diximus.	Then cut off the testicle with its suspension and draw out the egg: afterwards treat it as we said before.
Si uero aqua est aggregata in duabus partibus, tunc scias quia sunt duae ramices: seca ergo partem aliam secundum quod fecisti in altera aequaliter.	If water is gathered in two parts, then know that there are two branches: therefore cut the other part equally as you did in the first one.
Et si aequatur tibi, ut sit operatio una, tunc fac: deinde absterge sanguinem.	And if it seems equal to you, so that it is one operation, then do thus: afterwards wipe away the blood.
Et intromitte in sectiones lanam submersam in oleo, aut in oleo rosato: et pone deforis lanam aliam quam submersisti in uino et oleo, et expande eam super duos testiculos, et mirach uentris: et pone desuper pannos duplicatos, et sunt puluilli: et liga eos desuper cum ligamento, quod est habens sex secundum hanc formam.	Then introduce into the sections wool dipped in oil or rose oil; and place outside wool that has been dipped in wine and oil, and spread it over the two testicles and the navel; then put doubled cloths on top, which are poultices, and tie them up with a bandage that is six inches wide according to this form.
Deinde sumantur duo panni, et suantur, et impleantur la na carminata, secundum hanc similitudinem: et fiant extremitates quibus premitur ex coto, aut lana humida: et aggregentur cum strictura in lumbari bracharum: et una extremitatum accipiat super anum usque ad dorsum, et secunda accipiat ad partem pectinis: et duae extremitates super duas coxas inferius, et duae extremitates aliae super duo inguina, et aggregetur strictura tota in lumbari bracharum.	Then two cloths are taken and heated, and filled with powdered cinnamon according to this likeness: and their ends should be made of cotton or wet wool; and they should be attached together with the bandage at the flanks of the thighs; and one end should reach over the buttock up to the back, and the second to the breast; and two other ends over the two lower thighs, and two other ends over the two groins, and all the bandage should be gathered together at the flanks of the thighs.
Et, quandoque artificialiter medicatur haec ramex cum cauterio loco sectionis cum ferro: et est, ut accipias cauterium cultellare subtile, et seces cum eo cutem testiculorum: et est ignitum, secundum quod narrauimus: donec quando detegitur sifac album continens aquam: tunc accipe cauterium, secundum hanc formam.	And when this branch is artificially treated with a cautery instead of cutting it with an iron, then take a fine skinning knife cautery and cut the skin of the testicles with it; and heat it according to what we have described until when it is revealed that white foam containing water appears: then take the cautery in this form.
Assimilatur literae graecae.	Greek letters are used here.
Deinde perfora cum eo illud sifac, et est ignitum, donec egrediatur humiditas tota.	Then pierce that foam with it and heat it until all the moisture has come out.
Deinde extende sifac cum uncinis, et excoria cum cauterio subtili ignito, et incide ipsum secundum quod possibile est tibi, donec eradices totum eius.	Then stretch the foam with hooks and scrape it off with a fine heated cautery and cut into it as much as you can until you have removed all of it.
Et caue ex ouo, ne tangat ipsum ignis.	And beware that the fire does not touch the egg.
Et scias, quod haec operatio est saluior, et longinquior a fluxu sanguinis, et melior quam operatio cum sectione.	Know that this operation is safer and less prone to bleeding, and better than one involving cutting.
Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit in hora sectionis, aut in hora cauterii apostema calidum, aut fluxus sanguinis, aut aliquid aliud: tunc oportet ut cures quod contrarietatem tibi facit ex illo cum curatione quae conuenit ei, secundum quod praemissum est.	But if you encounter resistance during the hour of cutting or cauterizing, whether it be a hot abscess, bleeding, or anything else, then you must treat what is causing the resistance with the appropriate treatment, as previously described.
Si autem infirmus est timidus, et non expectat super hanc operationem, propter horribilitatem suam: tunc administra perforationem secundum quod ego narro illud: et est.	If the patient is fearful and does not eagerly await this procedure due to its frightening nature, then perform a puncture as I have described it.
Quando certificatur tibi apud te per illud quod diximus de significationibus, quod ramex est aquosa: tunc oportet quod facias sedere infirmum super sedem eleuatam.	Once you have confirmed through the signs that the stone is watery, then make the patient sit on a raised chair.
Deinde perfora apostema in inferiori parte sui cum spatumili lato: et pone perforationem secundum longitudinem corporis, et sit apertio ampla, donec currat aqua tota.	Then puncture the lower part of the abscess with a wide spatula and make the puncture along the length of the body; let the opening be large enough for all the water to flow out.
Deinde pone super locum cotum, et liga ipsum, et dimitte ipsum ut currat residuum aquae: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then place a cotton pad on the wound and bind it; let the remaining water run off, then treat it until the wound heals.
Si autem contrarietas sit egressioni aquae in hora qua perforas ipsam: et non sit illud nisi propterea, quia panniculus albus contrarietatem facit in orificio uulneris, et prohibet exitum aquae: tunc oportet ut intromittas pennam in uulnus, aut instrumentum cum quo extrahitur aqua hydropicorum, cuius forma praecessit: aut adde in operatione uulneris parumper.	If there is resistance to the outflow of water at the time you are puncturing it, and this is only because a white cloth causes obstruction at the wound's opening and prevents the water from exiting, then insert a feather into the wound or use an instrument for drawing out water from edematous tissues, whose shape has been previously described. Alternatively, wait briefly before resuming the procedure on the wound.
Et scias, quod aqua redit, et aggregatur post sex menses, aut circiter eos.	Know that the water will return and gather again after about six months.
Cum ergo aggregatur, tunc pertoretur secundum eundem modum, et pertransibit infirmus dies suos.	Therefore, when it gathers again, puncture it in the same manner, and the patient shall pass their days.
¶ De cura Ramicis carnosae.	¶ On the treatment of fleshly stones.
Caput LXIII.	Chapter 63
Scias, quod in sectione super hanc Ramicem, est ex timore perducente ad perniciem in pluribus dispositionibus.	Know that when cutting into this stone, fear often leads to harm in many situations.
Quapropter uidetur mihi eius dimissio saluari ex ea.	Therefore, it seems to me that its removal is safer than the operation itself.
Et ego sum rememorans operationem in ea, et species apostematis.	And I remember the operation performed on it and the appearance of the abscess.
Dico ergo, quod accidunt apostemata multa in corporibus, ex quibus componuntur testiculi: et fit illud ex caussis multis, scilicet.	I say therefore that many abscesses occur in bodies from which the testicles are composed; and this happens for many reasons, namely.
Aut ex superfluitate acuta, uel acri, quae effunditur ad testiculos.	Either due to acute or sharp excess fluid that flows towards the testicles.
Aut ex percussione.	Or from impact.
Et est color apostematis secundum colorem corporis, et non inuenitur ei dolor: et est apostema graue.	And the color of the abscess is according to the color of the body, and there is no pain found; and it is a severe abscess.
Et fortasse est apostema lapideum, cuius color est fuscus, et non est sensus ei.	And perhaps it may be a calcareous abscess, whose color is dark, and there is no sensation in it.
Et quandoque fit ex nodatione arteriarum, et inflatione earum: sicut iam praecessit eius rememoratio: aut ex inflatione uenarum.	And sometimes it occurs from obstruction of the arteries and inflammation of them; as has already been mentioned above: or from inflammation of the veins.
Quod ergo est ex eis ex inflatione arteriarum, cognoscitur per dispositionem apostematis, quando comprimis ipsum digitis tuis.	Therefore, that which is caused by inflammation of the arteries can be recognized through the arrangement of the abscess when you press it with your fingers.
Et non oportet ut tangas ipsum prorsus.	And do not touch it at all.
Illud uero quod fit ex inflatione uenarum, non dispergitur ex eo aliquid apud compressionem cum digitis.	But that which is caused by inflammation of the veins does not disperse upon pressing with fingers.
Et iam possibile est, quod super hanc speciem fiat sectio, et super reliquas carnes: et est, ut seces cutem testiculorum.	And now it is possible for an incision to be made on this kind of abscess and on the surrounding flesh; and it is necessary to separate the skin of the testicles.
Deinde extende ouum ad sursum, et extrahe ipsum cum sifach albo: et libera suspensorium ex uasis, et liga uasa: et incide suspensorium postquam tu liberas ipsum ab omni parte ex partibus oui.	Then raise up the testicle upwards and remove it along with its white sac; and free the suspensiony ligament from the vas deferens and ligate the vessels; and cut the suspensiony ligament after you have freed it from all sides of the testicle.
Si ergo ouum consolidatum est cum illis carnibus natis, tunc oportet ut attrahas ouum, et incidas ipsum.	If the testicle is united with those born flesh, then it is necessary to draw out the testicle and cut into it.
Et si adhaerentia est inter aliquid ex siphaket, aut in eo quod est inter uasa: tunc oportet ut liberes totam illam adhaerentiam, et incidas eam incisione rotunda.	And if there is adhesions between any part of the white sac or what lies between the vessels; then it is necessary to free all that adhesion and make a round incision into it.
Si autem est natiuitas carnis in loco adhaerentiae quae est retro: tunc oportet ut incidas totum eius, et extrahas ouum, sicut diximus.	But if there is born flesh in the place of adhesion which lies behind; then it is necessary to cut all of that and remove the testicle as we have said.
Cum ergo completur operatio tua, tnnc imple uulnus in lana infusa in oleo rosato, et uino: deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	When your operation is completed, then fill the wound with wool soaked in rose oil and wine; and care for it with the rest of the treatment until it heals.
¶ De cura Ramicis, quae est cum Vite.	On the Treatment of Hemorrhoids, which is done using Vite.
Caput LXIIII.	Chapter XLIV
Uitis est apostema inuolutum quadam inuolutione, simile botro, cum mollificatione testiculorum: et fit difficilis super infirmum motus et exercitium, et deambulatio.	An abscess has formed wrapped around the scrotum like a bunch of grapes with swelling of the testes; movement and exercise become difficult, and walking is impaired.
Et in curatione huius aegritudinis est ex timore, propter illud cuius praecessit rememoratio.	And in treating this condition, care must be taken out of fear, due to the reminder of what preceded it.
Verum oportet, ut dicamus operationem in ea secundum quod fecerunt primi.	But we must say that the operation for this is done as the first ones did.
Dico ergo, quod oportet ut facias sedere infirmum super sedem eleuatam.	I say therefore that you should make the patient sit on a raised seat.
Deinde impelle suspensorium testiculorum ad inferiora.	Then push the scrotum containing the testes downwards.
Deinde tene cutem testiculorum cum digitis tuis, cum uasis quae sunt propinqua uirgae: et teneat ea minister alius, et extendat ea extensione uehementi.	Next, hold the skin of the testes with your fingers along with the veins close to the penis; another assistant should help by pulling them out strongly and stretching them.
Deinde incide cum spatumili lato acuto sectione transuersa in directo uasorum, donec detegantur uasa.	Then cut with a wide, sharp knife horizontally across where the veins are located until the veins are exposed.
Deinde excoria ab omni parte, sicut diximus tibi in extractione Arteriarum quae sunt in timporibus.	Then strip them from all sides, as we have told you regarding the extraction of arteries in the temples.
Postea fige in eis acum in qua sit filum duplum, et liga ipsum in primo locorum quibus accidunt Vites: et liga ipsum iterum in ultimo eorum.	Afterwards, insert a needle with a double thread into them and tie it at the first point where the hemorrhoids occur; then tie it again at the last of them.
Deinde seca ea in media sectione recta secundum longitudinem corporis, et extrahe quod aggregatur ex humiditatibus faeculentis corruptis.	Then cut them in half lengthwise along the middle and remove what is attached by rotten fecal matter.
Deinde cura uulnus cum curatione reliquorum uulnerum, in quibus uis generari saniem, ut cadant uasa quae nutriunt unum testiculorum.	Then treat the wound with other wounds' treatment, ensuring that pus forms to make the veins nourishing one of the testes fall off.
Non est enim malum per illud.	For there is no harm in that.
Si autem accidat Vitis omnibus uasis, tunc oportet ut extrahantur propter hoc testiculi cum uasis: ut non priuetur ouum nutrimento, propter incisionem, et tabescat, uel arescat, et non sit iuuamentum cum eis.	But if hemorrhoids occur with all veins, then it is necessary to remove the testes along with their veins because otherwise, they would be deprived of nutrition due to the cut and become wasted or dried up without being beneficial.
¶ De cura Ramicis intestinalis.	On the Treatment of Internal Hemorrhoids.
Caput LXV.	Chapter XLVI
Euentus huius Ramicis est ex sectione, quae accidit in sifach extenso super uentrem in parte inguinum ex mirach uentris.	This event occurred due to a cut made on an extended thigh over the abdomen in the groin region as a result of stomach wound.
Quare descendunt intestina ex illa Ruptura ad unum testiculorum.	Therefore, the intestines protruded from that rupture towards one of the testes.
Et haec Ruptura est aut ex sifach, aut extensione eius.	And this rupture was either due to a cut or the extension thereof.
Et accidunt istae duae species ex caussis multis. Aut ex percussione. Aut saltu. Aut clamore. Aut eleuatione rei grauis, et similibus.	And these two kinds occur due to many causes. Or from a blow. Or from falling. Or from shouting. Or lifting of heavy objects, and similar things.
Et signum, quando est ex extensione sifach.	And the sign is when it is due to the extension of a cut.
Est quod accidit paulatim in tempore longo, et non accidit subito: et est apostema aequale uersus profundum: propterea, quod sifach comprimit intestinum.	It is that which happens gradually over time and not suddenly: and it is an equal abscess facing the deep part: because the cut compresses the intestine.
Et signum eius quando est ex sectione sifach, quia facit accidere ex principio sui dolorem uehementem subito: et est apostema diuersum, apparens sub cute propinque: et illud est propter exitum intestini, et cursus eius ad exteriora sifach.	And its sign when it is due to a cut is that there occurs from the beginning intense sudden pain: and it is a different abscess appearing near under the skin: and this is because of the exit of the intestine and its course towards the outside of the cut.
Et quandoque egreditur cum intestino zirbum: et nominatur haec Ramex intestinalis, et zirbia: et quandoque fit cum uentositate.	And sometimes it emerges with the intestine: and this is called a 'Ramex' or 'intestinal hernial ring': and sometimes it occurs with wind.
Et quandoque currit in intestinum stercus, et retinetur illic: et est cum eo pernicies infirmi: quoniam facit accidere dolorem prauum, et praecipue quando premitur.	And sometimes feces run into the intestine and become trapped there: and this brings danger to the patient, because it causes severe pain, especially when pressed.
Et in curatione specierum aegritudinis huius cum ferro est timor: quare oportet ut caueatur casus in ea.	And in treating these kinds of illnesses with iron there is fear of injury: therefore one must be careful not to cause harm in this way.
Et modus operationis est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut reducat intestinum manu sua ad interiora concauitatis suae, si obedit reditui.	And the method of operation is that you should instruct the patient to try to push their intestine back into its proper place with their own hand if it can be returned.
Deinde resupinetur super collum suum inter manus tuas: et eleua crura eius.	Then he should lie on his back between your hands and lift his legs up.
Deinde extende cutem quae sequitur cutem ad superiora, et seca cutem testiculorum totam per longitudinem.	Then extend the skin that follows it upwards and cut all of the skin covering the testes along its length.
Deinde fige in duobus labiis sectionis uncinos, secundum quod indiges ad aperiendum sectionem cum eis: et sectio sit secundum quantitatem, quod sit possibile, ut egrediatur ex ea ouum.	Then fasten hooks into both lips of the cut according to what is needed for opening it with them: and make the cut as large as possible so that an egg can pass through it.
Deinde excoria siphak, et quae sunt sub cute testiculorum, donec quando detegitur sifach album, durum ab omni parte: tunc intromitte digitum tuum indicem in eo quod sequitur testiculum, in eo quod est inter siphach album, quod est sub cute oui, et inter sifach secundum, et absolue cum eo adhaerentiam quae est in posteriori parte oui.	Then scrape off the skin of the scrotum and what is underneath it until when the white sifach (sperm) is uncovered, hard on all sides: then insert your index finger into that which follows the testicle, in that which is between the white sifach, which is under the skin of the egg, and between the second sifach, without adhering to that which is in the back part of the egg.
Deinde moue cum manu dextra ad interiora cutem testiculorum: et cum hoc extende sifach album ad sursum, cum manu sinistra: et eleua ouum cum sifach ad partem sectionis: et praecipe ministro, ut extendat ouum ad sursum: et tu solue adhaerentiam, quae est retro solutione completa.	Then move with your right hand towards the inside of the skin of the testicles: and with this stretch out the white sifach upwards with your left hand: and lift up the egg with the sifach to the part of the cut: and instruct your assistant to stretch the egg upwards: and you loosen the adhesion which is behind the completed solution.
Et quaere digitis tuis, ut non sit aliquid illic ex intestino inuoluto in sifach albo duro.	And search with your fingers so that there is nothing there of the intestine wrapped around the hard white sifach.
Si autem inuenis ex eo aliquid: tunc impelle ipsum ad uentrem inferius.	If however you find something from it, then push it downwards towards the belly.
Deinde accipe acum, in qua sit filum grossum, factum licinium ex decem filis: et intromitte ipsam apud postremum sifach, id est, tunicae, quod est sub cute testiculorum quae sequitur sectionem: deinde incide extremitates quae eminent ex filo, donec sint quatuor fila.	Then take a needle with a thick thread made of ten strands of linen and insert it into the last sifach, that is the tunic which is under the skin of the testicles following the cut: then cut off the ends that emerge from the thread until there are four strands.
Deinde compone quaedam eorum super quaedam cum figura quae sit in modo crucis: et liga cum eis alsifach, de quo diximus, quia est sub cute testiculorum ligamento uehementi, donec non possit aliquod ex uasis, quae nutriunt eos mittere ad eos aliquid: ut non accidat inde apostema calidum.	Then arrange some of them over others in the shape of a cross and tie them together with alsifach, of which we spoke, because it is under the skin of the testicles with a strong ligament, until nothing can be sent from the vessels that nourish it to them lest an inflamed swelling should occur.
Et pone iterum ligamentum secundum extra ligamentum primum, longinquum ab eo minus duobus digitis.	And place again a second ligature according to outside the first ligature, at a distance of two fingers from it.
Et post ista duo ligamenta dimitte ex sifach, quod est sub cute testiculorum, quantitatem magnitudinis digiti: et incide reliquum totum secundum rotunditatem, et aufer ex eo ouum.	And after these two ligatures let out from the sifach which is under the skin of the testicles a length equal to the size of a finger and cut off the rest entirely according to its roundness, and remove the egg.
Deinde seca in inferiori parte cutis testiculorum sectione, ex qua currit sanguis, et sanies: sicut narrauimus in eo quod praemissum est.	Then make an incision on the lower part of the skin of the testicles through which blood and pus are flowing, as we have described beforehand.
Deinde administra lanam submersam in oleo, et pone in uulnus: et administra ligamentum quod narrauimus.	Then apply wool immersed in oil to the wound, and also apply the ligature that has been mentioned.
Et quandoque cauterizatur sifach album quod diximus, post incisionem eius timendo de fluxu sanguinis.	And sometimes the white sifach which we have spoken of is cauterized after its incision is made, fearing bleeding.
Multotiens enim accidit illud.	For this happens frequently.
Et dimitte ligamentum, donec cadat per se.	And let go of the ligature until it falls off by itself.
Si autem tardatur casus eius, tunc embrocetur cum aqua calida: et pone super ipsum illud quod diximus, donec cadat.	But if its fall is delayed, then foment with warm water and place over it what we have mentioned until it falls off.
Deinde cura uulnus cum reliqua curatione uulnerum, donec curetur.	Then treat the wound with the usual treatment of wounds until it heals.
¶ De Ramice uentosa.	On Removing a Foreign Body.
Caput LXVI.	Chapter 66.
IN Hac Ramice non uidi aliquem qui ausus fuerit super curationem eius cum ferro.	I have not seen anyone who dared to attempt the removal of this foreign body with an iron instrument.
Et primi quidem dixerunt, quod fit sicut narrauimus in Ramice quae est cum Vite.	And initially they said that it is done like we described for a foreign body that has grown into the liver.
Quod est, ut liges uasa post sectionem super ea cum facilitate inferius: deinde seca in medio, et cura postremo cum eo quod aperit ipsum, donec cadant uasa: et cura uulnus, secundum quod diximus, donec sanetur.	That is to say, after the incision, tie off the vessels below it with ease, then cut through it in the middle and treat it afterwards with what opens it until the vessels fall out, and treat the wound according to what we have said until it heals.
¶ De disruptione quae fit in inguinibus.	On Dislocations of the Groin.
Caput LXVII.	Chapter 67.
Quando accidit Ruptura in inguinibus, sicut diximus, et eminet locus, et non descendit ad testiculos aliquid ex intestinis: et si descendit, est illud parum, et redit in omnibus horis: uerum si prolongatur cum ea tempus, additur fissura in sifach, donec descendunt intestina in sifach.	When a dislocation occurs in the groin, as we have mentioned, and there is a prominence but nothing from the intestines descends to the testicles: if something does descend it is not much and returns at all times. But if this continues over time, a tear forms in the sifach until the intestines descend into it.
Et accidit illud ex extensione sifach, quod est in inguinibus, sicut diximus.	And this happens because of the stretching of the sifach which is in the groin, as we have mentioned.
Quod est, quia extenditur sifach: deinde mollificatur, et apostematur locus, et eminet.	That is to say, because the sifach becomes stretched out, it then softens and the area becomes inflamed and protrudes.
Et cura eius est cum cauterio, sicut praecessit eius narratio.	And its treatment is with a cautery, as has been told before.
Et quandoque curatur cum ferro, secundum hunc modum: et est, ut iaceat infirmus super dorsum suum inter manus tuas.	Sometimes it is treated with iron in this manner: and it is done so that the patient lies on their back between your hands.
Deinde seca locum Rupturae apostematum et eminentem, sectione per latitudinem, secundum quantitatem trium digitorum.	Then cut the location of the ruptured inflammation and protrusion with a cut across its width, to the length of three fingers.
Deinde stringe alsifak et, quae sunt sub cute, donec quando detegitur sifach album, quod est sub cute quae sequitur ipsum.	Then tie up the alsifak and what is beneath the skin until the white sifach is revealed, which is under the skin that follows it.
Tunc accipe radium, et pone ipsum super locum eminentem ex sifach, et preme ipsum ad profundum uentris.	Then take a hot iron, place it on the protruding location of the sifach, and press it down to the depth of the abdomen.
Deinde sue duo loca eminentia super extremitatem radii ex sifach, et annecte cum sutura unum eorum cum altero: deinde extrahe extremitatem radii.	Then if there are two protruding locations on either side of the hot iron from the sifach, join one with the other using a suture; then remove the end of the iron.
Et non incidas alsifach omnino, neque tendas ouum, neque aliud, sicut feci te scire in curatione ramicis intestinalis.	And do not cut the alsifak entirely, nor stretch its opening nor anything else, as I have told you in treating a prolapse of the intestines.
Deinde cura illud curatione uulnerum.	Then treat it with the care for wounds.
Cum ergo incidis fila, mundifica illud, et restaura uulnus, donec consolidetur.	So when you cut the threads, cleanse them and restore the wound until it heals.
Sisach enim contrahitur, et non additur eminentia Rupturae.	For the sifach contracts, and there is no addition of the protrusion rupture.
Et cauterium est melius in hoc loco: quoniam est propinquius ad salutem.	And a cautery is better for this location because it is closer to health.
¶ De mollificatione cutis testiculorum.	§ On the softening of the skin of the testicles.
Caput LXVIII.	Chapter 68
Multotiens mollificatur cutis testiculorum in quibusdam hominibus, propter quod mollificantur carnes quae sunt inter ea, et foedatur aspectus eius.	Often the skin of the testicles becomes softened in certain men, causing the flesh between them to also soften and resulting in a foul appearance.
Ergo necesse est ei qui rogatur in curatione eius, ut faciat iacere infirmum super dorsum suum, et incidat totam cutem quae mollificata est super cutem naturalem.	Therefore it is necessary for the one who is called upon to treat this condition to make the patient lie on their back and cut all of the softened skin over the natural skin.
Deinde aggreget duo labia cum sutura: et si uis, sue in primis superfluitatem cutis mollificatae tribus suturis, aut quatuor, et firma suturam.	Then bring together the two lips with a suture; and if desired, first remove the excess softened skin with three or four sutures, and make a firm stitch.
Deinde incide inter sututuras.	Then cut between the sutures.
Deinde cura curatione reliquorum uulnerum, usquequo sanetur, et cadant fila.	Then treat the remaining wounds with care until they heal and the threads drop off.
¶ De Castratione.	Chapter on Castration.
Caput LXIX.	Chapter 69.
Scias, quod Castratio in lege nostra excommunicata est: et propter illud liceret mihi, ut non rememorarer eius in libro meo isto: et non est necessaria rememoratio eius, nisi propter duos modos.	You should know that castration is condemned by our religion. Therefore, I would have been allowed to omit it from this book of mine; and there is no need for its mention except for two methods.
Quorum unus est, ut sit illud in scientia medici quando interrogatur de ea: et ut sciat curationem eius cui accidit.	One reason is that the medical knowledge of castration should be known when asked about it; and so that he may know how to treat its consequences if they occur.
Et modus alter est, quod nos multotiens indigemus castratione quorundam animalium, propter iuuamenta nostra per illud, sicut arietum, hyrcorum, et gattorum, et similium ex animalibus.	And another reason is that we often need castration for certain animals to obtain useful things from them, such as rams, goats, cats, and similar beasts.
Dico ergo, quod Castratio fit secundum duos modos.	I therefore say that castration occurs in two ways.
Aut per attritionem.	Either by rubbing.
Aut per fissuram, et sectionem.	Or by cutting and slicing.
In illa autem quae fit per attritionem, uia operationis est: quod nos faciamus sedere animal in aqua calida, donec mollificentur testiculi eius, et leniantur, et pendeant: deinde attere eos manu tua, donec resoluantur et non appareant sub tactu.	In the case of castration by rubbing, the method is this: we make the animal sit in warm water until its testicles soften and relax, and hang down; then throw them with your hand until they dissolve and are no longer visible to touch.
In castratione autem per fissuram et sectionem, oportet ut teneas animal, et premas cutem testiculorum eius cum manu sinistra.	But in castration by cutting and slicing, it is necessary that you hold the animal and press the skin of its testicles with your left hand.
Deinde liga suspensorium, et seca super omne ouum sectione una, donec quando procedunt duo oua: tunc incide ea postquam excoriaueris utrumque, et non dimittas super ea ex sifaket aliquid praeter sifac subtile, quod est super uasa.	Then tie the suspension ligament and cut across all eggs with one cut until two emerge; then make an incision into them after you have scraped off both, leaving nothing but a thin membrane over the vessels.
Et iste modus castrationis est melior eo qui fit per attritonem: quoniam attritio fortasse relinquit aliquid ex testiculis, quare desiderat animal coitum.	And this method of castration is better than that done by rubbing, for rubbing may leave some of the testicles behind, causing the animal to desire mating.
Deinde cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	Then treat the wound until it heals.
¶ De cura Hermafroditae duorum modorum.	Chapter on the Treatment of Hermaphrodites in Two Ways.
Caput LXX.	Chapter 70.
Hermafrodita ex uiris est secundum duos modos.	A hermaphrodite is a person with male genitals according to two ways.
Vnus eorum est, quia apparet in eo quod sequitur spacium, aut in cute testiculorum, in eo quod est inter duos testiculos, figura quasi uulua mulieris, in qua sunt pili: et quandoque currit urina ex eo quod est in cute testiculorum.	One type is when a space appears at the scrotum or on the skin between the two testicles with a figure resembling a woman's vulva containing hairs; and sometimes urine flows from that area.
In mulieribus autem est species una, et est uulua mulieris super pectinem sicut testiculi uiri parui omnino, eminentes ad exteriora: quorum unus est sicut priapus uiri, et duo sicut duo testiculi.	In women there is one type, which is the vulva of a woman above the pubis like the small testes of a man protruding externally: among them one is like the priapus of a man, and two are like the two testicles.
Et curatio trium specierum, duarum ex uiris, et speciei unius ex mulieribus, est: quia oportet ut incidas carnes additas, donec effugiat impressio earum.	And the treatment for three types - two from men and one from women - is this: it is necessary to cut away the excess flesh until the indentation disappears.
Deinde cura eas curatione reliquorum uulnerum.	Then treat them with the same care as other wounds.
In specie autem secunda uirorum, ex qua egreditur urina, quae est in cute testiculorum, non est operatio, neque est eius curatio omnino.	But regarding the second type in men, from which urine flows and is located on the skin of the testicles, there is no operation or treatment at all.
¶ De incisione Tentiginis, et carnis eminentis in uuluis mulierum.	On incising hemorrhoids and excessive flesh protruding from the vulva of women.
Caput LXXI.	Chapter 71.
Tentigo fortasse additur super rem naturalem, donec foedatur et turpis fit aspectus eius: et quandoque magnificatur in quibusdam mulieribus adeo, donec expanditur sicut in uiris, et peruenit usque ad coitum.	Hemorrhoids may sometimes be added to the natural condition until it becomes foul and ugly in appearance; and sometimes they are greatly enlarged in some women so that they become like those of men, extending even to intercourse.
Oportet ergo ut teneas superfluitatem Tentiginis manu, aut cum uncino, et incidas: et non ultimes in incisione, praecipue in profundo radicis: ut non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	Therefore, you should hold back the excess hemorrhoids with your hand or with a hook and cut them; but do not cut too deeply, especially at the root of the depth, so that bleeding does not occur.
Deinde cura ipsam curatione uulnerum, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with the same care as wounds until it heals.
