Quod si medicina cogit eum ad exitum, tunc teneat quantum potest.	But if medication causes him to need to go, then hold back as much as possible.
Et si dormit cum ea nocte tota, est magis ultimum in iuuamento.	And if he sleeps with it all night long, it is the best in treatment.
Si autem clisterizas eum in aegritudinibus solutionis uentris, et festinat exitus eius: tunc itera clistere, donec sanetur.	But if you give him a clyster for intestinal inflammation and his bowel movement comes quickly, then repeat the procedure until he is healed.
Quod si in ano sunt hemorroides, aut apostemata laedentia, tunc sit clistere subtile ualde, lene, ex clisteribus quibus clisterizantur pueri.	But if there are hemorrhoids or sores wounding the anus, then use a very fine, gentle clyster like those used for children.
Et haec sit forma clisteris subtilis super quod sit stricta cutis.	And this is the shape of a fine clyster with a thin skin stretched over it.
¶ De curatione Vulnerum capitis sine fractura ossis.	Chapter on the Treatment of Head Wounds without Bone Fracture.
Caput LXXXIIII.	Chapter 84.
Iam dixi in diuisione de curatione uulnerum quod conueniebat libro, et ego dicam hic curationem eorum cum manu, et cum medicinis secundum complementum.	I have already spoken about the division of wound treatment suitable for this book; here I will discuss their treatment by hand and with medicines according to completion.
Dico ergo, quod uulnera diuersificantur secundum illud quo fiunt uulnera, et secundum locum super quem cadit uulnus.	So I say that wounds are differentiated according to the cause of the wound and its location.
Res ergo quibus fiunt uulnera multotiens, sunt sicut iactus lapidis: aut incisio ensis, aut cultelli: aut percussio cum lancea, aut ligno, aut sagitta: et similibus illis ex rebus multis.	Therefore, the things by which wounds are caused are often such as being struck by a stone; cut by a sword or knife; pierced by a spear, wood, arrow, and similar objects from many sources.
Vulnera autem quae fiunt secundum loca corporis sunt, sicut uulnus quod cadit super caput, aut collum, aut pectus, aut uentrem, aut epar: et similia ex eis membris.	But wounds that occur according to the location on the body are like those that fall upon the head, neck, chest, belly, or limbs, and others similar to them.
Et ego sum narrans curationes quorundam uulnerum, ut ponam eam ratiocinationem et regulam super reliqua uulnera.	And I am describing the treatment of certain wounds so that I may set forth a reasoning and rule for the rest of the wounds.
Et ego incipiam a uulneribus capitis simplicibus: quoniam rememoratio compositorum ueniet in principio capituli tertii.	And I will begin with simple head wounds, because the treatment of compound fractures will come up at the beginning of Chapter Three.
Dico ergo.	I therefore say:
Quando accidit in capite uulnus simplex, et non est fractura ossis: considera tunc, si est ex iactu lapidis, aut ei similibus, et iam fregit cutem tantum: et est uulnus magnum, et times super infirmum euentum apostematis calidi: tunc propera, et phlebotoma cephalicam statim: et non tardes illud: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis eius: si non fuerit prohibens aliquid a phlebotomia, praecipue si fuerit sanguis qui egreditur ex uulnere paucus.	When there is a simple wound in the head and no bone fracture exists, observe first whether it results from being struck by a stone or similar object, which has merely broken the skin: if it is a large wound and you fear an internal abscess will form due to heat: then act quickly, performing a cephalic phlebotomy immediately, and do not delay it: and draw off blood from him according to his strength: unless there is something preventing phlebotomy, especially if little blood flows out of the wound.
Et sit phlebotomia ex contrario partis uulneratae.	And let the phlebotomy be performed on the opposite side of the wounded part.
Et caueat infirmus sibi a repletione, et uino, et cibis grossis.	And the patient should abstain from overeating and drinking wine or consuming heavy foods.
Si autem minutionem prohibet aliquid, tunc minoretur ex cibo, et non appropinquet carnibus, neque uinis.	But if something prevents reduction, then reduce diet and avoid flesh and wines.
Et pone super uulnus si accidit ei apostema calidum, cotum infusum in oleo rosato solo, aut cum uino in quo est stipticitas.	And place over the wound, if an inflammatory abscess occurs, cotton soaked in rose oil alone or with wine that has been thickened.
Si autem securus fueris ab apostemate calido, tunc pone super uulnus, si est recens cum sanguine suo, et non mutauit ipsum aer, puluerem quem ego narrabo post paululum: et si iam mutauit ipsum aer, tunc pone super ipsum quaedam unguenta, donec sanetur.	But if you are secure from an inflammatory abscess, then place over the wound, if it is fresh with its own blood and has not changed color, powder which I will describe later: but if it has already changed color, then place over it some ointments until it heals.
Si autem uulnus est magnum, aut est ex incisione ensis, et similium: et non aggregantur labia eius per puluillos, tunc aggrega ipsa cum sutura, secundum quod ego narrabo in uulneribus uentris de sutura eorum.	But if the wound is large or results from an incision with a knife or similar tool and its edges do not come together by themselves: then close it with stitches according to what I will describe concerning the suturing of abdominal wounds.
Si autem uulnus iam detectum est ab osse, et pendet, et non est retentio eius, nisi in suspensorio paruo: tunc incide ipsum.	But if a wound is already exposed by bone and hangs open without retention unless held by a small suspension: then cut into it.
Deinde cura uulnus cum medicinis, et restaura in eo carnem duram loco cutis, et praecipe infirmo, ut alatur cibis in quibus est grossitudo, sicut sunt capita, et triticum coctum, donec sit ut puls: et eis similia.	Then treat the wound with medicines and restore hard flesh in place of skin, and instruct the patient to consume foods that are easily digested such as chicken and cooked wheat groats until they can tolerate solid food.
Quod si inuenis in cute putrefactionem, et non adhaeret ossi: tunc incide putrefactum totum, et proiice ipsum: deinde cura illud.	If you find that the skin has begun to decay but does not adhere to the bone, then cut away all of the decayed portion and cast it out. Afterwards treat the wound.
Si autem in his uulneribus est arteria, aut uena ex qua fluit sanguis: et non abscinditur per medicinas, tunc inquire super arteriam.	If in these wounds there is an artery or vein from which blood flows freely and it cannot be stopped by medicines, then search for the artery.
Si ergo inuenis eam non sectam, tunc seca eam cum Spatumili, aut liga eam.	Then if you find it uncut, cut it with a spatula or ligate it.
Quod si necessitas prouocat quando non confert illud quod diximus, tunc cauteriza eam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	But if the necessity requires it and what we have said does not help, then cauterize it until the blood is stopped.
Si autem uulnera ista sunt parua, simplicia, tunc res eorum est facilis, leuis: ita ut puluerizes super ea hunc puluerem: quoniam consolidat ea antequam mutet ea aer.	If these wounds are small and simple then their treatment is easy thus you should powder them with this powder for it solidifies them before they change color.
¶ Modus Pulueris incarnatiui.	Method of the Incarnation Powder.
Recipe olibani partem unam, et sanguinis draconis partes duas, et calcis non extinctae partes tres: teratur totum multum, et cribelletur: et impleatur ex eo uulnus, et constringatur constrictione bona, donec adhaereat super ipsum bene, et coaguletur cum sanguine.	Take one part of olibanum, two parts of dragon's blood, and three parts of unslaked lime. Grind all together very well and sieve it. Then fill the wound with this powder and bind it tightly until it adheres well and coagulates with the blood.
Deinde stringe ipsum desuper cum puluillis, et dimitte ipsum, neque soluas ipsum dum permanet, ita quod non apostemetur.	Then tie it above with bandages and leave it undisturbed until it is completely healed so that it does not break open.
Nam non eradicatur ab eo medicina, donec sanatur.	For the medicine will not be removed from it until it heals.
Et quandoque facit illud calx sola, quando non sunt tibi in praesenti olibanum, et sanguis draconis etiam facit eandem operationem in multis ex uulneribus magnis, quando conuenit ut ponatur super ea et stringantur, et sunt uulnera recentia cum sanguine suo, quae non alterauit aer.	And sometimes lime alone can do the job when you don't have olibanum and dragon's blood available. It also works well on many large wounds when it is applied and bound, especially for fresh wounds that have not yet changed color.
Quod si iam alterauit ea aer quadam alteratione, praecipue quando est in tempore aestatis, tunc non est in positione huius pulueris intentio: cura ergo ipsum cum eo quod diximus, ita ut ponas super ea quaedam unguenta digestiua: aut ponas super ea pultes ex farina hordei, factas cum aqua et melle, donec emittant pus.	But if the wound has already begun to change color, especially during summer time, then this powder is not suitable. Therefore treat it with what we have said and apply softening ointments or poultices made from barley flour mixed with water and honey until they discharge pus.
Deinde cura ea reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	Then treat the remainder according to usual care until they are healed.
Si uero accidat cum uulnere fractura in osse, et est parua, tunc extrahe illud cum Gesti: et ego iam dicam curationem fracturarum capitis in eo quod futurum est.	But if a fracture of the bone occurs with the wound, and it is small, then extract it with a pair of forceps. And I will speak later about the treatment of fractures of the head.
¶ De uulneribus Colli.	On Wounds of the Neck.
Caput LXXXV.	Chapter 85.
SI Autem uulnus accidat in Collo, tunc non est inter ipsum differentia in medicatione, et inter uulnus capitis quando est simplex.	If a wound occurs on the neck, then there is no difference between it and wounds of the head that are simple.
Si autem iam incisus est neruus Colli, aut arteria: tunc si est neruus, non est in eo ingenium, nisi ut deuitetur curatio eius cum eo quod facit stipticitatem uehementem, sicut ziniar, et zegi, et eis similia.	But if the neck vein or artery is cut: then if it is a vein, there is no treatment except to apply something that stops bleeding sharply, such as cineraria and zehir, and things like them.
Quoniam nocent neruis, et contrahunt eos.	For they harm nerves and cause them to contract.
Et non ponas super uulnus aliquid frigidum omnino: quoniam substantia neruorum est frigida, et continuatio eius est cum cerebro, quod est sublimius membrorum: et sit illud quo curatur ex medicinis lene, sicut calx lota cum aqua dulci aliquotiens infusa cum oleo, aut cum oleo rosato, et tuthia, quando abluitur etiam cum aqua dulci: et reliqui lapides minerales, secundum hunc modum, et unguenta humida.	And do not apply anything cold to the wound at all because the substance of nerves is cold and continuous with the brain, which is the most elevated organ. Therefore let what is applied for treatment be gentle medicines like chalk washed with sweet water infused several times with oil or rose oil, and tutty, also washed with sweet water: and other mineral stones in this way, and moist ointments.
Si autem uulnus est magnum, tunc administra suturam: aut coarta labia eius cum puluillis.	If the wound is large, then perform stitching: or press its lips together with lint.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then treat it until it heals.
Si uero uulneri est profunditas, aut accidit in eo sinus in inferiori parte eius, in quo iam aggregatur pus, tunc perfora ipsum in magis depresso loco in eo.	But if the wound is deep or there is a cavity at its lower part where pus has already collected: then pierce it at its lowest point.
Quod si iam incisa est in uulnere arteria, et consecutus est sanguinem eius fluxus: tunc separa, uel seca eam, et liga ipsam: aut cauteriza eam, si prouocat necessitas ad illud.	That if the artery is cut in the wound and its blood flow has begun: then separate or cut it and tie it: or cauterize it if necessity requires it.
Si autem iam incidit spondiles gutturis, aut totum, et saluatae sunt alhaudegi: tunc aggrega labia cutis cum sutura super cannam gutturis, et non tangas guttur, imo aequa ipsum, et reduc ipsum super figuram naturalem.	If however the throat has already been injured, or entirely [injured], and the larynx is saved: then approximate the edges of the skin with sutures over the windpipe, and do not touch the throat itself, rather preserve it, and return it to its natural shape.
Deinde stringe ipsum strictura decenti, et dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot.	Then bind it with a proper bandage, and leave it for several days.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguentis in quibus est stipticitas et exiccatio, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with ointments which have the qualities of absorption and drying until it heals.
Si autem uulnus iam fecit impressionem in osse, tunc perquire ipsum: tunc si in ipso sunt fragmenta ossis, extrahe ea omnia, aut quae potes ex eis: et quod non praeparatur, dimitte illud, donec putrescat uulnus, et separetur et alleuietur egressio eius.	If however the wound has already made an impression on the bone, then investigate it: if there are fragments of bone in it, remove all of them or as many as possible; and what cannot be prepared, leave it until the wound rots, separates and its discharge is alleviated.
Quod si uulnus fuerit recens, tunc pulueriza super ipsum puluerem quem narraui.	If however the wound is fresh, then sprinkle over it the powder which I have described [earlier].
Si autem uidetur in uulnere os, et fit Fistula: tunc cura ipsam cum eo cuius rememoratio uenit in capitulo suo.	But if bone appears in the wound and a fistula forms: then treat it with that about which there is mention in its own chapter.
¶ De uulnere in Spatulis.	Chapter on Wounds in the Scalp.
Caput LXXXVI.	Chapter 86.
SI Est percussio lanceae, aut cultelli: et uides eius profunditatem, tunc considera.	If there is a wound from a spear or knife and you see its depth, then consider [its severity].
Si ergo ex uulnere egreditur uentositas, quando anhelat ex eo infirmus, tunc scias, quia uulnus est mortale.	If therefore air flows out from the wound when the sick person gasps, then know that the wound is mortal.
Quod si non fuerit ei profunditas, et est recens cum sanguine suo: tunc non ponas in eo a prima hora puluerem, neque stringas ipsum, ut non retineatur sanguis in profunditate eius, et reuertatur ad cor, et interficiat infirmum: sed pone in ipso unguentum attractiuum, et solue ipsum in die bis.	But if it does not have depth and is fresh with its own blood: then do not put the powder on it from the first hour nor bind it, lest blood be retained in its depths and return to the heart and kill the sick person. Instead, put an absorbent ointment on it and dissolve it twice a day.
Si uero unguentum non est tibi praesens, tunc pone in orificio uulneris cotum uetustum, ut sugat illud quod egreditur de eo ex humiditatibus: et fac ut dormiat infirmus super uulnus, ut currat quod aggregatur in eo.	But if the ointment is not present for you, then put a piece of old cotton on the mouth of the wound so that it may suck up what flows out from it in terms of moisture; and make sure the sick person sleeps on the wound so that what collects in it may flow [out].
Si uero iam praeterierint uulneri tres dies, aut plures, et non accidit infirmo spasmus, neque tremor cordis malus, neque strictura in anhelitu, et uides reliquas dispositiones eius bonas: tunc scias, quia uulnus est saluum.	But if three days have passed since the wound occurred, or more, and no spasms have affected the sick person, nor has there been a bad trembling of the heart, nor any constriction in breathing, and you see that all other conditions are good: then know that the wound is safe.
Cura ergo ipsum et cum liciniis, et reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Therefore treat it with linens, and the rest of the treatment until it heals.
Si uero excusatur sanatio eius, et iam aperitur semper, tunc scias, quia iam factum est Fistula.	But if its healing is delayed, and it opens up again continually, then know that a fistula has formed.
Cura ergo ipsam ex capitulo suo.	Therefore treat the fistula according to its own chapter.
Et si uulnus est ex incisione ensis, aut cultelli, et est simplex in superficie pectoris, aut dorsi: tunc cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit ex sutura, si est magnum: aut cum puluere, si est paruum.	And if the wound is from a sword cut or knife wound and is simple on the surface of the chest or back: then treat it with what preceded in terms of suturing if it is large, or with powder if it is small.
Si autem iam fecit impressionem in osse, et incidit ex eo frusta: tunc inquire uulnus, et propera ad extrahendum illa frusta, si sunt separata.	But if it has already made an impression on the bone and chips of bone have come out from it: then probe the wound and hasten to remove those chips, if they are separated.
Si uero non sunt separata, tunc dimitte ea, donec putrefiat uulnus, alleuiatur enim extractio eorum.	But if they are not separated, then leave them until the wound putsrefies, for it is easier to remove them [then].
Reliquorum autem uulnerum accidentium in reliquis membris iudicium in curatione, est iudicium eius quod diximus.	The judgment regarding the treatment of other wounds that occur on the other limbs is the same as what we have said.
¶ De uulneribus Ventris, et exitu intestini, et exitura eorum.	Chapter: On Abdominal Wounds, Exit of Intestines, and Their Repair.
Caput LXXXVII.	Chapter 87.
Disruptio quae accidit uentri, est magna, et media, et parua.	A tear that occurs in the abdomen is either great, middle-sized, or small.
Ex magna igitur quandoque egreditur intestinum, aut numerus intestinorum.	Therefore from a large tear sometimes one intestine or several intestines may protrude.
Quare fit intromissio eorum, et eorum sutura uehementior et difficilior.	Thus their reduction and suture are urgent and difficult.
Et disruptio parua etiam fit difficilis ex modo alio.	And a small tear is also difficult in another way.
Sequitur ergo, ut sit reductio eorum difficilior, si non properas in intromissione sua ad locum suum statim: quoniam inflatur, aperitur, et ingrossatur: quare fit difficilis introitus eius.	Therefore the reduction of them is more difficult if you do not promptly perform their replacement to their place immediately: because they swell, open up, and become thickened; thus entrance becomes difficult.
Propter hoc ergo fit melior disruptionum disruptio media: quoniam cum ea non fit difficilis reductio intestini, sicut fit dissicilis in his duabus speciebus.	Therefore it is better to perform the middle incision of disruptions because with this there is no difficult reduction of the intestine as occurs in these two types.
Scias, quod sutura uenris est secundum quatuor modos.	Know that the suture of a vein is done in four ways.
Duae suturae communes conueniunt in sutura uentris, et in sutura reliquorum uulnerum corporis: et duae suturae aliae proprie communicant reliquis uulneribus.	The first two sutures are common to the suture of the belly and the suture of other wounds of the body; and there are two other sutures which properly pertain to other wounds.
Verumtamen sunt magis propriae cum sutura uentris: et ego narro tibi unamquamque cum expositione, et declaratione.	However they are more proper for the suture of the belly; and I shall explain each one to you with its exposition and description.
Dico ergo, quia quando uulnus est paruum, et egreditur ex eo aliquid ex intestino, et fit difficile reducere ipsum: tunc illud est propter unum duorum modorum.	Therefore I say that when a wound is small and some intestine protrudes from it, making reduction difficult, then that is due to one of the two methods.
Aut propter paruitatem disruptionis, sicut diximus: Aut quoniam in intestino est inflatio propter frigus aeris.	Either because of the smallness of the disruption, as we have said; or because there is swelling in the intestine due to the cold air.
Quando ergo illud est ita, tunc oportet ut calefacias ipsum, ita ut submergas spongiam, aut pannum humidum in aqua tepida sola.	When this occurs, then it is necessary that you warm it so that you immerse a sponge or damp cloth only in lukewarm water.
Aut decoquas in aqua squinantum, et cyperum, et spicam, et embroces cum ea intestinum, donec resoluatur inflatio.	Or boil with water of squirting cucumber and cypress and spice, and cover the intestine with it until the swelling is dissolved.
Quandoque facit illud uinum in quo est stipticitas: et est melius quam aqua sola in resolutione inflationis.	Sometimes wine that has been thickened does this, and it is better than water alone for dissolving swelling.
Cum ergo uides inflationem iam resolui, tunc humecta intestinum cum aqua in qua decocta est altea, aut malua.	When you see that the swelling has dissolved, then moisten the intestine with water in which althea or marsh mallow has been boiled.
Nam per illud alleuiatur introitus eius cum re parua.	For by this means its entrance is eased with a small thing.
Si autem excusatur reditus eius post hanc curationem, tunc finde in disruptione parum, cum instrumento quo secantur hemorrhoides.	But if its return cannot be achieved after this treatment, then cut into the small disruption with an instrument used for cutting haemorrhoids.
Et curatio prima est melior quando praeparatur, quam sectio: et non fit coactio ad secandum post necessitatem et defectum instrumenti.	And the first treatment is better when prepared than cutting; and there is no compulsion to cut after necessity and lack of instruments.
Sit pars eius una quae est torta, acuta, et pars eius altera non acuta, et extremitas subtilis non sit cum subtilitate Spatumilis, imo sit obtusior parumper: et est illa quae similatur caiada, sicut uides.	Let one part be sharp and pointed, and the other not sharp, and let its extremity not be too fine, but rather somewhat blunt, like a wedge.
Cum ergo amplificatur uulnus, et ingreditur intestinum, tunc oportet, ut sit reductio eius secundum formam suam naturalem in loco suo sibi proprio, si possibile est super illud: quoniam est melius.	When the wound is enlarged and enters into an internal organ, then it is necessary that its reduction be according to its own natural shape in its proper place, if possible.
Quando uero disruptio est ampla in inferiori parte uentris: tunc oportet ut facias iacere infirmum super dorsum suum, et pone crura sua altiora capite suo.	When the disruption is extensive in the lower part of the belly, then it is necessary to make the patient lie on their back and place their legs higher than their head.
Et si est in superiore parte uentris, tunc pone caput eius, et pectus ipsius altiora quam eius inferiora.	But if it is in the upper part of the belly, then place its head and chest higher than its lower parts.
Et similiter si est disruptio in una duarum partium uentris, tunc pone intentionem tuam, et tuam considerationem semper in hoc, ut pars in qua est uulnus sit altior parte altera.	And similarly, if there is a disruption in one of the two parts of the belly, then always place your purpose and attention on this: that the part where the wound is shall be higher than the other part.
Et ita oportet, ut admimistres illud in uulneribus magnis, et in uulneribus mediis.	And so it is necessary to do this with both large wounds and medium-sized ones.
In uulneribus autem paruis, pone illud secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	But in small wounds, place it however seems best to you.
Deinde fac ut sit praesens inter manus tuas minister pius, qui teneat disruptionem totam manu sua: et aggrega labia eius.	Then make sure there is present between your hands a pious assistant who shall hold the entire disruption with their hand and bring together its lips.
Deinde detege ex ea ei qui sequitur suturam aliquid post aliquid: et iste est modus suturae communis unius.	Then remove from it for him who follows in sewing a bit after another, and this is the common method of one stitch.
Et est, ut accipias acum, aut numerum acuum secundum quantitatem amplitudinis uulneris.	And take up needle(s), according to the number corresponding to the width of the wound.
Deinde dimitte ab extremitate disruptionis quantitatem digiti anularis, id est, medici: et fige acum unam praeter quod intromittas in eam filum in duabus extremitatibuis cutis, cum duabus extremitatibus sifac quod est sub cute ab interioribus, donec facias eam penetrare ab alia parte, et tu iam aggregasti duas extremitates cutis, et duas extremitates sifac: et fiunt quatuor ordines.	Then leave from the end of the disruption the quantity of a finger's breadth, that is to say, the width of a finger, and insert one needle into it after putting thread into both its ends of skin along with two endings of the sirac, which are beneath the skin from the inside, until you make it pierce through to the other side; and now you have brought together two edges of skin and two endings of sirac, making four layers.
Deinde stringe cum filo duplo in circumitu acus aliquotiens a duabus partibus simul, quousque sint aggregata duo labia uulneris aggregatione decenti.	Then tie with doubled thread around the needle repeatedly on both sides simultaneously until the two lips of the wound are brought together neatly.
Deinde dimitte grossitudinem digiti etiam, et fige in eis acum aliam: postea reta eam cum filo, sicut fecisti cum acu prima.	Then leave the thickness of a finger and insert another needle into them; afterwards straighten it with thread as you did with the first needle.
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum eo quo indiges ex acubus, donec compleas constrictionem uulneris totius.	Therefore do not cease doing this until you complete the closing of the entire wound.
Et sint acus mediae inter grossitudinem et subtilitatem: quoniam acus subtiles ualde uelociter incidunt carnem: et grossae sunt difficilis introitus in cutem: propter illud oportet ut sint mediae in subtilitate, et grossitudine.	And the needles should be of medium size between thickness and fineness; for fine needles wound flesh very quickly, while thick ones have difficult entry into skin. Therefore they should be of medium thickness and thinness.
Et non oportet, ut figatur acus in duabus extremitatibus cutis propinquae multum: ut non incidatur caro uelociter, et aperiatur uulnus ante consolidationem sui, et non elongentur etiam cum sutura, ut non prohibeatur uulnus a consolidatione.	And it is not necessary that the needle be inserted into both ends of skin near to each other much; so that flesh may not be wounded quickly, and wound open before its healing, nor become elongated even with stitching, lest it hinder wound from healing.
Deinde incide extremitatem acuum, ut non laedant infirmum apud somnum suum: et pone eis puluillos ex pannis ab omni parte, qui teneant extremitates acuum: et dimitte eos, donec scias quod uulnus iam consolidatum est.	Then cut the ends of needles so that they may not wound the patient during his sleep; and place on them small pieces of linen from all sides which hold the ends of needles; and leave them until you know that the wound is already healed.
Et haec quidem species suturae cum acubus taliter est conuenientior in uulneribus paruis.	And this kind of stitching with needles is most suitable for small wounds.
Quoniam sufficit in sutura eorum acus una, aut duae, aut circiter eas.	For one needle or two needles or about that number suffice in stitching them.
Sutura autem secunda communis est, ut aggreges cum sutura extremitates quatuor: extremitates, duas cutis, et extremitates duas sifac in uice una, cum acu in qua sit filum inuolutum aequale in subtilitate, et grossitudine.	The second kind of stitching is common, as you sew together with one stitch the four ends: two ends of skin and two internal ends together with one needle on which is wound thread of equal thinness and thickness.
Deinde quando penetraueris cum acu has extremitates quatuor, reduc acum a parte a qua incaepisti eadem, ut cadat filum retatum a superiori parte uulneris: ut sit sutura, sicut sutura panni quo stringuntur panni, et pone inter omnem suturam quantitatem grossitudinis digiti minoris.	Then when you have pierced with needle these four ends, bring back the needle from the side whence thou didst begin, so that the thread may fall on the upper part of wound; so that it may be a stitch like a stitch in cloth wherewith clothes are sewed together, and place between every stitch the thickness of a little finger.
Hanc autem suturam sciunt homines.	This kind of stitching men know.
Et cum hac sutura ego sui uulnus quod acciderat uiro in uentre suo, qui fuerat uulneratus cum cultello, et erat disruptio uulneris maior palmo uno: et exierat ex intestinis circiter duos palmos ex intestino medio, et erat disruptio in medio uentris.	And with this stitching I myself closed a wound which happened to a man in his belly; who had been wounded with a knife and there was a disruption of the wound more than one palm; and two palms of intestines had come out from the middle intestine, and there was disruption in the midst of the belly.
Reduxi ergo illud postquam stetit intestinum eius extra uulnus xxiiii horis.	Therefore I returned it after twenty-four hours, when his intestine stood outside of the wound.
Consolidatum est ergo uulnus in spacio quod fuit circiter XV dies: et curaui ipsum, et sanatus est: et uixit post illud annis multis, conuersatus in suis dispositionibus.	The wound was healed in about fifteen days; I treated him and he recovered: and he lived many years afterward, living his usual life.
Et medici iudicauerant, quod non sanaretur.	And the physicians judged that it would not be cured.
Et ex miraculo fuit, quod non curaui illud cum unguento.	But by miracle it happened that I did not heal it with ointment.
Quoniam fui in loco in quo non inueniebatur unguentum, neque aliquid ex medicinis.	For I was in a place where neither ointment nor any medicines were to be found.
Posui ergo super uulnus cotum uetustum bis in die, et assiduaui ablutionem eius cum aqua mellis, donec sanatum est.	So I placed an old cloth on the wound twice a day and washed it continually with honey water until it was healed.
Duas autem species suturae proprias dicam secundum narrationem sermonis.	Two kinds of stitching I shall now describe according to the spoken tradition.
Et est, ut incipias cum sutura acuta: et intromittas acum ab exteriori ad interiorem partem.	And thus you should begin with a sharp stitch: and insert the needle from the outer part to the inner part.
Cum ergo penetrat acus in cutem, et in lacertum euntem secundum longitudinem et latitudinem totius corporis: dimitte extremitatem sifac in latere in quo intromisisti acum, et fac penetrare in extremitatem aliam ab interiori parte ad exteriorem in extremitate altera mirach.	When the needle has pierced the skin and gone through the flesh according to the length and width of the whole body: let go the end of the thread on the side where you inserted the needle, and make it pierce through to the other end from inside out at another point nearby.
Cum ergo feceris eam penetrare, tunc fac eam penetrare secundum hoc in eadem hac extremitate mirach ab exteriori parte ad interiorem: et dimitte extremitatem sifac, quae est in hoc latere, et fac penetrare acum in extremitatem alteram ab interiori parte ad exteriorem: et fac penetrare cum penetratione tua qua facis eam penetrare in sifac extremitate mirach, quae est in parte eius, donec penetret in ipsum totum.	When you have done this, then make it pierce back through the same point from outside to inside: and let go the end of the thread which is on that side, and make the needle pierce through to the other end from inside out, following your usual penetration, until it reaches the whole.
Deinde incipe etiam ab hoc eodem latere, et sue ipsum cum extremitate, quae est ex sifac in latere alio, et extrahe acum ex cute quam penetrauit.	Then begin again on this same side, and with the end which is out on the other side, and pull out the needle from the skin that it pierced.
Deinde reduc eam in illam cutem, et sue extremitatem sifac, quae est in latere alio, cum hac extremitate mirach: et extrahe eam ex cute quae est ex parte eius, et fac illud uice una, et alia: et fac illud uice post uicem, usquequo suas extrinsecum totum secundum illud exemplum.	Then bring it back into that same skin, and with the end of the thread which is on the other side, pierce through again at another point nearby: and pull it out from the skin on its side, and do this alternately, once upon another, until you have gone all around according to that example.
Et summa huius suturae, est ut suas sutura pellipariorum qua suunt pelles: ita ut suas sifac uice una ex parte una extremitate cutis: et ut dimittas eam uice alia ex parte alia, donec compleas.	And the end of this stitching is like that of the stitching of tanners when they sew hides together, so that you pierce with the thread once on one side of the skin and let it out again on the other side, until it is complete.
Secunda species suturae propriae, quam dixit Gale nus.	The second kind of proper suture which Galen called the 'running stitch'.
Iste eius sermo narratus est, ut suas eam secundum similitudinem, qua suunt eas quidam medicantium, ita quod aggregant omnem partem ad comparem suam conuenientem per naturam: et applicant extremitatem sifac ad eius aliam extremitatem, et extremitatem mirach ad extremitatem eius aliam.	This manner of stitching is described so that the wound may be drawn together like those made by some physicians, such that every part is brought close to its corresponding counterpart naturally: and the point of the needle is applied to one end of the wound, and the eye of the needle to the other end.
Et illud fit secundum quod narro tibi.	And this is done as I have described to you.
Oportet ut figas acum in extremitatem mirach propinquam tibi ab exteriori parte, et facias eam penetrare ad interiorem in eo solo: et dimittas duas extremitates sifac.	It is necessary that you insert the point of the needle into the edge of the eye near to you from the outer part, and make it pierce through to the inside in just one place: and let both ends of the thread come out.
Deinde reuolue acum, et fac eam penetrare ab exteriori parte ad interiorem in duas extremitates sifac, scilicet utrinque.	Then turn the needle around, and make it pierce through from the outer part to the inner part at both ends of the thread, that is on either side.
Deinde reuolue utrasque, etiam fac penetrare utrasque ab interiori usque ad exteriorem, in duas extremitates mirach alias, quae sunt in latere opposito.	Then turn each one around again, and make them both pierce through from the inner part to the outer part at two other points of the eye which are on the opposite side.
Et iste modus suturae est melior sutura communi facili, et est sutura cuius praecessit rememoratio.	And this manner of stitching is a better stitch than the common easy one, and it is the stitch which was mentioned before.
Iste est ergo sermo Galeni etiam.	This is therefore also Galen's speech.
Et dixerunt quidam.	And some have said,
Retificatur sutura uentris cum duabus acubus.	The suture of the belly should be done with two needles.
Quod est, ut intromittas in eis utrisque filum unum: et incipe cum intromissione acus, ex eo quod est apud te, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, secundum suturam eorum qui suunt coria aequaliter.	That is, insert into each of them one thread and begin with the insertion of the needle from what is near you, and make it pierce through to the other side according to the stitching of those who sew hides evenly.
Et scias, quod quando disruptio est in medio uentris: tunc sutura eius est difficilior quam reliquorum locorum uentris.	And know that when a disruption occurs in the middle of the belly, its suture is more difficult than that of other parts of the belly.
Iudicium uero medicationis uulneris, est iudicium reliquorum uulnerum.	But the judgement concerning the treatment of wounds is the same for all wounds.
Quod est, quia quando tu consequeris uulnus recens cum sanguine suo, antequam alteret ipsum aer: et reducis intestinum, et suis ipsum, et aptas ipsum: tunc pone super puluerem incarnatiuum.	That is, because when you encounter a fresh wound with its blood, before the air alters it and reduces the intestine, and brings it back to itself and adapts it, then place upon powder of carpenters' incense.
Quod si aer iam alterauit uulnus: tunc pone super ipsum quaedam unguenta, quae sunt tibi praesentia, donec faciant pus: et cadant fila, et consolidentur sifac, et mirach.	But if the air has already altered the wound, then place upon it certain ointments which are present with you until they cause pus and remove threads and bring about healing, both sihlâq and mirrak.
Deinde cura illud sicut est curatio reliquorum uulnerum, donec sanetur.	Then treat it as other wounds are treated until it heals.
Si autem non sunt tibi praesentes medicinae, tunc pone super ipsum statim, exquo incipit emittere pus, cotum uetus: et permuta ipsum bis in die, sicut docui te, donec sanetur.	But if the medicines are not present with you, then place upon it immediately, from where it begins to discharge pus, cotton soaked in old wine and change it twice a day as I have taught you until it heals.
Nam tu non indiges medicatione alia in pluribus dispositionibus, quando uulnera sunt simplicia.	For you do not need another medication in many dispositions when wounds are simple.
Si autem times, quod communicet uulnus membris principalibus in laesione, tunc oportet ut submergas lanam lenem in oleo temperatae caliditatis, aut in oleo rosato: et pone ipsam in circumitu locorum quae sunt inter inguina, et sub ascellas.	But if you fear that the wound might communicate with the principal members in injury, then it is necessary to immerse soft wool in oil of moderate warmth or rose oil and place it around the regions which are between the thighs and under the armpits.
Quod si sentit dolorem, aut punctiones, aut putrefactionem in intestinis suis (nam multotiens accidit illud) tunc clisteriza ipsum cum uino stiptico, nigro, tepido: praecipue si putredo iam peruenit in intestino, et facta est exitura penetrans usque ad concauitatem eius.	That if it feels pain or punctures or putrefaction in its bowels (for this happens very often), then administer a clyster to it with astringent black wine, warm; especially if putrefaction has already reached the intestines and there is penetration of it into their cavity.
Et scias, quod illud quod est ex intestino grosso, est facilioris sanationis: et quod ex eis est ex subtili, difficilioris sanationis.	And know that that which comes from the large intestine is easier to heal and that which comes from the small intestine is more difficult to heal.
Intestinum autem quod nominatur Ieiunum, non suscipit sanationem ex uulnere quod accidit in eo omnino: et illud est propter multitudinem eius, quod est ex uenis, et magnitudine earum, et propter subtilitatem corporis eius, et propinquitatem ipsius naturae neruorum.	However, the intestine that is called the ileum does not receive healing from a wound that occurs in it at all: and this is because of its multitude, which comes from its veins, and the greatness of them, and because of the fineness of its body, and the closeness of its nature to the nerves.
Si autem illud quod procedit ex uulnere est zirbum, et consequeris ipsum recens: reduc ipsum secundum reductionem tuam, qua reducis intestina aequaliter.	But if that which proceeds from the wound is a worm, and you seek it fresh: reduce it according to your reduction, by which you reduce intestines equally.
Si uero praeteriit ei spacium, et iam factum est uiride, aut nigrum: tunc oportet ut stringas ipsum cum filo supra locum qui denigratus est ex eo, ut non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	But if a space has passed and it has already become green or black: then it is necessary that you tie it with thread above the place that has been darkened by it so that blood flow does not occur.
In zirbo enim sunt uenae et arteriae.	For in the worm there are veins and arteries.
Deinde incide quod est praeter illud ligamentum, et pone duas extremitates fili pendentes ex inferiori parte uulneris extra ipsum: ut alleuietur super te attractio eius, et extractio ipsius apud casum zirbi, et emissionem pus uulneris.	Then cut what is beyond that bond and place two ends of thread hanging from the lower part of the wound outside it: so that its attraction and extraction may be alleviated upon you at the time of pulling out the worm, and the discharge of pus from the wound.
¶ Rememoratio uulneris quod accidit in Intestino.	§ Memory aid for wounds that occur in the intestine.
Quando accidit disruptio in Intestino, et est parua: tunc possibile est, ut restauretur in quibusdam hominibus: propterea, quia ego uidi qui fuit uulneratus in uentre suo cum percussione lanceae, et erat uulnus a dextra stomachi, et antiquatum est uulnus: et factum Fistula, et exiuit ex eo egestio, et uentositas.	When there is disruption in the intestine and it is small: then it is possible that it may be restored in some people: therefore, because I have seen one who was wounded in his belly with a lance wound, and the wound was on the right side of the stomach, and the wound was old: and a fistula had formed, and there was discharge and wind from it.
Posui ergo curationem, usque quod ego non fui confisus in sanatione eius: neque cessaui subtiliare ipsum, donec sanatus est, et consolidatus est locus.	I therefore applied treatment until I was confident in its healing: nor did I cease to probe it until it was healed and the location consolidated.
Postquam ego uidi locum iam consolidatum, timui super infirmum, quod accideret super infirmum accidens malum in uentre suo: et non accidit ei ex illo accidens malum.	After I saw that the location was already consolidated, I feared over the sick man that some bad occurrence might happen to him in his belly: and no bad occurrence happened to him from it.
Et remansit in melioribus dispositionibus suis, comedens et bibens, et futuens, et intrauit balneum, et exercitatus est in dietis suis.	And he remained in better conditions than before, eating and drinking, and copulating, and entered the bath, and engaged in his usual exercises.
Et iam dixerunt quidam experimentatorum, quia quando accidit in Intestino uulnus, et est paruum: tunc oportet ut ligetur secundum hunc modum.	And some surgeons have said that when an injury occurs in the intestine and it is small, then it should be tied in this manner.
Et est, ut accipias formicas magnorum capitum.	And there are large-headed ants available.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris, et pone formicam unam ex eis quae habeant os apertum super duo labia uulneris.	Then bring together the two edges of the wound and place one ant with an open mouth over them.
Cum ergo capit super ea, et stringit os suum, abscinde caput eius, adhaeret enim, et non soluitur.	But when it takes hold there, and closes its mouth, cut off its head, for it sticks fast and cannot be dislodged.
Deinde pone formicam aliam prope primam, et non cesses facere illud cum formica post formicam secundum quantitatem uulneris totius.	Then place another ant near the first one, and continue doing this with ants successively according to the total length of the wound.
Deinde reduc ipsum, et sue uulnus.	Then close it up and dress the wound.
Illa enim capita remanent annexa in Intestino, donec cibetur Intestinum, et sanetur, et non accidat infirmo nocumentum penitus.	For those heads remain attached to the intestine until it heals, causing no further harm to the patient.
Et iam possibile est, ut ligetur Intestinum etiam cum filo subtili: quod abstersum est ex intestino animalis, annexo cum eo postquam intromittitur in acum.	And now it is possible also to tie the intestine with a fine thread; this has been demonstrated on an animal's intestine, after being attached to it when introduced into the wound.
Et est, ut accipias extremitatem huius fili ex intestino, et excarnetur multum.	And take one end of this thread from the intestine and burn it much.
Deinde liga in extremitate eius filum lini subtile inuolutum.	Then tie a fine linen thread onto its tip.
Deinde intromitte illud filum in acum, et sue cum eo intestinum.	Then introduce that thread into the wound together with the intestine.
Deinde reduc ipsum in disruptionem.	Then bring it back together again at the point of separation.
Et iste modus suturae cum formicis et intestino, non est nisi secundum uiam fiduciae et spei.	And this method of suturing with ants and intestine is only a matter of trust and hope.
Scias, uulnus quod est magnum, amplum, praecipue si est in uno intestinorum gracilium: tunc non est ingenium nisi subtiliatio, neque est eius sanatio omnino.	Know that a large, wide wound, especially if it is on one of the small intestines, cannot be healed by any means.
¶ De cura Zuchemen, et Fistularum.	On the Treatment of Hernias and Fistulas.
Caput LXXXVIII.	Chapter 78.
Scias, quod omne uulnus, aut apostema quando ueterascit et antiquatur, et fit ulcus, et non consolidatur, et emittit pus semper, et non abscinditur: tunc nominatur uniuersaliter in quocunque membro fuerit Fistula, et nos nominamus ipsum Zuchemen.	Know that any wound or abscess which becomes old and chronic, forms an ulcer, does not heal, constantly discharges pus, and is not incised, is universally called a fistula wherever it may be located; we call it zuchemen.
Et Fistula quidem est secundum ueritatem nodatio filtrata, dura, alba: cum qua non est dolor, cui est concauitas pennae auis: et propter illud nominant eam quidam Risati, id est, pennam.	And truly a fistula is a hard, white, filtered knot without pain; like the hollow of a bird's feather. Some call it 'risati', meaning 'feather'.
Et est in quibusdam horis humida, quae emittit pus.	At certain times it may be moist and discharge pus.
Et fortasse scinditur humiditas in quibusdam horis.	And perhaps the moisture may split open at some times.
Et quandoque est haec humiditas multa, et est pauca: et est grossa, et est subtilis.	Sometimes this moisture is abundant and sometimes scarce; it may be thick or thin.
Et ego iam praemisi in diuisione, tunc cum dixi uulnera, quod omne ulcus quod non sanatur, neque nascitur in eo caro, non est illud nisi propter unam nouem caussarum.	And as I have already said in the division of wounds when I spoke about ulcers, any ulcer that does not heal nor has flesh growing on it is due to one or more causes.
Quarum una est, aut propter paucitatem sanguinis in corpore: aut propter maliciam eius: aut quoniam inter ipsum, et super labia eius est caro dura, prohibens natiuitatem carnis: aut quia est multae sordis et sordiciei: aut quoniam ulcus in seipso est putridum, et materia quae mittitur ei est malae qualitatis: aut quoniam medicina est inconueniens in curatione eius: aut quoniam corruptio cadens in regione est genus pestilentiae, aut per proprietatem in regione, sicut accidit in Caesaraugusta: in qua fit difficilis digestio aegritudinum, et tardatur in ea sanatio apostematum per naturam: aut quoniam in eo est os unum, aut numerus ossium.	Of which one is that there is a lack of blood in the body; or because of its malice; or because between it and its edges there is hard flesh preventing the growth of new tissue; or because it has much foulness and dirtiness; or because the ulcer itself is putrid, and the matter discharged into it is of bad quality; or because the medicine used for its treatment is unsuitable; or because there is a corruption falling in the region causing pestilence, as happens in Caesaraugusta where digestion of diseases is difficult and the healing of abscesses is delayed by nature; or because there is one bone too many or one bone missing.
Et ego iam ostendi omnes istas caussas et signa earum, et curationes ipsarum cum medicinis in diuisione: et oportet hic ut faciam te scire curationem Fistulae et Zuken, quae fit per uiam operationis cum manu.	And I have already shown all these causes and their signs, as well as their treatments with medicines in the division; but here it is necessary for me to teach you the treatment of a fistula and zuchemen which are done by manual operation.
Scias ergo, quod Fistula accidit in omnibus membris corporis.	So know that a fistula can occur in all parts of the body.
Nam ex eis sunt Fistulae quae perueniunt ad uenas magnas et arterias, aut neruos, aut sifac: aut ad intestinum, aut ad uesicam, aut ad aliquam ex costis: aut ad aliquam ex spondilibus dorsi, aut ad aliquam iuncturarum compositarum compositione: sicut manus, et pedis: et ex eis sunt quae uadunt ad propinquitatem membri principalis, et similium.	For there are fistulas which reach the large veins and arteries, nerves or muscles; or the intestines, bladder or ribs; or some of the vertebrae or joints composed of bones like hands and feet; and there are those that approach the main limb and similar ones.
Quae ergo ex his Fistulis est secundum hunc modum, est ex aegritudinibus difficilis sanationis, et non recipit curationem, et occupatio cum ea est labor et ignorantia.	It is therefore difficult to heal these fistulas in this manner, and they do not receive treatment; dealing with them involves effort and ignorance.
Quod si est ex Fistulis aliqua cuius profunditas non peruenit ad haec loca quae dixi: et speras, et confidis in curatione eius, et uis peruenire ad cognitionem illius, tunc accipe tentam ex aere, aut ferro, si Fistula tendit secundum rectitudinem, et perquire eam cum ipsa.	But if there is a fistula whose depth does not reach the places I have mentioned, and you hope for its cure and trust in treatment, then take a probe made of silver or iron; if the fistula extends straightforwardly, follow it with this.
Si autem in Fistula est tortuositas, tunc inuestiga eam cum tenta de plumbo subtili.	But if there is a windingness in the fistula, then investigate it with a probe of fine lead.
Quoniam plumbum cum lenitate sui corporis alleuiatur, et curuatur circa tortuositatem.	Because lead with its gentle nature alleviates and curves around the windingness.
Quod si Fistula est habens orificia multa, non est tibi possibile ut significes super eam cum tenta.	But if a fistula has many openings, it is not possible for you to indicate it with a probe.
Clisteriza ergo ex eis orificium ex orificiis suis.	Therefore, choose one of its openings from the openings themselves.
Nam humiditas qua clisterizas ipsum, uadit uersus orificia alia, et currit ex eis.	But the moisture with which you irrigate it will flow towards the other openings and run out of them.
Deinde exquisite inquire secundum quem modum est tibi possibile: ut cognoscas quod illic est os, aut neruus, et est Fistulae concauitas longinqua, aut propinqua: aut est Fistula una cui sunt orificia multa, et sta super totum illud, cum summa fortitudinis tuae: cum interrogatione tua, qua interrogas infirmum, et inuentione doloris apud compressionem cum manu tua super locum, et similibus ex significationibus et caussis accidentibus apostemati.	Then examine carefully to determine whether it is possible for you to know which bone or nerve is there and how deep or close the cavity of the fistula is; or if it is a single fistula with many openings. Stand on all that with your utmost strength, asking the patient and discovering the pain upon compressing the area with your hand and similar signs and causes accompanying apostema.
Cum ergo steteris super omnia illa statione uera, tunc uade ad curationem secundum confidentiam: et est, ut consideres tunc, si est Fistula propinqua apparens, aut in loco saluo longinquo a iunctura, aut a neruo, aut arteria, aut uena, aut uno locorum quae dixi tibi: tunc seca Fistulam secundum quod praemissum est ex narratione mea, et aufer quod est in ea ex filtratione, et carnibus corruptis, quod nascitur in orificio eius ex carne, aut thelul, et similibus: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	When you have stood steadfast on all this, then proceed to treatment with confidence. Then consider whether the fistula is close and apparent or located far from a joint or nerve, artery, vein, or any of the places I mentioned to you. Then cut the fistula according to what has been described in my account, remove what is inside it through filtration, and remove the decayed flesh that appears at its opening made of skin or fat and similar things; treat it until it heals.
Si autem Fistula est longinquae profunditatis, et est secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut seces eam in profundo quantum est tibi possibile.	If the fistula is deep and straight, then you must cut into it as deeply as possible.
Deinde mundifica ipsam ex omnibus carnibus eius corruptis.	Then cleanse it of all its decayed flesh.
Deinde administra licinia inuoluta in medicinis acutis: et intromitte ea usque ad concauitatem Fistulae quam comprehendisti cum ferro: fac cum ea illud aliquotiens, donec corrodat medicina acuta totum quod remansit in concauitate Fistulae ex corruptione.	Then apply a linen strip dipped in sharp medicines and insert it into the cavity of the fistula you cut with the knife. Do this repeatedly until the sharp medicine has corroded all that remains inside the cavity from decay.
Deinde restaura ipsam cum unguentis quae generant carnem sanam, donec sanetur.	Then dress it with ointments that promote healing of flesh until it is healed.
Si uero non sanatur per illud, tunc cauteriza ipsam secundum quod narrauimus.	If it does not heal by this method, then cauterize it according to what has been described.
Si ergo caussa Fistulae est os, et certificatur apud te illud: tunc inquire ipsum, et seca ipsum secundum quod narraui tibi: si non prohibet te aliquid ex uena, aut neruo, aut membro principali, sicut diximus.	If the cause of the fistula is bone and you are certain of this, then examine it and cut it according to what I have described to you. If nothing prevents you from doing so in terms of a vein, nerve, or main member, as we mentioned.
Si ergo detegitur tibi os, et est in eo quiddam corruptionis, et nigredinis: tunc rade ipsum, donec auferatur corruptio eius tota.	If you find bone and it has some decay and blackness, then scrape it until all its decay is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with what will flesh it over until it heals.
Quod si non sanatur, et emittat pus sicut faciebat: tunc scias, quod tu non peruenisti ad totam eradicationem corruptionis.	But if it does not heal and continues to emit pus as before, then know that you have not completely eradicated the decay.
Detege ergo super illud secundo, et exquisite fac rasionem eius, et mundificationem ipsius cum ultima fortitudine tua.	Therefore, examine it again, investigate its cause thoroughly, and cleanse it with all your strength.
Deinde restaura ipsum.	Then dress it.
Si ergo sanatur, bonum est: et si non, tunc scias quod illa corruptio est in profunditate longinqua corporis, quam non es consecutus.	But if it heals, that is good. And if not, then know that the decay is deep within the body and you have not reached it.
Non est ergo tibi in ea ingenium, nisi dimittere ipsam naturae.	Therefore, you should leave it to its natural course.
Quod si corruptum est os paruum, et est possibile tibi, attrahe ipsum cum forficibus subtilibus quae conueniunt ad illud.	If the little bone is corrupted and it is possible for you, draw it out with fine forceps that fit it well.
Si autem sunt ossa multa, tunc exquisite fac attractionem eorum omnium, neque dimittas ex eis aliquid cum tua fortitudine.	But if there are many bones, then carefully draw them all out one by one, leaving none behind with your strength.
Si uero contrarietatem facit tibi aliquid ex humiditatibus, et non est in incisione eorum timor, uel error: tunc incide illas humiditates et carnes, si sunt illic, et libera ossa.	But if any moisture opposes you and there is no fear or mistake in cutting them, then cut those moistures and flesh, if they are there, and free the bones.
Si uero non est tibi praeparatio auferendi ossa ex hora tua, tunc pone super uulnus quod putrefaciat ipsum: et dimitte ipsum, donec putrefiat quod est in circumitu illorum ossium ex carnibus et humiditatibus.	But if you are not prepared to remove the bone from its socket at once, then apply something that will cause it to decay over the wound and leave it until what is around those bones in flesh and moisture decays.
Et custodi uulnus ut non consolidetur.	And keep the wound so that it does not heal over.
Et constringatur sectio quam tu secuisti in operatione tua.	And let the incision you made during your operation be closed up tightly.
Imo pone super ipsum, si times, cotum submersum sulfure trito cum oleo: aut cotum submersum in unguento aegyptio, aut aliquo unguentorum uiridium.	Rather, if you wish, apply over it cotton soaked in sulfur powder with oil, or cotton soaked in Egyptian ointment, or some other virulent ointment.
Nam quando putrefient illae scilicet humiditates, et separantur ex eis ossa, alleuiatur ablatio eorum, et ipsorum attractio.	For when those moistures decay and the bones separate from them, the removal of those bones and their drawing out are eased.
Si autem est os unum magnum, sicut os cruris, aut os coxae, et similia illis, et quod ex eo corruptum est, est pars magna: tunc rade ipsum rasione ultima, donec auferatur illa nigredo et corruptio.	But if it is one bone of great size, such as the leg bone or hip bone and others like them, and what has decayed from it is a large part, then shave it away little by little until that blackness and decay are removed.
Deinde restaura uulnus.	Then heal the wound.
Si uero quod est in eo corruptum, est pars magna, et corruptio iam consecuta est medullam ossis, tunc necesse est serrare ipsum, et incidere ipsum totum usque ad locum, ubi peruenit corruptio: tunc cura ipsum, donec consolidetur.	But if what has decayed in it is a large part and the decay has already reached the marrow of the bone, then it is necessary to close it up and cut it all the way down to where the decay has reached. Then treat it until it heals.
Et ego narro tibi zuken, quae accidit uiro in crure suo: ut ponas ipsam exemplum et adiutorium super operationem tuam.	And I tell you this case of Zuken which happened to a man in his leg so that you may use it as an example and help in your own operation.
Fuit uir iuuenis aetate circiter triginta annos, cui accidit dolor in crure suo, a caussa quae mota est super ipsum intra corpus, id est, ab interioribus, donec peruenerunt materiae ad crus, et apostematum est apostemate magno: et non fuit ei caussa extrinseca.	There was a young man about thirty years old, to whom pain occurred in his leg due to a cause that moved upon him from within the body, that is, from an internal source, until matter arrived at the leg, and there appeared a large abscess; and there was no external cause.
Extensum est ergo cum eo tempus cum errore medicorum, donec apertum est apostema, et concurrerunt cum eo materiae multae.	So much time passed with him in error on the part of physicians until the abscess burst open, and many materials gathered around it.
Et postposita est curatio eius, donec fistulatum est crus, et facta sunt in eo orificia multa: quae omnia emittebant pus, et humiditates corporis.	And its treatment was delayed until the leg became fistulous and many openings were made therein which all emitted pus and bodily humors.
Curauit ergo ipsum multitudo medicorum circiter duos annos, et non fuit in eo sapiens in arte manus, donec uocatus sum, et uidi crus eius, et materias quae currebant ex illis orificiis cursu magno: etiam omne uiri corpus iam tabuerat, et color eius citrinus erat.	So many physicians tried to cure him for about two years, and there was no wise hand in the art until I was summoned, and saw his leg, and the materials running out of those openings with great force: and indeed all the man's body had already wasted away, and his color was yellowish.
Intromisi ergo tentam in uno locorum orificiorum, et peruenit tenta ad os.	I therefore inserted a probe into one of the openings, and it reached to the bone.
Deinde perscrutatus sum orificia omnia: et inueni ea peruenire ad se inuicem ex omnibus partibus cruris.	Then I examined all the openings and found that they all connected with each other from all parts of the leg.
Properaui ergo, et secui super unum illorum orificiorum, donec detexi partem ossis: et inueni ipsum corruptum: quod iam corrosum erat, et denigratum, et putruerat, et perforatum erat, donec penetrauerat usque ad medullam.	So I prepared and cut over one of those openings until I exposed a part of the bone, which I found to be corrupted: it was already eaten away, blackened, decayed, and perforated, so that it had penetrated even to the marrow.
Serraui ergo quod detectum est mihi, et praeparatum ex osse corrupto.	I therefore cut away what I had exposed of the corrupted bone, and prepared it.
Et deputaui, quod non esset in osse nisi illa corruptio, quam abscidi, et serraui.	And I decreed that nothing should remain on the bone except that corruption which I cut off and removed.
Et ego iam eradicaueram eam.	I had already rooted it out.
Deinde posui restaurationem uulneris cum medicinis consolidatiuis spacio longo.	Then I applied a dressing to the wound with consolidating medicines over a long period of time.
Et non est consolidatum.	And it did not heal.
Deinde tentaui, et detexi super os secundo supra detectionem primam: et inueni corruptionem continuam cum osse: et serraui quod apparuit mihi etiam ex illa corruptione.	Then I probed and exposed a second time above the first exposure, and found continuous corruption with the bone; and I cut away what appeared to me from that corruption as well.
Deinde conatus sum restaurationem eius.	I then attempted its restoration.
Et non est restauratum.	And it was not restored.
Detexi ergo super ipsum iterum, et non cessaui incidere os particulatim, et conari restaurationem eius: et non est restauratum, donec incidi ex osse circiter palmum unum, et extraxi illud cum medulla sua.	So I exposed it again and did not cease cutting the bone piece by piece, attempting restoration; but it was not restored until I cut about a palm's length from the bone and extracted it along with its marrow.
Deinde restauraui ipsum cum medicinis, et consolidatum est uelociter, et sanatum: et non fuit necessaria haec iteratio in operatione eius, et sectione ipsius, nisi propter dispositionem debilitatis infirmi, et paucitatem tolerantiae eius, et timorem meum super ipsum de morte: quoniam accidebat ei in omnibus horis ex superfluitate euacuationis syncopis mala.	Then I restored it with medications, and it was quickly consolidated and healed. And this repetition of the operation and sectioning would not have been necessary if not for the disposition of the patient's weakness, his scarcity of tolerance, and my fear for him regarding death, since a harmful syncope occurred in him at all hours due to excessive evacuation.
Sanatus est ergo sanatione integra: et nata est in loco ossis caro dura, et bona facta est dispositio in corpore suo, et rediit uirtus eius: et conuersatus est in dispositionibus suis: et non fecit ei contrarietatem in ambulatione nocumentum omnino.	So he was healed with complete healing; and firm flesh grew in place of the bone, and his bodily condition became good, and his strength returned, and he resumed his usual activities, causing him no harm whatsoever in walking.
Si autem os eminens in loco corporis iam fractum est: tunc oportet ut serres ipsum, secundum hunc modum: et est: ut accipias ligamentum, et stringe ipsum in extremitate ossis eminentis: et praecipe alicui, qui extendat ipsum ad sursum: et pone ligamentum aliud ex lana grossius ligamento primo.	But if the bone protruding from the body is already broken, then it must be cut according to this method: take a bandage and tie it at the end of the projecting bone; then have someone else pull it upward; and place another bandage made of coarse wool over the first.
Deinde liga ipsum super carne, quae est suh osse: et extende extremitatem eius, ut trahas carnem ad inferiora: et tu detegis carnem super locum quem uis serrare, ut non laedat Serra carnem.	Then tie it over the flesh that is below the bone and stretch its end so that you pull the flesh downward; and you expose the flesh at the place where you wish to cut, so that the saw does not harm the flesh.
Pone lignum, aut tabulam sub osse inferius decenter: quoniam quando facis illud, non prohibetur quin secet carnem corruptam.	Place wood or a board beneath the lower bone appropriately, for when you do this, it prevents cutting through healthy flesh.
Et oportet ut sit Serratura super locum corruptum parumper, ut non sit in concauitate ossis corruptio: et non appareat in apparitione sua sensui, et cogat ad Serraturam sui uice alia.	And the sawing must be kept brief over the corrupted spot so that there is not too much excavation of bone, which would appear unsightly and necessitate another sawing operation.
Quod si os est corruptum, et non est eminens, imo continuatur pars eius cum parte: et corruptio est in medio eius, aut in parte ipsius: tunc detege carnem ab omnibus partibus totam.	But if the bone is corrupted and not protruding, indeed continuous with another part, and corruption is found in its middle or in one of its parts, then expose all surrounding flesh completely.
Deinde pone lignum inferius.	Then place wood underneath.
Postea serra illud ex parte prima, ubi est corruptio, donec continuetur Serratura ex parte altera: et sit Serratura secundum longitudinem a corruptione parumper, secundum quod diximus.	Next, saw it from the first part where corruption is until continuity of sawing reaches the other side; and let sawing be according to length barely away from corruption, as we have said.
Quod si corruptio est in iunctura, incide ipsam iuncturam corruptam, et serra os ubi continuatur ex parte altera.	But if corruption is at the joint, cut through the corrupted joint itself, and saw the bone where it continues on the other side.
Si uero corruptio est in continuatione duarum iuncturarum, tunc non est in ea ingenium nisi abrasio.	If however corruption is at the continuity of two joints, then there is no remedy except removal.
Quod si corruptio est in pectine manus, aut in pectine pedis: tunc res in eo est difficilis ualde.	But if corruption is in the hand's bone or foot's bone: then the case is very difficult.
Verum oportet, ut inquiras corruptionem qualiter appareat tibi.	Yet you must investigate how corruption appears to you.
Et abradas eam, et mundes ipsam secundum quamcunque dispositionem tibi possibile est, et cum quocunque ingenio rectificatur tibi: quando non facit tibi contrarietatem Vena, aut Neruus.	And abrade it and cleanse it according to whatever method is possible for you, and apply whichever remedy you can: provided that neither vein nor nerve opposes you.
Et scias quod incisoria, et Serrae ad incidendum ista ossa sunt multa, secundum situm ossium, et praparationem eorum, et ipsorum grossitudinem, et subtilitatem eorum, et magnitudinem, et paruitatem ipsorum, et duriciem ipsorum, et eorum raritatem.	And know that saws and blades for cutting these bones are many, according to the position of the bones, their preparation, their thickness and thinness, their length and width, their hardness and rarity.
Quapropter oportet, ut praepares omni speciei operationis instrumentum conueniens ad illam operationem.	Therefore you must prepare an appropriate tool for each type of operation.
Et scias, quod operationes istae significant tibi super speciem instrumenti quo indiges, quando tecum est studium longum.	And know that these operations indicate to you the species of instruments you need when you are engaged in a prolonged study.
Et cognitio modorum huius artis, testimonium modorum aegritudinum: tunc enim iam inuenies per teipsum illud quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis ad omnem infirmitatem.	And knowledge of the methods of this art is witness to the methods of diseases; then indeed you will already find yourself what is suitable for each ailment among instruments.
Et ego sum firmans tibi in ultimo huius capituli numerum instrumentorum, quae pones exempla super quae incides, et probationem qua experiaris super alia.	And I assure you that at the end of this chapter I will give you a list of instruments upon which you shall model yours and by which you shall try others.
Forma Serrae.	The Shape of the Saw.
Forma alterius Serrae.	Shape of Another Saw.
Forma Serrae alterius.	Form of Another Saw.
Forma Serrae alterius.	Form of Yet Another Saw.
Haec forma Serrae depicta, sit decenter facta.	This form of the saw should be depicted appropriately.
Fiat arcus eius superior, acuitas eius ex ferro: et manubrium eius ex buxo, et sit pyramidale decenter factum.	Let its top be curved, and its edge made of iron; let its handle be made of boxwood, and it should be properly fashioned in a pyramidal shape.
Forma Rasorii iuncturarum.	The form of the scalpel for joining.
Sit caput huius Rasorii, secundum formam capitis claui stellati: et puncta eius sint secundum formam punctorum elischetfegi.	Let the head of this scalpel be in the shape of a star-nail head; and let its points be like those of an 'elasticsearch'.
Et non conuenit, nisi ut fricentur cum eo capita iuncturarum, quando corrumpuntur, aut os amplum, et magnum est.	And it is not fitting except that it should scrape with the heads of joints when they are corrupted or the mouth is wide and large.
Forma maioris Rasorii.	The form of the larger scalpel.
Forma medii Rasorii.	The form of the medium-sized scalpel.
Forma Rasorii lati.	The form of the broad scalpel.
Forma Rasorii in quo est concauitas.	The form of the scalpel with a concave edge.
Forma Rasorii alterius subtilis.	The form of another fine scalpel.
Forma Rasorii alterius curuatae extremitatis.	The form of another scalpel with curved tip.
Forma Rasorii parui, subtilis tentae.	The form of the small, fine, pointed scalpel.
Forma Rasorii cum quo inciduntur ossa.	The form of the scalpel used for cutting bones.
Forma etiam Rasorii magni.	Also the form of the large scalpel.
Hoc similatur Radio, et extremitas est sicut Serra: exhibetur in locis multis ex rasione ossium.	This resembles a chisel, and its tip is like a saw; it is shown in many places due to the reason of bones.
Forma Rasorii quod conuenit ad rasionem eius quod perforatum est ex ossibus.	The form of the scalpel suited for the purpose of cutting through bone.
Extremitas eius triangula, acutarum est extremitatum.	 Its tip is triangular and sharp at both ends.
Fit ex Indi.	It is made from Indian iron.
Et similiter oportet, ut fiant omnia quae diximus ex Rasoriis, et Incisoriis, et Serris.	And similarly it is necessary that all the things we have spoken about regarding scalpel blades and chisels be made of iron.
¶ De incisione extremitatum, et Serratura ossium.	On the cutting of extremities and sawing of bones.
Caput LXXXIX.	Chapter 89.
Putrefiunt extremitates, aut ex caussa extrinseca, aut intrinseca.	Extremities putrefy either due to external or internal causes.
Cum ergo medicatus fueris illam corruptionem curatione medicinarum, et non confert curatio: et uides corruptionem incidere in membrum, quam non repercutit aliquid: tunc oportet ut incidas illud membrum usque ubi consequitu corruptio, ut euadat infirmus per illud a morte, aut a malicia quae est maior defectu membri.	Therefore, when you have treated that corruption with medicinal treatment and the treatment is ineffective, and you see corruption spreading to the limb without encountering any resistance, then it is necessary to cut off that limb where the corruption reaches, so that the patient may be freed from death or from the serious harm which is greater than the loss of the limb.
Et signum cui accidit illud est, quod denigratur membrum, donec putetur: quod ignis combussit ipsum, aut putrefit post nigredinem: donec inciditur illa putredo usque ad illud quod sequitur illud membrum, et serpit in totum corpus.	And the sign of this is that the limb becomes blackened until it putrifies; either fire has burned it or putrefaction occurs after the blackening. When this corruption is cut away up to what follows the limb and creeps into the whole body.
Propera ergo cum incisione eius, et similiter si caussa corruptionis est a percussione quorundam uenenosorum: sicut scorpionis marini, et uiperae, et rutellae, et similium.	Therefore hasten with the cutting of it and similarly if the cause of corruption is from the sting of some venomous creatures such as the marine scorpion, viper, asp, and others like them.
Si ergo corruptio, aut percussio est in extremitate digiti, tunc incide digitum, et non des spacium corruptioni, ut incedat usque ad reliquam manum.	If therefore corruption or injury is at the extremity of a finger, then cut off the finger and do not give space for corruption to proceed up to the rest of the hand.
Et similiter si accidit in manu, tunc incide eam ex radice focilis, et non des spacium corruptioni, donec capiat in focili brachii.	And similarly if it happens in the hand, then cut off the hand at its root of the forearm and do not give space for corruption until it reaches the elbow.
Et si inuadit in eo, tunc incide brachium apud cubitum in iunctura sua.	And if it invades there, then cut off the arm at the elbow joint.
Si autem pertransit corruptio, et uides eum circiter cubitum: tunc in illo est mors infirmi.	But if corruption passes through and you see that it is around the elbow, then death for the patient is there.
Et administrare praeter illud ex curatione, est quantitas uirtus.	And administering anything beyond that in treatment is useless effort.
Et similiter fac de pede, quando inuadit corruptio in digito, tunc incide ipsum apud unum nodorum: et si capit in pectine pedis, tunc incide pedem totum.	And similarly do with the foot when corruption invades a toe; then cut it off at one of its joints. And if it reaches the arch of the foot, then cut off the whole foot.
Si autem ascendit ad genu, tunc incide crus apud iuncturam genu.	But if it ascends to the knee, then cut off the leg at the knee joint.
Quod si corruptio iam peruenit supra genu, tunc non est in ea ingenium, nisi dimissio, et relinquere infirmum morti.	That if corruption has already reached above the knee, there is no treatment for it except abandonment and leaving the patient to die.
Et modus incidendi membrum, aut serrandi ipsum est, ut stringas ligamentum in inferiori, quem uis incidere: et stringe ligamentum aliud supra locum.	And the method of cutting a limb or closing it is to tie up the ligament below where you wish to cut and tie another ligament above that place.
Et extendat minister ligamentum unum ad inferiora: et extendat minister aliud ligamentum superius ad sursum.	And let one assistant pull down the lower ligament while another pulls up the upper ligament upwards.
Et tu separa carnem quae est inter duo ligamenta, cum Spatumili lato, donec detegatur caro tota.	And you separate the flesh which is between the two ligaments with a broad spatula until all the flesh is exposed.
Deinde incidatur, aut serretur.	Then it should be cut or tied.
Et oportet, ut ponas ab omnibus partibus pannum lini, et non tangat Serra locum sanum: et accidat infirmo laesio addita, et apostema calidum.	And it is necessary that you place linen cloths from all sides and that they do not touch the healthy place lest additional injury occur and a hot abscess form.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis interius dum operaris, tunc cauteriza locum uelociter: aut pone super ipsum quosdam pulueres abscindentes sanguinem.	But if blood flow occurs internally while you are operating, then cauterize the place quickly; or apply to it certain powders that stop bleeding.
Deinde redi ad medicationem tuam, donec compleatur.	Then return to your treatment until it is complete.
Deinde liga membrum uulneratum cum ligamento conueniente ei, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then bind the wounded member with an appropriate bandage and care for it until it heals.
Et ego narro tibi quod accidit uiro in pede suo, hoc idem accidens quod narro tibi.	And I tell you that what happened to a man's foot, the same thing can happen as I am telling you.
Quod est, quia accidit in pede suo nigredo, cum adustione quae assimilatur combustioni ignis: et corruptio illa in primis accidit in digito suo, donec coepit pedem totum.	What happened is that blackness occurred in his foot with a burning akin to fire-burning, and this corruption first occurred in his toe until it began to affect the whole foot.
Properauit ergo uir ex seipso, postquam uidit corruptionem incidere in membro cum uehementia eius, quod inuenit ex dolore, et adustione eius: et incidit ipsum apud iuncturam, et sanatus est.	So the man removed it from himself after he saw that the corruption was spreading vigorously, causing him pain and burning. He cut it at its junction and it healed.
Et postquam praeteriit ei tempus longum, accidit ei illa eadem corruptio in digito manus suae indice.	And after a long time had passed, he again suffered the same corruption in his right index finger.
Venit ergo ad me, et conatus sum recuperare illam superfluitatem cum eo quod posui super manum ex medicinis post mundificationem corporis eius: et non repercussa est superfluitas, et coepit incedere in digitum alium: donec coepit coruptio in manum.	He came to me and I attempted to remove the surplus with what I placed on his hand after cleansing his body. But the surplus was not removed, and corruption began to spread to another finger until it reached his hand.
Vocauit ergo me, ad incidendum manum eius: et nolui illud, sperans ex me super repercussionem illius superfluitatis: et timui etiam super ipsum apud incisionem manus eius mortem.	He called for me to cut off his hand. But I refused to do so, hoping that the surplus would be removed by me without needing to cut off his hand. And I feared that he might die from cutting off his hand.
Quoniam uirtus uiri erat super casum.	Because the man's strength was greater than his ailment.
Postquam ergo desperauit de me, reuersus est ad terram suam: et peruenit ad me de eo, quia properauit, et incidit manum suam totam: et sanatus est.	After he despaired of me, he returned to his land. And I was told that he had hurried and cut off his entire hand, and it healed.
Et non attuli hanc narrationem, nisi ut sit adiutorium super illud quod cadit de genere huius aegritudinis: et ut sit significatio qua significetur, et secundum quam agatur.	And I have not related this story except as a help for what can happen regarding this kind of ailment, and as an indication of how it should be treated.
¶ De cura Sinuum, et qualitate clisterizationis cum medicinis.	Chapter on the Treatment of Sinuses and the Nature of Enemas with Medicines.
Caput XC.	Chapter 90.
