Then turn up the patient's lip and look for two veins, one on the right side of the lip and one on the left. Both can be identified by their dark color.
Et illud uerum est: quia in circumitu earum sunt uenae minutae, nigrae.	It is true that there are small, dark veins around them.
Incide ergo utramque incisione incidente.	Therefore, make an incision on both veins simultaneously.
Si autem dubitatio est super te, et non scis quae earum est: tunc intende ad incisionem maioris earum, et ipsarum manifestiorem.	But if you are uncertain and do not know which one is which, then aim for the larger of the two veins, as it is more prominent.
Et similiter fac de duabus uenis quae sunt in labio superiore: et plurimum quidem currit consuetudo cum eo: et incide duas uenas quae sunt in labio inferiori.	Similarly, perform phlebotomy on the two veins found on the upper lip and it is customary to do so. Also, make incisions on the two veins found on the lower lip.
¶ De phlebotomia Venae sub lingua post Cephalicae phlebotomiam.	Regarding bloodletting: The vein under the tongue, after bloodletting of the cephalic veins.
Duarum uero Venarum quae sunt sub lingua phlebotomiae iuuamentum: est, quod phlebotomia Cephalicae est ad praefocationes quae sunt in gutture, et aegritudinem uuulae, et aegritudines oris.	The bloodletting of the two veins under the tongue is beneficial for: treating hoarseness in the throat, and ailments of the uvula, and diseases of the mouth.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est, ut sedeat infirmus inter manus tuas coram sole: et eleualinguam eius, et aspice sub lingua a latere eius uno uenam, et a latere eius alio uenam: et color utriusque decliuis ad nigredinem.	The quality of bloodletting these veins is such that the patient should sit between your hands facing the sun. Extend their tongue and observe under it. On one side you will see one vein, on the other side another vein. The color of both veins should incline towards darkness.
Phlebotoma ergo utramque: et custodi, ne ultimes manum tuam in phlebotomando eas.	Therefore, perform bloodletting on both veins and be careful not to let your hand slip while bloodletting them.
Nam sub eius sunt arteriae, et fortasse accidet fluxus sanguinis ex illis arteriis.	For underneath these veins are arteries, and it is possible that bleeding may occur from those arteries.
¶ De tribus Venis in cubito.	Regarding the three veins in the elbow.
Venae autem tres quae phlebotomantur in cubito, sunt in quarum phlebotomia cucurrit consuetudo in omnibus hominibus.	The three veins that are bloodlet from the elbow are ones whose bloodletting is customary for all people.
Et phlebotomia earum fit secundum duos modos.	And their bloodletting is done according to two methods.
Aut pungendo cum phlebotomo myrtino lato: aut oliuari ad subtilitatem decliui: aut secando cum phlebotomo cultellari, et est Alnesil.	Either by pricking with a wide myrtle bloodletter or by slicing with an olive oil-soaked lancet, or by cutting with a scalpel bloodletter. This is called Alnesil.
Et haec est forma eius.	This is its form:
Sic Alnesil est, quod conuenit ad sectionem.	Thus, Alnesil is suitable for cutting.
Et ex eis sunt species latae, et subtiles secundum amplitudinem uenarum et stricturam earum Forma phlebotomi myrtini sit lata, sicut uides.	And among them are wide and narrow types according to the width of the veins and their thickness. The form of the myrtle bloodletter should be wide, as you see.
Et conuenit ad aperiendas uenas concauas, plenas, procedentes, apparentes, grossas, et illas quae continent sanguinem grossum, turbidum.	And it is suitable for opening hollow veins that are full, protruding, visible, thick, and those that contain coarse, turbid blood.
Et iste phlebotomus est minoris latitudinis, et subtilioris extreminatis.	This bloodletter is of lesser width and more refined at its tip.
Et conuenit ad phlebotomiam uenarum subtilium, quae continent sanguinem subtilem citrinum	And it is suitable for bloodletting fine veins that contain clear, yellowish blood.
¶ De phlebotomia Basilicae.	Regarding Bloodletting at the Temple.
Basilicae autem quae est una harum trium uenarum phlebotomiae iuuamentum est.	But among these three veins, it is especially useful for bloodletting to choose the one at the temple.
Quia extrahit sanguinem ex aegritudinibus, quae sunt sub gutture et collo, ex eo quod sequitur pectus, et uentrem: et conuenit phlebotomatori cum phlebotomat eam, ut caueat, et sit super timorem ex ea nam sub ea est arteria.	For it draws blood from ailments that are below the throat and neck, extending to the chest and stomach. And the vein suits a bleeding practitioner because he can avoid causing fear [by not drawing attention] since there is an artery beneath it.
Si ergo errat, et addit in punctura phlebotomi, incidet illam arteriam, et accidet fluxus sanguinis.	If however he errs and adds too much pressure during bloodletting, he will strike the artery, and abundant bleeding will result.
Quapropter oportet, ne phlebotomet eam cum phlebotomo pungente: imo sit secans cum Alnesil.	Therefore, let him not pierce it with a lancet when performing bloodletting, but rather cut it with an artery forceps.
Quod si non apparet Basilica apparitione manifesta, tunc oportet, ut alienes ipsam, et permuteris ad aliam, aut quaeras aliquem ramum eius: aut phlebotomes loco eius Funem brachii.	But if the Temple does not appear clearly, then it is necessary to seek out other veins and exchange them, or else find some of its branches. Otherwise, one should perform bloodletting on the arm instead.
Ipsa enim est manifesta, et seca eam cum phlebotomo Anesil, sicut diximus.	Indeed, this vein is prominent, and cut it with an artery forceps using the method we have described.
Si autem uis phlebotomiam ipsius eiusdem, tunc oportet ante stricturam brachii, ut tangas locum, donec cognoscas locum pulsus.	But if you wish to perform bloodletting on this same vein, then before applying the tourniquet to the arm, touch the spot until you recognize the pulse point.
Deinde signa super locum cum encaustro, postea brachium, et seca uenam sectione concaua cum phlebotomo Alnesil, sicut diximus.	Then mark the spot with a cautery, afterwards apply the tourniquet to the arm, and cut the vein with a concave artery forceps using the method we have described.
Et caue ne cadat percussio per spacium a loco arteriae.	And take care not to strike too far from the location of the artery.
Et quando uides, cum tu stringis ligamen, inflationem in loco quem signasti cum encaustro, tunc illa inflatio est inflatio arteriae: deuita ergo eam.	And when you see that as you tighten the bandage, there is swelling at the spot you marked with a cautery, then that swelling is the swelling of the artery. Therefore avoid it.
Quod si uides sanguinem apud phlebotomiam salire, sicut urina pueri, et est sanguis subtilis, rubeus: tunc scias, quia est ex sanguine arteriae.	But if you see blood rising during bloodletting like urine from a child, and it is thin, red blood, then know that it comes from arterial blood.
Tunc ergo propera, et pone digitum tuum super ipsum spacio longo, deinde aufer digitum tuum.	Then quickly place your finger far above it, afterwards remove your finger.
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis (multotiens namque abscinditur) tunc stringe brachium, et dimitte ipsum: et caueat infirmus a motione eius: et sit super timorem eius.	If blood is severed (for it often happens that it is severed), then tighten the arm and let go. And caution the patient against moving too much, and cause him no fear.
Et non moueat ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	And do not move it for several days until it heals.
Si autem non abscinditur sanguis, et uincit te: et non est tibi praesens in momento tuo medicina, tunc incide arteriam, si apparet tibi.	But if blood is not severed and binds you, and there is no medicine present at your moment of need, then cut the artery if it appears to you.
Nam extremitates eius contrahuntur, et abscinditur sanguis.	For its ends are contracted, and blood is severed.
Aut accipe corticem fistici, et finde eum: accipe medietatem unam, et stringe eam super locum uenae strictura decenti, cum ligamento et puluillis usque ad diem alium.	Or take half a fig and wrap it around the place where the vein is tightly bound with bandages and lint until the next day.
Tunc si abscinditur sanguis, est bonum.	Then if blood is severed, that is good.
Et si non: tunc cura ipsum cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio ex loco puluerum abscindentium fluxum sanguinis: et abscisio sanguinis eius non est difficilis in pluribus dispositionibus, propter locum paruum uulneris, et possibilitatem ligamenti ex brachio.	But if not, then treat it with what preceded this remedy for stopping the flow of blood. And its bloodletting will not be difficult in many cases because of the small size of the wound and the ease of tying off the arm.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae Fuscae.	On Bloodletting from the Dark Vein.
Venae autem Fuscae phlebotomiae iuuamentum est, quod trahit sanguinem ex superiori parte capitis, et inferiore corporis: propterea, quia est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae, sicut diximus.	The Dark Vein is useful for bloodletting because it draws blood from the upper part of the head and the lower part of the body. This is because it is composed of a branch of the Basilic vein and a branch of the Cephalic vein, as we have said.
Et conuenit phlebotomanti eam, ut sit super timorem ex phlebotomia eius, nam sub ea est neruus.	And the bloodletter should fear bloodletting from it because underneath it lies a nerve.
Si ergo addit in punctura phlebotomi, et inuenit neruum, accidit in ea stupor, et difficilis fit sanatio eius, et fortasse non sanatur penitus.	So if the bloodletter adds too much pressure during the puncture and encounters a nerve, paralysis occurs and its healing becomes difficult, and perhaps it may not heal at all.
Et iste neruus multotiens apparet sensui.	And this nerve appears often to the touch.
Si autem occultatur in quibusdam hominibus, et est subtilis, et non ostenditur: tunc oportet ut ponas phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas, sectionem cum Alnesil, et deuita neruum cum fortitudine tua.	But if it is hidden in certain individuals and is thin and not apparent, then you must perform bloodletting carefully with a sharp instrument, avoiding the nerve as best you can.
Quod si uena est inter duos neruos, tunc finde uenam in longitudine.	If the vein lies between two nerves, then bind it lengthwise.
¶ De uena Cephalica.	On the Cephalic Vein.
Phlebotomiae autem uenae Cephalicae iuuamentum est, quia attrahit sanguinem ex capite, et confert ad aegritudines oculorum.	The Cephalic Vein is useful for bloodletting because it draws blood from the head and carries it to diseases of the eyes.
Et oportet in hac uena proprie, si uis, ut phlebotomes eam pungendo cum phlebotomo oliuari, aut cum phlebotomo myrtino: quoniam est saluior uenarum omnium, quoniam non est subea arteria, neque neruus.	And it is proper in this vein, if you wish to use a fleam with an olive-oil lubricated fleam or a myrtle-oil lubricated fleam, since it is the safest of all veins because it has no underlying artery nor nerve.
Verumtamen conuenit tibi apud phlebotomiam, ut deuites cum phlebotomo caput lacerti tantum, et quaeras locum leniorem: et non nocet ei, si non inuenitur cum percussione prima, ut iteretur super eam cum phlebotomia aliquotiens.	However, when performing bloodletting, you should avoid striking the head of the humerus with the fleam and seek a gentler spot. It does no harm if it is not found on the first strike, so that it may be struck again several times with the fleam.
Verumtamen fortasse apostematur in quibusdam hominibus quando non phlebotomatur in percussione prima, sed non nocet ei illud apostema in aliquo.	But sometimes a boil may form in some people when bloodletting is not done on the first strike, but this boil does no harm.
¶ De utilitate Phlebotomiae, et cautelis in ea obseruandis.	Chapter: On the Usefulness of Bloodletting and Precautions to be Observed Therein.
Qualitas autem Phlebotomiae, et accidentia eius ex ea, in cuius rectificatione oportet te cogitare.	The quality of bloodletting and its results from it require your consideration for their correction.
Primum ergo illius est de quo oportet ut scias, quod phlebotomia non administratur, nisi in conseruatione sanitatis, et perseuerantia eius, et cautela ab aduentu aegritudinum.	Firstly, you should know that bloodletting is not administered except for the sake of preserving health and maintaining its constancy with caution against the onset of illnesses.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in una uenarum trium quae sunt in cubito, scilicet Cephalica, et Fusca, et Basilica.	And that bloodletting should be performed on one of the three veins found in the elbow, namely the cephalic, dark-colored (fuscus), and basilica.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in principio Veris super ieiunium, in uere, et aestate: et autumno, et hyeme post comestionem, quando apparent significationes repletionis.	And bloodletting should be performed at the beginning of spring after a fast, during summer and autumn, and winter after meals when signs ofpletion appear.
Et fiat phlebotomia in die primo, aut in tertio, postquam praeterierint de die tres horae.	And bloodletting should be performed on the first or third day after three hours have passed since the previous meal.
Phlebotomia autem quae administratur in aegritudinibus, non habet horam determinatam: sed quando prouocat conuenientia et necessitas ad illud, in nocte, aut die, et in omni hora, et in omni tempore.	Bloodletting performed for illnesses does not have a fixed hour but should be done whenever the situation and necessity demand it, day or night, at any hour, and at all times.
Et non oportet, ut phlebotomentur pueri, donec ueniant super eos quatuordecim anni.	And children should not be bled until they reach the age of fourteen years.
Neque phlebotometur mulier praegnans, nisi a mense quarto usque ad septimum.	A pregnant woman should not be bled except from the fourth to the seventh month.
Neque phlebotomentur senes, qui iam pertransierunt sexaginta annos.	Nor should the elderly, who have already exceeded sixty years, be bled.
Cum ergo aliquis uult phlebotomari propter quemcumque modum sit: oportet, ut mundificet intestina sua ante phlebotomiam cum clisteri leni, si in eis est stercus multum retentum: ut non attrahant uenae apud phlebotomiam ex intestinis superfluitates putridas nocentes membris principalibus.	Therefore, when someone wishes to be bled for any reason, it is necessary that they cleanse their bowels beforehand with a gentle clyster, if there is much retained feces in them: so that the veins do not draw putrid harmful excesses from the intestines during phlebotomy, which harm the principal limbs.
Neque phlebotometur patiens toctina, id est, satietatem nauseatiuam: neque crapulatus, neque euadens ab ebrietate, donec remoueatur illud ab eis.	And the patient should not be bled if they are full or suffering from nausea; nor one who is drunk or coming out of drunkenness until that state has passed.
Neque infirmus cum hydropisi.	Nor an invalid with dropsy (hydropsy).
Et caueatur phlebotomia iterum post colicam passionem, et uomitum, et fluxum uentris, et multiplicationem coitus, et laboris, et exercitii, et uigiliarum, et ieiunii, et omnis quod dissoluit uirtutem ex re corporea aut animali.	And let phlebotomy be avoided again after an attack of colic, vomiting, abdominal flux, excessive sexual activity, hard labor, exercise, wakefulness, fasting, and all things that dissolve the power from the body or animal.
Deinde considera in subtilitate humorum ante illud, si sanguis est grossus cum cibis et potibus, et medicinis: si possibile est ei illud.	Then consider the fineness of the humors before that (i.e., phlebotomy), if blood is thick due to foods and drinks, and medicines: whether it is possible for him.
Deinde introeat balneum, si non prohibet ipsum aliquid: aut exercitetur aliquo exercitio, ut subtilietur sanguis.	Then he should take a bath if nothing prohibits it, or engage in some exercise to make the blood thinner.
Et pone phlebotomiam eius in pectore, circa tertiam diei, sicut diximus: et conare, ut euacuetur pectus eius illa die ex omnibus accidentibus animalibus malis: sicut angustia, et ira, et timor: et ex omnibus accidentibus corporeis, sicut labor, et poena, et superfluicoitus, et illis similia.	And perform phlebotomy on him in the chest around the third hour of the day, as we have said; and strive that his chest be emptied that day from all accidental passions of the soul, such as constriction, anger, fear, etc., and from all corporeal accidents, such as labor, punishment, superfluous coitus, etc.
Et sedi suae faciat esse praesentes res cum quarum usu cucurrit consuetudo hominum ex aromaticitate, et odoramento, et tripudio et similibus illis per quantitatem possibilitatis.	And let him have present in his dwelling things with which people are accustomed to use fragrance, pleasant smell, joy and similar things according to what is possible.
Deinde sedeat phlebotomator super puluinari, quod sit altius quam puluinar phlebotomandi: postea extrahat brachium suum, et fricet ipsum phlebotomator manu sua bis, aut ter.	Then the phlebotomist should sit on a high chair that is higher than the chair for phlebotomy; afterwards he should draw out his arm and rub it twice or thrice with his hand.
Deinde stringat ligamentum cum corrigia, et inuoluat eam bis.	Then tie the ligature with thread and wrap it around twice.
Et sit strictura temperata, quoniam strictura quando est inaequalis, aut per superfluitatem in strictura, tunc prohibet cursum sanguinis: aut in mollificatione, tunc etiam prohibet cursum sanguinis.	And let the binding be balanced, for if it is uneven, either through excess in the binding, then it obstructs the flow of blood, or in softness, it likewise obstructs the flow of blood.
Deinde post stricturam oportet, ut fricet phlebotomandus manus suas simul adinuicem, donec inflentur uenae, et declarentur sensui.	Then after binding, the one to be bled should rub his hands together until the veins are filled and become visible.
Deinde abstergat phlebotomator phlebotomum cum pauco oleo, antiquo proprie.	Then the phlebotomist should cleanse the vein with a little old oil.
Deinde ponat digitum suum indicem manus sinistrae super ipsam uenam sub loco cuius phlebotomiam uult, parum: ut non fugiat uena, et cassetur percussio.	Then he should place his left hand's index finger on the vein itself under the spot where he wishes to perform phlebotomy, gently so as not to make the vein flee and avoid striking.
Quoniam ex uenis est quam inuenis sicut chordam fugientem apud phlebotomiam: et ex eis est quae est plena uentositate: et quando ponis phlebotomum super eam, contrahitur sub phlebotomo, et decipitur phlebotomator, et non aperit phlebotomus uenam: et si aperit eam, est stricta: propter illud ergo oportet, ut firmetur phlebotomator, et sit sollicitus in his rebus omnibus.	For there are veins that flee like a string when you attempt phlebotomy, and others that are full of wind; thus when you place the phlebotome on them they contract beneath it and deceive the phlebotomist so that he does not open the vein or if he opens it, it is constricted. Therefore it is necessary for the phlebotomist to be steadfast and careful in all these matters.
Deinde deponat phlebotomum.	Then he should remove the phlebotome.
Si ergo aperitur uena ex uice una, tunc bonum est.	If the vein opens on the first attempt, then that is good.
Et si non, tunc itera illud uice alia sub illo loco parum, aut supra ipsum cum festinatione: si non apostematur locus.	But if not, then repeat it once or twice more beneath or above that spot with haste so long as the location does not become blunted.
Quod si apostematur, aut expauescit infirmus, tunc dimitte eum die, aut duobus diebus: et non stringat ligamentum.	But if the location becomes blunted or the patient becomes faint, then let him go for one or two days and do not apply a ligature.
Fortasse enim attrahet apostema calidum.	For perhaps it will draw out an abscess.
Neque ingrediatur balneum.	And he should not enter a bath.
Deinde iteret phlebotomiam, si amat.	Then repeat the phlebotomy if desired.
Quod si apertio est parua, aut currit sanguis subtiliter: et times ut non egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uis: tunc itera phlebotomum in foramine ipso secundum rectitudinem, et adde in operatione parum.	But if the opening is small or blood flows finely, and you fear that not enough blood will flow out as desired, then repeat the phlebotomy in the same spot but along its length, adding a little to the procedure.
Et fac illud cum festinatione, antequam apostemetur locus, apostematus enim locus est in multis hominibus apud operationem paruam.	And do this quickly before the site closes up, for many people find that a closed-up site hinders a small operation.
Si ergo uides ipsum iam apostematum, tunc non iteres super ipsum omnino, non enim excusat apud te aliquid.	If you see that it has already closed up, then do not repeat the procedure on it at all, for it will not help you any further.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex faece olei: quoniam alleuiat cursum sanguinis.	And place over it some olive oil feces to ease the flow of blood.
Et est melior in hoc loco quam oleum ipsum, et quam reliqua olea.	It is better for this purpose than olive oil itself or any other oils.
Et similiter administra faecem olei in omni phlebotomia tua, qua phlebotomas uenas apud prohibitionem cursus sanguinis: et faciunt illud tyriaca alfarach, et sagzenea, quando ponitur ex una earum super locum.	And similarly use olive oil feces for all your phlebotomies when veins are opened to control blood flow. Tyrians, Alpharachs, and sages do this when they apply one of these remedies to the site.
Sanguis enim subtiliatur et resoluitur, quando est grossus.	For fine blood is made subtler and more fluid when it is thick.
Quod si accidat in loco phlebotomiae apostema magnum, nam multotiens accidit, praecipue ei qui non est phlebotomatus nisi uice illa, aut est apertio uenae parua, tunc propera et pone super locum spongiam infusam in aqua et sale, calefacta parumper: et stringe eam hora una: quoniam soluitur.	But if a large hematoma occurs at the phlebotomy site, as it often does, especially when someone is not regularly bled or when there is only a small vein opening, then promptly place on the site a sponge soaked in warm water and salt for an hour to dissolve it.
Et oportet, ut facias illud post exitum sanguinis ex uena ipsa, cum complemento sui, aut ex uena alia.	And you should do this after blood has flowed out of the vein itself, or from another vein.
Quod si remanet in loco post dies aliquid nigredinis, aut uiriditatis, non nocet illud: et si uis, pone super ipsum aliquid aloe, aut myrrhae solutorum: aut aliquid ex succo menthastri, id est, calamenti aut simile illius.	If some darkness or greenness remains at the site after a few days, this is not harmful. If you wish, apply to it some aloë or dissolved myrrh, or some juice of mint leaves, such as catmint or its like.
Et multotiens quidem accidunt apostemata et eminentiae apud phlebotomiam Basilicae.	And indeed, hematomas and swellings often occur during basilica phlebotomy.
Pone ergo manum tuam super ipsam, tunc si inuenis molliciem apud compressionem tuam super ipsam, tunc illa eminentia est mala.	Therefore, place your hand on it. If you find softness upon compressing it, then that swelling is bad.
Caue ergo, ut ponas super eam aliquid ex eo quod diximus.	So be careful not to apply any of the remedies we have mentioned to it.
Nam fortasse fluet ex ea sanguis arteriae.	For perhaps blood from an artery may flow forth from it.
Sed fac emplastrum ei cum eo in quo est stipticitas, ut induretur locus.	But make a plaster for it with that which has astringent properties so that the spot hardens.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then treat the wound itself along with the rest of its treatment until it heals.
Et oportet, ut extrahas omni homini ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis suae.	And it is necessary to withdraw from every person blood according to the quantity of its power.
Et quod apparet ex colore uincente super sanguinem.	And that which appears as a victorious color over the blood.
Nam sanguis si est niger, tunc dimitte ipsum exire, donec rubeat: et similiter si uides ipsum grossum: tunc dimitte eum, donec subtilietur: et similiter si est acutus, donec auferatur acuitas eius.	For if the blood is black, then let it flow out until it turns red; and similarly if you see it as thick: then let it flow out until it becomes thin; and similarly if it is sharp: then let it flow out until its sharpness is removed.
Et oportet ei qui est plenus, fortis, et indiget extractione sanguinis uice una, ut amplificetur phlebotomia uenae, et sit phlebotomus latus: et in eo qui est debilis, sit econtrario illius.	And it is necessary for one who is full, strong, and in need of bloodletting to undergo phlebotomy once, so that the blood vessel may be widened and the phlebotomist's arm may become strong. But in one who is weak, it should be done conversely.
Et oportet, ut extrahat ipsum in uicibus, et ut sit foramen strictum: et melius quod administratur in phlebotomia uenae est, ut sit transuersa sectio, non punctura.	And it is necessary to withdraw it at intervals and that the opening be narrow. And what is better administered in bloodletting from a vein is that it be a transverse incision, not a puncture.
Et iste modus phlebotomiae est saluus a fluxu sanguinis, et ab incisione nerui: et est laudabilior, et saluior quam phlebotomia per latitudinem et longitudinem.	And this method of bloodletting is safe from the flow of blood and from cutting nerves. And it is more praiseworthy and safer than bloodletting through width and length.
Et cui consueuit peruenire apud phlebotomiam syncopis, oportet ut cibes ante phlebotomiam modico pane infuso in aqua granati muzi: aut secaniabin, si est calefactus: et extrahas ei ex sanguine in tribus uicibus, aut quatuor.	And whoever is accustomed to fainting during bloodletting should take beforehand some bread soaked in pomegranate juice or cooked dates, and have blood withdrawn from them at three or four intervals.
Et si est infrigidatae complexionis, tunc accipiat ante phlebotomiam panem infusum in syrupo miua, aut in syrupo de melle aromatizato cum speciebus, aut in syrupo aromatizato odorifero.	And if their temperament is cold, then let them take beforehand bread soaked in pomegranate syrup or in fragrant honey syrup seasoned with spices, or in fragrant aromatic syrup.
Quod si accidat syncopis apud phlebotomiam, et est caussa eius exitus sanguinis multi: tunc oportet, ut sumat in potu aquam carnis, et syrupum odoriferum subtilem: et utatur aromaticitate cum algalia, et liniatur pectus eius cum ea: et utatur reliquis quae diximus in diuisione in capitulo syncopis ex euacuatione.	If fainting occurs during bloodletting and the cause is a great loss of blood, then it is necessary to take water of flesh as a drink and thin fragrant syrup; and use aromatics with aloe and anoint the chest with it; and use the rest which we have mentioned in the division concerning fainting from evacuation.
Qui autem uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo: oportet ei cuius phlebotomia est propter euacuationem multam, et uirtus eius est debilis, ut soluat sanguinem paulatim per quantitatem uirtutis in diebus continuis.	Whoever wishes to discharge his arm and dissolve his blood a second time: it is necessary for him whose bloodletting is due to great evacuation, and whose strength is weak, to gradually dissolve blood little by little over continuous days according to the amount of his strength.
Qui uero uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo, et est corpus eius forte: tunc faciat illud post septem horas, aut nouem a phlebotomia sua prima.	Whoever wishes to discharge his arm and dissolve his blood a second time, but has a robust body, then let him do it after seven or nine hours from his first bloodletting.
Qui autem uult attrahere sanguinem ex corpore suo ad contrarium partis ad quam declinat: oportet ut euentetur ei in die secundo, aut in tertio.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from his body towards the opposite part from which it inclines should be evacuated on the second or third day.
In cuius uero corpore est sanguis multus iam calefactus, et acuitur, et facit accidere febrem: oportet, ut egrediatur ex eo sanguis in uice una, et extrahatur ex eo quantitas multa: et amplificetur apertio usquequo accidat syncopis: postquam tu fueris conseruans omnes conditiones phlebotomiae: et ut ponas manum tuam super pulsum eius apud cursum sanguinis, ut non accidat mors loco syncopis.	In the case of a body with much blood already heated and corrupted causing fever to occur, it is necessary for blood to be let out in one sitting and a large quantity to be drawn out until fainting occurs. After you have observed all conditions of bloodletting, place your hand over his pulse at the course of the blood so that death does not happen instead of fainting.
Multotiens enim accidit illud, quando ignorat phlebotomator, et cadit negligentia.	For it often happens thus when the bloodletter is ignorant and carelessness occurs.
Et non oportet quando uis soluere brachium, et soluere sanguinem secundo, cum iam clausum sit orificium uenae, et fiat difficilis exitus sanguinis, ut prematur super ipsum cum uehementia, et curuatum extendatur uelociter.	But when you wish to discharge the arm and dissolve blood a second time, it is not necessary, if the vein's opening has already closed and blood exits with difficulty, to press upon it forcefully and suddenly stretch out the limb.
Nam illud est malum ualde, imo dimitte ipsum, donec phlebotometur secundo.	For that is very harmful indeed; rather, leave it alone until it is bled a second time.
Aut remoue cum acuitate phlebotomi illud quod coagulatum est ex sanguine in orificio uenae, et pone super ipsum aliquid salis dissoluti in aqua.	Or remove with care the blood clot that has formed at the vein's opening and place upon it some salt dissolved in water.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex tyriaca alfaroch, aut sagzenea, et pone ipsum compressione leni, donec egrediatur sanguis.	And apply over it some of theriac of Alfaruch or senna, and apply gentle pressure until blood flows out.
Si uero iam apostemata est uena, tunc dimitte eam, et non tegas eam, donec sedetur apostema.	But if the vein has already formed an abscess, then let it be and do not cover it until the swelling subsides.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad soluendum sanguinem secundo, et non est excusatio, tunc aut phlebotoma ipsum supra illum locum, aut in brachio alio in uena alia.	If necessity demands a second bloodletting and there is no excuse for avoiding it, then perform the bloodletting either at that same location or on another arm vein.
Funis autem brachii phlebotomatur loco Fuscae, et Basilicae, cum non inueniuntur, et sunt occultae, quoniam est composita ex eis.	The bracelet used for bloodletting is located instead of the Cubit and Basilica veins if they are not found because it is composed from them.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus manum suam in aqua calida, donec rubeat focile, et appareat uena manifeste.	And the quality of bloodletting is such that the patient should immerse their hand in warm water until it becomes reddened and the vein appears clearly.
Deinde stringatur super ipsam cum ligamento parum constrictione media.	Then tie a bandage tightly around it midway.
Deinde phlebotoma secundum transuersationem paulatim, non latitudinaliter, neque secundum longitudinem: et sit apertio ampla, et sit phlebotomia tua qua eam phlebotomas super iuncturam manus parumper.	Then perform the bloodletting gradually across, not wide nor long: and let the opening be large, and make your bloodletting like those who perform it slightly above the hand joint.
Quod si prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera manum in aqua calida, et dimitte sanguinem currere in aqua, donec consequaris necessitatem tuam.	But if the flow of blood is impeded, then immerse your hand again in warm water and let the blood run into the water until you achieve your purpose.
Si autem fueris in diebus aestatis, tunc excusaris ab iteratione manus in aqua calida.	But if it be summer time, then thou mayest excuse thyself from immersing thy hand again in warm water.
Et plurimum quidem ponitur cursus sanguinis in aqua calida in tempore hyemis.	And especially is the course of bloodletting in warm water placed during wintertime.
Et phlebotomia huius uenae est saluior omnibus uenis, quoniam non est sub ea uena pulsatilis, neque neruus.	And bloodletting from this vein is safer than from all others because there are no pulsating veins or nerves beneath it.
Phlebotomia uero Saluatellae manus dextrae, est conferens aegritudinibus epatis.	But bloodletting from the Salutatella vein of the right hand is beneficial for ailments of the liver.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringas mahason manus cum ligamento, aut manu tua, postquam tu intromittis eam in aquam calidam, donec infletur uena, et demonsteretur sensui ualde.	And the quality of bloodletting from it is that you should tie a bandage around the wrist of your hand with your hand or compress it until the vein swells and becomes distinctly visible.
Deinde phlebotoma eam transuersando.	Then perform the bloodletting across it.
Et si incidis eam totaliter, non nocebit ei illud in aliquo.	And if you cut it entirely, it will not harm him at all.
Et conserua, ne ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo.	But keep your hand away from the phlebotome while closing.
Sub ea enim sunt nerui digitorum denudati ex carne.	For beneath it are nerves of the fingers laid bare from the flesh.
Deinde itera manum ad aquam calidam, et dimitte currere sanguinem in ea.	Then repeat hand-washing with warm water, and allow blood to flow into it.
Nam si tu non iteras eam in aqua calida, coagulatur sanguis in orificio uenae, et prohibetur a cursu.	For if you do not wash your hands again in warm water, the blood will clot at the opening of the vein and impede its flow.
Cum ergo extraxeris ex sanguine quantitatem necessitatis, tunc pone super uenam oleum et sal: ut non consolidetur uelociter.	Having drawn out the necessary amount of blood, then apply oil and salt over the vein to prevent rapid clotting.
Et similiter oportet, ut facias cum omni ramo stricto.	And similarly you should do with every cut branch.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae eius ex manu sinistra, est: quoniam est conferens ad aegritudines splenis: et similiter fac in phlebotomia eius, sicut fecisti in secunda aequaliter.	But the tourniquet for this bloodletting is on the left hand because it corresponds to diseases of the spleen. And similarly do likewise with its bandaging as you did with the second.
Saphenae autem phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad aegritudines quae sunt in inferiori parte corporis, sicut aegritudines matricum, et retentionem menstruorum, et infirmitates renum, et ulcera coxarum et crurium antiqua, et similia ex aegritudinibus.	However, the tourniquet for bloodletting from the saphenous vein is used for ailments in the lower part of the body such as disorders of the womb, retention of menstruation, weaknesses of the kidneys, and old ulcers of the hips and thighs, and similar diseases.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus pedem suum in aquam calidam: et faciat super ipsum fricationem, donec exuberent uenae: et liga supra iuncturam pedis cum corrigia.	And the quality of bloodletting from it is that the patient should immerse their foot in warm water and perform friction upon it until the veins become prominent. Then tie above the junction of the foot with a bandage.
Et uenae quidem locus est apud calcaneum, apparens uersus pollicem: et ramificantur ex ea in facie pedis rami multi.	And indeed, the location of the vein is at the heel appearing towards the thumb and it branches out into many branches on the surface of the foot.
Phlebotoma ergo eam in ampliore ramo eius, aut apud calcaneum in aggregatione eius: quoniam est melius et saluius.	Therefore perform bloodletting from its larger branch or at the heel where it congregates because this is better and safer.
Quod si phlebotomas eam in facie pedis, tunc caue a neruis qui sunt sub ea super faciem pedis.	But if you perform bloodletting on its surface of the foot, then beware of the nerves which are beneath it on the surface of the foot.
Et pone phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas ex transuerso, quasi tu uelis incidere eam: et sit phlebotomus Nesil.	And place your bloodletting vessel diagonally across it, as if you wish to cut into it; and let the bloodletter be a vein called Nesil.
Si autem prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera pedem eius in aqua calida: et dimitte sanguinem currere in eam, donec euacuatur.	But if the flow of blood is obstructed, then again immerse his foot in warm water; and allow blood to flow into it until it is emptied.
Quod si errat uenam phlebotomator in prima uice, tunc iteret cum phlebotomia ad superiora parumper, nam locus est saluus, et non times ex eo maliciam, quando tu caues a neruis, sicut diximus.	But if the bloodletting vein errs on the first attempt, then repeat it with bloodletting towards the upper areas briefly, for the place is safe, and do not fear harm from it when you are cautious about the nerves, as we have said.
Et similiter cum Saphena pedis alterius aequaliter.	And similarly when using the great saphenous vein of the other foot equally.
Venae autem Sciaticae locus, sicut diximus, est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	The location of the sciatic veins, as we have said, is at the heel on the inner side.
Et iuuamentum phlebotomiae eius est, ad dolorem anchae, quando est propter sanguinem calidum.	And the benefit of bloodletting it is for ankle pain when it is due to hot blood.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut ingrediatur infirmus balneum, et festinet: et stringe crus eius a latere anchae usque supra calcaneum quatuor digitis, cum uitta subtili longa: non enim apparet nisi propter illud.	And the quality of its bloodletting is such that the patient enters a bath and hastens; and bind his leg on the side of the ankle up to above the heel with four fingers using a long, thin bandage: for nothing else appears except for this.
Quando ergo apparet, tunc phlebotoma eam secundum quodcumque ingenium est tibi possibile, aut secundum transuersionem: et est melius, aut ut incidas eam incisione, aut seces eam sectione.	When it appears, then perform bloodletting on it according to whatever method is possible for you, either diagonally or by making an incision or by cutting it.
Locus enim eius est saluior, et ipsa est in pluribus hominibus occulta ualde.	For its location is safer, and indeed it is very hidden in many people.
Quod si non inuenis eam, et non apparet sensui omnino: tunc phlebotoma aliquem ramum eius, et est ille qui apparet in dorso pedis, et uersus auricularem: et caue a neruis, et fac currere ex sanguine quantitatem quam uis.	But if you do not find it and it does not appear at all: then perform bloodletting on one of its branches, which is that which appears on the back of the foot and turns towards the ear; and beware of the nerves, and let as much blood flow as you wish.
Deinde solue stricturam, et pone super locum phlebotomiae corium, et stringe locum.	Then release the binding, and place skin over the location of the bloodletting and bind it.
Uelociter enim sanatur.	For it is healed quickly.
¶ De Ventosatione, et qualitate usus eius.	On Venthouses [Fistulas] and their Nature.
Caput XCVIII.	Chapter 98.
Uentosae fiunt ex cornibus, et ex aere, et ex uitro.	A ventouse is made from horns, from bronze, or from glass.
Et Ventosatio quidem fit secundum duos modos.	And Venthouses are applied in two ways.
Cum scarificatione, et extractione sanguinis: et alter est uentosatio sine scarificatione.	One way is with scarification and bloodletting; the other is without scarification.
Et haec Ventosatio quae est sine scarificatione, est secundum duos modos.	And this ventouse which is performed without scarification is done in two ways.
Aut enim est cum igne.	Either it is performed with fire.
Aut est absque igne.	Or it is performed without fire.
Et uentosis quae administrantur cum scarificatione et extractione sanguinis sunt quatuordecim loca corporis.	And there are fourteen locations on the body where ventouses are used with scarification and bloodletting.
Quorum unus est, Ventosatio Alnocrati, et est postremum capitis: et Alkehel, et est medium colli: et uentosae Alhagdahim, et sunt duae laminae colli a duabus partibus simul: et uentosae menti, et est sub mandibula in inferiori oris: et uentosae duarum spatularum: et uentosae Alachosos super finem caudae: et uentosae duorum focilium, et sunt medium duorum brachiorum: et uentosae duorum crurium: et uentosae duarum cauillarum.	And among them is the ventouse of Alnocrati, which is at the back of the head; and Alkhehel, which is in the middle of the neck; and the ventouses called Alhagdahim, which are two plates on either side of the neck; and the ventouse of the chin, which is under the jawbone below the mouth; and the ventouses of the two shoulders; and the ventouse of Alachosos at the end of the buttocks; and the ventouses of the two flanks, which are in the middle of the two arms; and the ventouses of the two thighs; and the ventouses of the two calves.
Et Ventosatio quidem non extrahit sanguinem tibi ex uenis minutis sparsis in carne, et propter illud non cadit uirtus ex eis, sicut est casus eius ex phlebotomia.	And indeed, a ventouse does not draw blood from the small scattered veins in the flesh, and therefore it does not lose its strength like bloodletting.
Neque oportet, ut administretur uentosatio siue cum igne, aut absque igne in aliqua aegritudinum quae fiunt ex repletione, donec euacuetur totum corpus.	Nor is it necessary to apply a ventouse with or without fire in any condition resulting frompletion until the entire body has been evacuated.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad Ventosationem ex aegritudine, aut propter consuetudinem, administramus eam in omni hora in principio mensis, in fine eius, et in medio ipsius, et in quocumque tempore fuerit.	But if there is a necessity to apply a ventouse due to illness or habit, we perform it at any hour at the beginning of the month, at its end, and in the middle, whenever it may be appropriate.
Quod est, quia ex hominibus est qui quando multiplicatur in eo sanguis, donec indiget extractione eius per uentosationem, inuenit in capite suo grauedinem, et sodahan.	This is because there are people who have so much blood accumulate within them that they require its removal by means of a ventouse; such individuals experience headache and dizziness.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit repletionem et rubedinem in facie sua, capite suo, et collo suo.	And among them are those who find fullness and redness in their face, head, and neck.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit pruritum in facie sua, et fronte sua, et tenebrositatem, et hebetudinem in oculis suis.	Among them are those who find itching in their face, forehead, darkness, and dullness in their eyes.
Et ex eis est qui scalpit locum uentosationis suae.	And among them are those who scratch the place of their baldness.
Et ex eis est cuius risus multiplicatur.	And among them is one whose laughter is multiplied.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit gustum sanguinis in ore suo: aut apostematur lingua, et expuit sanguinem.	And among them are those who find the taste of blood in their mouth, or the tongue becomes affected and spews forth blood.
Et ex eis est cuius somnus multiplicatur.	And among them is one whose sleep is multiplied.
Et ex eis est qui uidet in somno suo sanguinem et rubedinem, et interfectos, et plagas, et quae sunt similia illis.	And among them are those who see in their dreams blood and redness, slain persons, wounds, and things similar to these.
Quando ergo uidemus aliquid ex illis, et proprie si est in tertia media mensis: praecipimus tunc uentosationem fieri, postquam praeterierunt de die duae horae, aut tres.	Therefore, when we see something of these [symptoms], and especially if it occurs in the middle of the month, we then advise shaving, after two or three days have passed.
Iuuamentum autem Ventosationis nuchae, est: quoniam ipsa confert ad grauitatem in capite, et quod effunditur ad oculos.	But shaving the nape of the neck is beneficial because it relieves heaviness in the head and promotes discharge to the eyes.
At uero oportet, ut sit illud post euacuationem totius corporis.	But it is necessary that this [shaving] should be done after the evacuation of the entire body.
Et haec quidem Ventosa est loco phlebotomiae Cephalicae.	And indeed, this is a cupping procedure instead of cephalic phlebotomy.
Et non licet, ut utatur ea qui est frigidae complexionis, aut in quo est catarrus.	And it is not permitted for one who has a cold temperament or catarrh to use this [cupping procedure].
Nam infert ei nocumentum magnum.	For it will cause him great harm.
Et propter illud non oportet, ut utantur ea senes, et in cuius capite sunt aegritudines frigidae.	And therefore the elderly and those whose head has cold ailments should not use this [cupping procedure].
Qui autem super eam fit assiduus, generatur super eum obliuio.	But one who makes it a habit becomes forgetful.
Et propter illud oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut deponat manum suam cum uentosa parumper ad inferiora, timendo ex generatione obliuionis.	And therefore you should instruct the cupper to withdraw his hand with the cup for a short moment toward the lower part, fearing the generation of forgetfulness.
Ventosatio aut Alkehel, est loco phlebotomiae Fuscae, et phlebotomiae Basilicae, et propter illud confert asmati, et constrictioni anhelitus, et fissurae instrumenti anhelitus, et tussi, et repletioni.	Cupping (Alkehel) is instead of black cupping and common phlebotomy. It benefits asthma, shortness of breath, fissures in the breathing instrument, coughing, and fullness.
Et oportet, ut impellatur Ventosa Alkehel parumper, quoniam si ponitur inferius, generat debilitatem in corde, et stomacho.	And cupping with Alkehel should be briefly applied, for if it is placed below, it generates weakness in the heart and stomach.
Ventosatio uero alhagdahim, confert doloribus accidentibus in capite, et obtalmiae, et hemigraneae, et perforationi, et dolori in radicibus dentium: et est loco phlebotomiae Basilicae.	Ventosa Alhagdahim alleviates pains occurring in the head, eyes, and temples, as well as toothache and perforation pain. It is a substitute for basilica bloodletting.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne premat manum suam cum scarificatione: ut non incidat arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And you should instruct the cupping practitioner not to press their hand with the scarification, lest they strike an artery and cause excessive bleeding.
Ventosatio autem sub mento, confert alcolae in ore, et corruptioni gingiuae, et similibus eis ex aegritudinibus quae sunt in ore: et stat loco phlebotomiae alieherich, quae sunt in duobus labiis.	Cupping under the chin is beneficial for mouth ulcers and gum decay, as well as similar conditions affecting the mouth. It serves as an alternative to bloodletting at the lips.
Ventosatio autem spatularum, confert ad alchafacham, quae fit ex replexione, et caliditate.	Cupping with spatulas is beneficial for treating retention of urine and heat-related ailments.
Ventosatio uero interiorum partium duorum focilium, confert iuuamentum phlebotomiae uenarum trium, Basilicae, et Fuscae, et Cephalicae: quoniam ipsa attrahit sanguinem ex omnibus illis uenis minutis, quae sunt in carne: et attrahunt illae uenae minutae ex uenis aliis grossioribus eis, donec peruenit attractio ad uenas tres.	Cupping of the interior parts of two cups is equivalent to bloodletting from three veins, Basilica, Fusca, and Cephalica. This is because it attracts blood from all those tiny veins in the flesh, which then attracts blood from other larger veins until it reaches these three veins.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne multum procedat in scarificatione: quoniam locus est denudatus carne, et sub eo sunt nerui et arteriae.	And you should instruct the cupping practitioner not to cut too deeply in the scarification, as the area is bare of flesh and beneath it lie nerves and arteries.
Ventosa autem quae uentosatur super alchausos, confert hemorroidibus Ani, et ulceribus inferioribus.	Cupping performed over piles (hemorrhoids) relieves symptoms of the anus and lower ulcers.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut sit uentosa magna, et ut sit ex aere: quoniam locus indiget suctione forti, et fortasse franguntur Ventosae subtiles: et scarificetur scarificatione magna.	And you should instruct the cupping practitioner to use a large glass cup and to make sure it is airtight. This is because the area requires strong suction, and delicate cups may break. The incision should also be made deeply.
Ventosae autem crurium minuunt diminutione manifesta: quoniam attrahunt sanguinem ex toto corpore, et conferunt doloribus antiquis in renibus, et matricibus, et uesica: prouocant menstrua, et conferunt bothor, et ademenul: et stant loco phlebotomiae duarum saphenarum, et alhorcobeni.	Cupping of the legs reduces swelling noticeably. It attracts blood from the entire body and alleviates chronic pain in the kidneys, uterus, and bladder. It induces menstruation, treats dropsy, and acts as an alternative to bloodletting from both saphenous veins.
Verumtamen debilitant corpus multum, et faciunt accidere syncopim in pluribus hominibus.	Nevertheless, they greatly weaken the body and cause fainting spells in many people.
Et Ventosarum alhorcobeni iuuamentum est propinquum iuuamento Ventosarum duorum crurium.	And cupping of the hips is akin to cupping of both legs.
Qualitas positionis Ventosarum est, ut ponas uentosam in primis uacuam, et sugas suctione temperata: et non prolonges positionem uentosarum, sed pone eas uelociter, et remoue eas uelociter, ut ueniant humores ad locum aduentu aequali: et non cesses iterare illud et continuare, donec uideas locum iam rubere et inflari, et appareat rubedo sanguinis: tunc ergo scarifica, et itera suctione paulatim.	The proper method of applying cupping is to first place the cups in an empty state and create suction with moderate force. Do not prolong the application of the cups; rather, place them quickly and remove them quickly so that the humors come to the area evenly. Continue this process until you see the area turn red and swell, and blood appears on the surface. Then scarify the skin and gradually increase suction.
Deinde considera in dispositione corporum.	Then consider the condition of the bodies.
Nam qui ex hominibus est tenerae carnis, rarorum pororum, oportet ut scarifices ipsum semel, non plus: ut non ulceretur locus.	For those who are tender and have sparse pores, it is sufficient to scarify them once, no more than that, so as not to cause an ulcer.
Et praecipe Ventosatori, ut amplificet scarificationem, et profundet parum: et temperet suctionem in facilitate, et uelocitate, et motu suaui.	And instruct the cupper to make the incision wide but not deep, and to maintain a gentle, quick, steady suction.
Quod si in sanguine est grossitudo, tunc oportet, ut scarifices ipsum bis.	If there is thickness in the blood, then you must scarify twice.
In uice quidem prima aperitur uia subtiliationi sanguinis, et aquositati eius: et in secunda quidem perscrutationi exquisitae extractionis sanguinis grossi.	Indeed, the first opening serves to facilitate the refinement of blood and its purification, while the second enables a thorough examination and removal of thick blood.
Si uero sanguis est faeculentus ualde, tunc fiat scarificatio uice tertia: ut consequatur ultimum.	But if the blood is very impure, then perform a third scarification to achieve the final result.
Et ad ultimum, quando uolumus extrahere sanguinem paulatim, uel parumper, sufficit nobis scarificatio una.	And finally, when we wish to remove blood gradually or in small amounts, one scarification will suffice.
Quod si uolumus extractionem sanguinis multi, scarificamus scarificatione plurima.	If we wish to remove a large amount of blood, then perform multiple scarifications.
Et si nos mensuramus, quod sanguis est grossus: tunc oportet, ut scarificetur scarificatione profunda: et terminus aequalis in scarificatione, est profunditas cutis.	And if we measure that the blood is thick, then it is necessary to perform a deep scarification, with the depth equaling the thickness of the skin.
¶ Quid sit illud quod oportet administrari ex oleis apud positionem Ventosarum, et quid caueat uentosandus.	What should be applied from oils at the site of Ventosarum, and what it prevents when winded.
IN illo quidem cuius cutis est grossa, dura, fusca, et pori eius sunt stricti, oportet ut ungantur loca Ventosare cum oleis apertiuis, lenitiuis, resolutiuis: si est in tempore aestatis, sicut est oleum alkeiri, aut oleum uiolatum, aut oleum de amigdalis dulcibus, aut oleum de semine cucurbitae.	Indeed, for one whose skin is thick, hard, dark, and whose pores are closed, it is necessary to apply oils that are openers, soothers, dissolvers at the site of Ventosarum: if it is in the time of summer, such as oil of alkanet, or violet oil, or sweet almond oil, or pumpkin seed oil.
Et si est in tempore hyemis, tunc oleum narcissinum, aut oleum de lilio, aut oleum camomellinum, aut sarbatinum: et eis similia.	And if it is in the time of winter, then narcissus oil, or lily oil, or chamomile oil, or cypress oil: and similar oils.
Si uero superfluitas est grossa, frigida: tunc oleum sit amaracinum, aut oleum de balsamita aut oleum alben, aut oleum anetinum: et eis similia.	If however the excess is thick and cold, then let it be of bitter almond oil, or balsam oil, or white oil, or walnut oil: and similar oils.
Si uero uentosandus est amplorum pororum, tenerae carnis: tunc oportet, ut prohibeatur ab oleo, et oportet ut isti abluant loca Ventosarum earum post uentosationem cum aqua rosata, aut cum aqua frigida, aut cum aqua solatri, aut cum aqua cucurbitae, aut cum aqua portulacae: et similibus eis.	If however the one to be winded has large pores and tender flesh, then it is necessary that he be prohibited from oil, and it is necessary that these places after being winded be washed with rose water, or cold water, or watermelon water, or pumpkin water, or purslane water: and similar waters.
Ille autem cuius sanguis est multae humiditatis, abluat uentosas cum aceto, aut cum aqua myrti, et sumach: et similibus eis.	He whose blood is of great moisture should wash the winded places with vinegar, or myrtle water, and pomegranate: and similar waters.
Cuius autem superfluitates sunt grossae, abluat uentosas suas cum uino antiquo, aut cum aqua samsuci, aut decoctione aneti, aut camomillae: et eis similibus.	He whose excesses are thick should wash his winded places with old wine, or sampsuch water, or decoction of walnut, or chamomile: and similar waters.
Et oportet, ut caueatur uentosatio in balneo, aut in uestigio balnei, imo oportet, ut administretur post exitum ex balneo per horam, aut per horas duas.	And it is necessary to avoid being winded in a bath, or in the trail of a bath, indeed it is necessary that it be administered after exiting from the bath for an hour, or two hours.
Et non oportet, ut dormiat aliquis post uentosationem.	And one should not sleep after being winded.
¶ Quid est quo oportet ut regatur Ventosandus, aut Phlebotomatus ante uentosationem.	What is the reason that one should regulate the breath or perform phlebotomy before cauterization?
ET post eam oportet, ut consideres in primis: tunc si Ventosatus, aut Phlebotomatus sit cholericus, et uincunt super sanguinem eius acuitas et inflammatio: tunc oportet, ut accipiat infrigidantia, sicut granatum muzum: et etiam endiuiam cum aceto et lactuca, et secaniabin, et iuleb: et eis similia.	Afterward, one should first consider this: if the patient is choleric and winded or bled, then acuteness and inflammation will prevail over his blood. Therefore, he should take cooling remedies such as pomegranate juice, a drink of vinegar and lettuce, and saffron and pennyroyal, along with similar things.
Et pone cibaria eius pullos, et carnes ouium sekebiget, et cibos conditos cum agresta: et eis similia.	And let his food be small and soft, consisting of the flesh of young birds, and roasted meats seasoned with herbs, and similar foods.
Et cuius complexio est frigida, oportet ut sumat in potu syrupum de melle, aut de almiua, aut alsecaniabin de seminibus factum: et sumat uinum odoriferum medium, quod est inter uetus et nouum: et praecipiatur, ut utatur paucitate cibi.	And if his complexion is cold, he should take syrup made from honey or almonds, or saffron made from seeds; and he should drink mediocre fragrant wine that is neither too old nor too new; and it should be prescribed that he use little food.
Et pone cibum eius pullos, et canebir: et passeres, id est, paruas aues: et pullos columborum issiadebet.	And let his food be small birds, partridges, and sparrows (that is, small birds), and the young of pigeons.
Et oportet, ut potus die uentosationis et phlebotomiae plus sit quam cibus: et oportet, ut detur in potu in quibusdam hominibus in horis tyriaca alfaroch, aut medicamen de musco, id est, muscata, aut alesselithe ante uentosationem: et ante phlebotomiam, aut post: ut confortentur membra principalia, et subtilietur sanguis.	And on the day of cauterization and bloodletting, drink should be greater than food. And for some people, it is necessary to give in drink either theriaca alfaroch or medication made from musk (that is, muscat) before cauterization, or before or after bloodletting, so that the principal members may be strengthened and the blood refined.
Et non oportet, ut sumant eam in potu calefacto.	And one should not drink it warm.
¶ De Ventosis sine scarificatione.	On Windings Without Scarification.
Uentosae autem quae sunt sine scarificatione, sunt Ventosae quae ponuntur super epar, et splenem, et podagram, et super uentrem, umbilicum, et loca renum, et pixidem anchae: quoniam ista membra non sufferunt scarificationem super se.	Windings that are performed without scarification are those placed over the liver, spleen, gouty joints, abdomen, navel, kidneys, and bladder, since these parts do not tolerate scarification upon them.
Et non quaeritur per eas, nisi aut attactio ex membro sanguinis ad membrum: sicut ponimus Ventosam super mammillas in aegritudine fluxus sanguinis narium.	And they are sought only for the purpose of drawing blood from one member to another, such as when we place a cupping glass on the breasts in cases of bloody discharge from the nose.
Et utimur eis, ut soluamus a membro uentositatem frigidam inuiscatam in membro: sicut ponimus uentosam super uentrem, et umbilicum.	And we use them to remove cold and damp windiness from one member by applying it to another; such as placing the cupping glass on the belly or navel.
Ipsa enim rarificat membrum, et calefacit ipsum, et remouet dolorem propterea, quia resoluit illam uentositatem.	For indeed, it rarifies the member, warms it, and removes pain because it dissolves that dampness.
Etiam ponitur super renes, quando accidit in eis opilatio, aut lapis.	It is also placed over the kidneys when there occurs blockage or stone.
Uirtute enim attractionis suae fortasse aperit opilationem, aut eradicat lapidem ex loco suo.	For by its attractive power it may perhaps open up the blockage or root out the stone from its place.
Et similiter facit quando ponitur super epar, et splenem apud uentositatem terendam in eis utrisque.	And similarly, it does when placed over the liver and spleen to remove windiness from both.
Et istae Ventosae administrantur uacuae cum sectione tantum.	These cupping glasses are administered empty with just a single cut.
Et quandoque administrantur cum igne.	And sometimes they are administered with fire.
Et quandoque administrantur plenae aqua tepida in aegritudinibus pleuresis: et illud est, ut impleatur Ventosa, et sit magna, aqua calida sola, aut aqua in qua decoctae sint herbae quae conueniunt.	And sometimes they are administered full of warm water for ailments of the lungs; this is done by filling the cupping glass with only hot water or water in which suitable herbs have been cooked.
¶ Forma Ventosae administratae cum igne.	Form of administering cupping glasses with fire.
Sit amplitudo orificii eius duorum digitorum apertorum, secundum quod formauimus: et quantitas eius in profundo sit medietas palmi: et sit in latere eius in loco qui est circiter medium eius, foramen paruum, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum acus: fiat ex aere simul, aut citrino, grossorum marginum, lenium, aequalium, tersorum: ut non laedat membrum apud positionem suam super ipsum: et sit in medio eius uirga transuersa ex aere, aut ferro, ubi ponitur candela cum igne.	Let its opening be two finger-breadths wide, as we have formed it; and let its depth be half the width of the palm; and let there be a small hole in its side near the middle, through which a needle can enter; let it be made of bronze or glass with thick, smooth, even edges so that it does not injure the member when placed upon it; and let there be a transverse rod of iron or bronze in its center where the candle with fire is placed.
Et iam fit haec uentosa magna, maior ea quam narrauimus, et parum minor illa, secundum aegritudines et aetatem eius qui utitur.	And now this large cupping glass is made, larger than what we have described, and slightly smaller according to the ailments and age of the person using it.
Ventosae enim puerorum, et extenuatorum sunt aliae, quam uentosae uirorum, et grossorum corporum.	For cupping glasses for children and thin persons are different from those for men and robust bodies.
Qualitas autem ponendi hanc uentosam cum igne super membrum, est, ut accendas licinium cum igne ex lino decenter, aut candelam paruam ex caera: et pone eam super medium uirgae transuersae quae est in medio uentosae: ut sit accensus ignis circiter inferiorem partem uentosae, ut non comburatur corpus infirmi.	But the manner of placing this cupping glass with fire on the member is to light a wick made of clean linen or a small candle made of wax and place it on the middle of the transverse rod which is in the center of the cupping glass so that the fire is near the lower part of the cupping glass, without burning the body of the sick person.
Deinde ponatur super membrum: et digitus sit super foramen quod dixi, donec quando tenemus uentosam: dum indigemus, auferamus digitum, et egredietur uapor super illud foramen, et soluetur uentosa statim.	Then place it on the member; and hold your finger over the hole I mentioned until you feel a draft, then remove your finger when needed, and steam will exit through that hole, releasing the cupping glass immediately.
Deinde igni licinium secundum modum suum, et itera eam, si indiges illa.	Then relight the wick according to its usual manner, and repeat this process if necessary.
In Ventosa autem quae administratur in aegritudine pleuresis cum aqua, non est uirga transuersa, neque foramen: et non administratur, nisi quia impletur aqua, et ponitur super membrum tantum.	However, the cupping glass used for treating pleural disorders with water does not have a transverse rod or hole; it is only filled with water and placed on the member.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its shape.
Et haec Ventosa quanto plus est magna, ut capiat aquam multam, est melior.	The larger the cupping glass, the better it is for holding much water.
¶ De suspensione Sanguisugarum.	On suspending bloodletting cups.
Caput XCIX.	Chapter 99.
Sanguisugae non administrantur in pluribus, nisi in quibus membris non est possibilis positio uentosarum, propter paruitatem eorum, sicut labium, et gingiua, et eis similia.	Bloodletting cups are not usually used except in those parts of the body where it is impossible to apply cupping glasses due to their smallness, such as the lips and gums, and similar areas.
Aut in membro denudato a carne, sicut digitus, et nasus, et eis similia.	Or on bare flesh without skin, such as fingers, nose, and similar parts.
Et qualitas utendi eis est: ut ueneris ex Sanguisugis quae sunt in aquis dulcibus, mundis a putredinibus.	And the quality of using them is to use those bloodletting cups which are found in sweet waters, clean from impurities.
Deinde dimittantur die et nocte in aqua dulci, donec famelicae sint, et non remaneat in uentre earum aliquid.	Then they should be kept day and night in sweet water until they are hungry, and there is nothing left inside them.
Deinde euacuetur corpus in primis cum phlebotomia, et cum uentosis.	Then the body should first be evacuated through bloodletting and cupping glasses.
Deinde absterge membrum infirmi, donec rubeat.	Then cleanse the sick person's member until it is reddened.
Postea ponantur super ipsum.	Then place them on it.
Cum ergo implentur, et cadunt, et est possibilis suctio loci cum uentosa, tunc est magis ultimum in iuuamento: et si non, tunc ablue locum cum aceto.	But when they are full and fall off, and suction of the place with a cupping glass is possible, then that is more useful for healing. But if not, then wash the spot with vinegar.
Deinde cum aqua multa, et fricetur, et exprimatur.	Then with much water, it should be rubbed and squeezed out.
Quod si prolongatur cursus sanguinis post casum Sanguisugarum, et est illud resudando: tunc infunde pannum lini in aqua frigida, et pone ipsum desuper, donec abscindatur resudatio.	If the flow of blood continues after the removal of the bloodletting cups, and this is a discharge [to be absorbed], then dip a linen cloth in cold water and place it on top until the discharge stops.
Quod si multiplicatur sanguis, tunc pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, aut gallas, et similia eis ex stipticis: donec abscindatur sanguis.	If blood increases abundantly, then sprinkle powdered myrrh or gall nuts and similar astringents on it until the bleeding stops.
Aut ponantur super locum medietates fabarum excorticatarum: et dimittantur, donec adhaereant fabae in loco, nam sanguis abscinditur.	Or place halves of peeled broad beans on the spot; let them remain until the beans adhere to the place, for then the bleeding will stop.
Et oportet si necessaria est iteratio Sanguisugarum, quando est possibile, mutare eas.	And if repetition of bloodletting is necessary, it should be done with different cups whenever possible.
Si autem prohibentur Sanguisugae a suspensione, tunc abstergatur locus cum sanguine recenti.	But if bloodletting is prohibited by suspension, then wipe the spot clean with fresh blood.
Aut fige acum in locis, donec egrediatur aliquid ex sanguine.	Or insert needles into the spots until some blood emerges.
Deinde ponantur, nam ipsae quando sentiunt aliquid ex sanguine, adhaerent statim.	Then place them there, for they immediately adhere when they sense any blood emerging.
Quando ergo uis ut cadant, pulueriza super eas aliquid ex aloe trito, aut salem, aut cinerem: et cadent statim.	When you wish for them to fall off, sprinkle powdered aloe or salt or ash on them and they will immediately fall off.
¶ Partis Secundae Finis.	End of the Second Part.
¶ Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars III.	Book of Surgery by Albucasis. Part III.
¶ Sermo uniuersalis de restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus.	A general discussion on restoration, dislocation, treatment of dislocations and similar conditions.
Caput I.	Chapter 1.
Hoc Capitulum etiam multotiens est necessarium in arte Medicinae, et est restauratio fracturae, et dislocationis accidentium in ossibus.	This chapter is also frequently necessary in the art of medicine, namely restoration of fractures and dislocations that occur in bones.
Scitote o Filii, quia iactant se de hoc Capitulo stolidi medicorum et uulgi, et qui non inspexerunt unquam antiquorum librum, neque legerunt ex eo literam.	Know this, O sons, that foolish physicians and laymen boast about this chapter, those who have never examined the books of the ancients nor read a letter from them.
Et propter hanc caussam fit, quod iste modus ex scientiis in terra nostra est priuatus.	And for this reason, this method is lacking among our people here.
Et ego non obuiaui in eo unquam bono omnino, et non adeptus sum ex eo illud, quod sum adeptus nisi propter longitudinem lectionis librorum antiquorum, et studium super intellectum eorum, donec extraxi scientiam illius ex eis.	But I have not gained anything good from it at all, nor have I obtained that which I have obtained except through the length of reading ancient books and effort in understanding them until I extracted knowledge of this method from them.
Deinde adhaesi experimento et studio longitudine uitae meae.	Then I adhered to experimentation and study throughout my life.
Et iam descripsi uobis ex illo in hoc Capitulo totum quod continet scientia mea: et super quod praeteriit experimentum meum, postquam abbreuiaui illud uobis, et liberaui illud ex occupatione elongationis, et abbreuiaui illud fine abbreuiationis, et ostendi illud fine declinationis: et formaui in eo formas multas ex formis instrumentorum quae administrantur in eo, cum sit ex additione declinationis, sicut feci in duobus Capitulis praecedentibus.	And now I have described for you all that contains my knowledge from it in this Chapter, and over which my experience has passed. After abbreviating it for you, and freeing it from the labor of elongation, and abbreviating it to the end of abbreviation, and showing it to the end of declination: I have formed many shapes from the shapes of instruments used therein, with it being from the addition of declination, as I did in the two preceding Chapters.
¶ Summae, et collectiones ex esse fracturae ossium, ex eis quarum praemissio necessaria est, antequam incipiamus rememorationem membrorum fractorum, et diuersorum, si uniuscuiusque.	Summaries and collections concerning the setting of bone fractures, from which a preface is necessary before beginning the recollection of broken limbs, and various ones if there is any.
Caput II.	Chapter 2.
Oportet, ut dicamus in prologo huius Capituli, summas sermonis, et capitula, ad quarum intellectum cogitur in primis artifex ad stationem super earum ueritatem: scilicet ut uos, et qui sunt prompti, sciant, uel addiscant hanc artem nobilem, et alii a uobis.	It is necessary that we say in the prologue of this Chapter the summaries of speech and chapters whose understanding the artisan is compelled to stand over their truth: namely so that you, and those who are eager, may know or learn this noble art, and others from you.
Dico, ergo, quod quando accidit alicui fractura, aut dislocatio, aut torsio, aut casus: tunc oportet, ut properes in primis ad phlebotomandum eum, et soluendum ipsum, aut utraque simul: si non prohibeat aliquid, sicut debilitas uirtutis: aut est ille cui accidit aliquid ex illis puer, aut senex decrepitus: aut est tempus uehementis caloris, aut uehementis frigoris ualde.	I say therefore that when a fracture or dislocation or torsion or fall occurs to someone, then it is necessary to rush first to phlebotomize him and loosen him, or both at once: if nothing prohibits it, such as weakness of strength: or he is a child or an elderly decrepit person: or it is the time of violent heat or violent cold very much.
Deinde sit contentus in cibo suo, oleribus frigidis, et carnibus auium, et haedorum: et prohibe uinum, et carnes grossas, et repleri ex cibis et omni cibo qui replet uenas sanguine.	Then let him be satisfied with his food of cold greens and birds' meat and hedgehogs': and prohibit wine and fatty meats, and being filled from foods and all food that fills the veins with blood.
Donec quando securus sis ex apostemate calido, et non times effusionem materiei ad membrum: tunc redeat infirmus ad regimen suum primum cum quo cucurrit consuetudo eius.	Until when you are secure from hot aposteme and do not fear the outflow of matter to the limb: then the sick person should return to his first regimen with which he was accustomed.
Cum ergo incipit os fractum restaurari, tunc oportet, ut cibetur infirmus cibis nutrientibus nutrimento multo, grosso, graui, in quibus sit uiscositas: sicut cibaria facta ex tritico cocto cum aqua, et rizum, et capita, et pedes, et uentres uaccarum, et oua, et pisces recentes: et uinum grossum, et similia illis.	Therefore, when the broken bone begins to be restored, then it is necessary that the sick person eats foods rich in nourishment, thick, heavy, and moist, such as those made from boiled wheat dough with water, and rice, and heads, feet, and entrails of lambs, and eggs, and fresh fish: and thick wine, and similar things.
Cum hoc enim regimine fit coagulatio fracturae uelocius, et melius.	This regimen causes the coagulation of fractures to happen more quickly and better.
Et scias, quod ossa fracta, quando sunt in uiris qui sunt in prima senectute, et decrepitis, non est possibile, ut continuentur et consolidentur secundum naturam suam semper, propter exiccationem membrorum eorum: et consolidantur et continuantur quae ex eis sunt in fine lenitatis, sicut ossa puerornm paruorum.	And know that bones which are broken when they are in the first stage of old age and feebleness cannot be joined and consolidated according to their nature always, because of the drying out of their limbs. But those which are broken at the end of infancy consolidate and join like the bones of young children.
Verumtamen natura annectit super os fractum ex omni parte aliquid simile glutino, in quo est grossitudo, quo adhaeret et stringit ipsum, donec conglutinantur adinuicem, et ligantur adinuicem, donec uenit in fine fortitudinis et firmitudinis, sicut fuit in primis, donec non prohibet ipsum aliquid ab operationibus suis: et propter hanc caussam est necesse, ut ponas nutrimentum infirmi cibaria, in quibus sunt grauitas, et uiscositas, et grossitudo, sicut diximus.	However, nature adheres to the broken bone on all sides with something similar to glue, which is thick and sticks it together until they adhere to each other and are bound together until they reach full strength and firmness, as they were at first, unless something prevents them from operating. And for this reason, it is necessary to put before the sick person foods that have weight, moisture, and thickness, as we have said.
Et scias, quod fracturae species sunt diuersae, secundum diuersitatem membrorum: quoniam fractura cruris, est diuersa a fractura ossis capitis: et fractura ossis pectoris, est diuersa a fractura ossis dorsi: et similiter reliqua membra omnia diuersa existunt adinuicem: et ego ueni cum rememoratione omnis speciei fracturae expositae in Capitulo suo distinctae ab alia.	And know that fractures are of different kinds, according to the diversity of limbs. For a fracture of the leg is different from a fracture of the head bone; and a fracture of the chest bone is different from a fracture of the back bone; and likewise all other limbs have different fractures from one another: and I come with the memory of every kind of fracture set forth in its own chapter, distinguished from others.
Et diuersificantur species fracturae ossis etiam in seipsa.	And even kinds of bone fractures differ among themselves.
Quoniam fit fractura eius arcuata, praeter quod accidant in ea astellae.	For a fracture can occur with an arch shape, besides the fact that splinters may also happen in it.
Et quandoque fit fractura eius secundum longitudinem ossis: et sunt fracturae eius satagiae, id est, astellae, et additiones procedentes, sicut sunt in calamo, cum aptatur cultello ad scribendum.	Also, sometimes a fracture occurs along the length of the bone: such fractures can be jagged, with splinters and additional cracks protruding outwards, like those seen in reeds when prepared for writing with a knife.
Et non procedentes: et est fractura cum uulnere et disruptione in capite: et est fractura fissura parua.	And not protruding: there is also fracture with wounding and disruption at the head of the bone, and a fracture that appears as a small split.
Et omni speciei est ingenium, uel instrumentum proprium in restauratione eius, secundum quod ueniet rememoratio eius, distincta in locis suis.	And for every type of fracture, there is a particular method or tool suited to its repair, according to the recollection of which I will now detail them in their respective places.
Et ex eo quo cognoscitur fractura ossis, est tortuositas eius, et ipsius eminentia: et apparitio eius sensui, et sonitus eius quando comprimis ipsum manu tua.	And by what is recognized as a fracture of the bone is its curvature, and its prominence; it becomes apparent to sensation, and produces a sound when compressed with your hand.
Quando ergo non est in loco tortuositas apparens, neque sonitus apud tactum tuum cum tangis os cum agitatione, neque inuenit infirmus magnum dolorem: tunc non est illic fractura, imo possibile est, ut sit tortuositas, aut fissura parua: non ergo oportet, ut moueas ipsum cum manu et compressione omnino, imo pone super ipsum ex medicinis, quarum uenit rememoratio, post momentum illud quod conuenit loco: deinde stringatur strictura subtili.	Therefore, when there is no visible curvature or sound upon touching the bone with gentle pressure, and the patient does not experience severe pain, then a fracture may not be present; rather, it might simply be a slight curvature or small crack. Thus, one should not move or compress the area entirely but instead apply medicaments suited to that particular location according to your recollection. Afterwards, bind it with a subtle bandage.
Et scias, quod locus quando arcuatur, et scinditur in duo, praeter quod accidant in eo satagiae, uerumtamen remouetur omnis pars a compari sua: tunc oportet tibi, ut incipias ab hora tua ad rectificationem eius, aequando ipsum antequam accidat ei apostema calidum.	And know that when the site curves and splits into two parts, with splinters occurring besides, still every part moves away from its comparison. Therefore, you must begin immediately to straighten it by aligning both parts before inflammation sets in.
Si autem accidat ei apostema calidum, tunc dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec quiescat apoestema.	But if inflammation has already set in, then let it rest for several days until the inflammation subsides.
Deinde aequa ipsum secundum quemcunque modum potest ex lenitate et ingenio.	Then straighten it according to whatever method is possible given its tenderness and nature.
Et scias, quod restauratio eius, et ipsius aequatio, est facilior quam ossis, in quo accidunt satagiae.	And know that the restoration and alignment of such fractures are easier than those with jagged splinters.
Deinde stringe ipsum, secundum quod ueniet tibi rememoratio eius.	Then bind it according to your recollection of the method.
Si uero in osse sunt satagiae, tunc necessaria est extensio huius membri fracti ex duabus partibus, si manus sit, aut pes: aut cum manu tua, si membrum est paruum: aut cum duobus funibus, aut cum fune et manu.	But if the bone has jagged splinters, then it is necessary to extend this broken limb from both sides, whether it be an arm or a leg.
