For smaller limbs, use your hand; for larger ones, use two strings or one string and your hand.
Et sit positio tua qua ponis membrum super locum aequalem, secundum figuram suam naturalem, donec quando extenduntur partes membri fracti: tunc conare, ut redire facias illas additiones omni ingenio, et secundum quemcunque modum potes in locis suis: et caue secundum fortitudinem tuam, ne accidat super infirmum per operationem tuam dolor, neque laesio: et conare secundum fortitudinem tuam, ut applices unum duorum ossium cum socio suo, secundum meliores formas.	And let the position in which you place the limb be equal to its natural shape until such time as the broken parts are extended. Then strive with all your skill to bring them back together again and fix them securely into their proper places. Be careful not to cause pain or injury through your operation, but apply one of the two bones gently with its fellow according to the best forms.
Et oportet in illa hora, ut tentes et tangas ipsum manu tua.	And it is necessary at that moment for you to test and touch it with your hand.
Si ergo uides illic aliquid diuersum, rectifica ipsum, et aequa illud per quantitatem tuae uirtutis.	If you find anything different there, correct it and make it equal by the measure of your strength.
Et caue extensionem uehementem, et compressionem fortem, sicut faciunt multi stolidorum.	But beware of extreme stretching and harsh compression, as many foolish people do.
Multotiens enim faciunt accidere per operationem illam suam apostema calidum, aut contractionem in membro: sicut iam uidimus illud ex operationibus eorum multotiens.	For often they cause hot inflammation or contraction of the limb through their careless treatment, as we have seen happen many times before.
Deinde annecte post aequationem, et decentem operationem, et stricturam illius membri, et quietem, et tranquillitatem: et mone infirmum super ipsum.	Then apply bandages after the limb has been set correctly and secured in place, ensuring restfulness and calm. Instruct the patient to keep it still.
Et fac ipsum cauere, ne moueat ipsum in hora suarum uigiliarum, et somni sui apud reuolutionem suam, et agitationem suam, et apud egestionem suam, et omnes motus suos ultima uirtute sua.	And tell him to keep it still at all times - during his wakefulness and sleep, turning, tossing, evacuations, and every other movement.
Et ut caueat, ne sit positio membri positio cum qua sequatur dolor.	And that he should be careful not to place the limb in a position which causes pain.
Quod est, quia quando sentit in dispositione positionis membri dolorem, aut laesionem: tunc oportet, ut permutes ipsum ad dispositionem aliam ab illa cum qua non sentiat dolorem.	That is, whenever he feels pain or injury from the current position of the limb, it is necessary to change its position to one that does not cause pain.
Et caue cum illo, ut sit positio eius illa aequalis, recta: ut non accidat in membro tortuositas, quando restauratur.	And be careful with him so that his position remains even and upright, lest the limb become crooked when it is restored.
Et qualitas stricturae membri fracti est, secundum quod narro.	The manner of bandaging a broken limb should be as I have described.
Scias, quod membra fracta diuersificantur in paruitate sua, et eorum magnitudine, et ipsorum forma.	Know that fractured limbs differ from one another in their smallness or greatness and shape.
Quae ergo ex eis sunt parua, sicut brachium, et digitus, et focile, et similia eis, tunc oportet, ut sit inuolutio panni mollis, subtilis.	Therefore, for those which are small, such as the arm, finger, toe, and similar things, a wrapping of soft, fine cloth is necessary.
Quae autem ex eis sunt grossa, sicut coxa, et crus, oportet ut sit in eis inuolutio lata, dura.	But for those which are large, such as the thigh and leg, it is necessary that a broad, firm wrapping be applied.
Quoniam ligamentum latum, connectit membrum magnum, et stringit ipsum ab omni parte strictura aequali, ita quod non ingreditur ipsum macula.	For a wide band connects a large limb and holds it tightly on all sides with equal tension, so that no crease enters.
Deinde incipe post euacuationem tuam ab aequatione ponere linimentum conueniens ad illud, in stuppa leni super locum fracturae ipsius.	Then, after your evacuation, begin to apply the suitable ointment on a soft cloth over the location of the fracture itself.
Deinde incipe inuoluere ligamentum super locum fracturae ipsius tribus inuolutionibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod meretur membrum: et stringe manum tuam parumper cum ligamento.	Then begin wrapping the bandage over the location of the fracture itself with three or four wrappings, depending on what the limb merits: and hold your hand tightly with the bandage for a moment.
Deinde uade cum eo ad partem superiorem a loco fracturae, et stringe minus quam fuit strictura tua, qua strinxisti locum fractum.	Then go with it to the upper part of the location of the fracture, and bind less tightly than you bound the fractured area.
Deinde elonga te cum inuolutione a loco fracturae parumper, et mollifica stricturam paulatim, donec capias ex loco sano rem magnam.	Then extend yourself with the wrapping from the location of the fracture slightly, and gradually loosen the tension until you grasp something large at a healthy spot.
Deinde accipe uittam aliam, et inuolue eam iterum super locum fractum inuolutionibus.	Then take another bandage and wrap it again over the location of the fracture with wrappings.
Postea uade cum inuolutione ad partem inferiorem a fractura.	Then go with the wrapping to the lower part from the fracture.
Et sit operatio tua in strictura inuolutionis, et mollificatione eius, secundum quod diximus in inuolutione prima superiore.	And let your operation be in the tightening and loosening of the wrappings, as we have said in the first upper wrapping.
Deinde pone inter inuolutiones ex stuppa leni, aut panno, cum quo aequetur tortuositas fracturae, si est in ea tortuositas: et si non, non ponas in ea aliquid.	Then place between the wrappings of soft cloth or linen something that will fit the crookedness of the fracture if it is crooked; and if not, do not place anything in it.
Deinde inuolue super ipsam uittam aliam.	Then wrap another bandage over it.
Postea aequa super has inuolutiones astellas decenter factas statim, si non est in loco inflatio, neque apostema calidum.	After that, apply dressings evenly and appropriately on these wrappings immediately, if there is no swelling or warm inflammation at the location.
Si autem in ea est inflatio, aut apostema: tunc pone super eam quod sedet illud apostema, et auferat inflationem: et dimitte eam aliquot diebus.	But if there is swelling or an abscess at the location: then place over it something that will sit on the abscess and reduce the swelling: and leave it for a few days.
Deinde stringe super ipsam tunc astellas.	Then tie starshaped pads upon it.
Et sint Astellae ex medietatibus cannae latae, rasae, formatae sapienter: aut sint ex ligno unde fiunt cribra, quae fiunt ex pino, aut geraid, id est, ramis palmae, aut calingi: et sit amplitudo omnis Astellae, secundum hanc formam, et hanc eandem figuram.	And let the starshaped pads be made from half-cuts of rushes (reeds), smooth and skillfully fashioned, or from wood used for making sieves, such as pinewood, or from branches of palm trees, or calami reeds; and let each star-shaped pad have this breadth and the same shape.
Verumtamen oportet, ut Astella quae ponitur super ipsam tracturam, sit grossior et latior parumper, quam reliquae Astellae: et longitudo Astellae sit secundum quod licet membro ex magnitudine et paruitate.	However, the star-shaped pad placed on the part being treated should be thicker and broader than the others for a short distance; and its length should be according to what is suitable for the member, in terms of size and tenderness.
Deinde stringe super Astellas cum uitta alia, secundum stricturam primam eandem.	Then bind over the starshaped pads with another bandage, following the same binding method.
Deinde liga desuper cum filis decenter, secundum quod diximus de strictura: et est, ut sit strictura tua super locum fracturae plus: et quanto plus elongatur a fractura sit, strictura minor.	Then bind it down with suitable threads, following what we have said about binding: and the binding should be tighter over the broken area; and the further it extends from the break, the lighter the binding.
Et oportet, ut sint fila media in grossitudine et subtilitate, et sint ex lino molli.	And the threads should be of medium thickness and fineness, and made of soft linen.
Quoniam si fila sunt grossa, sicut uidi ex operatione stolidorum ponentium fila sua ex chordis lini tortis, est error magnus: quoniam cadit strictura cum eis extra qualitatem.	For if the threads are thick, as I have seen foolish practitioners using twisted hemp cords for their stitches, it is a great mistake; because the binding falls out with them beyond its proper quality.
Et fila subtilia iterum non conueniunt: quoniam tu non consequeris per stricturam cum eis illud quod uis.	And fine threads again do not suit; because you will not achieve through binding what you desire with them.
Et non oportet, ut sit inter astellam et astellam minus quam digitus.	And there should be no less than one finger's width between each star-shaped pad.
Quod si laeditur infirmus per extremitates astellarum post stricturam in locis sanis: tunc pone sub eis ex stuppa leni, aut lana carminata, donec nihil laedatur ex illo.	But if the patient is injured by the edges of the star-shaped pads after binding on healthy areas, then place under them soft tow or dyed wool until no injury occurs.
Quando autem est fractura cum uulnere, et accidit disruptio in cute, ego ueniam cum rememoratione eius in capitulo secundum singularitatem.	When there is a break with a wound and the skin tears open, I will come back to this in the second chapter according to its particulars.
Et scias, quod non omne membrum fractum oportet ut stringatur cum astellis a primo die.	And know that not every broken limb should be bound with star-shaped pads from the very first day.
Quod est, quia membrum quando est magnum, non oportet ut ponas superipsum astellas, nisi post quinque dies, aut septem, aut plus, secundum securitatem tuam ab euentu apostematis calidi.	That is to say, when a limb is large, you should not place star-shaped pads upon it until five days have passed, or seven at the most, according to your certainty about the outcome of the warm inflammation.
Et iste est modus emplastrorum, quibus restaurabant antiqui, quae ponuntur super fracturam et dislocationem.	And this is the method of plasters which the ancients used to apply over fractures and dislocations.
¶ Modus Emplastri communis abbreuiati, restaurans fracturam, conueniens pluribus complexionibus, praecipue mulieribus, et pueris: quoniam est ex eo super quod non uincit calor, neque frigus.	A general method of abbreviated plaster for healing fractures, suitable for many constitutions, especially women and children, as it does not cause excessive heat or cold.
Et est, ut accipias ex puluere molendini, et est medulla farinae quae pendet in parietibus molendini apud motum molae: et conficias ipsum sicut est, praeter quod cribelles ipsum cum albugine oui: et pone confectionem eius non spissam, neque subtilem.	And it is done by taking flour dust from the millstone, which is the bran that adheres to the walls of the mill near the movement of the grindstone. Mix this with egg white, and make the plaster neither too thick nor too thin.
Deinde utere eo.	Then use it.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius, restaurantis fracturam, et dislocationem, et torsionem.	A different method for plasters used in healing fractures, dislocations, and strains.
Recipe almess, et laudani, et acaciae, et enulae, et mugath: et suc, omnium ana ʒ X myrrhae, et aloes amborum ana ʒ V et alethil ʒ XX terantur omnia, et cribellentur, et misceantur cum aqua alethil: aut cum albugine oui, si complexio infirmi est calefacta.	Take equal amounts of almonds, laudanum, acacia gum, enula, and mugwort; myrrh in the amount of 10 parts; both kinds of aloes in the amount of 5 parts each. Grind everything together and sift it, then mix with the juice of aleth, or with egg white if the patient's constitution is hot.
Deinde utere hoc emplastro.	Then apply this plaster.
Nam ipsum est bonae compositionis, restaurat ossa fracta uelociter, et confert pluribus hominibus.	For it is of good composition and quickly heals broken bones, suitable for many people.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius, quod etiam confert fracturae et torsioni.	A different method that also helps fractures and strains.
Recipe mugath, et mess, et alteae albae, omnium ana ʒ X myrrhae, et aloes amborum ana ʒ V acaciae ʒ VI boli armeni ʒ XX terantur omnia contritione multa, et cribellentur, et conficiantur cum aqua, aut albugine oui: et administrentur.	Take equal amounts of mugwort, sesame, and white barley; myrrh in the amount of 10 parts; both kinds of aloes in the amount of 5 parts each; acacia gum in the amount of 6 parts; bdellium armeniacum in the amount of 20 parts. Grind everything together thoroughly and sift it, then mix with water or egg white and apply.
¶ Modus Emplastri ad iuncturas, et ossa separata ex locis suis: et sedat dolorem accidentem eis, et scissuram ossis, et fracturam.	A method for plasters used in joining bones and reducing dislocations, relieving pain and healing cracked or broken bones.
Sumatur lana succida, et submergatur in aceto, et oleo decocto: et ponatur super locum.	Wool is to be cut and immersed in vinegar and oil cooked [heated]: then it is placed on the location [of the injury].
Et in hoc quidem Emplastro non est uirtus restaurationis, sed est bonum in sedatione apostematis calidi: et expellit dolores proprie.	And indeed this plaster has no virtue of restoration, but it is good for soothing hot inflammation and expelling proper pains.
¶ Modus Emplastri, quod restaurat os fractum.	A method for a plaster that restores broken bone.
Sume folia fici surdi, et folia papaueris syluestris: et tere omnia, et fac emplastrum ex utrisque.	Take leaves of figs and leaves of wild mallow: grind both and make a plaster from them.
¶ Modus Emplastri abbreuiati, administrati apud restaurationem fracturae ossis: et quando tu uis resolutionem residui apostematis.	A method for applying a plaster to shorten the duration of healing broken bones, and when you wish to resolve remaining inflammation.
Recipe radicis alteae, et camomillae, et florum uiolarum, et farinae herbi, omnium ana partem unam: terantur omnia, et conficiantur cum uino, si non est membrum calefactum.	Take equal parts of the root of althea, chamomile flowers, violet flowers, and herb flour. Grind all together and mix with wine if the limb is not heated.
Si uero est calefactum, tunc confice illud cum aqua coriandri humidi, aut cum aqua, et utere eo.	But if it is heated, then cook it with moist coriander water, or with water, and use it.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius fortioris in resolutione, quam istud primum, quando accidit apostema durum apud restaurationem membri.	A different method of plaster stronger for resolving hardness when inflammation occurs during healing a limb.
Recipe radicis alteae, et seminis lini, et balaustiae, et melliloti, et samsuci, et floris uiolarum, et camomillae, omnium ana, partem unam, terantur omnia, et conficiantur cum aqua salicis, aut cum aqua dulci, aut cum uino.	Take equal parts of the root of althea, linseed, balm, melilot, sampsuk [?], violet flowers and chamomile. Grind all together and cook with willow water or sweet water or wine.
Totum illud secundum caliditatem membri, et quietem caloris eius.	This one according to the warmth of the limb and its calm heat.
Hippocrates uero non dixit in libro suo, quod ponatur super membrum fractum apud restaurationem eius, nisi caerotum factum ex caera, et oleo: non aliud: et narrauit, ut sit medium inter grossitudinem et subtilitatem.	But Hippocrates did not say in his book that anything other than a plaster made from wax and oil should be placed on the broken limb during its healing. And he described it as being between thickness and subtlety.
Galeno autem uisum est, ut ponantur super membrum fractum apud restaurationem eius res, in quibus est exiccatio caliditatis, sicut myrrha, et aloes et olibanum, et similia eis ex eis quae narrauimus.	However, Galen thought that substances which dry out heat should be placed on the broken limb during its healing, such as myrrh, aloe, and frankincense, and similar things to those we have mentioned.
¶ Modus Emplastri quod confert ad laesionem et dolorem.	Method of plaster that alleviates injury and pain.
Recipe mugath, et ciceris, et capillorum hominis incisorum, aut pennae auis, et alteae, et salis partes aequales: terantur, et cribellentur, et conficiantur: et fiat ex eo emplastrum.	Take equal parts of antimony, chickpeas, human hair cuttings, or feathers from birds and straw, salt; grind them together and sift them to make a plaster.
Quantitas autem secundum quam oportet, ut remaneat ligatura, deinde soluatur, est, ut consideres tunc, si non accidit infirmo dolor, neque pruritus, neque mouetur os fractum a loco suo: tunc non resoluas ipsum diebus multis.	However, the amount that should be used so that there remains enough for binding and then dissolving is such that you should consider whether it has happened that the patient does not feel pain, nor itching, nor does the broken bone move from its place; then do not dissolve it for many days.
Quod si accidat ei in loco pruritus uehemens, aut dolor inquietans, aut inflatio: tunc propera, et solue in hora ipsum, et aufer emplastrum ab eo: et accipe pannum lenem, aut spongiam marinam lenem, humidam: et submerge eam in aqua tepida, et ablue cum ea locum, donec quiescat pruritus, et sedetur dolor.	But if itching occurs severely at that place, or restless pain, or swelling: then hurry, and dissolve it within the hour, and remove the plaster from him: and take a soft cloth or soft sea sponge, moistened: and immerse it in warm water, and wash the area with it until the itching stops and the pain subsides.
Deinde dimitte membrum quiescere una hora.	Then let the limb rest for an hour.
Deinde pone super ipsum lanam succidam, submersam in aceto et oleo, aut oleo rosato: et liga super ipsum nocte una, donec sis securus ab apostemate calido, et quiescat inflatio membri, et remoueatur dolor eius.	Then place on it a piece of wool soaked in vinegar and oil, or rose oil; and bind it there overnight until you are secure that there will be no hot discharge, and the swelling of the limb has subsided and its pain has eased.
Deinde itera ipsum ad stricturam subtilem, et emplastrum paruum: et non stringas ipsum constrictione tua prima, et subtilia cum eo, donec sanetur.	Then repeat the procedure for a fine dressing and apply a small plaster; but do not bind it tightly at first, and make dressings fine with it until it is healed.
Quod si uides, quod apostema, et rubedo, et dolor, et inflatio, et omnia accidentia iam remota sunt penitus, et indiges emplastro et strictura, tunc itera illud sicut fecisti in primis aequaliter.	If you see that all symptoms of discharge, redness, pain, swelling, and other accidents have already disappeared completely, and you need a plaster and dressing again, then repeat the procedure as you did at first, equally.
Quod si non accidit membro aliquid ex eis quae diximus, tune non soluas ipsum, nisi post tres dies, aut quatuor, aut quinque, aut septem.	But if none of what we have mentioned happens to the limb, then do not dissolve the plaster until after three days, or four, or five, or seven.
Et quando que dimittitur uiginti diebus totum illud, secundum quod apparet tibi ex solutione membri, sicut diximus, donec quando adhaeret fractura, et approximat coagulatio carnis super eam: adde etiam tunc in strictura plus quam strictura tua prima tota: et adde etiam in ingrossatione cibi infirmi, secundum quod praecessit rememoratio eius.	And when it is left on for twenty days, according to what you see from the resolution of the limb, as we said, until when the fracture adheres and coagulation of flesh occurs over it: then also add more plaster than your first plaster in cases of stiffness; and also increase the amount of food for the patient, according to what has been remembered.
Si autem uides locum fracturae iam exiccari, et extenuari plus quam oportet: tunc scias, quod nutrimentum prohibetur peruenire ad ipsum.	If however you see that the site of the fracture is already drying out and becoming thinner than it should be, then know that nutrition is being prevented from reaching it.
Embroca ergo ipsum cum aqua tepida apud omnem uicem qua soluis ipsum, et sit illud in omnibus tribus diebus, et alleuia stricturam parumper.	Therefore moisten the plaster with warm water wherever you dissolve it, and let it remain for three days to relieve stiffness slightly.
Per hanc ergo operationem currit ad membrum nutrimentum, et sanatur uelociter.	Through this procedure, nutrition reaches the limb and healing is swift.
Illud autem quod faciunt stolidi restauratores ex fractura membri uice alia, quando non restauratur in primis, secundum quod oportet, et restauratur secundum tortuositatem, est error ex operatione eorum, et timor magnus: et si esset rectum, dixissent illud antiqui in libris suis, et operati fuissent cum eo.	But what those foolish restorers of a fractured limb do instead, when it is not restored properly at first and is restored crookedly, is an error due to their procedure, and there is great fear: and if it were correct, the ancients would have said so in their books and operated with it.
Et ego non uidi alicubi eorum uestigium in illo omnino, et rectius est, ut non fiat illud.	And I have not seen any trace of theirs in this matter at all, and it is better that this not be done.
¶ De factura accidente in capite.	Section on treating injuries to the head.
Caput III.	Chapter Three:
Species fracturae sunt diuersae, et figurae eius multae: et caussae eius sunt distinctae.	The types of fractures are varied, and their shapes many; and the causes of them are distinct.
Nam ex fractura est quae fit a percussione cum ense: et percussio aufert os totum usquequo peruenit ad siphac, quod est sub osse, sicut facit axia in ligno: et propter illud nominatur haec species fracturae Axialis.	For there is the fracture that occurs from being struck by a sword; and the blow carries away all of the bone until it reaches the spongy substance beneath it, just as an axe does to wood; and because of this, this type of fracture is called 'Axial'.
Aut ensis incidit quiddam ossis, et incidit faciem eius, et non penetrat incisio usque ad ultimum eius: et nominatur haec species fracturae Kalaan, id est, Leuatio absolute.	Or the sword strikes something on the bone and cuts its surface without penetrating all the way through it; and this type of fracture is called 'Kalaan,' that is, a 'Superficial Cut'.
Et est uulnus duarum fracturarum, aut magnum, aut paruum.	And there are two kinds of wounds: large or small.
Et ex fractura est, quae est contritio, aut attritio: et caussa eius est percussio cum lapide, aut casus super lapidem, aut eis similia.	And among fractures, there is one called 'contritio' or 'attritio,' which results from a blow with a stone, falling onto stones, or similar causes.
Et haec fractura est etiam aut penetrans, quae iam appropinquat panniculo, quod est sub osse: aut est in facie ossis: et est uulnus harum duarum fracturarum etiam aut paruum, aut magnum.	And this fracture is either penetrating, which approaches the periosteum beneath the bone, or is on the surface of the bone. There are also two types of wounds resulting from these fractures, large or small.
Et ex fractura est, quae est occulta in osse in subtilitate capilli: et est fissura parua, et propter illud nominatur haec species fracturae Capillaris.	And there is also a fracture which is hidden within the bone like a hair's breadth; it is called 'Capillaris' due to its small size.
Et ex eis est fractura, quae fit a casu, aut percussione lapidis, et eis similium, quae faciunt ingredi laminam ossis ad interiora, et fit loco concauitas: sicut accidit caldariis aeris, quando occurrit eis percussio, et ingreditur pars eorum ad interiora.	And among these is the fracture that occurs due to a fall or blow from stones and similar objects, which causes the blade of the bone to become hollowed out within.
Et plurimum quidem fit illud in capitibus humidorum ossium, sicut sunt capita puerorum.	Especially this happens in the heads of moist bones, such as the skulls of children.
Et fiunt omnibus istis speciebus fracturae satagiae separatae, et ego ueniam cum rememoratione illius totius in loco suo.	And for all these types of fractures, there are separate treatments, which I will discuss in their appropriate places later on.
Et cognoscimus omnes has species fracturae per detectionem super eam, et inquisitionem earum cum tentis, et ablationem carnium corruptarum, quae sunt super eas.	And we recognize all these types of fractures through examination of them and by probing them with probes, and removing any rotting flesh that may be on top of them.
Species uero Capillaris cognoscitur per hoc, quod detegitur super os, et abstergitur, et linitur super ipsum cum encaustro: fractura enim apparet nigra.	But the species Capillaris is recognized by this method: when detected over the bone and cleaned off with a cautery, the fracture appears black.
In curatione autem fracturae, considera in primis accidentia infirmi: tunc si uides ex accidentibus quod significet significatione manifesta super timorem, sicut uomitus cholerae, et extensio, et amissio intellectus, et abscisio uocis, et syncopis, et febris acuta, et egressus oculorum, et rubedo eorum, et similia eis ex accidentibus in pluribus dispositionibus, proculdubio non sanatur: et si uides accidentia non terrentia te, et speras salutem: tunc incipe curationem eius.	In treating a fracture, first consider the patient's condition. If you see signs indicative of serious danger, such as vomiting, convulsions, loss of consciousness, aphasia, syncopal attacks, acute fever, protrusion of the eyes, redness of the eyes, or similar accidents occurring in various states, then do not attempt to treat it. But if you observe conditions that do not cause alarm and hope for recovery, then begin treatment.
Quod est, si uenit ad te uulneratus in primis cum uulneratur: et est illud in diebus hyemis, tunc oportet, ut studeas in ablatione ossis ante diem quartumdecimum secundum omnem dispositionem.	If a wounded person comes to you at first when wounded and it occurs during the winter season, then it is necessary that you strive for the removal of bone before the fourteenth day according to every disposition.
Et si est in diebus aestatis, tunc oportet, ut properes remouere os ante diem septimum, antequam corrumpatur quod est sub osse ex panniculo, et accidant illa accidentia quae narrauimus.	And if it occurs during the summer season, then you should hasten to remove the bone before the seventh day, before corruption sets in under the bone from inflammation, and those accidents which we have mentioned occur.
Quod si fractura ossis iam peruenit ad panniculum tangentem cerebrum, et est cum minutiis, et attractione: tunc oportet, ut incidas partem comminutam, et attritam, secundum quod narro tibi.	If a fracture of the bone has reached the brain's meninges and is accompanied by fragments and adhesion, then you should cut into the affected portion, as I will describe to you.
Et est, ut radas caput uulnerati: et detege super os secundum quemcunque modum possibile est tibi: et secundum figuram uulneris, et quod leue est super infirmum.	And it is necessary that you shave the head of the wounded person and clean the bone according to whatever method is possible for you, and according to the shape of the wound and what is lightest upon the sick.
Quod si accidat tibi apud detectionem ossis fluxus sanguinis, aut apostema calidum: tunc oppone ei cum eo quod oportet.	If during bone exposure, bleeding or a warm abscess occurs, then apply to it whatever is necessary.
Et est, ut impleas locum cum pannis infusis in uino, et oleo rosato: et facias quiescere uulnus, donec sedetur apostema, et sis securus a fluxu sanguinis.	And fill the space with cloths soaked in wine and rose oil, and allow the wound to rest until the abscess settles and you are secure from bleeding.
Deinde incipe in curatione ossis, et ablatione eius.	Then begin treatment of the bone and its removal.
Et illud fit secundum unum duorum modorum.	And this is done according to one of two methods.
Modus quidem unus est, ut incidas os cum Incisorio strictae aciei: et haec est forma eius.	The first method is to cut the bone with an incision made by a scalpel with a narrow point: and this is its shape.
Dende administra Incisorium aliud post Incisorum latius eo parumper: et haec est forma eius.	Then use another scalpel, slightly broader, for a short while: and this is its shape.
Deinde administra etiam Incisorium aliud latius etiam quam secundum.	And then apply yet another scalpel still broader than the second one.
Et modus secundus est, ut sit apud te numerus Incisoriorum diuersorum: quorum quaedam sint latiora quibusdam, et quaedam eorum breuiora quibusdam: et sint in ultimo acuitatis extremitatum suarum, et sint ex ferro indo, aut fuled: et utere facilitate in percussione super Incisorium, ut non concutiat caput, et laedat ipsum.	And the second way is for you to have a variety of scalpel sizes on hand; some broader than others and some shorter than others. They should be sharp-pointed at their tips and made of good steel or iron, so that they may strike with ease without shaking the head and injuring it.
Si autem os est forte, durum: tunc oportet, ut perfores in circumitu eius, antequam tu administres Incisoria, cum Terebris quae nominantur Terebra non profundantia: et non nominantur ita, nisi quoniam ipsa non pertranseunt terminum ossis carnei ad illud, quod est post ipsum: propterea, quod Terebro est extremitas rotunda super illud, quod est sub capite eius acuto, similis margini, et circulus paruus prohibet submergi, et pertransire spissitudinem ossis.	But if the bone is hard and tough, then you should drill around it before applying the scalpel with trephines called 'terebrae', which do not penetrate deeply. They are not so named because they do not pass through the thickness of the bony substance to that which lies beyond it; for a trephine has a rounded end above its sharp head, and a small circle prevents it from being submerged and penetrating too deeply into the bone.
Et conuenit tibi, ut accipias ex istis Terebris numerum multum, quorum unumquodque conueniat quantitati spissitudinis ossis, donec praesens sit tibi omni craneo Terebrum: cuius extremitatis acutae quantitas in longitudine et breuitate sit, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis illius cranei.	And you should take a great many of these trephines, each suited to the thickness of the bone until you have enough for every skull; their sharp ends should be long or short according to the thickness of the bone.
Et haec est forma trium specierum Terebrorum, uel Trepanorum.	And this is the shape of three kinds of trephines or borers.
Qualitas autem perforandi in circumitu ossis fracti, est: ut ponas Terebrum super os, et reuoluas ipsum digitis tuis, donec scias, os iam penetratum esse.	The method of drilling around a broken bone is to place the trephine on the bone and turn it with your fingers until you know that the bone has been penetrated.
Deinde permuta Terebrum ad locum alium, et pone quod est inter omne foramen quantitatem grossitudinis radii, aut circiter illud.	Then move the trephine to another place and put in between all the holes a bit of bone or something similar in thickness.
Deinde incide cum Incisoriis quod est inter omne foramen ex osse: et fac illud subtilius quam potes super illud ex fine leuitatis, sicut diximus, donec eradices os, aut manu tua, aut cum aliquo alio ex quibusdam instrumentis, quae parasti ad illud: sicut tenaliae, et forpices subtiles.	Then cut with scalpel blades between all the holes in the bone and do it more gently than you can at its end as we have said, until you remove the bone by hand or with some other suitable instrument, such as forceps or fine tweezers that you have prepared for this purpose.
Et oportet, ut caueas omni cautela, ne tangat Terebrum, aut Incisorium aliquid ex siphac.	And it is necessary to take every precaution to ensure that the drill or scalpel does not touch any part of the brain or spinal cord.
Cum ergo circumieris os perforando, et separatum fuerit a siphac, si fuerit continuum cum eo, et extraxeris ipsum, oportet ut radas, et aeques extremitatem eius quod remanet in osse cum instrumento alio simili Incisorio.	When you have circumcised the bone by drilling and it has been separated from its connection, if it is continuous with the bone, and you have extracted it, then smooth and level its remaining end in the bone using another similar instrument to the scalpel.
Verumtamen oportet, ut sit tenuis et subtilis magis aliis Incisoriis.	But it must be thin and subtle more than other scalpels.
Quod si remanet aliquid ex ossibus paruis, et satagiae: tunc accipe ea cum facilitate, cum eo quod est apud te ex instrumentis.	If there remains any small bones or splinters, then remove them with ease using the appropriate instruments that you have.
Deinde cura uulnus post illud cum liciniis, et unguentis quae diximus.	Then care for the wound afterwards with bandages and ointments as we have said.
Et modus alius operationis est facilis, prorsus longinquus a timore: quem dixit Galenus, et laudauit ipsum laude magna: et iste est sermo eius.	And another way of operating is easy and far from causing fear, which Galen praised highly with great praise: this is his saying.
Necese est tibi in primis, ut incipias detegere partem ossis ex loco, in quo fractura est uehementior, et manifestior: donec quando detexeris illam partem, et posueris sub eo extremitatem huius Incisorii lenticularis, cuius haec est forma.	It is necessary for you to begin by revealing the part of the bone from the location where the fracture is most violent and apparent: until when you have revealed that part and placed under it the end of this lens-shaped scalpel, whose shape is as follows.
Et pars lenticularis, lenis non incidit aliquid: et pars acuta eius in duabus lateribus eius uadens in longitudinem, sicut uides: ut sit pars lenticularis innixa ad siphac, facie eius incidente acuta in osse.	And the lenticular part is gentle and does not cut anything: and its sharp part on both its sides extends lengthwise, as you see: so that the lenticular part rests on the bone with its sharp face cutting into it.
Deinde percute super Incisorium a parte una cum malleo paruo, donec incidas totum os cum facilitate, sicut reuoluitur: et tu sis securus ex panniculo, quod non accidat in eo accidens, quod timeas prorsus.	Then strike on the scalpel from one side with a small hammer until you have cut through the bone easily, and you should be confident that nothing will happen as you fear absolutely.
Et si medicans non esset stultior hominum, et magis ignarus eius, nec esset dormiens, tunc si remaneret aliquid annexum ossi ex panniculo in quibusdam locis, incideret ipsum ab eo cum extremitate incisorii lenticularis ipsius, et liberaret ipsum ab eo cum facilitate.	And if the physician were not foolish among men and more ignorant of this, nor sleeping, then if there remained any attached bone from the bandage in certain places, he would cut it off with the end of the lens-shaped scalpel itself and free it easily.
Liberatur enim ab eo sine nocumento, et absque timore.	For it is freed from it without harm, and without fear.
Et si fractura ossis non penetret usque ad panniculum, et illud quod abscinditur ab osse est facies eius, et remanent in ipso asperitas et satagiae subtiles: tunc oportet, ut radas illam asperitatem, et eradices illas satagias cum rasoriis subtilibus ex quibus praeparasti numerum diuersarum quantitatum, ut sit tibi possibile administrare ex eis in omni loco conuenientiora eorum, et rectiora ipsorum, secundum illud ad quod perducit te operatio, et ipsum os fractum, et figura eius.	And if the fracture of bone does not reach to the bandage, and that which is cut off from the bone is its surface, and there remain in it roughnesses and fine points: then it is necessary to shave off that roughness with fine razors which you have previously prepared in various quantities, so that it may be possible for you to administer those most suitable and straight ones in every place according to what the operation leads you to, and that same broken bone, and its shape.
Et oportet, ut administres in rasione tua, qua in primis radis os, latius illorum rasoriorum.	And it is necessary for you to administer in your manner, first shaving the bone broadly with those razors of yours.
Deinde utere post ipsum subtiliore eo.	Then use afterwards a finer one.
Et non cesses facere illud secundum continuitatem, donec peruenias ad administrandum tenuius, et subtilius eorum omnium.	And do not cease to do this continuously until you arrive at administering the thinnest and finest of them all.
In unaquaque autem fissurarum reliquarum paruarum capillarium, et fractura subtili, oportet ut administres curam, secundum illud quod perducit ad rectificationem eius.	But in each small remaining crevice or fine fracture, it is necessary for you to administer care according to what leads to its correction.
Et est res quae non occultatur super omnem, cui in hac arte est quodlibet studium, et stetit super illud quod scripsimus, et ostendimus in fracturis magnis.	And this thing which is not hidden from anyone who has any study in this art, and it stood upon what we have written and demonstrated concerning great fractures.
Si autem panniculus detectus retinetur, quando tu eradicas os: tunc oportet, ut accipias pannum lini, secundum quantitatem uulneris, et submerge ipsum in oleo rosa, et pone ipsum super orificium uulneris.	But if the bandage is detected as retained when you erase the bone, then it is necessary for you to take a linen cloth according to the size of the wound, and immerse it in rose oil, and place it upon the opening of the wound.
Deinde accipe pannum alium duplicatum, aut triplicatum, et submerge ipsum in uino et oleo rosa, et pone ipsum super pannum primum: et fac illud quam facilius potes super illud, ut non grauetur siphac.	Then take another doubled or tripled cloth, and immerse it in wine and rose oil, and place it upon the first cloth: and do this as easily as possible above it so that the bandage may not be heavy.
Deinde administra supra ipsum ligamentum latum: et non stringas ipsum, nisi per quantitatem quae teneat uulnus tantum: et dimitte ipsum cum hac cura die uno, aut diebus duobus, donec sis securus ab apostemate calido.	Then apply above it a broad bandage: and do not tighten it except by so much as holds the wound only: and leave it with this care for one day or two days until you are secure from hot inflammation.
Deinde solue ipsum, et administra post illud medicinas cum quibus est superflua siccitas: sicut radices lilii, et farina herbi, et puluis thuris, et aristolochia, et similia eis: et est, ut facias ex istis medicinis puluerem, qui puluerizetur super uulnus sicut sunt siccae.	Then dissolve it and apply after it medicines with which there is excessive dryness, such as lily roots, wheat flour, frankincense powder, aristolochia, and others like them: and it is that you make from these medicines a powder that is dusted over the wound just as they are dry.
Et uniuersaliter administra in illo omnem medicinam de proprietate cuius est ut abstergat, et non mordicet.	And universally apply to it every medicine whose property it is to cleanse and not to bite.
Et caue secundum tuam uirtutem, ut uulnus in curatione tua sit limpidum: neque sit in ea sordes unguenti, neque sordicies.	And see that according to your ability the wound may be clean in its healing: and let there not be in it filth of ointment nor foulness.
Neque dimittas uirus aggregari in eo omnino: quoniam quando uirus aggregatur super panniculum cerebri, corrumpit eum, et putrefacit ipsum, et accidit super infirmum post illud malicia magna: et iam accidit in siphac capitis, cum mundificatur ab eo os, praecipue quando negligitur cura eius, nigredo in superficie eius.	Nor let pus accumulate in it at all, for when pus accumulates on the cerebral membrane it corrupts and putrefies it and afterwards great evils happen to the sick person; and especially when the head is washed from it, a blackness appears on its surface, particularly if care of it is neglected.
Considera ergo tunc, si accidunt infirmo accidentia quae diximus, scias, quia est pernitiosum proculdubio.	Therefore consider that if the accidents which we have spoken about happen to the sick person, know that they are certainly harmful.
Et si nigredo non accidit, nisi a medicina quae ponitur super ipsum, et est in uirtute illius medicinae, ut faciat illam nigredinem: tunc oportet, ut accipias ex melle partem unam, ex oleo rosato partes tres, et linias cum eis pannum.	And if blackness does not happen except from the medicine which is placed upon it and there is in its power to make that blackness: then it is necessary that you take one part of honey, three parts of rose oil, and mix them with linen cloth.
Deinde pone ipsum super siphac: postea cura ipsum cum speciebus curationis quae conueniunt, donec sanetur.	Then place the same over the wound; afterwards care for it with appropriate remedies until it heals.
¶ De restauratione Nasi quando frangitur.	On the restoration of the nose when broken.
Caput IIII.	Chapter IV
Scias, quod non franguntur ex Naso nisi duae partes eius superiores simul, aut una earum: propterea, quod ipse sunt duo ossa: quoniam inferius eius est cartilaginosum, non frangitur, et non accidit ei nisi attritio, et tortuositas, et simitas.	Know that the nose is not broken except in its two upper parts simultaneously or one of them, because it has two bones; since the lower part of it is cartilaginous, it does not break and nothing happens to it except rubbing, twisting, and similar things.
Si frangitur una duarum partium eius, tunc oportet, ut intromittas digitum paruum in foramen Nasi, et aeques illam fracturam digito tuo indice, et pollice deforis, donec redeat Nasus super figuram suam naturalem: et fiat illud arte, cum facilitate.	If one of its two parts is broken, then it is necessary to insert a small finger into the nostril and straighten that fracture with your index finger and thumb from outside until the nose returns to its natural shape. And this should be done skillfully with ease.
Et caue, ne accidat per operationem tuam illam super infirmum dolor.	And be careful not to cause additional harm during your operation.
Quod si fractura est in superiore parte Nasi, et non perueniat ad illam digitus: tunc oportet, ut aequetur extremitate radii, in quo sit grossitudo parua.	But if the fracture is in the upper part of the nose and it is not possible to reach it with your finger, then you should use the end of a rod that has a small thickness.
Si uero fractura est in duabus partibus, tunc fac simile illius: et propera cum restauratione eius in die primo fracturae, si est possibile.	But if the fracture is in both parts, then make an imprint of it and restore its shape on the first day after the fracture, if possible.
Et si non, tunc post diem septimum, aut decimum apud quietem apostematis calidi.	And if not, then after the seventh or tenth day when the swelling has gone down due to rest and warm poultices.
Deinde intromitte in extremitate Nasi licinium ex panno lini, si fractura est in parte una: aut intromite duo licinia si fractura est in duabus partibus: et sit in licinio grossitudo tantae quantitatis, quae impleat foramen Nasi.	Then insert a linen strip into the tip of the nose if there is a fracture in one part, or insert two strips if there is a fracture in both parts. The thickness of the strip should be such that it fills the nostril.
Et dixerunt quidam antiquorum restauratorum, ut infundantur licinia in butyro, et permutentur omni die.	And some ancient restorers have said to dip the strips in butter and change them daily.
Illud uero non uidetur mihi, imo oportet, ut infundatur licinium in albugine oui, confecto cum puluere molendini.	But it seems better to me that the strip should be dipped in egg white mixed with flour paste.
Deinde dimitte licinium, donec firmetur os, et induretur cartilago.	Then leave the strip until the bone has hardened and the cartilage has solidified.
Et quandoque intromittitur in Nasum loco licinii penna anseris, postquam inuoluitur super ipsam pannus lenis: et fit, quod ipsa tenet fracturam Nasi uehementius, et ut non prohibeatur infirmus ab inspiratione.	And sometimes a goose feather is inserted into the nose instead of the strip, wrapped in soft cloth. This holds the fracture of the nose more firmly and prevents the patient from breathing.
Et non est haec res necessaria.	This is not necessary.
Si uis, fac illud: et si uis, fac licinia.	If you wish, do this; and if you wish, do that.
Quod si accidat Naso iterum dum operaris apostema calidum, emplastra nasum cum caeroto, aut cum coto infuso in oleo rosato, aut modico ex dyaquilon.	If a boil occurs again while working on an abscess, apply poultices to the nose with cerate, or with cotton soaked in rose oil, or a little of diacathyon.
Si autem non accidit apostema calidum, tunc oportet, ut emplastres ipsum cum farina sisami, et puluere thuris confecti cum albugine oui.	But if no hot abscess occurs, then it is necessary that poultices be made with sesame flour, and ground frankincense powder mixed with egg white.
Deinde pone super ipsum stuppam lenem, et non liges Nasum cum aliquo omnino.	Then place soft gauze on it, and do not bind the nose at all.
Si uero franguntur ossa Nasi fractura parua, aut comminuuntur, tunc oportet, ut scindas super ea, et extrahas ipsa cum instrumentis quae conueniunt eis.	But if the bones of the nose are broken by a small fracture or crushed, then it is necessary to cut over them and remove them with appropriate instruments.
Deinde sue scissuram, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat, et consolidat ex emplastris conuenientibus ad illud, uel unguentis.	Then close the wound, and treat it with appropriate poultices or ointments that promote healing and consolidation.
Quod si accidat inter Nasum uulnus, tunc oportet, ut cures ipsum cum liciniis: et administres cannulam de plumbo, donec sanetur.	But if a wound occurs between the nostrils, then it is necessary to treat it with bandages and insert a lead cannula until it heals.
¶ De restauratione Mandibulae inferioris, quando disrumpitur.	On the restoration of the lower jawbone when it is shattered.
Caput V.	Chapter Five.
Quando disrumpitur Mandibula inferior, et fractura eius non est cum uulnere: conspice tunc si est fractura eius deforis tantum, et non frangitur in duo, et curuatur ad interiora: tunc cognitio eius est facilis.	When the lower jawbone is shattered and there is no wound, look then if the fracture extends only to the outer side and does not split into two pieces towards the inside. Then its recognition is easy.
Oportet ergo, si est fractura eius in parte dextra, ut intromittas digitum indicem sinistrae in os infirmi: similiter si fractura est in mandibula sinistra, tunc intromitte indicem manus dextrae: et impelle cum eo gibbositatem fracturae deintus cum facilitate ad exteriora cum manu tua altera ab interiori parte ossis decenter, et cum eo aequa ipsam.	It is therefore necessary, if the fracture is on the right side, to insert the index finger of your left hand into the jawbone: similarly, if the fracture is on the left side, then insert the index finger of your right hand: and push with it the prominence of the fracture from within towards the outside with ease using your other hand from inside the bone, and thus make it even.
Quod si fractura mandibulae iam separata est in duo, tunc oportet, ut administres extersionem a duabus partibus, secundum rectitudinem: donec possibilis sit aequatio eius.	But if the fracture of the jawbone is already separated into two pieces, then it is necessary to exert traction from both sides according to its length until it is possible to align it.
Si autem iam accidit in dentibus commotio, aut disruptio: tunc stringe illos de quibus speras quod remaneant cum filo auri, aut argenti, aut seta.	But if there has already been movement or displacement of the teeth, then tie those which you hope will remain with gold or silver wire, or silk thread.
Deinde pone super mandibulam fractam caerotum.	Then place a splint over the broken jaw.
Deinde pone super ipsum pannum duplicatum, et pone super pannum astellam magnam decenter factam: aut frustum cutis soleae aequale, in longitudinem mandibulae.	Next, place a doubled cloth on it and put on top of the cloth a well-made large plaster or an equal piece of leathersole, the length of the jawbone.
Deinde liga ipsum desuper, secundum quod praeparatur tibi ligatura eius, et conuenit ipsius applicatio, donec non destruitur: et praecipe infirmo, uti tranquillitate et quiete: et pone cibum eius sorbitiones lenes.	Then bind it from above according to how you prepare the bandage and how it fits, until it is not destroyed. And instruct the patient to remain quiet and at rest, and give them soft foods to eat.
Si autem estimas, quod iam alteratur aliquid figurae aliquo modorum: tunc propera, et solue ipsum in die tertio.	But if you think that there has been some change in its shape in any way, then hurry and remove it on the third day.
Deinde rectifica quod alteratum est ex eo, et emplastra ipsum ex puluere molendini, cum albugine oui, aut cum farina sisami, postquam tu abstuleris caerotum: et pone super emplastrum lanam lenem.	Then correct what has been altered from it and apply a plaster made from flour of barley meal with egg white or sesame flour, after you have removed the splint. And place soft wool on top of the plaster.
Dum ergo permanet annexum illud emplastrum super ipsum, et non alteratur ossis dispositio, dimitte ipsum, ne soluas, donec sanetur: aut stringe fracturam.	Therefore, while that plaster remains attached to it and the arrangement of the bone is not altered, leave it alone without removing it until it heals, or bind the fracture.
Multotiens enim stringitur haec fractura in tribus septimanis.	This fracture should be bound for three weeks.
Quod si interim accidat apostema calidum, tunc administra illud quod diximus multotiens in sedatione eius, donec remoueatur illud apostema.	But if an abscess forms in the meantime, then apply what we have mentioned many times to reduce it until the abscess is removed.
Et si fractura est cum uulnere, considera.	And if there is a fracture with a wound, pay attention.
Namsi iam separatur ex osse frustum, aut a satagie: tunc subtilia te in hoc, ut auferas illa frusta satagiae cum eo quod conuenit tibi in ablatione eorum ex instrumentis.	For if a piece of bone or a splinter has become separated from the bone, then take care to remove those fragments of splinter carefully with suitable instruments.
Si uero orificium uulneris est strictum, tunc amplifica ipsum cum phlebotomo secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	But if the wound opening is narrow, then widen it with a cautery according to your need.
Deinde quando abstuleris illa satagie, et non remanserit ex eis aliquid, sue tunc orificium uulneris, si est amplum: et si non, pone super ipsum ex emplastris quae conueniunt ad illud, et incarnant illud, donec sanetur.	Then when you have removed those splinters and none remain, whether the wound opening is wide or not, then apply to it plasters that are suitable for it and cause it to heal until it is healed.
¶ De restauratione Furculae, quando frangitur.	On the restoration of the jawbone when it is broken.
Caput VI.	Chapter 6
Plurimum quidem frangitur Furcula ab anteriore parte ex parte humeri, et fractura eius fit secundum unum trium modorum.	The jawbone is most often broken at its anterior part near the side of the shoulder, and such a fracture occurs in one of three ways.
Aut enim frangitur et separatur in duo, praeter quod accidant in ea satagiae: et est facilius ad restaurationem eius.	Or it breaks and separates into two pieces, but without any displacement; this is easier to restore.
Aut ita, quod accidunt in osse satagiae: et est difficilius ad restaurationem.	Or it occurs with displacement of the bone fragments, which makes restoration more difficult.
Aut ita, quod est fractura cum uulnere.	Or it happens with a fracture accompanied by a wound.
Et operatio in ea quando fractura est absque uulnere, est, ut facias praesentes esse duos ministros, ut teneat unus eorum adiutorium quod sequitur Furculam fractam, et alter extendat collum uersus partem.	And the procedure when there is a fracture without a wound is as follows: have two assistants present, one to hold the broken jawbone in place and the other to extend the patient's neck towards that side.
Deinde aequa fracturam digitis tuis, donec fiat forma eius, secundum quod oportet: et non sit in ea eminentia, neque concauitas.	Then, using your fingers, bring the fragments together evenly until they assume their proper form without any prominent ridges or hollows.
Quod si indiges extensione plus, tunc oportet, ut ponas sub titillico infirmi spheram ex panno, aut lana: et sit magnitudo eius secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae: et extende, et eleua Furculam, et coarta spheram manu tua, donec aeques fracturam, secundum quod oportet.	But if you need more extension, then place under the patient's chin a ball of linen or wool, the size of which should be determined by your needs. Extend and elevate the jawbone and compress the ball with your hand until the fragments are evenly aligned as required.
Quod si non potes trahere extremitatem Furculae ad exteriora: propterea, quia peruenit ad profundum: tunc oportet, ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam: et ponas sub humero eius puluinar medium in magnitudine, et premat minister humerum eius ad inferiora, donec eleuetur os Furculae quod est in profundo ad sursum: atque tunc rectifica fracturam, et aequa eam digitis tuis.	But if you cannot draw the end of the jawbone towards the outside because it has gone too deep, then have the patient lie on their back and place a medium-sized pillow under their shoulder. Have an assistant press down on their shoulder until the deeply situated bone is elevated upwards, then correct the fracture using your fingers.
Si autem sentis sathaiatum ex Furcula, et mouetur: tunc oportet, ut findas super illud, et extrahas ipsum alsathaiatum cum facilitate.	But if you feel something sharp projecting from the jawbone and it moves, then carefully cut into it and remove the sharp fragment.
Si autem est retentum in osse, tunc ingenia in incisione eius cum uno Incisoriorum quae praeparasti ad illud, postquam tu posueris sub Furcula instrumentum quod seruat sifach: et est instrumentum ex ligno, aut ex ferro.	But if the fragment is impacted within the bone, then use one of the special forceps you have prepared for this purpose. After placing a retractor under the jawbone to keep it open, make an incision through which you can extract the embedded fragment. The retractor can be made of wood or iron.
Et haec est forma eius.	This is its shape.
Assimilatur cochleari cui non est concauitas.	It resembles a seashell that has no hollow indentation.
Et sit latitudo eius secundum illud quo indiges eo ex magnitudine ossis, et paruitate eius.	And its width should be according to what you need it for, based on the size of the bone and the delicacy of its use.
Longitudo uero eius etiam secundum quod possibile est tibi ad operationem.	But its length should also be as convenient for you as possible for the operation.
Et habeat duas extremitates, sicut uides: et extremitas una sit ampla, et altera stricta.	And it should have two ends, one wide and the other narrow, as you see here.
Si autem disruptio uulneris quod scidisti quando extraxisti sathaiatum ossis, est ampla, et securaris ab apostemate calido: tunc aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura.	But if the disruption of the wound you made when extracting the bone fragment is wide, and there is danger of excessive bleeding: then approximate the two lips of the wound with stitching.
Et si disruptio est parua, aut times apostema calidum: tunc imple uulnus cum pannis, et puluillis secundum quantitatem scissurae uulneris.	And if the disruption is small, or you fear excessive bleeding: then fill the wound with linen cloth and lint according to the size of the wound's slit.
Quod si accidat apostema calidum, tunc infunde pannum in oleo rosato, et aceto, et uino, et pone super ipsum.	But if an inflammatory swelling occurs, then dip a cloth in rose oil and vinegar and wine, and place it upon it.
Strictura uero ossis quando est absque uulnere, et absque sectione, est, ut ponas super os emplastrum factum ex farina molendini cum albugine oui.	But the reduction of a bone fracture without wound or incision is achieved by placing over the bone a poultice made from grinding flour mixed with egg white.
Et pone stuppam lenem super ipsum.	And place soft gauze over it.
Deinde pone spheram sub titillico eius, si indiges illa.	Then place a small pillow under his armpit if necessary.
Deinde accipe himematem, id est, rotam quam tenent Saraceni, quae sit longa ualde: et sit latitudo eius palmi unius, aut circiter illud.	Then take a splint, that is, the round one used by the Saracens, which should be very long: its width should be one palm or about that.
Deinde pone puluillum duplicatum super stuppam et emplastrum.	Then place doubled lint over the gauze and poultice.
Deinde accipe astellam ex tabula subtili, cuius latitudo sit trium digitorum, et in longitudine similiter.	Then take a star from a thin board, its width should be three fingers, and similarly in length.
Deinde inuolue eam in panno.	Then wrap it in cloth.
Deinde inuolue pannum illum cum astella in loco alhimemati qui cadit super fracturam et locum.	Then wrap that cloth with the star in the place where the splint falls over the fracture and site.
Deinde pone alhimemati super fracturam sicut reuoluiur, et inuolue eam super collum eius, et sub titillico eius sano, et sub titillico eius infirmo: et reduc eam super omnem partem, et quomodo uides quod strictura tenet fracturam strictura decenti: et est illud, quod non occultatur super te, et totum, ut non remoueatur astella desuper os fractum.	Then place the splint over the fracture as I have shown you, and wrap it around his neck, both under the healthy armpit and under the injured one. Then bring it back over all parts and make sure that the reduction holds the fracture correctly: so that the star is not concealed from your view and does not slip off the broken bone.
Et propter hoc oportet, ut aspicias infirmum in omni die.	Therefore, you must examine the patient every day.
Quotiens ergo mollificatur ligamentum, et uides astellam iam remoueri: tunc rectifica illud, et stringe ligamentum.	Whenever the ligament becomes softened and you see that the star has shifted, then correct it and tighten the ligament.
Deinde pone somnum infirmi super dorsum eius, et pone sub titillico eius apud somnum eius puluinar paruum in nocte, ut cum eo eleuetur adiutorium eius a latere ipsius.	Then place the patient's pillow on his back and put a small cushion under his armpit at night so that his arm aid is lifted up beside him.
Eleuatur ergo fractura furculae per eleuationem humeri.	Therefore, elevate the elbow fracture by lifting the shoulder.
Aut liga brachium eius ad collum ipsius: et non soluas ligamentum, si non accidat in loco accidens ex pruritu, aut ab apostemate, usque ad duodecim dies.	Or bind his arm to his neck: and do not loosen the bandage unless something happens unexpectedly due to itching or suppuration up to twelve days.
Deinde renoua emplastrum, si uideris faciem eius ad illud.	Then renew the plaster if you see that its surface has dried out.
Et adde in strictura, et dimitte ipsum, donec restauretur et coaguletur.	And add to the dressing and leave him until he is restored and coagulation occurs.
Et fractura quidem furculae stringitur et confortatur secundum plurimum in uigintiocto diebus: et quandoque fit in quibusdam hominibus in minore illo.	Indeed, an elbow fracture is generally immobilized and supported for twenty-eight days; however, sometimes it takes less time for certain individuals.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Spatulae.	Chapter on the Reduction of a Scapula Fracture.
Caput VII.	Chapter 7
Raro frangitur Spatula, et in loco lato eius: et non franguntur ex ea nisi margines eius.	The scapula is rarely fractured, and only its margins are broken.
Quando ergo frangitur ex eo locus, et frangitur in medio eius, et non cognoscitur illud nisi per tactum: tunc secundum quod est figura fracturae conare praeparationem eius.	When it is fractured in the middle and not discernible except by touch, then prepare a splint according to the figure of the fracture.
Et reduc eam super figuram naturalem omni modo ingenii, quod est tibi possibile.	And reduce it back into its natural shape using all means possible within your ability.
Deinde pone super locum puluerem molendini cum albugine oui, et stuppam lenem, et pone desuper puluillum ex panno duplato.	Then apply over the site powder of millstone with egg-white, linseed and a folded cloth pad on top.
Deinde pone super ipsum astellam latam ex tabula subtili secundum quantitatem Spatulae totius, aut ampliorem ea parum.	Then place over it a wide star made from thin board according to the size of the entire scapula or slightly larger than it.
Si uero sub astella est concauitas in aliquo locorum Spatulae, tunc aequa illam concauitatem cum stuppa leni, donec descendat astella secundum aequalitatem.	If there is hollowness under the star on any part of the scapula, then smooth it out with soft cotton until the star lies evenly.
Deinde ftringe desuper cum alhimemati longa, constrictione decenti, et firmitudine astellae, donec non remoueatur a loco suo.	Then tie it firmly from above with a long piece of linen, with moderate tension and sufficient tightness so that the star does not move from its position.
Et considera ligamentum in omni die.	And check the bandage every day.
Quotienscunque ergo mollificatur ligamentum, stringe ipsum, et aequa astellam si remoueatur a loco suo: et iaceat infirmus super latus suum sanum.	Whenever the bandage becomes loose, tighten it and smooth out the star if it has moved from its position. Then have the patient lie on their healthy side.
Et Spatula quidem restauratur in uiginti diebus, aut in uigintiquinque diebus.	And the scapula will be restored in twenty days or sometimes up to twenty-five days.
Quando ergo completur iste numerus, tunc solue ligamentum: et tu sis in securitate.	When this number is complete, then untie the bandage and you can be assured of success.
Nam ipsa est ex ossibus quorum communitio non timetur, neque eorum solutio.	For it is among those bones whose fracture is not feared nor their displacement.
Si autem procedat ex osse frustum, et pungit sub cute: tune scinde super ipsum, et aufer ipsum.	But if a splinter of bone protrudes and causes pain under the skin, then cut over it and remove the splinter.
Et fac quod diximus in fractura furculae ex sedatione apostematis calidi, si accidat ex eo aliquid.	And do what we have said for the fracture of the fork [scapula] with regard to the hot seduction [drainage] of the abscess if any occurs.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Pectoris.	Chapter on the Reduction of a Fracture of the Breastbone
Caput VIII.	Chapter Eight
Pectus quandoque frangitur in medio sui, et raro accidit illud.	The breastbone sometimes breaks in the middle of itself, and this happens rarely.
Extremitates eius quidem plurimum franguntur, et comminuuntur ex accidentibus eius.	Its ends are mostly broken or crushed due to accidents happening to it.
Quando frangitur eius medium, quod declinat ad inferiora, et accidit ei dolor uehemens, et difficultas in anhelitu, et tussis: et fortasse euomit sanguinem, et declaratur concauitas in osse fracto, et non occultatur sensui, Restauratio eius est, ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum: et pone inter Spatulas eius puluinar.	When its middle is broken and it slopes downward, causing severe pain, difficulty in breathing, coughing, and sometimes vomiting blood, with a concavity felt on the fractured bone and clearly apparent to the touch, then restore it by placing the patient on their back and putting a bolster between their shoulder blades.
Deinde preme humeros eius, et aggrega costas a duabus partibus uel lateribus cum manibus: et subtiliare in aequatione eius, secundum omnem modum quo possibile est illud et conuenit, donec redeat figura ossis, secundum quod oportet.	Then press down on their elbows and bring together the ribs from both sides or from the flanks with your hands, carefully aligning them until the shape of the bone returns to its proper form.
Deinde pone super ipsum emplastrum et stuppam, et pone desuper astellam ex tabula subtili ex salice, aut chalingi, et ex eis similibus in leuitate, postquam tu inuoluis eam in panno.	Then place upon it a plaster and lint, and on top of that place a star made from thin slices of willow or hazel wood, or other similar lightweight materials, after you have wrapped it in cloth.
Deinde subtiliare in ligando eam super os fractum, ut non remoueatur: et uade cum ligatura secundum rotunditatem ad dorsum aliquotiens, et stringe ipsum strictura decenti.	Then carefully tie it over the broken bone so that it does not move; and wind the bandage around to the back several times, tightening it with a suitable knot.
Deinde considera ligaturam in omni hora, et quotienscumque mollificatur, stringe eam: et si necessitas eius prouocat ad solutionem eius apud pruritum, uel corrosionem quae accidit in loco, aut dolorem, aut apostema: tunc propera, et solue eam, et eradica emplastrum, et rectifica quod accidit cum modo curationis eius.	Then examine the bandage at every hour and whenever it becomes loose, tighten it. And if the need arises for its removal due to itching, corrosion occurring in the area, pain, or swelling, then promptly remove it, discard the plaster, and correct what has happened according to the method of treatment.
Deinde reduc emplastrum, si uides ad illud faciem: et annecte ei stricturam, donec sanetur.	Then apply a new plaster if necessary; and add a fresh bandage until it heals.
¶ De restauratione Costarum, quando franguntur.	On the restoration of broken ribs.
Caput IX.	Chapter IX
Scias, quod Costarum fractura non accidit, nisi in locis grossis quae sequuntur dorsum, et ex extremitatibus earum ab anteriori parte.	Know that rib fractures do not occur except at thick points which follow the back and from their extremities on the front side.
Et non accidit eis attritio, nisi propterea, quia sunt cartilaginosae.	And they are not crushed unless because they are cartilaginous.
Et cognitio ipsius non occultatur sensui apud inquisitionem cum digitis.	And the recognition of it is not hidden to sensation when examined with fingers.
Et restauratio eius fit ita, ut aeques fracturam cum digitis secundum modum possibilem, donec aequetur figura, secundum quod oportet.	And its restoration is accomplished thus: press the fracture back together with your fingers in whatever way possible until the shape returns to its proper form.
Deinde emplastra, et stringe os fractum cum astella, si indiget illo.	Then plaster it, and secure the broken bone with a star-shaped bandage if necessary.
Et si fractura Costarum est decliuis ad interiora: tunc accidit infirmo dolor uehemens, et punctura, sicut punctura illa quae accidit illi qui habet pleuresim: propterea, quod os pungit uelamen, et etiam ei accidit difficultas anhelitus, et tussis, et uomitus sanguinis multi: et haec est difficilis curationis.	And if the rib fracture slopes inward, then severe pain and piercing sensation occur in the sick person, like the pain that occurs in those who have pleurisy. This is because the bone pierces the membrane, causing difficulty in breathing, coughing, and vomiting blood. These are difficult to cure.
Et iam ingeniati sunt antiqui in ea cum ingeniis multis: et ex eis sunt qui dicunt, ut ponas cibos infirmi qui generent inflammationem et uentositatem, ut inflammetur uenter, et extendatur, et impellatur fractura ad exteriora.	Now the ancients have devised many methods for this, and among them are those who say that you should place foods that generate inflammation and windiness in front of the sick person, so that the stomach becomes inflamed, expanded, and the fracture is pushed outward.
Nos uero abhorremus, ut non fiat caussa uelox ad faciendum apostema calidum, si non accidit.	But we disagree, so that there may not be a quick cause for creating a hot boil unless it happens naturally.
Si autem iam accidit, tunc addit in eo.	If however it has already happened, then add to it.
Et dixerunt quidam eorum: ponatur super locum uentosa, deinde sugatur cum fortitudine, et est similius ratiocinationi.	And some of them said: place something windy on the location, then suck it out forcefully, which is somewhat similar to reasoning.
Verumtamen timetur, quod attrahat uentosa superfluitates ad locum, propter dispositionem debilitatis.	However, there is fear that windy substances may draw superfluities to the place due to the weakness of the constitution.
Et dixerunt quidam eorum: oportet ut cooperiatur locus cum lana quae iam submersa est in oleo calido: et ponantur puluilli inter Costas, donec impleatur: ut sit ligatura aequalis quando inuoluis eam secundum rotunditatem.	And some of them said: it is necessary to cover the place with wool which has already been immersed in hot oil, and powders should be placed between the ribs until it is filled, so that there may be an even bandage when it is wound around according to its circumference.
Deinde curetur infirmus curatione pleuresis ex cibo et medicina.	Then the sick person should be treated with the cure for pleurisy by means of diet and medicine.
Quod si coartat infirmum res uehemens, quam non tolerat, et os pungit uelamen punctura laedente, et timemus super infirmum: tunc oportet, ut scindamus super locum, et detegamus a Costa fracta.	But if the sick person is severely constricted and cannot tolerate it, and the bone pierces the membrane with a painful puncture, and we fear for the sick person, then it is necessary to cut over the place and expose the broken rib.
Deinde ponamus super ea instrumentum quod conseruat sifac, cuius rememoratio praecessit: et incidamus os cum facilitate, et incidamus ipsum.	Then place on it the instrument that holds in place, which was mentioned earlier, and cut the bone easily with a saw, and cut it.
Deinde aggregemus duo labia uulneris, si est magnum cum sutura: et curemus ipsum cum emplastris, donec sanetur.	Then bring together the two lips of the wound if it is large, with suturing, and treat it with dressings until it heals.
Quod si accidat interim apostema calidum, tunc propera, et infunde puluillos in oleo rosato, et pone super locum: et curetur infirmus cum eo quod conuenit apostemati.	But if a hot boil should occur in the meantime, then hasten and sprinkle powders in rose oil on the place. And treat the sick person with whatever is suitable for boils.
Interim etiam resupinetur super latus super quod dormit, donec sanetur.	Additionally, let him be turned onto his side while sleeping until healed.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Spondilium dorsi et colli.	On the restoration of fractures of the dorsal and cervical vertebrae.
Caput X.	Chapter 10
Ossibus quidem colli quandoque aduenit fractura, et raro accidit eis attritio: et similiter Spondilibus dorsi etiam.	Indeed, fractures happen to the bones of the neck sometimes, and rarely do they grind against each other; similarly for the dorsal vertebrae.
Cum ergo accidit illud alicui, et uis scire, an sanetur, an non sanetur: tunc confidera.	But when this happens to someone, and you wish to know whether it will heal or not, then consider [this].
Nam si uides manus eius iam mollificatas, et stupefactas, et mortuas: et non potest mouere eas, neque extendere eas, neque constringere eas: et quando constringis eas cum digitis tuis, et pungis eas cum acu, non sentit illud, et non sentit in eis dolorem: tunc scias, quia non sanatur, et in pluribus dispositionibus est mortale.	For if you see that his hands are already softened, numb, and lifeless, and he cannot move them, nor extend them, nor make a fist; and when you compress them with your fingers or prick them with a needle, he does not feel it and feels no pain in them: then know that it will not heal, and there is death in many cases.
Quod si mouet eas, et sentit in eis constrictionem cum digitis et puncturam: tunc scias, quia nucha ossis salua est, et quod infirmus sanabitur cum curatione.	But if he moves them and feels the compression with your fingers or prick with a needle, then know that the cervical vertebra is sound, and that the patient will be healed with care.
Quod si eueniat Spondilibus dorsi simile illius, et uis scire, an sanetur etiam, an non: tunc considera ad pedes eius: tunc si uides quod mollificati sunt, et accidit in eis illud quod accidit in manibus: deinde quando iacet super dorsum suum, egreditur uentositas et egestio absque uoluntate: et quando resupinatur super uentrem suum, egreditur egestio sine uoluntate: et quando resupinatur super dorsum suum, et uult mingere, et non potest: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	But if a similar condition occurs in the dorsal vertebrae and you wish to know whether it will heal or not, then consider his feet. If you see that they are softened, and what happens there also happens to his hands, then when he lies on his back wind passes out without his will, and when he is turned onto his stomach waste passes out without his will; and when he is turned onto his back and wishes to urinate but cannot: then know that it is fatal.
Non ergo labores in curatione eius.	Therefore do not trouble yourself with treating him.
Si uero non accidit ei aliquid ex illo, res est leuior.	But if nothing like that happens to him, the condition is lighter.
Et curatio eius quod accidit ex illo est, ut coneris sedationem apostematis calidi: ita, ut ponas super Spondilem attritam oleum rosatum solum: aut cum uitellis oui assati.	And its treatment is to attempt the alleviation of a hot boil thus: put rose oil alone or with yolks of well-fed hens on the rubbed vertebra.
Pone super ipsam illud aliquotiens in die, donec quando sedatur apostema calidum: tum pone super locum unum ex emplastris confortantibus, exiccantibus, et stringe super ipsum cum ligamento: et praecipe infirmo, ut utatur quiete et tranquillitate.	Apply this repeatedly during the day until the hot boil is sedated. Then apply one of the comforting and drying plasters on the spot and bind it with a bandage; and instruct the patient to use rest and tranquility.
Nec dormiat super partem cum qua inuenit dolorem, donec sanetur.	And let him not sleep upon that part where he finds pain until it is healed.
Quod si accidit apud attritionem ossis sathaiatum, aut aliquid quod iam separatum fit ex eo: tunc oportet, ut seces super cutem, et auferas illud.	But if it occurs at the friction of the bone or some part that has already separated from it, then it is necessary to cut through the skin and remove it.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris, si est magnum, cum sutura.	Then bring together the two lips of the wound with a suture if it is large.
Deinde cura ipsum cum aliquo incarnatiuo, ex unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with some flesh-colored ointment until it heals.
Si uero frangitur postremum ossis alhausos, et est finis caudae: tunc oportet, ut intromittas pollicem manus sinistrae in anum, et aeques os fractum manu altera, secundum quod possibile est, et secunda aequatione.	But if the last part of the tailbone breaks and is the end of the coccyx: then it is necessary to insert the thumb of the left hand into the anus and bring the broken bone into alignment with the other hand as much as possible and with repeated adjustments.
Deinde pone super ipsum, et aufer ipsum: et cura uulnus cum curatione quae praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then apply something on it and remove it; and treat the wound with the same treatment until it heals.
¶ De restauratione Anchae.	Chapter on the Reduction of Dislocations
Caput XI.	Chapter 11
Raro franguntur ossa Ancharum.	Bones of the hips rarely break.
Quod si franguntur, tunc fractura eorum non est, nisi comminutio in extremitatibus ipsorum: et scinduntur in longitudine, et declinantur ad interiora: et accidit infirmo dolor in loco, et punctura: et stupescit crus quod frangitur.	If they do break, then the fracture is not complete but rather comminuted at their extremities; and they split lengthwise and incline inward, causing pain and tenderness at the site of the fracture, and the injured limb becomes numb.
Et restauratio quidem eius est, ut extendas manum tuam super ipsum, donec stes super fracturam qualiter est figura eius.	And its reduction is accomplished by placing your hand on it until you stand over the fracture in accordance with its shape.
Quod si fractura est in extremitatibus eius tantum, tunc aequa illam fracturam, secundum quod praeparatur tibi ex aequatione, donec assimiletur figurae suae naturali.	If the fracture is only at the extremities, then align it according to how you prepare yourself for reduction until it resembles its natural shape.
Si autem fractura est in longitudine, aut iam declinat ad interiora: tunc fac iacere infirmum super uentrem suum, donec praeparetur tibi restauratio illius fracturae.	But if the fracture is lengthwise or already inclined inward, then have the patient lie on his belly until you are prepared to reduce that fracture.
Quando ergo aequaueris ipsam, pone super ipsam emplastrum: deinde pone super ipsam astellam ex ligno, aut ex cute: et stringe strictura super quam non timeas permutationem fracturae, neque remotionem astellae.	When you have aligned it properly, place an adhesive plaster on top; then place upon it a splint made of wood or leather. Bind this securely with a bandage so that there is no fear of displacement of the fracture or removal of the splint.
Et aequa concauitatem illorum cum eo quod impleat eam, donec capiat eam strictura secundum aequalitatem: et praecipe infirmo, ut dormiat super dorsum suum, aut super latus suum sanum.	And make sure the hollow spaces fit perfectly with what fills them so that the bandage holds it evenly. Then instruct the patient to sleep on their back or healthy side.
Si autem accidat ei apostema calidum: tunc cessa ab extensione eius, et ipsius restauratione, donec sedetur apostema calidum: et pone super ipsum quod sedet ipsum, secundum quod praecessit, deinde redi ad restaurationem eius: et stringe ipsum sicut oportet.	But if a hot abscess occurs, then cease from extending it and its reduction until the hot abscess subsides. Then apply to it what is prescribed, after which return to its reduction and bind it as necessary.
