Know that the joint of the elbow is dislocated with difficulty and also returns with difficulty; indeed it can be dislocated in all directions but especially towards the front or back.
Et eius dislocatio non occultatur tibi: quoniam est cadens sub uisu, et sub tactu, secundum quamcunque figuram dislocetur.	And its dislocation will not be concealed from you for it is apparent to sight and touch according to whatever shape it may be dislocated.
Et quando coniungis cubitum dislocatum cum sano, declaratur tibi illud manifeste.	And when you reduce a dislocated elbow, it becomes manifestly clear.
Concauatur enim iunctura, et non potest duplicare brachium, neque tangere cum eo humerum suum.	For the joint becomes hollowed out and cannot bend the arm nor touch its own humerus.
Et oportet, ut properes, et reducas dislocationem statim, antequam accidat ei apostema calidum.	And you must hasten to reduce the dislocation immediately before gangrene sets in.
Nam si accidit ei apostema calidum, difficilis fit eius reductio: et fortasse non sanatur omnino, praecipue quando est ad posteriora.	For if gangrene occurs, reducing it becomes difficult; and perhaps it will not heal at all, especially when it is on the back.
Est enim deterior omnibus speciebus dislocationis, et uehementioris doloris eis: et multotiens descendit cum ea mors.	It is worse than any other kind of dislocation, causing intense pain; and death often accompanies it.
Et restauratio eius quando est ex eis quae possibile est reducere, est, ut extendatur manus eius cum duabus manibus: et brachium eius sit expansum, et manus medici sint supra cubitum et sub eo, et ipse impellat iuncturam cum pollicibus manuum suarum simul, aut cum radice palmae suae, donec redeat ad locum suum.	And the restoration of it when it is possible to reduce it is this: extend his hand with both hands of the physician, and let his arm be stretched out, and let the hands of the physician be above his elbow and below it; and he should push the joint with the roots of his fingers or with the palm of his hand until it returns to its place.
Aut uero dislocatio est ad anteriora: tunc redit ita, ut duplicet manum cum manu sua, donec percutiat cum radice palmae suae cubitum qui est dislocatus.	Or if the dislocation is towards the front, then he should extend his hand with his own hand until he strikes the dislocated elbow with the root of his palm.
Quod si non obedit dislocatio ad reductionem, tunc administra extensionem uehementem, fortem ualde: et est, ut extendant brachium duo ministri: et teneant ipsum duo ministri etiam, ut non remoueatur apud extensionem.	But if the dislocation does not yield to reduction, then apply strong and vigorous traction; let two assistants extend his arm and hold it so that it cannot move during traction.
Deinde reuoluatur brachium ad omnem partem postquam inuoluitur super manum eius pannus duplicatus longus, aut ligamentum latum.	Then revolve the arm in every direction after wrapping a doubled cloth or wide bandage around his hand.
Et quando tangit medicus manu sua iuncturam, inungat ipsam cum oleo: ut sit illud ex eis quae adiuuant in lubricitate iuncturae cum facilitate.	And when the physician touches the joint with his hand, he should anoint it with oil so that it may be among those which aid in the smoothness of the joint with ease.
Deinde impellat iuncturam impulsione uehementi, donec redeat.	Then push the joint forcefully until it returns to its place.
Et post reductionem eius oportet, ut ponatur super ipsam emplastrum, in quo sit stipticitas, et exiccatio cum albugine oui: et stringatur strictura decenti.	And after its reduction, an poultice should be applied to it containing astringent and egg white; and let it be bound with a suitable bandage.
Et suspendatur brachium a collo infirmi: et dimitte diebus aliquot.	And suspend the arm from the neck of the patient for several days.
Deinde soluatur.	Then untie it.
Si ergo firmatur iunctura in loco suo, tunc solue ligamentum ab ea, et dimitte ipsam.	If therefore the joint remains firm in its place, then release the bandage from it and leave it alone.
Et si uides iuncturam non bene stringi, tunc itera emplastrum, et ligamentum, et dimitte ipsam diebus aliquot, donec stringatur.	And if you see that the joint is not being held firmly, then apply the poultice and bandage again, and leave it alone for several days until it is well secured.
Deinde solue ipsam.	Then release it.
Si autem accidit ei grauitas post reductionem iuncturae, et dispositio sit in motu: tunc administra humectationem in balneatione, et fricationem subtilem, et compressionem, donec liniatur, aut pone super iuncturam iliati, id est, natem arietis pinguem.	If, however, heaviness occurs after the reduction of the joint, and the condition is one of movement: then apply moistening in bathing, gentle friction, and compression until it is aligned, or place upon the joint grease from the fat of a lamb.
Deinde ligetur, et dimitte ipsam super eam die et nocte.	Then bind it, and leave it alone for that day and night.
Deinde aufer eam, et intromitte ipsum in balneum.	Then remove it, and immerse it in the bath.
Cum ergo sudat, tunc frica iuncturam fricatione temperata.	When it begins to sweat, then rub the joint gently.
Deinde itera super ipsam aleliati uice una, et secunda, et tertia cum introitu balnei, donec leniatur.	Then apply the poultice of aloe again once, twice, or three times with immersion in the bath until it becomes soft.
Et si uis, pone super ipsam stercus uaccinum, humidum, calefactum cum butyro, et stringe super ipsum.	And if you wish, place upon it damp dog's dung warmed with butter, and bind it over that.
Fac illud aliquotiens.	Do this repeatedly.
Ipsa namque lenitur, et redit ad dispositionem suam.	For it will thereby become softened, and return to its former condition.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Almahassem.	Chapter on the Treatment of Dislocation of the Shoulder
Caput XXIX.	Chapter 29
Mahassem manus multotiens dislocatur, id est, iunctura quae est inter brachium et manum.	The shoulder joint is frequently dislocated, that is, the articulation between the arm and the hand.
Et reductio dislocationis eius est facilis.	And its reduction is easy.
Econtrario reliquarum iuncturarum.	Unlike other joints.
Verumtamen oportet, ut uelocitas sit in reductione dislocationis eius in hora in qua dislocatur, antequam apostemetur locus: aut accidat in eo apostema calidum.	But it is necessary that the reduction of its dislocation be done quickly at the time when it occurs, before there is accumulation [of fluid], lest a hot swelling occur.
Et reductio dislocationis in eo est, ut ponas Mahassem manus infirmae super tabulam, et extendat minister manum eius: et ponat medicus palmam suam super eminentiam iuncturae, et impellat eam, donec redeat.	And the reduction of its dislocation is as follows: place the shoulder of the afflicted hand upon a table, and have an assistant extend the hand; then place your palm upon the prominence of the joint, and press it until it returns to its former position.
Verumtamen oportet, ut consyderetur, si palma iam recessit ad uentrem manus: tunc ponat infirmus dorsum manus suae super tabulam apud extensionem et reductionem: et si dislocatio est procedens ad dorsum manus, tunc sit positio manus eius intrinsece super tabulam, id est, interior pars manus eius super tabulam ponatur, ut cadat manus medici super ipsam eminentiam iuncturae.	But it is necessary to consider if the palm has already receded towards the belly of the hand: then let the infirm place the back of his hand upon the table at extension and reduction; and if the dislocation is proceeding towards the back of the hand, then let the position of his hand be internal upon the table, that is, let the inner part of his hand be placed upon the table so that the doctor's hand may fall upon that prominence of the joint.
Si ergo redit statim, bonum est: et si non, tunc stringe eam cum emplastro sedante apostema: et dimitte ipsum, neque iteres illud.	If it returns immediately, then this is good; but if not, then bind it with a plaster to suppress the swelling and let him go, without repeating it.
Nam si non tolerat, neque potes super reductionem eius, postquam praetereunt ei dies, uerumtamen iunctura remanet secundum tortuositatem suam: et non nocet infirmo aliquid, nisi quod mollificatur manus, et non potest stringere aliquid: tunc scias, quod nerui sunt abscissi, aut attriti.	For if it does not bear up, nor can you succeed in reducing it, after the days have passed, yet the joint remains according to its tortuosity, and causes no harm to the patient except that the hand becomes softened and cannot grasp anything: then know that either the nerves are cut or frayed.
Non est ergo ingenium in ea, nisi ut stringatur cum cauterio prope casum eius.	Therefore, it has no remedy but to be bandaged with a caustic near its fall.
Et fortasse non confert illud aliquid.	And perhaps this will do no good.
Cum ergo non redit Almahassem, tunc pone super ipsum emplastrum, quod narrauimus.	When therefore it does not return, then place upon it the plaster which I have described.
Deinde stringatur, et dimittatur quinque diebus: postea soluatur et dimittatur, et exercitetur manus.	Then let it be bandaged and left for five days; afterwards let it be untied and allowed to rest, and the hand exercised.
Si autem priuatur motus eius, et accidat in ea aliquid grauitatis: tunc leni eam cum aqua calefacta, et fricatione aliquotiens, donec leniatur.	But if it is deprived of its movement and some heaviness occurs therein: then soften it with warm water and friction often, until it becomes softened.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Digitorum.	On the Treatment of Dislocation of Fingers.
Caput XXX.	Chapter 30
Quando dislocatur ex eis Digitus ad omnem partem, uel ex eis Digitus ad dorsum palmae, aut uentrem eius: tunc extende Digitum, et impelle dislocationem pollicibus tuis, donec redeat.	When any of the fingers is dislocated towards any part or towards the back of the palm or its belly, then extend the finger and press the dislocation with your thumbs until it returns.
Deinde sustenta caput Digiti, et suspende ipsum uersus partem ad quam dislocatur, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	Then support the head of the finger, suspend it towards the part to which it is dislocated, and let it hang for two days.
Deinde suspende eum, et extende ipsum, donec aequetur rectus in illo die suo.	Then suspend it and extend it until it equals the straightness of its day.
Cum ergo fuerit nox, liga ipsum secundum narrationem ipsam: et non cesses soluere ipsum in die: et exerce eum cum motu: et liga ipsum in nocte.	When therefore night falls, bind it according to that description; and do not cease to unbind it during the day; and exercise it with movement; and bind it at night.
Fac illud diebus aliquot, donec stringatur.	Do this for several days until it becomes firm.
Et similiter fac cum eo, si dislocatur ad uentrem manus: et liga eum ad partem ipsam, et fac cum eo operationem tuam primam, donec sanetur.	And do likewise if it becomes dislocated towards the palm of the hand; bind it to that part and perform your first operation until it heals.
Et similiter fac cum eo quando dislocatur ad reliquas partes.	And similarly do with it when it becomes dislocated elsewhere.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Spondilium dorsi.	On the Treatment of Spinal Vertebra Dislocations.
Caput XXXI.	Chapter XXXI
Quando accidit alicui Spondilium dorsi, aut colli dislocatio completa, aut remouentur Spondiles multae a locis suis: tunc non est in ea curatio, quoniam mors properat infirmo.	When complete dislocation occurs to any of the spinal vertebrae or neck, or many are displaced from their places, then there is no cure for it because death approaches the sick person.
Et signum illius est, quod egestio infirmi egreditur absque uoluntate, neque potest tenere eam: et multotiens mollificantur ex eo quaedam membra eius, aut duo crura eius, aut duo brachia ipsius, aut unum eorum: aut remouetur Spondilis una de loco suo.	And the sign of this is that the discharge from the sick person exits without intention and they cannot hold it back. And sometimes certain limbs become softened because of it, either both legs or both arms or one of them, or a vertebra is displaced from its place.
Multotiens enim remouetur, quod multotiens fit remotio earum ad quatuor partes.	For indeed displacement often occurs, which happens frequently in four parts.
Illa ergo quae remouetur ad posteriora, nominatur Gibbositas.	Therefore, that which is displaced backwards is called Kyphosis (Hunchback).
Curatio uero eius est, ut consyderes tunc, si Gibbositas accidit a puericia: tunc non est in ea curatio, neque ex ea est sanatio omnino.	But its treatment is to consider whether Kyphosis occurs from childhood. If it does, there is no treatment for it nor any healing from it at all.
In illa autem quae accidit a casu, aut percussione, aut similibus illis, iam dixerunt antiqui modos curationis sermone prolixo.	But in that which occurs by chance, or by injury, or similar things, the ancients have already spoken of methods of treatment at length.
Cuius plurimum non redit cum proficuo.	Of which most does not return with profit.
Ego uero iam abbreuiaui ex illo, cuius parum excusat a multo eius ex propinquitate mea ad intentionem: et expositione mea qua exposui illud, et formaui instrumentum eius diuerso modo ab eo quo ostenderunt illud, et exposuerunt ipsum.	But I have already shortened it from that one (Albucasis), of which little excuses the abundance of his nearness to my intention and exposition. And I have formed an instrument for it in a different way than they showed it and explained it.
Dico ergo, quod in gibbositate quae accidit ab anteriori parte, non est ingenium, neque sanatio ex ea.	I say therefore that there is no remedy nor healing from Kyphosis that occurs on the anterior part.
Et similiter in illa quae fit ad duo latera etiam.	And likewise for that which occurs to both sides also.
Et non curatur ex eis, nisi illa quae accidit in dorso proprie, cum eo quod ego narro: et est, ut extendatur infirmus super faciem suam super podium aequale prope parietem: et expandatur sub eo stramentum humidum, ut non laedatur pectus eius.	And they are not treated except for that which occurs on the back properly, as I tell it. And it is to extend the sick person face down over an even footstool near a wall, with a damp cloth under them so that their chest is not injured.
Deinde ponatur lignum rectum fixum in fouea in terra, in extremitate podii, circiter caput eius: et lignum aliud circiter pedes eius in extremitate altera podii: et minister teneat lignum, et sit non firmatum in fouea.	Then place a straight stick fixed into a hole in the ground at the head of the footstool and another stick at the feet. The assistant should hold the sticks and they should not be firmly fixed in the holes.
Et minister alter teneat alterum.	And another assistant should hold the other [stick].
Deinde inuolue super caput infirmi, et sub titillicis eius ligamentum lene, firmum: et extende extremitatem ligamenti ad lignum quod est apud caput eius: et liga ipsum in eo.	Then tie around the head of the patient and underneath the tendons a soft, strong cord. Extend the end of the cord to the stick at the head and tie it there.
Deinde stringe ligamentum aliud supra anchas eius, et supra genua ipsius, et apud cauillas eius.	Then bind another cord above his hips, above his knees, and around his calves.
Deinde aggrega ligamenta omnia, et liga ea in ligno altero quod est apud pedes eius.	Then gather all the cords together and tie them to the stick at his feet.
Deinde extendat omnis minister ad partem ligni ligamentum, et non remoueantur duo ligna ex locis suis in quibus sunt fixa: uerumtamen non sint firmata, sicut diximus.	Then all assistants should pull on the cords towards their respective sticks. The two sticks should not be moved from their places, but they should not be firmly fixed as we have said.
Et medicus ponat palmas suas super Spondilem cum fortitudine, donec redeat: aut ponat super eam tabulam.	And the physician should place his palms on the Spondyle with force until it returns to its original position or he may place a board on top of it.
Deinde annectat super tabulam pedes suos, donec redeat.	Then apply his feet against the board and push until it returns to its proper position.
Si autem non redit per hanc curationem, tunc accipe tabulam cuius longitudo sit circiter tria brachia.	If it does not return with this treatment, then take a board whose length is about three cubits (approximately 4½ feet).
Et caua in pariete de quo diximus quod est prope infirmum, locum in quem ingrediatur extremitas tabulae.	And hollow out a place on the wall we mentioned which is near the patient, into which the end of the board will fit.
Deinde pone medium tabulae super Spondilem.	Then place the middle of the board over the Spondyle.
Et ponat pedes suos medicus super extremitatem alteram.	And the physician should place his feet on the other end of the board.
Et stringat bene, donec coartetur Spondilis, et redeat ad locum suum.	And press firmly until the Spondyle is squeezed together and returns to its proper position.
Deinde si uis, operare cum torno quod inuoluitur cum manu tua: et est, ut figas in terram apud caput infirmi in postremo podii duo ligna, quorum longitudo sit brachii unius: et apud caput eius in postremo podii duo ligna.	Then if you wish, use a drill and turn it with your hand. This is done by driving two sticks into the ground at the end of the footstool near the head of the patient, each stick being one cubit long.
Et sit longitudo quae est inter omne lignum palmus unus: et iam factum est in omni loco foramen, in quo currit tornum: et firmetur lignum omne in terra multum, ne moueatur omnino.	And the distance between each stick should be one palm (about 7 inches). Once this is done, ensure that all sticks are firmly planted into the ground so they do not move at all.
Et intromittatur lignum rotundum: et est tornum in quo reuoluitur ligamentum in duobus foraminibus duorum lignorum.	Then insert a round stick (the drill) and let it revolve in the holes of the two sticks, securing the limb in place.
Et in extremitate eius est foramen, in quo firmatur lignum, cuius longitudo est palmus cum eo quod reuoluitur: et in duobus lignis aliis est similiter illius.	And at its end there is a hole to secure the stick with the length of a palm plus the drill. Two more sticks are similarly positioned on either side of these two.
Deinde stringe ligamenta quae strinxisti in pectore infirmi torno quod est apud caput eius: et ligamenta quae strinxisti in cruribus eius in torno quod est apud pedes eius.	Then, wrap the ligatures that you have placed on the patient's chest around the drill at the head end and those placed on their legs around the drill at the foot end.
Deinde stet apud omne tornum minister, qui torqueat manum suam cum licinio, cum quo reuoluitur tornum: et medicus aequet Spondilem, secundum quod diximus.	Next, have an assistant stand by each drill turning the hand crank with a bandage to rotate the drill. The surgeon should apply pressure evenly using the leverage of the sponge forceps, as previously described.
Haec est forma torni, quae sequitur.	This is the form of the tourniquet that follows.
Deinde postquam redit Spondilis, et aequatur locus, tunc oportet, ut ponas emplastrum exiccatiuum cum albumine oui.	Then, once the sponge forceps has been applied and the location is evened out, you should then place an absorbent dressing made with egg whites.
Deinde stuppam.	Then apply a wick.
Postea pone supra emplastrum astellam ex tabula, cuius latitudo sit trium digitorum, aut circiter eos.	Next, place over the dressing a star-shaped piece of linen or cloth, approximately three fingers wide (about 2 inches).
Et longitudo eius quantitas quae capiat locum Gibbositatis, et super partem Spondilis sanae.	And its length should be equal to the size that covers the gibbosity and extends beyond it onto the healthy part of the sponge forceps.
Deinde ligetur cum ligamento quod diximus.	Then tie it with the ligature mentioned earlier.
Et utatur infirmus nutrimento subtili, donec sanetur.	And let the patient have a light diet until they are healed.
Quod si remaneat quiddam eminentiae in loco in fine sanationis: tunc oportet, ut administrentur medicinae quae mollificant, et leniunt, cum administratione tabulae quam narrauimus tempore longo.	If there is still some prominence remaining at the site after healing, then it is necessary to apply softening and soothing medications with the application of compresses as described earlier for an extended period.
Et iam administratur in illo lamina plumbi.	And now apply a lead plate over that area.
Et quandoque accidit eminentia in postremo Spondilium dorsi: et putatur per eam dislocatio, et est illud os quod iam eminet.	Sometimes there may be an elevation at the last lumbar vertebra of the back; this is thought to cause dislocation and is the bone that protrudes.
Quare non oportet, ut praesumptio fiat ei cum hac medicina: fortasse enim accidere faciet mortem.	Therefore, one should not dare to treat him with this medicine, for it may possibly cause his death.
¶ De curatione Anchae dislocatae.	Concerning the treatment of a dislocated ankle.
Caput XXXII.	Chapter 32
Scias, quod iuncturae Anchae, et iuncturae humeri, non accidit, nisi dislocatio tantum: neque accidit eis quod accidit reliquis iuncturis ex remotione parua, et concauitate.	Know that the joints of the ankle and shoulder are not subjected to dislocation unless there is a great force; nor do they undergo what happens to other joints with slight displacement and concavity.
Et iunctura quidem Anchae dislocatur secundum quatuor partes.	And indeed, the ankle joint may become dislocated in four directions.
Quod est, quia dislocatur ad anteriora, et ad posteriora.	That is to say, it becomes dislocated towards the front or towards the back.
Et plurimum quidem dislocatur ad interiora: et parum dislocatur ad anteriora, et ad posteriora.	Indeed, it most often dislocates inwardly, and rarely dislocates forward or backward.
Et curatio dislocationis eius ad interiora, est: quia quando tu coniungis crus infirmi sanum cum infirmo, est longius: et est genu eius eminens plus quam sani, et non potest infirmus duplicare pedem suum apud inguen: et est locus qui sequitur inguen apostematus apostemate calido, propterea, quod caput coxae iam peruenit illic.	And the treatment for inward dislocation of the ankle is as follows: when you align the healthy leg with the injured one, the injured leg is longer; the knee rises higher than that of a healthy person, and the injured individual cannot bend their foot at the groin. There is swelling below the groin due to inflammation caused by the head of the femur having reached there.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad exteriora est, quod sunt accidentia eius contraria istis accidentibus.	The sign that inward dislocation has occurred is that its symptoms are opposite to those described above.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad anteriora, est, quia expandit crus sanum secundum complementum: uerumtamen non duplicat ipsum absque dolore qui est in genu: et si conatur ad ambulandum, non potest super illud ad anteriora: et retinetur urina eius, et apostematur inguen eius, et apud ambulationem est calcatio eius super calcaneum.	And the sign of forward dislocation is that when the healthy leg is extended, it cannot be fully bent at the knee without pain. The patient cannot walk forward on the injured foot and urine retention occurs; there is swelling below the groin and the heel bears weight during walking.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad posteriora est, ut non expandat genu, neque possit duplicare ipsum antequam duplicet inguen: et est crus eius etiam breuius altero: et inguen est mollificatum, et est caput coxae apud locum ilii.	The sign of backward dislocation is that the knee cannot be extended nor bent without first bending the hip. The injured leg appears shorter than the other; the groin becomes softened and the head of the femur protrudes at the buttock area.
Reductio uero huius dislocationis specierum est, ut consyderes tunc, si dislocatio est uetusta, quae iam antiquatur cum habente ipsam.	The reduction of this dislocation consists in considering whether the dislocation is old and has already begun to heal when the patient presents with it.
Deinde si tu administres reductionem eius, et remanet secundum dispositionem suam: tunc non est in ea curatio omnino.	If you attempt reduction but it remains unchanged, then there is no cure for it at all.
Non ergo oportet, ut praesumptio fiat ei penitus.	Therefore, do not make any presumption about it whatsoever.
In illo autem cuius dislocatio est recens, et est ex una specierum quatuor dislocationis: tunc propera ad hoc, ut uoluas iuncturam, et extendas ipsam ad interiora et ad exteriora, et moueas eam dextra et sinistra: fortasse enim redit, et non indiget alia cura.	But if the dislocation is recent and of one of four types, then hurry to bring about union by moving it inwards and outwards and from side to side. Perhaps it will return spontaneously without needing further treatment.
Si autem non redit hoc modo, tunc oportet, ut praepares ministrum fortem, et extendat crus eius ab inferiori parte: aut cum manibus suis, aut cum ligamento, quod ligetur super crus eius supra genu: et minister alius extendat manum eius desuper, ita ut intromittat manus suas sub titillicis eius.	But if it does not return this way, then prepare a strong assistant who will extend the leg from below either with his hands or using a bandage tied above the knee. Another assistant should grasp the foot from above, inserting their hands under the sole of the foot.
Deinde stringat cum ligamento leni super radicem coxae, et teneat extremitatem ligamenti alterius.	Then tie it gently with a bandage at the root of the hip and hold onto the other end of the bandage.
Et sit extensio eius aut ab anteriori parte inguinis ad partem furculae, aut a posteriori ad partem dorsi.	And the extension should be either from the front of the groin to the fork or from behind to the backside.
Et sit extensio eorum omnium uice una, donec eleuetur infirmus cum corpore suo a terra, et remaneat pendens.	All of these extensions are to be carried out simultaneously until the patient is lifted off the ground with their body hanging freely.
Et haec enim species extensionis est species communis specierum quatuor.	This is the common method of extension for all four types of dislocation.
Si ergo redit dislocatio cum eo quod diximus, est bonum: et si non, tunc necesse est omni speciei illud quod dicam de curatione propria.	If the dislocation returns as described, that is good. But if not, then it is necessary to consider the specific treatment for each type of dislocation.
In reductione quidem eius propria quando dislocatio est ad interiora, oportet, ut resupinetur infirmus super latus suum sanum.	For reducing a dislocation inward, the patient should lie on their healthy side.
Deinde ponat ligamentum super radicem coxae, in eo quod est inter caput coxae, et locum qui est sub inguine.	Then place a bandage over the root of the hip between the head of the femur and the space beneath the groin.
Deinde extende ligamentum ad sursum a parte inguinis ad altiorem partem corporis, ad partem furculae.	Next, extend the bandage upwards from the groin towards the upper part of the body on the side of the hip socket.
Deinde accipiat minister alius fortis brachia eius, et minuat locum grossum coxae infirmae, et extendat ad exteriora extensione uehementi.	Then another strong assistant should take hold of the patient's arms and move the affected hip joint outwards with a forceful extension.
Iam enim redit ad locum suum.	Now it has returned to its proper place.
Et haec species est facilioris reliquis speciebus curationis, qua reducitur hoc membrum.	And this method is easier than other methods of treatment, by which this limb is reduced.
Si autem excusatur super te, et non obedit tibi ad introitum cum hac specie curationis omnino: tunc oportet, ut ligentur duo pedes infirmi simul cum ligamento forti, leni, super duos calcaneos, et super duo genua: et sit longitudo cuiusque a compare suo quantitatis quatuor digitorum: et sit crus infirmum extensum plus altero quantitate duorum digitorum.	But if it refuses to submit to you and does not obey your entry with this species of treatment entirely, then it is necessary that both feet of the sick person be bound together with a strong, soft bandage over both heels and both knees; and let the length of each one be equal to four fingers' breadth, and let the sick leg be extended more by the quantity of two fingers than the other.
Deinde suspendatur infirmus super caput ligni, quod sit in domo: et sit longitudo eius a terra quantitas duorum brachiorum.	Then let the sick person be suspended over the head of a wooden beam that is in the house; and let its length from the ground be equal to two cubits.
Deinde praecipe iuueni forti, ut muniat caput coxae: et suspendatur cum infirmo inuenis alius: et impellat iuuenis alius, muniens coxam cum fortitudine, nam iunctura redit ad locum suum cum uelocitate.	Then command a strong young man to guard the head of the hip; and let another youth be suspended with the sick person, and let another young man push with force while guarding the hip, for the joint will return to its place with speed.
In reditione autem eius propria, quando est dislocatio ad exteriora, oportet, ut iaceat infirmus super podium, secundum quod narrauimus in habente gibbositatem.	But in returning it to its proper place, when the dislocation is towards the outside, it is necessary that the sick person lie on a pedestal, as we have described in the case of one with humpback.
Et stringatur ligamentum super crus eius, infirmum proprie, et super pectus eius.	And let the bandage be bound over his sick leg properly and over his chest.
Deinde ponantur duo ligna, unum apud pedes eius, et alterum apud caput ipsius.	Then let two pieces of wood be placed, one at his feet and another at his head.
Deinde ponatur lignum additum in medio podii, fixum bene: super quod inuoluti sint panni humidi, ut non laedat infirmum: et sit lignum inter coxas eius, ut non attrahatur ad inferiora apud extensionem.	Then let another piece of wood be placed in the middle of the pedestal, securely fixed; over which wet cloths should be wrapped so that it does not harm the sick person; and let the wood be between his thighs so that he is not drawn downwards during extension.
Deinde extendat omnis minister ad partem suam, et medicus aequet reductionem manu sua.	Then let every assistant extend himself to his own part, and let the physician bring about the reduction with his own hand.
Si ergo obedit ad reuersionem, erit bonum.	If it submits to the reduction, that will be good.
Et si non, pone super ipsam tabulam, et preme ipsam, sicut diximus in gibbositate, aequaliter.	And if not, place upon it the board and press it equally, as we have said in the case of humpback.
Verumtamen oportet, ut iaceat infirmus super latus suum sanum.	But it is necessary that the sick person lie on his healthy side.
Et quando dislocatio est ad anteriora, tunc oportet, ut extendatur crus infirmi uelociter: et est secundum hanc eandem narrationem super podium: et ponat medicus palmam manus suae dextrae super inguen infirmum.	And when the dislocation is towards the front, then it is necessary that the sick leg be extended quickly; and this is according to the same description on the pedestal; and let the physician place the palm of his right hand upon the sick groin.
Deinde coartet ipsum cum manu altera, et cum illa coartatione pone ipsum extensum ad inferiora ad partem genu.	Then grasp it with the other hand, and with that grasping place it extended downwards towards the knee region.
Et si dislocatio est ad posteriora: tunc non oportet, ut extendatur infirmus ad inferiora, et sit eleuatus super terram: imo oportet, ut sit positus super rem duram, sicut oportet, ut fit etiam si dislocatur ancha eius ad exteriora, secundum illud quod diximus de accubitu eius super duas anchas: et est super faciem eius, et ligamenta extensa: secundum quod diximus nuper.	But if the dislocation is towards the back, then it is not necessary that the sick be extended downwards; rather let him be raised upon the earth; indeed it is necessary that he be placed upon a hard object, as is also done when his hip is dislocated externally, according to what we have said about his lying upon two pillows: and this is with his face upwards, and with the ligaments extended, as we have recently mentioned.
Et oportet, ut administretur compressio cum tabula etiam super locum ad quem egreditur iunctura, cum completur reductio secundum quod oportet.	And it is necessary that compression be administered with a board even upon the place where the joint comes out, when the reduction is completed as is necessary.
Et signum reditionis eius non occultatur tibi: et est, ut extendas duo crura infirmi: et quando uides ea aequalia, et infirmus stringit crus suum, et expandit ipsum absque excusatione: tunc scias, quia iam redit membrum, secundum quod oportet: tunc coniunge duas coxas, et pone emplastrum, et stringe cum imemati, id est, rota: ita, ut non moueatur ancha ad aliquam partium: et adhaereat infirmus quieti tribus diebus, aut quatuor.	And the sign of its return is not hidden from you: and this is, when you extend both legs of the sick person; and when you see them equal, and the sick person clenches his leg, and extends it without hesitation: then know that now the member has returned as it should be: then join the two hips, and place a poultice, and secure with linen, i.e., bandage it, so that the hip is not moved to any part; and let the sick person remain at rest for three days or four.
Deinde solue ligamentum, et emplastrum, et compara crus cum altero: tunc si uides ea aequalia in statu, tunc scias, quod dislocatio iam firmata est: absolue ergo infirmum ad ambulandum.	Then untie the bandage and poultice, and compare the leg with the other; then if you see them equal in state, then know that the dislocation is now firm: without therefore keeping the sick person from walking.
Et si uides aliquid mollificationis: tunc redi, et emplastra illud, et stringe illud secundum stricturam tuam primam: et dimitte illud etiam tribus diebus.	And if you see any softness: then return and poultice it, and bind it according to your first binding: and let it remain also for three days.
Deinde solue illud et fac ipsum tardare in ambulatione super utrumque aliquot diebus, donec confortetur bene.	Then untie it and make him walk slowly upon both feet for several days until he is fully strengthened.
¶ De dislocationis Genu.	Chapter on Dislocation of the Knee.
Caput XXXIII.	Chapter 33
Genu dislocatur secundum tres modos.	The knee joint can be dislocated in three ways.
Dislocatur ad exteriora, ad interiora, et ad inferiora, scilicet ad posteriora.	It can dislocate outwardly, inwardly, and downward, specifically backwards.
Et non dislocatur ad anteriora.	And it does not dislocate forwards.
Et signum dislocationis eius, est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut applicet crus suum ad coxam suam.	The sign of this dislocation is that you should instruct the patient to bring their thigh towards their hip.
Si autem non adhaeret cum coxa: tunc scias, quod Genu est dislocatum.	If it does not adhere with the hip, then know that the knee joint has been dislocated.
Et restauratio omnium modorum dislocationis eius est, ut facias sedere infirmum rectum, ita ut iam extendat crus suum si potest super illud, et adhaeret dorsum tuum ad faciem eius: et pone pedem eius inter pedes tuos.	And the reduction of all modes of its dislocation is that you should make the patient sit upright so that they can already extend their leg if possible upon it, and have your back against their face, and place their foot between yours.
Deinde adhaerere fac Genu eius cum palmis tuis, et recta eas inter digitos tuos super Genu eius.	Then bring the patient's knee with the palms of your hands and stretch out your fingers over the knee joint.
Deinde applica cum palma tua duo latera Genu eius cum fortitudine.	Then apply both sides of the knee joint with force using your palm.
Et minister alius extendat pedem eius, donec redeat Genu ad locum suum.	And another assistant should extend their foot until the knee joint returns to its place.
Et signum reditionis est, ut adhaereat crus cum coxa in lenitate, non laboriose.	The sign of reduction is that the thigh adheres to the hip gently, not with difficulty.
Deinde emplastra ipsum, et adhaerere fac crus cum coxa.	Then apply a bandage and make sure the thigh stays close to the hip.
Deinde liga ea simul cum uitta tribus diebus, aut quatuor.	Then bind it together with a linen bandage for three or four days.
Deinde solue ea.	Then untie it.
Et non utatur infirmus ambulatione aliquot diebus, donec sanetur.	And do not let the patient walk for several days until they are healed.
Si autem recusatur tibi reductio eius, tunc administra extensionem fortem cum ligamentis, quorum praecessit narratio in curatione anchae, donec redeat.	But if reduction is refused to you, then apply strong traction with bandages, about which there has been narration in the treatment of dislocation of the ankle joint, until it returns.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Calcanei.	Chapter on Treatment of Dislocation of the Heel.
Caput XXXIIII.	Chapter 34
Calcaneus quandoque remouetur remotione parua, et quandoque dislocatur secundum complementum.	Sometimes the heel bone is merely pushed back a little bit and sometimes it is completely dislocated.
Et dislocatio eius fit, aut ad interiora, aut ad exteriora.	Its dislocation occurs either inwardly or outwardly.
Et signum dislocationis eius est, quod uides Calcaneum inflatum, procedentem ad partem ad quam dislocatur.	The sign of its dislocation is that you see the heel swollen and protruding towards the part to which it has been dislocated.
Curatio autem remotionis eius, est facilis reditionis: et est, ut extendatur cum facilitate cum manibus, et aequetur, donec redeat.	But the treatment of its displacement is easy reduction; it is that you should extend it gently with your hands and align it until it returns.
In curatione autem eius quando dislocatur secundum complementum, oportet, ut facias sedere infirmum rectum: et teneat ipsum minister fortis ualde a posteriori parte dorsi eius, in medio ipsius.	But when treating it after it has been displaced forward, you should make the patient sit upright, and have a strong servant hold him firmly from behind at his mid-back.
Deinde tene tu cum manu tua dextra pedem eius a superiori parte eius, et cum manu tua sinistra ab inferiori parte pedis eius loco cauillae.	Then take his foot with your right hand from above and with your left hand below the ankle joint.
Deinde trahe pedem ad tecum manu tua dextra.	Then pull the foot towards you with your right hand.
Deinde cum sinistra duabus uicibus.	Then with your left hand, grasp both ankles.
Deinde extende cum sinistra, et impelle pectus pedis cum dextra uersus crus absque labore.	Then extend it with your left hand and push the sole of the foot towards the thigh without force with your right hand.
Fac illud bis, sicut narrauimus.	Do this twice as described.
Deinde impelle pectus pedis ad crus in uice tertia, et tu trahis cauillam.	Then push the sole of the foot against the thigh for a third time and you pull the ankle.
Si ergo redit in uice una, aut in duabus secundum hunc modum, et uides pedem aequatum, est bonum: et si non, tunc itera operationem super ipsum: quoniam ipse redit.	If it returns on the first or second attempt according to this method and you see that the foot is aligned, then that's good. But if not, repeat the procedure until it does return.
Si autem prohibetur tibi reductio eius cum eo quod narrauimus: tunc fac iacere infirmum super dorsum suum super terram, et fige paxillum in terra firmatum ualde, ut cadat inter coxas eius: et tu iam inuoluisti super ipsum pannum, ut non laedat infirmum.	But if you are unable to reduce it with the method I have described, then make the patient lie on his back on the ground. Fix a stake firmly in the ground so that it falls between his thighs. Then wrap a cloth around it so that it does not injure the patient.
Deinde accipiat minister coxam eius: postea extendat minister alter pedem, aut cum manibus suis, aut cum ligamento quod liget super collum pedis.	Then let one servant hold his hip, and another extend his other foot either with his hands or using a band tied around the ankle.
Deinde extendat omnis minister contra extensionem comparis sui: et paxillus sit stans inter duas coxas infirmi retinens eum, ut non attrahatur corpus eius ad inferiora apud extensionem.	Then all servants should pull against the extension of the comparing foot, and the stake should stand between the two hips of the sick person, preventing his body from being drawn downwards during the extension.
Deinde aequet medicus dislocationem manibus suis, et minister alter teneat crus sanum ad inferiora.	Then the physician should align the dislocation with their hands, and another servant should hold the healthy thigh below it.
Nam dislocatio redit cum uelocitate.	For reduction occurs quickly.
Quando ergo redit dislocatio, et declaratur tibi sanitas reditionis eius: tunc pone emplastrum et stuppam, et stringe ipsam cum ligamentis firmiter, et liga pedem cum ligamento ad crus.	When the dislocation has returned and you are sure of its reduction, then apply a plaster and bandages. Bind it firmly with bandages and tie the foot to the thigh with a bandage.
Et oportet, ut caueas uel timeas de neruis, qui sunt supra calcaneum posterius, ut non sit ligamentum super eos uehemens, et laedat eos.	You must be careful or fearful of nerves above the heel bone lest a tight bandage presses upon them and causes injury.
Deinde dimitte ipsum duobus diebus, aut tribus.	Then allow him to rest for two days or three.
Quod si mollificatur ligamentum, stringe ipsum: deinde solue ipsum in die tertio, aut quarto: et prohibe infirmum ab ambulatione quadraginta diebus.	If the ligature becomes loose after a few days, tighten it again. Then on the third or fourth day, remove it; and forbid the patient from walking for forty days.
Si uero conatur ambulare ante illud spacium, non fit securitas quin dissoluatur super ipsum dislocatio, et corrumpatur, et non recipiat post illud curationem.	But if he tries to walk before that period has passed, there will be no certainty that the dislocation will not recur and become worse, and it may not thereafter respond to treatment.
Quod si accidat ei apostema calidum: tunc oportet, ut administres in sedatione eius illud, in quo praecessit narratio nostra in alio loco ex curatione, et embrocationem, donec remoueatur.	But if an inflamed swelling occurs, you must apply the remedy for it as described elsewhere in this book, and use fomentations until it is removed.
¶ De dislocatione Digitorum pedis, et cura.	On Dislocations of the Toes of the Foot, and Their Treatment
Caput XXXV.	Chapter 35
Oportet, ut aequetur quod dislocatur ex eis cum extensione pauca absque labore: et illud quidem non est difficile, imo est facile.	It is necessary that what is dislocated among them be gently reduced with slight extension without effort; and this indeed is not difficult, but rather easy.
Si autem dislocatio est in quibusdam nodis dorsi pedis: tunc oportet, ut faciat sedere infirmus pedem suum super locum aequalem terrae, aut super tabulam: et est stans sicut ambulans.	But if the dislocation is in some nodes on the back of the foot, then have the patient sit with their foot flat on the ground or on a board, and let them stand as though walking.
Deinde tu sta, et pone pedem tuum super illud quod eminet ex illis iuncturis.	Then you stand and place your foot upon that which protrudes from those joints.
Deinde calca illud cum pede tuo cum uirtute, donec redeat, et uideas ipsum iam aequatum, et non appareat in loco eminentia.	Then press upon it with your foot with force until it returns and you see that it has been reduced and there is no longer any prominence.
Deinde pone sub uentre pedis eius tabulam quae capiat pedem totum, cui sint duo capita.	Then place under the sole of his foot a board which can hold the whole foot, having two heads (i.e., ends).
Deinde stringe ipsum strictura decenti tribus diebus.	Then bind it with a suitable bandage for three days.
Deinde solue ipsum, et fac quiescere eum ab ambulatione diebus multis, donec stringatur et securetur a reductione.	Then remove the bandage and let him rest from walking for many days until he is securely bound and reduced.
¶ De speciebus dislocationis cum uulnere uel fractura.	On Cases of Dislocation with Associated Wound or Fracture
Caput XXXVI.	Chapter 36.
Quando accidit aliquid ex illo, et conaris curationem eius, et ipsius restaurationem, multotiens succedit mors: et propter illud non oportet, ut praesumat super curationem eius, quod est huiusmodi, nisi qui est prudens in arte longi usus, misericors, pius, tardus, non audax, neque praesumptuosus: et ut utatur in incaeptionce medicinis quae sedant apostemata calida tantum: et dimittat infirmum diuino iudicio.	When something happens to a patient and you attempt their treatment and restoration, many times death follows. Therefore, it is not advisable for anyone but one who is wise and experienced in the art to undertake such cases - one who is compassionate, merciful, careful, not hasty or presumptuous. In the beginning of treatment, use medicines that only cool inflammation; then leave the patient to God's judgment.
Nisi uideas, aut speras salutem a perditione cum lenitate aegritudinis, et in quo apparet quiddam spei.	Unless you see or hope for recovery from impending danger, and where there is some sign of hope.
Conare ergo reductionem eius statim in principio rei, antequam accidat apostema calidum.	Therefore, attempt to reduce the dislocation at once, before inflammation sets in.
Si ergo redit membrum, secundum quod uolumus, tunc administra regimen quod sedat apostema: et cura uulnus cum eo quod conuenit ei ex unguentis desiccatiuis.	If the limb returns to its proper position as desired, then apply a regimen that cools the inflammation and treat the wound with suitable drying ointments.
Quod si dislocatio est cum fractura, et accidunt in osse satagiae separatae, tunc conare ablationem earum, et fac in illo quod diximus in aegritudinibus simplicibus ex eo quod praecessit in locis earum.	If the dislocation is accompanied by fracture and bone fragments are separated, then attempt to remove them and treat as described for simple injuries at those locations.
Et caue secundum tuam uirtutem, et custodi teipsum ab introitu in uiam timoris: secundum quod praecessit praedicatio mea tibi.	Be careful according to your ability and guard yourself from entering the path of fear; as I have previously taught you.
Nam illud est melius tibi apud Creatorem tuum, et magis permanens ad gloriam tuam, et magis saluum tuo corpori apud illos in tuo tempore.	For that will be better for you before your Creator, more lasting to your glory, and safer for your body among your peers in your time.
